DOC.HEAD: Iraq Says It Will Hold All Foreigners from `Aggressive Nations'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 9 `Mahdi said' to UPDATE with other ministries involved in housing, minor editing. Picks up 10th pvs, `The speaker...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos HK1, LON3
DOC.TEXT: The speaker of Iraq's parliament said Friday that Iraq will hold all foreigners from ``aggressive nations'' _ presumably including 3,000 Americans _ until the threat of war against his country ends. He said they would be housed throughout the country in military and civilian installations. The White House refused comment Friday night on Baghdad's announcement. ``We don't have a reaction,'' said Doug Davidson, an assistant White House press secretary. ``We may well have one in the morning.'' The United States sent some of its most sophisticated offensive weapons to the region as the Persian Gulf crisis entered its third week. Included too were up to 38 commercial airliners, which the Pentagon said Friday night were being turned over to the military to help haul troops and cargo overseas. Such a move by 16 airlines was the first time the U.S. civilian air fleet has been diverted to a military use. The moves continue in the aftermath of Iraq's lightning invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, which precipitated the crisis and also trapped at least 4,000 British citizens. ``The people of Iraq have decided to play host to the citizens of these aggressive nations as long as Iraq remains threatened with an aggressive war,'' speaker Sadi Mahdi said late Friday in a statement carried by the official Iraqi news agency. Mahdi's announcement, monitored in Nicosia, came after a meeting of Iraq's Revolutionary Command Council, presided over by President Saddam Hussein. Mahdi said arrangements were being made for housing the foreigners with the ministries of oil and military installations, the armed forces and other ministries. Military and oil-related installations would be potential targets in an armed conflict. The speaker urged all American and allied forces to withdraw from the region and attacked mandatory economic sanctions on Iraq voted by the United Nations, saying, ``These governments are . . . going out of their way to starve the Iraqi people in an unprecedentedly brutal fashion.'' Iraq, which imports about three-quarters of its food but is being impacted by an international blockade in the region, holds an estimated 14,000 Westerners besides the Americans and Britons. Americans and other foreigners who feared being rounded up in Kuwait disguised themselves as Arabs, drove through the Kuwaiti desert in a convoy of 13 cars and reached Saudi Arabia on Friday. ``As soon as we left the paved road, we ran into Iraqis and they said we had to go back,'' said Stephanie McGehee, 37, one of at least three Americans in the group. ``We moved away and then took another turn through the desert sands and made a dash for it.'' ``It was very, very terrifying.'' McGehee, an Associated Press photographer and part-time correspondent from Leucadia, Calif., reported by telephone from the Khafji border post that the entire convoy was safe and sound. It was not clear how many escaped, though her car carried nine, including a Canadian friend, one Briton and four Indians. In New York, the U.N. Security Council expressed concern over the fate of the detained foreigners and asked the secretary-general to take all necessary steps to help them. At the same time, a special Security Council committee met to discuss compliance with the international embargo intended to force Iraq to withdraw its troops from Kuwait and the Saudi border. If the panel decides the boycott is not being honored, the Security Council can declare a military blockade and urge member states to enforce it. That would be an important development for the United States, which did not seek U.N. approval before ordering its ships in the Middle East to intercept vessels carrying goods to or from Iraq or Kuwait. The Pentagon said Navy commanders stopped two Iraqi vessels in the Persian Gulf on Friday, but let them proceed after determining they carried no goods. Washington recently decided to strengthen its forces by adding Stealth fighter-bombers and amphibious assault ships, among other offensive weapons. And on Friday President Bush decided to call up some military reserve units, administration officials in Washington said. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze said Friday the Soviet Union would send troops to the Persian Gulf if the United Nations calls for a multinational military force to solve the crisis. Japan also was considering joining the forces defending Saudi Arabia against a possible Iraqi attack. It may break with its long-held policy against deployment of military equipment overseas, perhaps by sending minesweepers. Concern about the U.S. citizens detained in occupied Kuwait and Iraq grew Friday after about three dozen Americans in the Rashid Hotel in Baghdad were reportedly moved to an undisclosed location. Bush protested attempts to move Americans ``against their will.'' U.S. officials in the Iraqi capital demanded access to the detainees, who were taken to Iraq from Kuwait after Iraq invaded the emirate to increase its share of world oil reserves to 20 percent. The Iraqi invasion stranded more than 2 million foreigners, including more than 450 Japanese. About 6,500 foreigners fled to Jordan from Iraq and Kuwait on Friday. Bush, asked what would happen if the Americans in Kuwait were taken to Iraq, said: ``I don't think anybody ought to be moved against their will in contravention of international law.'' Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., on a stop in Israel, went further, saying Iraq would face American military retaliation if Americans were harmed. In other crisis-related developments Friday: _Iraq freed 1,000 prisoners of its 1980-88 war with Iran and started pulling Iraqi troops back from the Iranian border, part of its campaign to focus on the escalating confrontation with the United States. It has about 300,000 troops facing Iran and could send some to Kuwait and the Saudi border. _Prices fell broadly on the New York Stock Exchange, echoing losses overseas amid continued concern about the Mideast. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks fell 36.64 to 2,644.80, and at one point was down by as much as 65 points. _Lebanon's most influential Shiite Moslem cleric, Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, called for a pan-Islamic confrontation of U.S. military forces in the gulf. ``America has declared war on Islam. . . . So let us . . . confront the immense challenge that threatens us all,'' said Fadlallah, spiritual guide of the fundamentalist Hezbollah, Iran's main ally in Lebanon. When Bush, 1st graf, a0709

DOC.HEAD: Merry Gangsters Celebrate Chicago's Sordid Past
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language 13th graf.
DOC.TEXT: The three young cops did a double-take when they spotted the city's most-arrested burglar sitting in the back room of Chicago Joe's, but there was nothing to worry about. Joseph ``Pops'' Panczko, a 12-time loser with more than 150 arrests under his belt, was in good hands. The plainclothes detectives and the FBI agent were chipping in for his shrimp dinner, and the advertising executive was plying him with shots and beer. It was the monthly meeting of the Merry Gangsters, and Panczko, a frequent guest of the state, was the guest of honor. Despite their fearsome name, the Gangsters are just a group of otherwise reputable citizens who take pride in Chicago's sordid past. ``We just sit around and talk,'' said retired adman Billy Reilly, who founded the group with friends Richard Lindberg and Nathan Kaplan a year and a half ago. Much of the talk is about mobsters and madams, but honor is also paid to corrupt cops and greedy politicians. ``You can never get tired of this city. It's got real people in it _ real characters,'' said Kaplan, 69, a free-lance writer and retired salesman. ``I go to other cities and watch the news. I see their city councils. They've got straight bellies and good posture. They use good diction. I don't feel like I'm with real people.'' By Kaplan's definition, Panczko, 72, is a real person, complete with potbelly. Despite his 50-plus years as a professional criminal, he was greeted affectionately Tuesday night by the Gangster regulars, including Burt Neilson and Jim Brindisi _ both retired detectives. Panczko also got a special hello from a newcomer, FBI agent Bill Clancy. ``I've heard a lot about you, Pops, but don't worry, I'm a specialist in white-collar crime,'' Clancy said. There's nothing white collar about Panczko, who got his nickname from the only legitimate job he ever tried _ driving a soft-drink truck. ``I hated them calling me, `Hey, pop man,' so I went back to stealing,'' he said. ``I started stealing chickens when I was 11 and got my first pinch for swiping some of those dago cheeses you grind up and put on spaghetti,'' said Panczko. ``If it wasn't wired down, I stole it _ or maybe my brothers did. One time I took the milkman's whole wagon _ horse, too. And my brother Butch stole a cement mixer once. Somebody watched him and got him pinched _ him and the junkyard guy he sold it to.'' Panczko said he once paid a policeman a $1,000 bribe to overlook the heist of a load of socks from the trunk of a salesman's car, and then got only $20 for the socks. ``Damn cops, that's where all my money went,'' he complained. Gangster member Lindberg, the official historian of the Chicago White Sox, smiled. ``Dick's writing a true history of the Chicago police,'' said Reilly. ``He'll probably be arrested.'' Gangster member Harold Rubin of Cicero does some filching, too, but he does his legally _ moving in on former mob-owned buildings one step ahead of the wreckers. A dealer in Al Capone memorabilia, Rubin isn't content with the small trophies like guns, autographs and Capone's barber's straight razor. He wants the impressive, stuff, too. ``I just went into the old 4811 Club in Cicero _ the old gambling dive _ and I got some great items,'' he said. ``I got the 26 table. That's the dice game you played against the young ladies with the big busts; you wouldn't know if you won or lost. I also got the cell door.'' Cell door? ``Yeah, they had this jail cell in the basement for guys who couldn't pay their tabs,'' he said. ``I pulled the door out of a couple of feet of water.'' Rubin said one of his coups was removing the interior marble from the Lexington Hotel, a one-time Capone headquarters. Kenan Heise, a Chicago Tribune obituary editor and historian, spoke of another Capone-owned hotel, the Metropole. ``It was a beautiful place in its day, and when my first book came out in 1971, I gave the publication party there,'' he remembered. ``It was a whorehouse by then, though, and I had a little trouble explaining what kind of party I wanted.''

DOC.HEAD: Historians Think This Is No New Vietnam
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein's takeover of Kuwait wasn't 24 hours old when the Senate interrupted its business to deplore it and denounce him. But what was that echo in the chamber? Why did a senator or two refer _ in a looking-over-his-shoulder way _ to the ``Gulf of Tonkin Resolution''? Why did minds turn back to an August debate 26 years ago? In that debate, the Senate, over the misgivings of only two senators, reacted to reports that U.S. Navy vessels had been attacked off North Vietnam's coast by authorizing President Lyndon Johnson ``to prevent further aggression.'' LBJ used that resolution as the equivalent of a declaration of war, the basis on which he sent 250,000 American soldiers to fight an Asian war, America's longest war, the first it lost. Almost by stealth, America was sucked into a guerrilla war on the side of an unpopular government. Johnson hoped each escalation would be enough _ only to find that each, instead, made withdrawal more difficult. And Vietnam deteriorated into a quagmire, an inextricable situation. The United States couldn't win and couldn't quit. Is the gulf crisis another quagmire in the making, another place where U.S. forces can't win and can't get out, stuck in 100 degree heat, unable to do more than wait to react to Saddam Hussein? Does history offer some guidance here? For the most part, historians familiar with the region and with the ways war develop are more optimistic than that. They find some similarities to Vietnam. But they draw encouragement from some big differences. ``Not the least of which,'' said John Gaddis, diplomatic historian at Ohio University in Athens, Ohio, ``is that this thing really is a multinational effort that grows out of a rather shocking provocation _ and neither was true in Vietnam.'' Bernard Lewis, a retired Princeton University historian and author of 20 books on the Islamic world, said Saddam Hussein made a crucial miscalculation last weekend. He sought to turn his invasion of Iraq into a religious crusade; instead, said Lewis, he only ``succeeded in isolating himself even in the Arab world.'' If his maneuver had worked, Saddam might have made his battle into an Arab-against-the-West struggle. Instead, he made it the-world-against-Iraq, Lewis said. Saddam called for a jihad, a religious war, for the Arab masses to rise up against their leaders. And he did it just as the leaders were assembled in a summit at Cairo. ``They were hesitating when he produced this call to jihad,'' said Lewis. ``This was a direct challenge. It was an act of desperation.'' In response, the leaders of Egypt, Syria, Saudi Arabia and the other oil states of the Persian Gulf, in an extraordinary rebuff to a fellow Arab, decided to send a military force to protect Saudi Arabia from Saddam. In Vietnam, by contrast, America's allies, even in Asia, largely limited their support to the sidelines. Only Australia, New Zealand, Thailand and Korea sent sizeable combat contingents. Political scientist Nathan Brown, a Mideast specialist at George Washington University, said quagmire in the Persian Gulf may be ``the best we can hope for,'' considering the alternatives _ a humiliating U.S. withdrawal or a military offensive against the Iraqis in Kuwait, requiring a scale of warfare ``that is politically impossible.'' Brown questions whether the Bush administration thought through its options. Even if Iraq gains enough control in the region to restrict petroleum output and boost the price, ``I'm not sure the repercussions are serious enough to say our national security is at stake,'' Brown said. ``The worst that people are talking about is a recession,'' Brown said. ``We've lived through recessions before. That doesn't really affect our national security.'' Brown recalls the Suez Crisis of 1956 when Britain, in a break with the United States, decided it simply could not permit the canal to fall into Egypt's hands. But that's what happened. Eleven years later, in the 1967 Arab-Israel war, the canal was closed for seven years _ ``and nobody noticed.'' But Lewis views the threat of Saddam controlling the oilfields of Iraq, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia as graver than that. ``You simply can't allow this man to obtain a stranglehold on the world's supplies,'' he said. George Herring, a University of Kentucky historian of the Vietnam war, said he sees in the Persian Gulf one big similarity to Vietnam and one big difference. The difference, he said, is that the American commitment to Vietnam was slow and as concealed as Lyndon Johnson could manage. It grew from a few hundred U.S. troops sent to advise the French in the 1950s to more than 200,000 troops, engaged in full-fledged combat in July 1965. In contrast, the Persian Gulf operations has been ``sudden and dramatically large,'' Herring said. Where Johnson sought to underplay the buildup, President Bush broadcasts his determination to commit whatever force it takes to pry Iraq out of Kuwait. The similarity, Herring said, is in ``the nature of the beast you are dealing with. All the Vietnam policymakers have admitted in the last 10 or 15 years that the crucial mistake they made was underestimating the enemy and the enemy's willingness to make huge sacrifices.'' ``If they miss that this time, we're in bad shape,'' Herring said. ``They should have seen it in the Iran-Iraq war. They missed it in the French war against the Vietnamese.'' Gaddis said the proper analogy is Korea, not Vietnam. Then, as now, he said, there was a swift cross-border invasion. Then as now, it was met by a multinational, U.N.-backed, response. Korea became an American quagmire, too, but Gaddis sees a crucially different factor at play this time. ``Korea proved difficult to get out of but what kept us there was Chinese intervention in November 1950,'' he said. ``What's interesting this time is that this is the first crisis where the great powers have all been in agreement. Saddam Hussein doesn't have that ability to play the superpowers against each other. It's been a most remarkable thing, the unanimity that Bush has been able to rally behind him.'' Kenneth Oye of Massachusetts Institute of Technology, an expert on economic warfare, also finds remarkable the degree of compliance Bush has commanded so far in his call for an international embargo against Iraq. But he questions the staying power of nations for whom sanctions against Iraq _ and life without oil from Iraq and Kuwait _ will be painful. ``If Saddam Hussein makes no big moves, doesn't use poison gas, doesn't go into Jordan, doesn't stage air raids on the Turkish border, if he just sits tight, I suspect that international support for sanctions will lose ground,'' Oye says. ``And if they are not universally supported they lose their effectiveness.'' He notes how President Jimmy Carter's grain embargo to punish the Soviet Union for its Afghanistan invasion became so unpopular with farmers that Ronald Reagan used it as an issue in his campaign against Carter. Lewis concurs that patience is the key. He says Saddam clearly hopes the American people and business, with their famously short attention span, ultimately will pressure Bush to bring the boys home _ just as public opinion ultimately forced the United States to find a face-saving formula for leaving Vietnam with the war unwon. But this time he thinks it won't work. ``My guess is that the Iraqis will break under the pressure of sanctions before American patience wears out. But that's the key question.'' Bush compares Saddam not to Ho Chi Minh, the ideologically driven strategist who commanded communist forces in Vietnam, but to Adolf Hitler, a dictator who invaded his neighbors to enlarge his fascist Reich. Historians Lewis and Gaddis find the comparison apt. ``I think what happened (in Kuwait) is very much the decision of one irrational leader and not some new trend in world politics,'' said Gaddis. ``It is almost a reversion to the way leaders used to act in the 1930s.'' Said Lewis: ``If one can invade another country and get away with it, we're back in the 1930s, we're back in the international jungles. Then the world will belong to the violent and the ruthless.''

DOC.HEAD: A Little Bit of Soul
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PX1 of 8-12
DOC.TEXT: Stay out of the music scene for four years and look what happens. British soul stylist Paul Young can tell you all about it. After his third album, ``Between Two Fires,'' ran its course in 1986, he slowed down to start a family. He then took two more years to put together his latest album, ``Other Voices.'' While he was gone, the Motown sound returned to the charts with blue-eyed soul singers and fellow Brits at the helm: George Michael, Simply Red and Lisa Stansfield. Young returned just in time. ``People could say I've been away long enough to be forgotten,'' he said in an interview. ``In some territories, it is long enough to be forgotten, but in other territories, it's been a break, and that's not such a bad thing.'' Young began ``Other Voices'' with the same staff he had used on his three previous albums, but was unsatisfied with the results. Six months' work, as he said, went ``down the pan.'' So he started anew. He brought in plenty of guest musicians _ Pink Floyd's David Gilmour on guitar, singer Chaka Khan on backing vocals and Stevie Wonder on harmonica. Nile Rodgers produced a track, and two more were done with former J. Geils Band leader Peter Wolf. But Young still felt he had to get back to his roots in Britain and did some recording there as well. ``Working with Peter, I was coming up with music that was very different from what I'd done before, much more American,'' he said. ``My biggest audience is in Europe and I can't ignore that.'' ``Other Voices'' is filled with material by other artists, including covers of the Chi-Lites' ``Oh Girl'' and Free's ``A Little Bit of Love.'' Young sees doing these songs as a way of distancing himself from his own material. ``I'd like to forget that I wrote them and approach them as an arranger and then I could probably enjoy it more,'' he said. ``But underneath it, there's always my song and so I see it one particular way. That somehow stops me from doing certain things. ``With other songs, I've heard them one way, I see them another way, so straightaway, I've got this choice of things I can do with it and I think that makes it more enjoyable.'' He also sees doing covers as a way to keep great old songs alive, but likes to look for the less well-known standards. ``I tend to prefer finding songs that are little gems in the dust, as it were, and making them out to be something special, because maybe they (the audience) missed it the first time 'round,'' he said. ``I don't like a lot of music that loses track of its roots. I hope that what I'm doing when I do these things is keeping the old stuff in their minds, but keeping up to date in terms of how I work the arrangements, what instruments I use, stuff like that.'' On ``Other Voices,'' Young said he went back to ``playing a lot of stuff live again and not using too much machinery. I think the trick is to use the machinery but still make it sound very human.'' Songwriting is not his forte, he said, but he's looking to change that. ``I think I was working with a guy who also found it very hard to be a songwriter and that made it even more difficult,'' he said. ``So now I've made some contacts with people who actually enjoy the process of being stuck in a room for eight hours, which I don't find in the least bit inviting.'' Young's solo career began in 1982 after 3{ years with the soul outfit the Q-Tips. His first break came in 1983 with a version of the Marvin Gaye classic, ``Wherever I Lay My Hat,'' which stayed at No. 1 in England for three weeks. His debut album, ``No Parlez,'' also reached the top of the charts there. His long-awaited U.S. success came with the Top 20 song, ``Come Back and Stay,'' also from ``No Parlez.'' But his second album, ``The Secret of Association,'' released in 1985, contained his first U.S. No. 1 hit _ ``Everytime You Go Away,'' written by Daryl Hall of Hall and Oates. He doesn't necessarily see ``Other Voices'' as a progression, but rather a beginning of new things. ``I think I've now built myself another little base to work from,'' he said. ``It's a pretty good mixture of what the last three albums had done and it's now on one album. There's quite a few indications of ways I could go.''

DOC.HEAD: Old Soviet Names Coming Back, Maybe Even St. Petersburg
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Citizens of Tver and dozens of other Soviet cities are casting off the names and symbols of a painful past. The people of this ancient city 100 miles northwest of Moscow started by taking back the name it bore for centuries before Stalin called it Kalinin, for a henchman born near Tver. To Catherine the Great, the city was ``the most beautiful in the empire'' after St. Petersburg, now Leningrad, because of its 18th century architecture. As the namesake of Mikhail Kalinin, it became a reminder of repression and death. Gorky Street in Moscow, the capital's main thoroughfare, has been changed back to Tverskaya Street. Fashionable shops and stores lined the street before the Bolshevik revolution, and outside the city it became the main road to Tver. On July 19, the front page of Kalininskaya Pravda, the local newspaper, carried a decree signed by Boris N. Yeltsin, president of the Russian republic. It said the republic's Presidium ``decrees: Rename the city Kalinin to the city Tver.'' Yeltsin had reversed half a century and fulfilled a dream of many residents. A poem published with the decree said: ``Well, goodbye Kalinin. You were just a pseudonym of our returning Tver.'' Now, even the newspaper will have to call itself something else. The name game is sweeping this vast country. For decades, cities, streets, ships, farms and factories were renamed for Bolshevik heroes and officials. Then, as political times changed under Mikhail S. Gorbachev and history was rewritten, some of the officials were disgraced and the circle was completed. Naberezhni Chelny, renamed Brezhnev, was returned to its original name. Tsaritsyn, renamed Stalingrad, became Volgograd. Other name changes actual or likely include the emergence of old Samara from Kuibyshev, Nizhny Novgorod from Gorky; transformation of Kirov to Vzyatka, Sverdlovsk to old Ekaterinburg, Andropov to Rybinsk; the rescue of Marnupol from Zhdanov, Lugansk from Voroshilovgrad and Vladikavkaz from Ordzhonikidze. Some people who are fed up with the old order even want to change Leningrad back to St. Petersburg. The name of Mikhail Kalinin, the Soviet president in 1938-1946, was attached to many places other than Tver, which became Kalinin on his birthday in 1931. Koenigsberg, a historic German city incorporated into the Soviet Union at the end of World War II, became Kaliningrad. Major streets in other Soviet cities, including Moscow, honor Kalinin. He was a figurehead president hated by victims of the collectivization of agriculture, a dark period in the country's history. Millions of people were arrested and executed as ``enemies of the people''' during the collectivization of the 1930s, including many from Kalinin's home region. Some of the bodies are believed to have been dumped into mass, unmarked graves near Tver. The campaign to regain Kalinin's old name began in the 1960s, but did not get far until Gorbachev and glasnost came along. Eleven engineers and intellectuals founded a group called Return in March 1988 with that as its goal. Boris Yershov, a leader of the group and a local legislator, said Return's members were described at first as ``extremists, sometimes as hooligans.'' People asked, ```How could you insult the memory of Mikhail Kalinin, a leading figure in the party, government and society?''' Yershov said. ``When we said he wasn't a leading figure of the party and the government, people just didn't believe us. People were so fooled by the propaganda ... for years, for decades, about our leaders, they just didn't accept our words.'' Support for Return gradually increased, Yershov said, and people began asking: ``If Kalinin is not the person he's made out to be, why do we bear his name? Why such a supreme honor to a person who promoted Stalin's crimes?'' More than 14,000 of the city's 475,000 people signed a petition last year demanding it be called Tver again. Local party and legislative bodies eventually gave their support and the idea was ratified by Yeltsin, a radical reformer elected president of Russia, the country's largest republic, in June. Residents interviewed the day Yeltsin's decree was published said the move was welcome but they also wanted other changes. ``I'm not in a festive mood,'' said Natalya Drozdenko, a woman in her mid-30s waiting in a long line to buy chickens. ``It's only right to change the name and we have been struggling for it, lending our signatures to petitions, etcetera, but somehow I understand it's only symbolic and it won't affect our well-being.'' Alexander Bartyenyev, an 84-year-old World War II veteran strolling past the shops, remembers when the city was still called Tver and said Mikhail Kalinin never deserved the honor. ``Kalinin was treated as one of our own,'' Bartyenyev said. ``He was born here and worked here, but as president of the country, he could not stop the blood-letting.'' Yershov said his organization now would turn its attention to restoring monuments, churches and the old street names.

DOC.HEAD: Dutch Enlist ``Fingerprinting'' Method to Spot Iraqi Oil
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Dutch customs officials have enlisted a chemical ``fingerprinting'' method to spot any Iraqi or Kuwaiti oil smuggled into Rotterdam, Europe's largest oil port, in violation of sanctions. The method relies on a process known as gas chromatography and is already used by oil companies and by a government agency trying to identify sources of North Sea oil pollution, customs service spokesman Cornelis Verlaan said Thursday. Verlaan told The Associated Press the customs laboratory in Amsterdam now plans to use the technique to check samples of crude oil shipments arriving in Rotterdam. In line with the Aug. 6 U.N. embargo, the Netherlands has banned all Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil imports and transshipments through Rotterdam, Europe's largest refining center and site of a huge oil spot market. The U.N. action was to punish Iraqi for its miitary takeover of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Verlaan said it takes five to six weeks for an oil tanker to reach Rotterdam, so ``no oil loaded after Aug. 7 has arrived here yet.'' The identification process is based on differences in texture and chemical composition found in every oil field's deposits. Verlaan said samples taken in Rotterdam will be compared with a file of about 40 crude samples, including those from Iraq and Kuwait. ``You kind of take a fingerprint,'' said Verlaan. ``If we're in a real hurry, we can conduct an analysis in 24 hours.'' He said the procedure is now about 80 percent accurate, adding, ``We're refining the technique all the time.'' Verlaan conceded that crude oil could be tampered with on its way to Rotterdam, but said ``you would see an entirely different picture than with oil that hasn't been doctored.'' Oil companies are using the process to check on the origin of their crude. The Traffic and Waterways Ministry has been using the gas chromatography technique to trace ships suspected of causing North Sea oil spills, Verlaan said.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Saddam's Open Letter to Bush
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Following is the text of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's open letter to President Bush, broadcast by the Iraqi media in Arabic and translated by The Associated Press: ``In the name of God, the almighty, the compassionate, ``An open letter to the President of the United States: ``I have become aware of your latest statements and heated comments before the staff of the American defense ministry that reflected your intention in pursuing a policy harmful to Iraq, a policy of occupation that humiliates the sacred shrine and lands of the Arabs and Moslems in Hijaz and Najd. ``I will not hesitate, Mr. President, to tell you that while I read your words that reflected clearly your mockery and disregard for the Arab mentality and national and official Arab sentiment, your shallowness became so apparent. I had thought you were more farsighted than that. And I cannot but admit that my conviction in the just policy chosen by the Iraqi people, which I serve and lead, has increased, and so has increased my conviction in the righteousness of every patriotic Arab and Moslem who supports the path of holy war against the invading forces. ``You have tried, you, as a President of a superpower, along with your small agents, to brand Saddam Hussein a liar after failing to stab him in other ways. You, all, whose files are thickest in this respect. ``You and your business partners in the region and your agents have said that Saddam Hussein promised (Egyptian President) Hosni Mubarak that he would not do this or that, yet he did, although you are fully aware that it is beyond your wildest dream that Saddam Hussein should lie because he who lies will undoubtedly lose the ability of persuasion, lose the drive for determination and lose the basic requirements for confidence. ``What you, the policy-makers in the United States and your small agents in the region, hate above all is the veracity of men, and the most hated among these men is Saddam Hussein because his sincerity toward principles, toward himself, his people and his country make of him a true servant and leader of the people, not a servant for the foreigner. You consider those liars in the region your trusted friends, although you are fully aware who is the liar and who are the liars in the region. ``The Western public opinion, even the American public opinion, will be on the side of righteousness so that even when the confrontation intensifies and the speeches become abundant your face and that of your mutilated allies will be unveiled and the Americans will tell you, `We have unified America with blood so why are you acting against the unity of the people of Iraq who were split by colonialism and why are you falling in the laps of those retarded opportunists?' ``They will ask you where are these legitimate interests that are threatened by Iraq? When they realize that Iraq welcomes the legitimate interests, the anger of the American people will rise and it is then that your downfall will come and the defeat will be inevitable for the forces that you had massed and hoped to use to terrorize the Arab nation, this great nation from which emerged the prophets and holy books. ``You have lied, Mr. U.S. President, to your people when you told them that you were massing troops to protect American interests in Saudi Arabia. Now you tell them that you did that to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. You never asked yourself if it is permissible that Iraq asks you to withdraw from southern states in America. Will you respond to such a request if it were made? ``We are on our soil. Kuwaitis and Iraqis are all Iraqis, eternally. The borders of Iraq, from the begining of times, were Zako in the north through the city of Nidaa and the city of Kuwait in the south along the sea. The Iraqis, with their own, irrevocable will, have become one people as their history dictates, despite the split caused by colonialism during which, and for a short period, they lived within fences set up by colonialism. ``That era is gone and there is no way that the retarded oil emirs will ever be allowed back, after they had mutilated the image of an Arab by sitting on thrones and bringing shame to the Arabs through their behavior and their alliances with their likes among the Westerners and the Americans. ``You must be loyal to your people, you elected president of the United States of America. You must tell them that you have made a mistake and took hasty decisions after you had been misled by those who misled you. ``And then you must ask for our help to save face by agreeing to measures and arrangements that will not change the core of what has been achieved in terms of the unit of Iraq, people and land. You must be sincere to your people and tell them that the Arab and Islamic public opinion is against your presence on the land of holy messages and prophets, and against your aggression against sacred shrines and Iraq. Tell them that they will fight schemes and that pure souls will be sacrificed in the defense of the principles, the sacred shrines and patriotic dignity. And you will be defeated because there is no chance for the bad to win over the good among people clinging to justice, righteousness and equality. ``Mr. President, aren't you sad as you boast about democracy that your allies are the retarded, thieves and liars among the Arabs, while the believers, the warriors and the elite be on the opposite side? ``But despite all that, we will continue to pray, and pray hard, that there will be no confrontation by which you will receive thousands of Americans wrapped in sad coffins after you had pushed them into a dark tunnel. ``The doors of heavens are open to all Arabs, and the scent is so sweet. The opportunity for a respectable life is here and the doors of Jihad (holy war), which angered the rude Bush, are open to all Moslems and believers. ``God is Great. The Infidels and Aggressors will be defeated. ``Pride and dignity will go to the Arabs, Moslems and the supporters of righteousness. ``Saddam Hussein ``25 Moharram, 1411 ``16 August 1990.''

DOC.HEAD: How U.S. and Iraqi Planes Stack Up
With PM-Cat and Mouse
DOC.TEXT: Planes from the Iraqi air force have been playing a grim sort of tag with U.S. fighter planes in the skies over the Persian Gulf region. Here's a brief look at the aircraft thought to be involved:
DOC.HEAD: F-15C
DOC.TEXT: Single-seat air-superiority tactical fighter, with Doppler radar that provides long-range detection and tracking of small high-speed targets and feeds tracking information to a computer linked to the firing of anti-aircraft missiles or gun. For close-in dogfights, the radar acquires the target automatically. The steering and weapon information is shown on a convenient screen _ ``head-up display'' _ that allows the pilot to intercept enemy aircraft without removing his eyes from the target. Length: 63 feet, 9 inches. Wingspan: 42 feet, 9} inches. Maximum speed: More than 1,700 mph. Armament: One M-61A1 20mm multibarrel gun, with 940 rounds of ammunition, four AIM-9L@m Sidewinder and four AIM-7F@ Sparrow missiles.
DOC.HEAD: Mirage F1-EQ5
DOC.TEXT: Single-seat, multi-role aircraft _ air superiority, ground attack, reconnaissance. It has an inertial navigation system, navigational-attack computer and a head-up screen display. Length: 50 feet, 2{ inches. Wingspan: 27 feet, 6} inches. Maximum speed: More than 1,500 mph. Armament: Two 30mm DEFA 553 cannon, Exocet anti-ship missiles, AS30L missile, and Matra 900-pound laser-guided bomb.

DOC.HEAD: Infant Left for Dead in Liberia Survives by Chance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: No one knows for sure how many people have died in Liberia's bloody civil war. This is the story of a 9-month-old baby who survived. Last week, doctors from the humanitarian organization Doctors Without Borders evacuated 300 patients from St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Hospital in this suburb of Monrovia. Heavy fighting was going on next to the hospital, the last working clinic anywhere near the capital. The doctors could not take everyone on the long trip behind rebel lines. On Tuesday, a foreign correspondent entered the hospital morgue, which was filled with corpses of those left behind. A child was lying next to her mother, eyes frozen in the blank stare of death. The body of the child's mother lay next to her, said hospital workers. They did not know how long the woman had been dead. After months of exposure to the brutality of Liberia's war, many of the journalists covering it have developed thick skins. Fighters on both sides have gleefully shot civilians in front of journalists and photographers. So it was only a fluke that Steven Smith, looking at the body of the rail-thin infant, was moved to close the baby's eyes. As his thumb brushed the baby's eyelash, she blinked and the vacant stare transformed into consciousness. The girl appeared to have nearly starved to death, having had no mother's milk or any other food since her mother died. After several hours of treatment by one of the Liberian nurses still staffing the hospital, the baby appeared to have revived. The next day Smith, Africa editor for the Parisian newspaper Liberation, decided to find a safer location for the infant. There were few people left in Monrovia's eastern suburbs, but the journalist knew one man who might be able to help. So the child was taken to an Italian with the last name of Albertini, who managed an Italian construction company and has stayed behind to watch over the Italian Embassy residences. Albertini, whose first name was not immediately available, promised he would do what he could to look after the child. No one knows the name her parents gave her, but the journalist said that in recognition of Albertini's compassion, the child would be called Albertina.

Gov. L. Douglas Wilder told Virginians on Thursday night he will freeze state employee salaries, cut state spending by $375 million and consider eliminating some agencies to cope with budget woes. Some layoffs and office closings will result from the proposals to deal with a projected $1.4 billion shortfall in the state's $26 billion, 1990-1992 budget, the governor said in a statewide televised address. ``My plan is tough but fair,'' Wilder said. ``This plan requires government to be more efficient and effective in its use of scarce resources.'' Wilder said he would not recommend any increase in taxes, would not reduce direct aid payments to the poor and medically needy, would maintain public safety funding and would keep a $200 million budget reserve for emergencies. The major points of his plan included: _ Reducing state agency budgets by nearly $375 million over the next two years. ``Every agency of state government, including colleges and universities, direct service agencies, administrative agencies _ and yes, even the office of the governor _ will reduce expenditures,'' he said. Wilder said some employees will be laid off, some field offices will be closed and some agencies and programs will be eliminated. _ Eliminate state funding for private museums, foundations and attractions. These projects cost $11 million in the current two-year budget, he said. Their funding will be reduced this fiscal year and recommended for elimination next fiscal year, Wilder said. _ Continue a moratorium on state construction ``for all but the most essential projects.'' About $300 million in projected lottery profits over the next two years will go to operating expenses instead of building construction. _ Withhold 2 percent salary increases that state employees were to have received in December, saving more than $145 million. _ Reduce state aid to localities, which makes up more than half the state's budget. Wilder did not specify how much aid would be reduced. Wilder said he will ask the General Assembly in January to eliminate the Department of World Trade and possibly the Department of Volunteerism, the Council on the Status of Women and the Council on Indians. The governor also said he will look into consolidating children's services handled by several state agencies. He said he would study cutting the use of state-owned vehicles, cutting the number of field offices in the Department of Motor Vehicles and providing an early retirement program to reduce the state work force. In a 14-minute televised response, Republicans said the governor had borrowed many of their ideas for budget cutting but still did not go far enough. ``I think the governor has barely touched on any budget reform,'' said Del. Clint Miller. Another Republican delegate, Vincent F. Callahan Jr., said Virginians still may wind up paying more taxes despite Wilder's no-new-taxes pledge. The governor did not provide details on how his spending cuts and other savings would add up to $1.4 billion. He said he would give specifics in an address Friday to the money committees of the General Assembly.

DOC.HEAD: Airwaves Crackle with Saddam Parodies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Chill out, Madonna and Janet Jackson. Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein is catching heavy play on rock 'n' roll radio these days. Disc jockeys across the country are dubbing over pop songs to produce parodies aimed at Saddam. It evoked memories of the time when radio stations blasted Iran's taking of American hostages with the song ``Bomb Iran'' set to the Beach Boys' ``Barbara Ann.'' The results are often more popular than the top 40. To the strains of the Marvelettes' ``Please Mr. Postman,'' WZLX-FM in Boston lambasted Saddam on Wednesday for his country's march into neighboring Kuwait. The song changes the original lyrics from ``Stop, oh yes, wait a minute Mr. Postman, wa-a-a-it Mr. Postman,'' to ``Oh yeah, wait a minute Mr. Hussein, Kuwait isn't yours Mr. Hussein.'' The song continues: ``Saddam Hussein is cut off at sea, ``Our troops are poised so patiently, ``We're gonna be there for a long, long time ``You'll have nothing but an empty pipeline ...'' In Philadelphia, WMGK-FM aired ``I Am Iraq,'' to the tune of Simon and Garfunkel's ``I Am A Rock,'' on its show ``Harvey in the Morning.'' The song blasts Saddam with the lyrics: ``I am the chosen leader, no I'm not insane, it's right and just because I am Hussein, I am Iraq, I am a tyrant ...'' ``It's our biggest hit,'' said Julie Roberts, the show's producer. ``People want to know where they can buy copies, and there are a lot of requests. We've gotten a few dozen calls.'' Saddam has chosen to be known by his first name, but the songwriters are generally calling him Hussein. WTIC-FM in Hartford, Conn., played ``Blame it on Hussein'' to the tune of Milli Vanilli's ``Blame it on the Rain.'' The song was part of a station promotion Wednesday in which disc jockeys dressed as Arab sheiks and a service station offered drivers premium gasoline for 96 cents a gallon. Traffic tie-ups forced an early end to the event. WHHY-FM in Montgomery, Ala., caused a traffic jam Tuesday when it held an ``Insane Hussein'' party. There were no song parodies. But the station gave away five gallons of gas to the first 102 cars in line and had a dunking booth with a person dressed as the Iraqi leader. Following in the footsteps of history, Rush Limbaugh's nationally syndicated radio talk show set ``Bomb Iraq'' to ``Barbara Ann.'' ``We had a guy call up who said, `let's go in there and take Hussein out,' '' Limbaugh said. ``I said, `here's a song for you,' and we played it.'' In Dallas, KMGC-FM dubbed over the Fine Young Cannibals' ``She Drives Me Crazy'' with the lyrics: ``Hussein is crazy, ooh, ooh ``So call his bluff, ooh, ooh ``Hussein is crazy, and things could really get rough. ``Ooh, ooh ...'' KLZX AM & FM in Salt Lake City serenaded its listeners with ``Iraq, Iraq,'' based on ``New York, New York,'' and ``Hussein,'' sung to Eric Clapton's ``Cocaine.'' Country and western stations are also getting into the act. Disc jockey Ken Cooper at KZLA in Burbank, Calif., came up with several parodies, such as a twist on Hank Williams Jr.'s ``All My Rowdy Friends Are Coming Over Tonight'' that goes ``All My Saudi Friends are Coming Over Tonight.'' Michael Coleman, production director of Boston's WZLX, said the station's first parody got such a response he decided to produce several others. One, to the tune of ``End of the Line'' by the Traveling Wilburys, goes: ``Well it's an oil fight, ``Riding in the Middle East. ``Well it's an oil fight. ``Iraq is acting like a beast.'' Others in the works for national airwaves include ``One More in the Name of Allah'' to U2's ``Pride, in the Name of Love''; ``Me and Hussein Down by the Oil Field'' to Paul Simon's ``Me And Julio Down by the Schoolyard''; and ``Who'll Stop Hussein'' to Creedence Clearwater Revival's ``Who'll Stop the Rain.'' ``I don't want to make a joke of this,'' Coleman said. ``This is just tongue-in-cheek, but we have to be careful.''

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Invokes Iraq's Ancient Glory To Become New Nebuchadnezzar
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein is invoking the cultural glories of Iraq's ancient empires and their legendary warrior-kings like Nebuchadnezzar II of Babylon to enhance his claim to be the new champion of the Arab world. The Iraqi president has rewritten history books and purports to be a descendant of the Prophet Mohammed, who founded Islam in the 6th century. He has employed more than 1,000 workers and spent millions to rebuild Babylon, capital of Nebuchadnezzar's empire. Saddam seeks to rally support among the world's estimated 1 billion Moslems and legitimize his crusade against the West and Israel in their eyes as he finds himself facing a U.S.-led international quarantine for invading Kuwait on Aug. 2. Saddam's evocation of Iraq's ancient dynasties has given rise to suspicions among other Arabs that he harbors imperial ambitions. Nebuchadnezzar's empire embraced Kuwait, now gobbled up by Iraq, and what are now Syria, Jordan, Israel and Saudi Arabia. Saddam, 54, has been shrouding himself in the mythology of Iraq's historical heyday from the 6th century B.C. to the 8th century to consolidate his power. Around this he has created an all-pervasive personality cult. Huge posters and wall paintings of Saddam in noble pose are ever-present, as are photos of him on front pages of Iraqi newspapers. A plaque in the Shiite Moslem mosque of Imam Hussein in the holy city of Karbala in southern Iraq shows a family tree that supposedly proves that the former peasant boy can trace his lineage back to Mohammed through the Hashemite kings of Arabia. The Information Ministry in Baghdad freely hands out copies, although the accuracy of the family tree cannot be authenticated and many non-Iraqi Arabs are highly skeptical of its provenance. But to help it along, Saddam has in the last couple of years rehabilitated the once discredited Hashemite monarchy of Iraq, overthrown in a 1958 coup and denounced as a British puppet regime. Iraqis like to point out that ancient Mesopotamia, in present-day Iraq, is generally viewed as the cradle of civilization. Mesopotamis means ``the land between the rivers'' _ the Euphrates and the Tigris. Archaeological excavations have produced evidence of settlements dating from 7,000 B.C. The Garden of Eden is reputed to have been at Al-Qurna, where the Euphrates and Tigris join. Saddam's most ambitious effort to project himself as the new Nebuchadnezzar has been the resurrection of Babylon, the jewel of Mesopotamian civilization. Saddam began rebuilding Babylon four years ago during the 1980-88 war with Iran. He brought in more than 1,000 laborers from Sudan to toil in the desert heat on the banks of the Euphrates to rebuild Nebuchadnezzar's Southern Palace and other parts of the ruined city, 60 miles north of Baghdad. By encouraging Iraqis to steep themselves in the glories of Babylon, and those of the great Mesopotamian cultures that flourished around the cities of Nineveh, Nimrud and Ur, Saddam sought to boost national morale as well as enhance his own dynastic credentials. Nebuchadnezzar was tailor-made for Saddam's grandiose crusade to portray himself as the savior of the Arabs against Israel. The Baylonian king sacked Jerusalem. He took the Children of Israel into captivity for 50 years and fought for years with the Persians, ancient enemies of the Arabs. Iraqi officials conveniently ignore, however, that the Achaemenian Persians conquered Babylon in 539 B.C. Iraqi history books now refer to Nebuchadnezzar as the defender of ``the Arab nation,'' even though he lived 1,000 years before there was such a thing. Rebuilding Babylon has cost Iraq millions of dollars while the country is saddled with a war debt estimated from $50 billion to $60 billion. That does not include the $10 billion owed to Kuwait which the puppet government Saddam installed there conveniently wrote off. Saddam has not restricted himself to identifying with Nebuchadnezzar. He has likened himself to Hammurabi, who ruled Babylon in the 17th century B.C. and is credited with drawing up the world's first written code of law and with razing the cities of his enemies. Mesopotamia was the center of the Parthian empire which emerged in the 2nd century B.C. and lasted for 400 years. Its capital was Ctesiphon, whose ruins lie near modern Baghdad. The Parthians came later and held back the Romans and the Byzantine empire until A.D. 637, when they were conquered by the Arabs sweeping out of the south to spread the new religion of Islam by the sword. In 750, the Abbasids, whose capital was Baghdad, carved out an Islamic empire stretching from what is now Pakistan to Morocco. This was the era of Caliph Haroun al-Rashid, when Baghdad flowered as the center of Arabic culture and the beguiling city of the Thousand and One Nights.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: This Time Sherry Won't Do
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Diplomats have been known to greet each other politely, sip a glass of sherry and do away with entire nations. Other times, they end wars. More often than not, diplomacy is a way to avert bloodshed. It's a civilized occupation, best performed by representatives of civilized nations. Evidently, it has no place in the Persian Gulf. At least not now. President Bush is relying on an economic blockade backed by a nuclear-armed American naval armada _ not gentle conversation _ to try to persuade Iraq's Saddam Hussein to reverse his takeover of Kuwait. ``What we need to do at this point is to enforce the international law,'' Bush said Thursday in dismissing any notion of using Jordan's King Hussein as a diplomatic intermediary to Baghdad. In fact, it turned out the king did not bring Bush any message from Iraq, where he stopped before flying to Washington and then to Maine to see the president. History provides little evidence that diplomacy works with dictators or terrorists. It did not restrain Moammar Gadhafi of Libya. However, the State Department detected a marked decrease in terrorism after U.S. warplanes bombed Tripoli in April 1986. In 1981, diplomacy finally achieved the release of 52 American hostages in Iran. But only after they had spent 444 days in desperate captivity. Six Americans still are being held hostage in Lebanon, despite questionable overtures to Tehran by the Reagan administration and repeated intercessions through third parties. In confronting Saddam, Bush is using U.S. diplomats in Iraq and Kuwait solely to convey messages of protest and to insist that the more than 3,000 Americans trapped in the two countries be permitted to depart. He isn't calling the Americans hostages yet. But neither are Bush, Secretary of State James A. Baker III and other senior U.S. officials attempting to cultivate the Iraqi leader with sweet talk or to negotiate a settlement in the gulf. They are demanding a full Iraqi withdrawal _ and not very diplomatically. Baker branded Saddam a dictator in a report last week to NATO foreign ministers in Brussels. Bush has said several times that Saddam is not a man of his word. Both Bush and Baker have made very thinly veiled appeals to the Iraqi people to get rid of him. The rhetoric is even sharper at the other end. On Thursday, in a rambling attack carried on Iraqi television, Saddam called the American president a liar and said the outbreak of holy war _ which Saddam has called for _ could bring ``thousands of Americans wrapped in sad coffins.'' That's the sort of undiplomatic language Saddam used to hurl against Tehran when he was locked in an eight-year war with Iran. But as he tries to wriggle out of Bush's economic noose, Saddam is not above engaging in diplomacy with the very people in Tehran who only a few years ago sought to overthrow him. On Wednesday, Saddam offered to return seized Iranian territory and Iranian prisoners, thereby meeting two key Iranian demands. The Iraqi leader was not just being nice. An accord with Iran would free most of the Iraqi military units deployed along the border. Saddam also hopes Iran would be so gratified it would defy the international blockade arranged by Bush and approved by the U.N. Security Council. And who asked Iran to bring whatever pressure it could on Iraq? Well, in this upside down world, the United States did _ through third-party intermediaries. That's the same Iran that denounced the United States as ``the great Satan'' and held 52 Americans in captivity.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid is the chief diplomatic writer for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Greenhouse Gases Rising in Earth's Atmosphere
DOC.TEXT: Carbon dioxide _ the most common of the so-called greenhouse gases _ is increasing in the Earth's atmosphere faster than during the 1960s and early 1980s, a federal agency reports. According to a study by Dr. Pieter Tans of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the concentration of carbon dioxide increased at an average rate of 1.71 parts per million over the last four years. That is somewhat faster than the 1.5 parts per million rise reported in much of the 1980s. In the 1960s the increase was reported at only 0.7 parts per million annually. ``I think there is a tendency for the rate to be still increasing, but it doesn't go smoothly, just like the climate,'' Tans said Thursday. ``The (carbon dioxide) increase varies a lot from year to year. One year it can change very little, and the next year it makes up for the slow increase,'' he explained in a telephone interview. ``At the moment it seems to be increasing fairly fast.'' Concentrations of carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, CFC-11 and CFC-12 are monitored by NOAA's Climate Monitoring and Diagnostics Laboratory in Boulder, Colo. The increasing amount of these gases in the air has caused concern in recent years. The gases are produced by industrial processes, heating and other human activities as well as some natural sources. Many scientists worry that the gases will act somewhat like a greenhouse, causing Earth to overheat. The shortwave radiation from the sun that warms the Earth passes through the gases easily, but they can trap the longer wave radiation from Earth that normally cools the planet and keeps overall temperatures in balance. Global concentrations of carbon dioxide, the most common of the so-called greenhouse gases, have increased by about 25 percent since the mid-1800s, to just over 350 parts per million. However, scientists disagree over whether any global heating has already occurred. Increasing the atmospheric level of carbon dioxide by 1 part per million requires the addition of 2.13 billion tons of carbon to the air. Much of this occurs through the burning of fossil fuels such as coal and oil. Other greenhouse gases are much less common. _Methane concentrations rose by 12 parts per billion per year, although officials said this growth rate may have declined slightly. _Nitrous oxide increased at a rate of 0.7 parts per billion per year. _CFC-11 was rising at 10 parts per trillion, while the rate for CFC-12 was 16 parts per trillion. Both of these chemicals are chlorofluorocarbons, used in refrigeration and other industrial processes. These chemicals also can damage the Earth's protective ozone layer, and an international agreement has been signed to reduce their use.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: David Keith, who acted in ``An Officer and a Gentleman'' and ``Lords of Discipline,'' is branching out as a singer in a country music band. Keith, 36, will make his debut next week in his hometown of Knoxville with his Hard Country band, which he said has a ``traditional, Appalachian hillbilly beat ... but with electric guitars turned up just a little bit.'' ``I just try everything,'' Keith said. ``When I go into something I never really think, `Oh, gosh, what if I fail at this?' '' Keith played with a more rock-oriented band called the Road Roosters a few years ago. In his latest acting role, Keith appears in ``The Two Jakes,'' Jack Nicholson's sequel to ``Chinatown.''

Jamaican Prime Minister Michael Manley underwent prostate surgery at Sloan Kettering Hospital, the Jamaican Consulate said. The 65-year-old Manley has had no complications from the four-hour operation Wednesday to remove a benign nodule found in April, said consulate spokesman Ian Edwards.

Tippi Hedren, who starred in Alfred Hitchcock's ``The Birds,'' is joining the cast of the CBS soap opera ``The Bold and the Beautiful.'' Miss Hedren, 55, said Thursday she will play Helen MacLaine, a mother of two grown children, beginning Sept. 6. She is not the only actor from ``The Birds'' to join a soap opera cast. Darlene Conley, who played the waitress in the film's gas station explosion scene, also has a role on ``The Bold and the Beautiful.'' Miss Hedren, whose daughter is ``Working Girl'' star Melanie Griffith, has also appeared on television in ``Baby Boom,'' ``Tales From the Darkside'' and ``Alfred Hitchcock Presents.''

Comedian Francesca Hilton, daughter of hotel magnate Conrad Hilton and Zsa Zsa Gabor, doesn't worry about running out of material. ``Everytime I need material I ask my mother to go out there and do something,'' Miss Hilton said Thursday. She begins a two-week Vegas World casino stand on Sept. 12, opening for Tony Martin in what she calls ``the biggest break of my career.'' She has been playing the comedy club circuit for years. ``Comedy is OK,'' Miss Hilton said. ``I felt it was cheaper than shock treatment. If I survived the Gabors all these years, I figure comedy should be easy.'' Miss Hilton opens her routine by getting family matters out of the way. ``I tell them who I am right away. I say my mother is the queen of outer space,'' said Miss Hilton, referring to one of Miss Gabor's campy movies, ``Queen of Outer Space.''

ABC's Sam Donaldson and NBC's Tom Brokaw are the latest U.S. network anchormen to report for duty in Saudi Arabia. Brokaw and Donaldson flew in Wednesday night, raising to seven the number of network anchormen sent to report on the Middle East crisis. ABC's Ted Koppel on Tuesday became the first U.S. network correspondent allowed into Iraq, then flew to Jordan. Dan Rather, who entered Iraq on Wednesday, has been reporting from the Middle East for CBS since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait started the crisis. Also sent to the Middle East are Harry Smith of CBS, ABC's Forrest Sawyer and Garrick Utley of NBC.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration Ignored Iraq's Human Rights Record, Book Says
With PM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration largely ignored Iraq's ``brutal and repressive'' human rights record while seeking to foster good relations with Baghdad before the current Persian Gulf crisis, a former U.S. diplomat says in a forthcoming book. David A. Korn, who worked in the Middle East and Washington for about 20 years as a foreign service officer, writes that the Reagan and Bush administrations ``paid scant attention to human rights in their dealings with Iraq.'' ``Both have put the nurturing of new friendly relations with President Saddam Hussein's government well ahead of addressing the violent and repressive nature of his regime,'' Korn said in uncorrected page proofs of the book. The volume, ``Human Rights in Iraq,'' is scheduled for November publication by Human Rights Watch and Yale University Press. Human Rights Watch is a private organization that monitors rights violations worldwide. ``Iraq is a well-organized police state and its government is one of the most brutal and repressive regimes in power today,'' said Korn. President Bush has strongly condemned Saddam in recent days. He halted trade with Iraq and sent troops to Saudi Arabia in response to Saddam's Aug. 2 invasion of neighboring Kuwait and the massing of Iraqi troops near the Saudi border. As recently as June 15, however, Joshua Gilder, deputy assistant secretary of state for human rights, told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that the administration was not prepared to declare Iraq guilty of ``a consistent pattern of gross violations'' that would trigger sanctions. Gilder made the statement after Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., called for an end to U.S. exports to Iraq because of alleged human rights violations. The book details a long history of human rights violations in Iraq. It does not deal with the human rights records of other Persian Gulf countries, although Iraq's neighbors also have come in for sharp criticism. ``Iraq is particularly bad, but the other countries in the region are far from having a clean slate,'' said Laurie Mylroie, an Iraq analyst with the Harvard Center for Middle East Studies. ``Iraq is probably the worst, then Iran, then Saudi Arabia and then Kuwait. Palestinians in Kuwait, for instance, live much better than Palestinians in Iraq.'' Andrew Whitley of Human Rights Watch in New York said, ``The Iraqi record, in terms of monolithic political repression and total abuse of the norms of law and natural justice, is far worse than any of the others.'' Amnesty International, another human rights organization, said last month that members of the Kurdish minority have been subject to brutal treatment in Iran and Turkey as well as Iraq. The report said Kurds were victims of a wave of secret executions in Iran that ended in January 1989. One of the most sensational human rights charges against Iraq, one that Bush has mentioned repeatedly in recent days, involves the use of poison gas against rebellious Kurds in August 1988. An official of the International Committee of the Red Cross estimated that 5,000 Kurds were killed. The State Department condemned the action and has consistently criticized the Iraqis in its annual human rights report. Last year, the Iraqi human rights record was described as ``abysmal.'' Nevertheless, wrote Korn, ``the Bush administration did not raise with Iraqi authorities the report's findings of murder, extralegal detention, torture and disappearance of political opponents and government critics, according to State Department sources.'' Nathan Kingsley, public affairs advisor in the State Department's human rights bureau, said, ``Our responsibility is to deliver a complete, whole, objective analysis of human rights abuses around the world. That we have done. You can't get much more public than this report, which, when it comes out, is regarded sort of universally as the department's position.'' James Graham, Middle East coordinator for Amnesty International, said several hundred Iraqi dissidents who had been living in Kuwait were arrested after the invasion, and the organization had reports that some of them had been returned to Iraq. ``Given the past patterns of that regime, there is good reason to believe that those people will certainly be imprisoned if not tortured and executed,'' Graham said.

DOC.HEAD: Sheik Loses Millions at Gambling Tables, Reports Say
DOC.TEXT: A Saudi sheik, known for his fervor at the gambling table, lost more than $18 million in recent weeks at clubs in Cannes and Monte Carlo, the French press reported. Sheik Eynani, described as a counselor to Prince Faisal, lost $12.4 million in just four nights between June 15 and July 15 while gambling at this city's Carlton Club, according to sources quoted by the news agency Agence France-Presse on Thursday. The newspaper Le Parisien, quoting an unidentified witness, said the sheik, hoping to recover some of his losses, later played tables at the casino of Monte Carlo in the nearby principality _ only to lose $5.7 million. The reports said Eynani was able to make immediate payment of only 60 percent on the debt.

DOC.HEAD: Flying Tankers Top Off Fighter Jets Headed for the Mideast
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhoto BX2
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS NOTE: The steady stream of U.S. air power to the Middle East is dependent on midair refueling. National Writer Fred Bayles was aboard an Air Force tanker as it rendezvoused with combat aircraft on their way to the military buildup.

There is little time for ceremony while traveling 530 mph five miles above the ocean. ``Pinch 15, are you full?'' asked the airman first class operating the refueling boom of the Air Force KC-135 tanker. ``Pinch 15 is full. Disconnecting,'' said the pilot of the F-4 Phantom fighter flying a scant 20 feet below. The pilot's face was hidden by his helmet, visor and oxygen mask as the graceful gray aircraft severed its connection to the tanker in a spray of jet fuel. ``Good journey,'' said the boom operator, and the Phantom was gone. The brief ritual is being repeated often over the Atlantic these days. While the technological miracle of air-to-air refueling has long been commonplace, the difference is these pilots are flying to an uncertainty that may include combat. ``We train to do this all the time,'' said the tanker's boom operator, a 22-year-old Massachusetts woman. ``But it makes it a little more urgent when it's the real thing.'' Thursday's mission by the Plattsburgh, N.Y., Air Force Base crew was one of untold numbers conducted as the U.S. military buildup grows in the Iraq crisis. The refueling of the 24 Phantoms involved eight KC-135s from Plattsburgh along with eight from Griffiss AFB in New York and Pease AFB in New Hampshire. Details about the total number of missions is classified. Lt. Col. Rick Oborn, an Air Force spokesman at the Pentagon, would only say the number of refueling sorties is well above normal military activity. Secrecy was a passenger on Thursday's flight. Journalists aboard the tanker were asked not to use the names of the crew or identify the squadron. Squadron emblems and identification patches were removed from the flight crew's uniforms. ``Potential terrorist reprisals,'' explained base spokesman Lt. Casey Mahon. Whatever the number of refueling missions, the stolid tankers, the military cousin of the Boeing 707 airliner, are a vital link in the quick deployment of men and material to the Persian Gulf. All combat aircraft and many of the transports flying to the Middle East are potential ``receivers'' that need to be ``dragged across the pond,'' Air Force lexicon for air-to-air refueling over the Atlantic. ``There aren't too many missions that can take place in the Air Force without a KC-135,'' said the tanker's pilot, whose husband also flies the venerable aircraft. The tanker's crew of two men and two women was proud of their role and their aircraft, despite the seemingly glamorless task of operating a flying gas station. Hot and noisy, permeated with the odor of its kerosene cargo, the sky-blue airplane was flying well before John Kennedy was president, before the Beatles, before Vietnam. ``Every time we fly we get pumped up,'' said the pilot, who, at 28, was born three years after her plane went into service. Thursday's receivers were Phantoms known as Wild Weasels, based at George AFB outside Los Angeles. The fighters are loaded with electronic gear and arms for the high-risk job of disrupting and destroying enemy radar and anti-aircraft installations. That deadly business was made apparent as the thirsty fighters swung into formation with the tankers 190 miles east of Cape Cod. Each of the sharp-nosed aircraft carried gleaming white missiles under its wings. Inside the cavernous tanker the 22-year-old boom operator took her position in the tail of the plane, lying on a platform to maneuver the 20-foot refueling boom into a port just behind a fighter's canopy. The nimble jet eased into position by listening to quick, curt instructions from the operator and watching red, green and white directional signals flashing from the tanker's belly. With three fighters flying in formation with the tanker, she ran through the routine for more than an hour, loading each plane with 900 gallons of JP4 fuel, then adding 400 gallons to top off the fighters' already emptying fuel tanks. When the process was finished, the jets had been ``dragged'' 560 more miles across the ocean. It was time to turn for home. Other tankers were waiting along the flight path to escort the fighters farther along their journey. And despite the protestations that this was just another mission, the thoughts of the tanker's crew turned to where the fighters were heading. ``I know what they're going over there for and I think about them,'' said the plane's captain. ``We're over here in our safe United States and they're asked to do a lot more than we are right now.''

DOC.HEAD: Legislator Calls for Australian Royal Family
DOC.TEXT: Hey, Prince Charles _ tired of that British climate? A politician is putting out the welcome mat in hopes that you or another member of the royal family will move Down Under. Legislator Bob Such told the South Australia state Parliament Thursday that Australia should consider having its own resident royal family. When asked who was on his royal short list, Such said one or several members of the British royal family could move Down Under to start Australia's own royal line. Such said the royals could become Australians eventually.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaitis Reported To Be Still Fighting Back
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Kuwait City has been eerily silent during the day, but gunfire crackles in the night as Kuwaitis stage hit-and-run raids against the Iraqi invaders, refugees say. They also claimed Thursday that the Iraqi troops who invaded Aug. 2 have still not been able to completely stifle resistance by the citizens of the oil-rich kingdom. But some said the Kuwaiti underground is waiting for help from outside before launching a major offensive against the conquerors. ``When the sun shines you're gripped with the awesome silence and desolation, and after sundown there's the fear of violence and death,'' said one Kuwaiti, Saeed Hussein. ``Resistance has been reactivated, but only after dark.'' A Kuwaiti woman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said some Kuwaiti men ``go out with machine guns every night and kill one or two Iraqis.'' There was no independent confirmation of any significant resistance in the northern Persian Gulf state. The extent of casualties in what clashes there may be is not known. Communications with Kuwait are still cut. Iraq has an estimated 120,000 troops in Kuwait. A growing U.S. force, backed by an international fleet drawn from the British, French and other navies, is mustering in Saudi Arabia to face the Iraqis massed along the kingdom's northern border. Kuwait's radio station, once the liveliest in the gulf region, broadcasts clandestinely, calling for resistance against the Iraqi invaders. ``Kuwait will ... never be part of Iraq,'' announcers stress in between nationalist songs. ``Today brave Kuwaitis in a speeding car hurled a grenade at a security base, killing a number of Iraqi soldiers and injuring others,'' it claimed in a broadcast Wednesday. Another traveler from Kuwait, who also requested anonymity, said: ``Resistance is spreading ... Young Kuwaitis don't know mercy any more. Greg Maine, a 35-year-old British businessman, said: ``The world shouldn't have the impression that Kuwait has been rolled over. The Kuwaitis are there, waiting for the outside world to act so they can respond.'' His wife, Patricia, said the invasion had ``brought out the best'' in the Kuwaitis. She said some Kuwaitis, who have a reputation for being prudent with their cash, were handing out money to those left destitute. Most of the refugees fled with few assets from their country, which once boasted one of the highest per capita incomes in the world. Now the refugees line up for handouts outside the Kuwaiti Embassy in Bahrain, an archipelago off the coast of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait's southern neighbor. The embassy provides mattresses, bedsheets, pillows and other necessities. The embassy is the only place where the Kuwaiti dinar, its value demolished by the invasion, can be exchanged at anything near its former value. Banks won't touch it anymore. The Kuwaiti currency was worth $3.50 before the invasion but plunged below $1 after the invasion. But the embassy changes one Kuwaiti dinar for one Bahraini dinar, worth $2.65. Authorities in Saudi Arabia, Oman and the United Arab Emirates offer the refugees free accommodation. The U.A.E. also provides every refugee family with $550. In Bahrain's markets, a group of Kuwaiti refugees tried to give vendors Kuwaiti dinars for their fish and shrimp, but the vendors refused to take any money. For many of the refugees, their days are spent in gloomy hotel rooms, huddled around radio and television sets reporting the crisis that has made them homeless.

DOC.HEAD: Marketing Orders Cause High Fruit and Vegetable Prices, Critics Say
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department has used so-called federal marketing orders to give generations of fruit and vegetable farmers a way to boost prices, but officials say that application is less prevalent than before. Through federal marketing orders, the department can affect the volume, quality, appearance, packaging or public perception of about 45 fruit and vegetable crops worth about $4.5 billion a year. It's a touchy subject. Defenders of marketing orders insist the programs assure consumers of consistent supplies and high quality. But others claim the system promotes greed and waste by providing indirect subsidies to favored industries. Federal marketing orders for horticultural crops, as fruits and vegetables are collectively called, are controls authorized by law to let producers in a geographic area decide as a group how, and sometimes when, their crops are sold on the market. The system is subject to regulations and supervision by the Agriculture Department, although local boards carry out the day-to-day functions. Nicholas J. Powers of the department's Economic Research Service says the controls were sanctioned by Congress in the early 1930s, following earlier attempts by western cooperatives to withhold produce and limit market sales when supplies were abundant. But those attempts failed because not everyone went along with the co-op efforts, and the U.S. Supreme Court threw out early laws on controls and taxes for processing. Congress finally devised the Agricultural Marketing Agreement Act of 1937, the underlying basis for today's marketing orders and agreements. In a report published this month in Farmline magazine, Powers outlined the different kinds of marketing orders. Virtually all the orders allow growers to set minimum grade and size requirements. In many, handlers pay for advertising and promotion programs and for research on production and marketing. Twenty-one marketing orders allow growers to apply some kind of volume control to limit the amount sent to market during certain times of the year. ``Consumers who buy produce in markets with limited quantities pay a higher price than otherwise,'' Powers said. A few years ago, federal marketing orders generated court challenges and other snarls. In one case, surplus navel oranges were used as livestock feed after being barred from the market. The conservative Heritage Foundation in 1985 called federal marketing orders ``government-backed cartels'' that forced consumers to pay millions of dollars more for food than they would otherwise. But there has been less flak about marketing orders lately, and Powers, in a telephone interview Thursday, suggested some reasons why. ``Over the last decade, there's been less emphasis on what are called the volume-control regulations,'' he said. ``Those are the regulations which can be used to restrict supply to certain markets and thereby elevate prices in those markets.'' Marketing orders now ``tend to emphasize more of the advertising, promotional activities, along with the grading of produce'' to make sure crops are mature enough for sale to users, Powers said. Also, more orders emphasize research and packaging of the produce. But volume controls are still used. Last winter, he said, news reports described how California was controlling the amount of citrus going to market even after freezing weather had devastated so much of the Florida citrus crop. ``Volume controls are still used in some of the orders but much less vigorously now than just a few years ago,'' Powers said. Powers says the decline in the use of marketing orders also is due in part to USDA policy, which ``does not encourage the industry to use volume controls as vigorously as they had in the past.''
