One alternative generally favored by USDA is the use of marketing orders to formulate promotion and research programs, which are paid for by the industry itself. The 1985 farm law, for example, authorized such a national program for watermelons, administered by the department's Agricultural Marketing Service. A few of the crops covered by federal marketing orders include Florida citrus and tomatoes; California peaches, pears and plums; California and Arizona navel oranges; Idaho and East Oregon potatoes; Georgia peaches; Virginia and North Carolina potatoes; Maine potatoes; peanuts grown in 16 states; and Hawaiian papayas.

DOC.HEAD: Layoff Warnings Assure Congress Will Get Earful
DOC.TEXT: Warnings about possible federal layoffs come when Congress is most vulnerable to public pressure to reach a budget agreement with the administration, the leader of a government employees union says. ``The administration is reaping the benefits of the timing of this,'' John Sturdivant, president of the 700,000-member American Federation of Government Employees, said Thursday. ``It just happens to be that these notices are going out when the Congress is back home.'' Although complaining that federal employees are being ``kicked around for political reasons'' again, he said ``elections are an amazing motivator for people who are elected to do their jobs.'' Under memos that began going out this week, the nation's 2.4 million federal workers were told that they could face up to 22 days without pay in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1 if no agreement on a deficit-reduction package is reached and mandatory budget cuts follow. Workers subject to the furloughs might be forced to take a day off without pay in each two-week pay period, said the Office of Personnel Management. Because President Bush and Congress have failed to agree on a deficit-reduction package, the administration has ordered federal agencies to draw up plans to cut spending by 31.9 percent. As much as $104 billion in spending cuts, known in Washington jargon as ``sequestration,'' would take effect Oct. 15 unless Congress and Bush agree on a package of tax increases and spending reductions. ``Our people are outraged. They don't appreciate being jerked around by the Congress and the White House, and there's certainly enough blame for both sides,'' Sturdivant said. OPM Director Constance Newman advised federal personnel directors Wednesday that they should begin contacting employees about the potential layoffs. She noted Bush's announced plans to implement massive budget cuts Oct. 15 as a result of the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law. ``It was imperative that they begin making plans now. It's not our wish that they furlough employees nor are we encouraging them to do so. It's just an option that they have to consider,'' said OPM spokeswoman Sharon Wells. Under federal law, agencies have to warn workers who might be threatened by layoffs by at least Aug. 31, a month before the deadline for reaching a deficit-reduction package. Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole was one of the first department heads to send a memo to agency workers. ``I want to emphasize that this does not mean that furloughs are a certainty, only that they may happen,'' Mrs. Dole wrote. Department-wide hiring freezes and cutbacks on travel, equipment and contracts would be implemented before layoffs, Mrs. Dole said.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Says Gulf Operation to Cost $1.18 Billion Through September
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon is putting a $1.18 billion price tag on the deployment of U.S. air, ground and naval forces in Saudi Arabia through September. According to preliminary figures released Thursday, the Army's deployment of ground troops supported by aircraft will cost $750 million; the Navy's share, $230 million; and the Air Force's, $200 million. No estimate was given for costs beyond next month. Chief Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said the figures include neither $120 million in increased fuel costs due to higher oil prices nor the costs that would be incurred if Bush decides to call up reserve forces for active duty. The deployment, called Operation Desert Shield, began Aug. 8, two days after President Bush ordered U.S. forces to head for Saudi Arabia to guard against a possible Iraqi invasion. The announcement said costs beyond Sept. 30 could not be estimated because the size and composition of the armed forces in Desert Shield and their level of activity ``are still evolving.'' The Pentagon gave this partial breakdown of the total cost through Sept. 30: _$294 million for transport of cargo by commercial and government aircraft. Activation and deployment of additional transport ships cost $74 million. _Imminent danger and family separation pay totals $50 million. _Use of volunteer reserve units for airlift, tanker refueling and cargo handling cost $12 million. _Activation and deployment of two hospital ships cost $10 million. _$25 million for medical supplies. _Chemical protective equipment at a cost of $56 million.

DOC.HEAD: US Pilots Lock in Iraqis on Radar But `They Don't Want to Play'
DOC.NOTE: EDS: This is based on a pool dispatch
DOC.TEXT: American pilots have locked in their weapons radar on Iraqi planes in what one crew chief described as ``a little cat and mouse'' game that the Iraqis refuse to go along with, U.S. airmen say. ``They don't want to play with us,'' one crew chief said Thursday. ``If I were in a Mirage and an F-15 locked onto me, I'd get out of there fast, too.'' When an American jet's weapons systems radar locks onto another plane, it means the U.S. jet has found its target and communicated that to its missile. The Iraqi pilot knows it, too, because his plane carries a warning system something like the ``fuzzbuster'' radar used by some automobile drivers in America to warn them that they're under the scrutiny of police radar. Although the U.S. airmen declined to go into detail, there was no indication that any of the encounters involved Iraqi planes attempting to intrude into Saudi Arabian air space. The airmen suggested that the encounters occurred during missions near the border with Kuwait. Col. John McBroom, commander of the 1st Tactical Fighter Wing from Langley Air Force Base in Virginia, refused to confirm the pilots' reports and said he had instructed his airmen not to discuss any contact with Iraqi jets. ``I'm not going to get into our encounters,'' he said. But McBroom did say he considered U.S. air power here far superior to Iraq's. ``We're not over here to go to war,'' McBroom said, ``but we will finish one quickly in the air.'' Another officer in the unit and several crew chiefs said there have been several instances in which weapons systems aboard U.S. F-15s locked onto the Iraqis' French-made Mirage jets. ``One of my pilots told me they turn and run as soon as the radar locks on,'' one crew chief said. ``There's been a little cat and mouse but when the weapons lock on, they're gone,'' said another. Asked again about the encounters, McBroom said: ``All I'll do is remind you our radar can lock on at a pretty good range. Beyond that you'll have to ask the Iraqis.'' He seemed to be suggesting that the episodes involved Iraqi planes flying well within Kuwaiti airspace. In Washington, Pete Williams, the chief Pentagon spokesman, said he had asked military officials about the report but had received no information that would enable him to confirm or deny the accuracy of the crew chiefs' remarks. McBroom said the fighter unit felt somewhat vulnerable on the ground when it arrived last week. But now it has received powerful ground protection from other U.S. forces, including Patriot ground-to-air missile systems. The unit has set up camp at a Saudi air base. It uses spare Saudi hangars, maintenance garages and other facilities. Ground rules for the a pool of U.S. reporters flown here by the Pentagon prohibit disclosure of the base's location, the number of planes and other weapons systems or the names of non-command officers. The men are living in Saudi barracks and schools. But a tent city is under construction on the base, as is a portable hospital. Heat is a big problem. The hospital is treating about 15 cases of heat stress a day, Air Force officials said. Interviews with the airmen were conducted between 9 a.m. and 10 a.m. local time, when temperatures already were approaching triple digits and the sun was scorching. One Air Force sergeant was taken to the hospital during the pool's visit for a minor case of heat stress. He had been swinging a sledge hammer for several hours helping to set up the tents. McBroom said the Saudi base facilities are the best he has ever seen. ``The Saudis build everything big and everything right,'' he said. McBroom and his crew chiefs and maintenance personnel said they have had very few equipment problems associated with the heat. Most of the planes are being kept outdoors in the heat because electronic systems sometimes have temporary troubles when going from a cool to hot environment, McBroom said. The Air Force has extensive stocks of missiles for the jets, and crews were seen unloading boxes of 20mm shells for their on-board guns as well.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Foreign Minister Flying to Meet Saddam
DOC.TEXT: India's foreign minister planned to meet with Saddam Hussein in Baghdad today to ask that 185,000 Indian citizens be allowed to leave Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. Speaking Thursday in Washington before his overseas flight, External Affairs Minister Inder K. Gujral said he also would do whatever possible to prevent a flare-up of hostilities in the Persian Gulf region. But he emphasized he is neither a mediator nor a messenger and suggested the crisis is not yet ripe for mediation. ``To tell Saddam Hussein to let my people come out, that is my primary concern, and also to try to see if better sense can prevail on all sides to see that the situation does not go to the flare point,'' Gujral told reporters after conferring by telephone with Indian Prime Minister V. P. Singh. He met Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in Moscow Tuesday, then flew here for talks with Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Wednesday and national security adviser Brent Scowcroft on Thursday. Gujral said there are 10,000 Indian citizens in Iraq and 175,000 in Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Bicycles Recalled Over Potentially Defective Forks
DOC.TEXT: About 1,600 ``Randonneur'' bicycles, marketed nationwide between January 1982 and June 1984, have been voluntarily recalled by Bianchi, USA, Inc., of San Francisco because of potentially defective front forks, the government says. The Consumer Product Safety Commission said Thursday it knows of three cases in which riders suffered broken bones in crashes caused by sudden breakage of the forks at the junction of the crown and blade. Bianchi will provide new forks at no charge under terms of the recall, coordinated with CPSC. Only Randonneur bicycles with the letter ``B'' on the crown of the fork are involved, the agency said. Owners may call their nearest Bianchi dealer or the firm's toll-free number, 1-800-699-6400, extension 200, to learn if their bicycles are subject to the recall.
DOC.HEAD: Former Judge Takes Drug Enforcement Administration Helm
DOC.TEXT: It will take at least five years for the United States to emerge from its drug crisis, the new head of the federal Drug Enforcement Administration says. ``Let us remember that it took over 20 years to get ourselves into this mess,'' Robert C. Bonner, a former federal judge, said during his swearing-in ceremony on Thursday. ``It is going to take at least five years, and perhaps more, of steady effort and involvement by all segments of our society to work our way out of it,'' Bonner told about 300 people gathered at DEA headquarters to see him take the oath of office from Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia. Bonner, 48, had been a U.S. District Judge in Los Angeles since June 16, 1989. He was the U.S. attorney in Los Angeles from 1984 to 1989 and spent nine years in private law practice. He was assistant U.S. attorney in Los Angeles from 1971 to 1975. President Bush nominated Bonner to succeed John C. Lawn, who retired in March after five years at DEA's helm. The Senate approved the nomination by voice vote on July 27.
DOC.HEAD: Most Adult Men In Ivory Coast Capital Die From AIDS
DOC.TEXT: AIDS has become the leading cause of death among adult men in the West African city of Abidjan, the magazine Science says. It is the second most common cause in adult women there, after deaths related to pregnancy and abortion. A recent study in the Ivory Coast capital city found a minimum annual incidence of AIDS of 1,447 cases per million in adult men and 340 per million in adult women, Science said in its Aug. 17 edition. The study of cadavers was done in a 62-day and 43-day period. Among 698 adult bodies examined, 41 percent of men and 32 percent of women were infected with HIV, the agent that causes Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome. The highest rates were found in men and women aged 30 to 39. Science said the figures ``probably underestimate the true mortality due to HIV infection.'' Among factors skewing the figures were the exclusion of pediatric patients, the unknown proportion of AIDS deaths not brought to the mortuaries studied, and the cultural practice of seriously ill persons leaving Abidjan to die in their home areas. In addition, deaths due to pulmonary tuberculosis _ the third ranking cause of male adult death _ specifically were not counted as AIDS cases, although 50 percent of such cadavers tested HIV positive. ``Although data concerning mortality due to AIDS are scarce,'' the article said, ``AIDS is likely to be the leading cause of adult death in a number of other African cities also.'' In the United States, according to the Centers for Disease Control, there were 16.1 cases of AIDS per 100,000 population in the year ending in July.
DOC.HEAD: Agency Considers Ban On Crib Toys
DOC.TEXT: The Consumer Product Safety Commission is considering a ban or limit on what toys and decorations can be hung over infant cribs. The decision to consider the problem, approved Thursday on a 2-1 vote, calls for the staff to investigate solutions to the hazards posed by such items. The commission received reports of 30 strangulation deaths, one case of severe brain damage, and 18 ``near-misses'' involving decorative ropes or mobiles for cribs. The Consumer Federation of American and the New York attorney general's office petitioned the agency for an outright ban of the items. Thursday's vote means the panel will await further recommendations of its staff and general comment from the public before deciding upon any mandatory requirements. One alternative to banning the products, said staff member Ann Pavlich, might be labeling which warns parents to remove the overhead crib items before infants are large enough to reach them and try to pull themselves upright _ possibly to tumble with them wrapped around their neck. She suggested an age guideline might be 5 months. Such ``crib toys'' or ``gyms'' are not to be confused with separate baby toys, designed for actual handling by the infant, and for which the government has long since set safety standards.

DOC.HEAD: Rabbi Says Ultra-Orthodox Jewish Men May Shave
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Israel's chief rabbi has ruled Ultra-Orthodox Jewish men may shave their beards so gas masks fit properly in the event of a chemical attack by Iraq, and he urged them to carry scissors to shave quickly. Law forbids men from shaving, and many ultra-Orthodox men grow full beards and wear side curls. But traditional gas masks won't seal properly over facial hair and the issue had caused great anxiety among Israel's ultra-Orthodox community until Thursday's ruling by Chief Rabbi Mordechai Eliyahu. The government has considered distributing masks because of threats by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to attack the Jewish state with chemical weapons. Private sales of masks have boomed. The religious weekly Yom Hashishi on Thursday suggested ultra-Orthodox men consider acquiring gas masks designed for children because they cover the entire head. But the Civil Defense agency, responsible for procuring and distributing gas masks, has said catering to the needs of bearded men would not be possible because the masks are mass-produced. In his ruling, Eliyahu said that although Jewish tradition always spoke of Jewish men wearing beards, there was no prohibition against shaving in the body of Jewish law. ``Bearded men have to shave off their beards before wearing a gas mask since even a two-day beard prevents the mask from sealing properly and may allow the gas to penetrate inside,'' he said. Eliyahu also said bearded men should carry scissors in their pocket in case they need to shave in a hurry, the national Itim news agency reported.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Lower in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 26,786.72, down 762.72 points or 2.77 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Hubble Problem Simple, Can Be Corrected
DOC.TEXT: A thin washer may have caused the focusing flaw in the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope, and a space shuttle mission can easily fix much of the problem, NASA officials say. ``The Hubble could actually be better than it could be now,'' Charles Pellerin, NASA director of astrophysics, said Thursday. Pellerin and members of a NASA investigative team held a news conference after two days of hearings at Hughes Danbury Optical Systems Inc., maker of the flawed primary mirror that is producing blurry pictures from the orbiting observatory. The mirror has an aberration caused by a 1.3-millimeter error in a measuring device that was used to grind the telescope's mirrors, said Lew Allen, head of the team and director of NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. ``The error that we discovered is one that leads to an essentially pure spherical aberration, and that's relatively easy to correct,'' Allen said. Pellerin said that all that needs to be done is remove the Hubble's wide-field planetary camera during a previously scheduled shuttle mission in 1993 and replace it with a camera designed to correct the error. The camera was going to be replaced during the 1993 mission anyway because machinery undergoes extraordinary wear and tear in space, Pellerin said. ``The only thing that's different is we didn't anticipate doing this because of optical problems,'' he said. The main camera is the Hubble's most powerful instrument, designed to peer almost to the edge of the universe and produce the telescope's most exciting discoveries. NASA officials said earlier that replacing the camera won't solve the problem for the Hubble's faint-object camera and other instruments, which still will receive poorly focused light from the flawed mirror. Compared with the main camera, however, those instruments are much less severely impaired by the bad mirror. The discovery of the flaw shortly after the Hubble was launched April 25 proved a major embarrassment for NASA. The telescope is designed to take clearer pictures of the far reaches of space than are possible from ground-based telescopes. The 1.3-millimeter error was discovered in a device called a reflective null corrector, NASA officials said. Allen said that simple washers might have thrown off the entire instrument because the washers appear to be the same thickness as the error. But he said that could be a coincidence, and the team will study many other possibilities. The 1.3-millimeter error is huge in optics terms, Allen said. Pellerin likened it to a room that was accidentally built 3 feet too long. Allen said a test had indicated the error when the mirror was manufactured in the early 1980s at a division of Perkin-Elmer Corp. that was bought last year by Hughes. But he said Perkin-Elmer engineers had placed complete faith in the null corrector and disregarded the test results. While declining to say whether Hughes Danbury was to blame for the error, Allen did say NASA was not aware of the results that showed there was an error. ``As we go back through the documents, we don't find any case where they called this to the attention of NASA,'' he said. Thomas Arconti, spokesman for Hughes Danbury, said only that the company would continue to work with NASA to find the answers to the remaining questions. Pellerin said the news would not shake NASA's confidence in Hughes Danbury, which is working on other NASA optics projects and made other highly technical parts of the telescope. ``Everything that's difficult is working fine,'' he said. Allen said during the team's two days at Hughes Danbury, it interviewed former and current employees who worked on the telescope. He said they were all cooperative, even though it was hard for them to accept that they had made an error. ``People find it very hard to say `oops,' '' he said. ``They instead say that we had good reasons for doing what we did, we had no reason to think it was wrong and so on. ... Everyone we talked to is finding it very hard to not be proud of what he did when he thought it was very good work.'' The team will return to Hughes Danbury on Sept. 12 and 13, Allen said.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Starts Investigating Reports of Buzzing
DOC.TEXT: Japanese officials today began investigating reports that U.S. jet fighters buzzed Japanese pleasure boats as imaginary targets during training flights. U.S. military officials said Navy aircraft were training in the area Wednesday where two yachts were buzzed by jet fighters. The U.S. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, would not give any further details about the incidents, in which a man was injured after a low-flying fighter buzzed his yacht. Japan's Maritime Safety Agency has received reports from local fishermen and boat captains of similar incidents occurring in the same area during the last two months, agency spokesman Naoki Maeda said. The presence of the U.S. armed forces in Japan under a mutual security pact is still a sensitive topic, and reports of accidents involving U.S. military personnel receive wide publicity. He quoted one person as saying that earlier this month two jets with U.S. military marks suddenly flew down very low as if they had been aiming at yachts near Oshima, an island 70 miles south of Tokyo. Japanese newspapers quoting U.S. military sources said the jets involved in Wednesday's incidents were FA-18 fighters attached to the aircraft carrier Midway. Kyodo News Service reported that Japanese officials believed the fighters were using the pleasure craft as imaginary enemy targets.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels To Urge U.N. Human Rights Observers In Salvadoran Peace Talks,
DOC.TEXT: Salvadoran rebel leaders say they will ask President Alfredo Cristiani to accept U.N. human rights observers as a condition for an immediate cease-fire in El Salvador's decade-old civil war. The proposal will be presented later today when the latest round of peace talks begins in San Jose, according to Miguel Saenz, a spokesman for the leftist Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front. ``If the Salvadoran government accepts that such a commission oversee observance of human rights in the country, then agreement could be reached for a cease-fire at this meeting,'' Saenz said Thursday. The five-day meeting, under U.N. mediation, is the fourth round of talks between the rebels and the government since Cristiani took office last year. The previous rounds ended in deadlock, with the government insisting the rebels enter into a cease-fire agreement before any other issues were discussed. Rebel leaders have demanded political reform, principally that the government purge the armed forces of rightist elements and bring human rights violators to justice. Saenz said that establishing a U.N. human rights commission in El Salvador would be an effective way of getting around the deadlock. Human rights groups say 73,000 people have died since El Salvador's civil war began in 1979 and nearly half were civilians slain by the military or rightist death squads for suspected leftist sympathies. Last November, six Jesuit priests were roused from their beds at night in their university campus home in San Salvador and shot dead by uniformed soldiers along with their housekeeper and her daughter. The assassinations took place at the height of a guerrilla assault on the Salvadoran capital, and while that section of the city was under military control and a dusk-to-dawn curfew. Meanwhile, in El Salvador, repair crews today were restoring power to large sections of the country blacked out by guerrilla sabotage earlier this week. Officials of the state-owned Lempa Executive Commission said the rebels attacked 17 main transmission lines, knocking out power to nearly half of the small Central American nation of 5 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Alleged Rape Victim With 21 Personalities Complicates Prosecution
LaserPhoto APP1 of Aug. 16
DOC.TEXT: A woman who says she has 21 personalities displayed three of them _ herself and characters named Franny and Jennifer _ in testifying she was raped by a man who took her out for coffee. The judge required her to take an oath each time she changed identities during the hearing Thursday. Lawyers introduced themselves to the different personalities. Each time, she behaved as if the testimony was just beginning. After hearing the testimony, Judge Robert Hawley ordered Mark A. Peterson, 29, to stand trial for sexual assault. No trial date was set. To convict Peterson, District Attorney Joseph Paulus said he must prove three things _ that the victim had a mental illness, that she was incapable of appraising her own conduct and that Peterson knew about the illness. Peterson claims the woman consented to sex and that he did not know she had multiple personalties. But the woman said she told Peterson she had multiple personalities and introduced him to some of them, and that he took advantage of one of them _ Jennifer, a fun-loving 20-year-old. That personality was dominant when Peterson forced her to have sex in the front seat of a car after they went out for coffee, the woman said. On Thursday, she also testified as herself, a 26-year-old single Oshkosh woman who is in therapy for multiple personality disorder and cannot remember the incident, and as Franny, a 32-year-old motherly type who reported the alleged attack to friends. According to Leonard Kaplan, a University of Wisconsin Law School professor, state law clearly says that someone deemed mentally ill cannot consent to sex. Defense lawyer Edward Salzsieder said the key issue is whether the woman is mentally ill or just a ``big show.'' During about 90 minutes of testimony, the woman paused only briefly during personality switches requested by Paulus. ``Can I have Jennifer, the one who likes to have fun?'' Paulus asked after talking with Franny. ``Of course,'' the woman replied, smiling and closing her eyes. Seconds later, she opened her eyes and blurted, ``Hi, Mr. Paulus'' in a slightly higher voice. The woman, her therapist seated nearby, testified that Peterson, a man she met two days earlier while fishing, raped her June 11. She testified Peterson wanted Jennifer to appear. She said he asked: ```Can I love you?' I said, `OK.''' Jennifer did not know what sex was but agreed because ``he just told me to,'' the woman said. Police said Peterson noted that during sex, the woman's 6-year-old personality, Emily, appeared before she eventually became Franny again. Inam Haque, a psychiatrist at Winnebago Mental Health Institute in Oshkosh, testified he treated the woman for four years and diagnosed her in February as suffering from multiple personality disorder. The disorder is triggered by emotional or physical abuse during childhood. Victims create separate personalities to avoid confronting reality. It affects about 7,000 Americans, he said.

DOC.HEAD: American Experts Search For Remains In Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: Vietnam has shown American military experts 70 sets of remains of what the Vietnamese believe could be missing U.S. soldiers, a U.S. official said today. The remains were shown to an American team that arrived Aug. 6 in the Vietnamese capital, Hanoi, to begin a joint search expedition, said Lt. Col. James Spurgeon. Spurgeon said he did not know if the Americans had made an assessment of the 70 remains. Spurgeon is the chief representative in Thailand of the Joint Casualty Resolution Center, a Hawaii-based military agency that accounts for America's wartime missing. Usually, remains suspected to be those of Americans are flown to Hawaii for analysis. Most remains recovered by the Vietnamese have not been those of Americans missing in action. The Pentagon lists 2,300 Americans as missing from the war that ended in 1975 with communist victories in Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia. About 70 percent are missing in Vietnam. The current search is the 11th joint search with Vietnamese workers. It began the same day the Americans and Vietnamese held, at the United Nations, their first talks on ending the war in Cambodia between guerrillas and the Vietnamese-installed government. The United States and Vietnam do not have diplomatic relations, and previous talks were limited to humanitarian issues such as the missing in action.

DOC.HEAD: Actors' Equity Says OK for White Actor to Play Part
Laserphoto NY8
DOC.TEXT: Actors' Equity bowed to pressure from within its ranks and agreed to let a white actor play a Eurasian pimp in the Broadway production of the hit London musical ``Miss Saigon.'' Now the question is whether the show will go on. Producer Cameron Mackintosh, who had scrapped the $10 million show after the union's initial ban on Jonathan Pryce, said Thursday he will confer with the English actor and the ``Miss Saigon'' creative team to determine whether it can still be brought to Broadway. A decision is not expected until next week, said Mackintosh spokesman Marc Thibodeau. ``Miss Saigon,'' which was to have begun previews here in March, already has $25 million in advance ticket sales, the largest in Broadway history. Mackintosh has said the cancellation would cost him about $600,000. Actors' Equity, which has a veto over foreign actors in the United States, had denied permission Aug. 7 for Pryce to repeat his London performance because casting a white actor in Asian makeup is ``an affront to the Asian community.'' The decision stirred fierce debate over color-blind casting, minority opportunities on stage and artistic freedom. Some complained it called into question the nature of acting itself _ pretending to be someone the actor is not. Equity reversed itself at a special meeting Thursday of its 70-member council, called in response to a petition from more than 600 Equity members outraged by the decision to bar the actor. The union has 37,500 active members. Alan Eisenberg, the union's executive secretary, said the council was influenced by a demonstration of good intent by the producer. Mackintosh had said that Pryce eliminated his slanted-eye makeup immediately after learning that it ``offended members of the American-Asian community.'' In addition, the union said it had a commitment from Mackintosh to seek out Asian actors for Broadway roles and to help give them voice training. In explaining the reversal, Eisenberg said the council, which met for nearly six hours, determined that Pryce qualified as a ``star.'' Stars from other countries usually get automatic approval to perform in the United States. Pryce has appeared on Broadway twice, winning a Tony in 1977 for his performance in ``Comedians'' and starring in ``Accidental Death of an Anarchist'' in 1984. Eisenberg said the controversy highlighted the need for the theater to address ``the frustrations felt over past and present discriminations and the lack of employment opportunities'' for minority actors. On Wednesday, Asian-Americans had urged Equity not to waver in its decision to bar Pryce. ``In an ideal world, any artist can play any role for which he or she is suited,'' said Tisa Chang, artistic director of the Pan Asian Repertory Theater. ``Until that time arrives, artists of color must fight to retain access to the few roles which are culturally and racially suited to them.'' Mackintosh has said the show has a cast of 50 actors, including roles for 34 minority performers. No other casting, except Pryce, has been announced. ``Miss Saigon'' is a love story about an American soldier during the closing days of the Vietnam War in 1975. Pryce won the Olivier Award, London's equivalent of the Tony, for his portrayal of the Engineer, a brothel owner, in ``Miss Saigon.''

DOC.HEAD: Village Cuts Out Smiling Symbol
DOC.TEXT: The ``Village With A Smile'' isn't anymore. Gone are the yellow, empty-eyed smiley faces that stared oncoming motorists in the face as they drove through this suburb west of Chicago. Some residents and city officials thought the symbol of happiness _ an image from the 1970s _ was behind the times. ``It was just a little out of fashion,'' said resident Donna Danielson. ``Sometimes people would make fun _ like co-workers.'' So she and her husband, Dan, offered to redesign the village's vehicle stickers and city limit signs. The new city symbol is now a leafy branch with a cardinal perched on top. ``You just can't say anymore `Hey, don't worry about it _ smile,' '' said Danielson, an advertisement designer in Chicago. ``I think there is a lot more depth to Forest Park than a smiley face.'' Smiley faces also have been falling from fashion graces outside Forest Park. A survey conducted last year by the Roper Organization at 10 U.S. college campuses found the ``Have-a-nice-day'' face was a fashion no-no. The loss of the smiles has been greeted with some frowns. ``I just thought it was unique,'' said Edward Lambke, who headed the effort to adopt the smiley face while serving as a village commissioner. ``They've changed the smiley. Never if I was there would that ever happen. I thought it was good for the town and I still do.'' Lambke, who coined Forest Park's nickname, ``A Village With A Smile,'' has since retired from village government but has left the vehicle stickers on his car. The smiley faces were painted on water towers at both ends of the town in 1974. In 1986, the smileys were adopted for the car stickers to give the village individuality in a sea of suburbs. Judging by some reactions to the new symbol, the village may be a happier place without the smiley faces. ``Some people would pick up their (new) sticker and say, `Oh my gosh, I'm glad you got rid of it,' '' said village clerk Marlene J. Quandt. ``I just think it had seen its day. ``But there are those who express a little sadness when they see the smiley face isn't here anymore.'' Forest Park has not entirely abandoned the smiley face, however. No one has dared contend with the giant saffron smiles on the water towers. The Danielsons say those faces might have to wait a few years until the towers need a new coat of paint.

DOC.HEAD: Six Law Officers Accused of Protecting Drug Smugglers
DOC.TEXT: Four sheriffs, a deputy sheriff and a police chief caught up in an FBI sting code-named Walking Short have been charged with setting up a protection racket for drug traffickers. Two FBI agents acting as Chicago businessmen interested in shipping cocaine led the yearlong sting, whose name was inspired by the 1973 movie ``Walking Tall,'' about a Tennessee sheriff who did not cave in to corruption around him. Forty FBI agents fanned out through four contiguous eastern Kentucky counties to make the arrests Thursday. The six were indicted on charges of conspiracy, drug distribution and taking money to protect drug traffickers. U.S. Attorney Louie DeFalaise said the arrests demonstrated ``the absolute corrupting influence of drugs.'' Arrested were Lee County Sheriff Johnny Mann, 39; Breathitt County Sheriff Dean Spencer, 46; Wolfe County Sheriff Lester Drake, 51; Owsley County Sheriff Billy McIntosh, 57; Beattyville Police Chief Omer Noe, and Wolfe County deputy Sheriff Wilson Stone. At a hearing Thursday, five of the men were released on bail ranging from $5,000 to $20,000. Mann, the alleged ringleader, was denied bail after an undercover agent testified he had threatened to kill anyone who set him up. According to the indictment, agents paid the law officers more than $85,000 to protect a phony cocaine and marijuana smuggling operation from police interference. At one point, cocaine packages were dropped by air onto a farm owned by one of the officers, authorities said. DeFalaise said the cocaine, which totaled nearly 250 pounds, was never distributed for sale to the public. Most of the drug counts carry up to life in prison. The major conspiracy and extortion charges carry up to 20 years.

DOC.HEAD: Musawi: Gulf Crisis Reduces Hopes For Freeing U.S. Hostages
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Shiite Moslem leader says the U.S. military intervention in Saudi Arabia ``leaves no chance'' for a quick release of any Americans held hostage in Lebanon. But Hussin Musawi, a reputed mentor of pro-Iranian kidnap factions in Lebanon, said Thursday that a Western European hostage might be freed soon. Musawi spoke hours after the leftist Beirut newspaper As-Safir said all 14 Western hostages held in Lebanon, including six Americans, will be freed by year's end. ``I think there is a demarcation line between American and European hostages,'' Musawi said in a telephone interview from his home in Baalbek. ``I think the American occupation of Saudi Arabia leaves no chance for an early release of the American captives. But there is a chance the case of the European hostages might shortly ease up.'' Musawi leads a pro-Syrian wing in the fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, Iran's main ally in Lebanon. Hezbollah is believed the umbrella for several hostage-holding factions. He said the outlook for the European captives was brighter because France has taken an independent stance from the United States in the gulf crisis. French President Francois Mitterrand's decision to release Anis Naccache, a Lebanese serving life for trying to assassinate former Iranian Prime Minister Shahpour Bakhtiar in Paris in 1980, was a contributing factor, Musawi said. All French hostages have been freed. Four Britons, two West Germans, an Italian and an Irishman, as well as six Americans, are held by extremist Moslem groups in Lebanon. Most have been held three years or more. The longest held, since March 16, 1985, is Terry Anderson, the AP's chief Middle East correspondent. As-Safir quoted unidentified diplomatic sources as saying ``secret contacts . . . involving the concerned capitals, particularly Tehran,'' were under way to resolve the hostage issue. The hostage-takers have made various demands for the release of prisoners held by Israel in southern Lebanon and of convicted terrorists jailed in Kuwait and Western capitals. Since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, which set off the crisis, no firm word has emerged on the fate of 15 Shiite prisoners whose release was demanded by kidnappers in return for American hostages. Most were serving long prison terms and three were awaiting execution for involvement in 1983 bombings the U.S. and French embassies and Kuwaiti installations. Some reports said the prisoners escaped after the invasion, others said they were killed and some suggested they were moved to Baghdad, Iraq's capital.

DOC.HEAD: Homicide Leading On-The-Job Killer of Women
DOC.TEXT: The leading killer of American women in the workplace isn't crashes or fire. It's homicide. The Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday that 42 percent of the on-the-job injury deaths of women in the United States from 1980 to 1985 were homicides. Second was vehicle accidents, at around 39 percent, said Catherine Bell, an epidemiologist with the CDC's National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health. ``If a woman's going to die from an injury at work, she's probably going to be murdered,'' Ms. Bell said. NIOSH investigators identified 950 female occupational homicides over the six-year period. Of that number, 389 _ or 41 percent _ worked in the retail field. Researchers aren't certain, but it appears that strangers in the store _ not co-workers _ are responsible for most workplace killings of women, Ms. Bell said. ``They appear to be robbery-associated crimes in the retail trade,'' she said. ``It quite likely is stranger violence.'' The killings peaked in the winter months. Sixty-four percent of the killings were committed with guns; 19 percent were stabbings. Nationwide, for both sexes, about 13 percent of on-the-job injury deaths during 1980-85 were homicides, the CDC reported. Homicides accounted for 12 percent of men's occupational fatalities, compared with the 42 percent for women. Findings regarding killings of men in the workplace are not complete. But most on-the-job deaths involve male workers _ who traditionally dominate more dangerous occupations _ and most of those male workplace deaths are accidental. The CDC did not release figures for causes of workplace injury deaths among women other than homicides and vehicular accidents. Measures such as better lighting, safer cash-handling and even bulletproof barricades should be considered to help stop slayings at work, the agency said. The workplace homicide rate for black women was nearly double that for white women, but that was not necessarily unexpected; nationwide, black women are nearly four times as likely to be murdered as white women, the CDC said, citing a 1986 study.

DOC.HEAD: Human Rights Interns Learn to Be Skeptical of U.S. Immigration Practices
DOC.TEXT: Eleven U.S. students have spent the summer near the Mexican border listening to horror stories and trying to give them happy endings. They weren't studying fiction _ they're trainee human rights activists. The students from colleges across the nation served as interns for Amnesty International. For 10 weeks, they worked on behalf of asylum-seekers who claim to be fleeing harassment, torture and death squads from Haiti to El Salvador. In the process, they became skeptical of their own government. ``Everything is really interconnected,'' said Amy Voege, a 23-year-old junior at Central Michigan University in Mount Pleasant, Mich. ``The people who are fleeing their countries are fleeing because of human rights abuses there, or fleeing because of war there,'' she said. ``But those human rights abuses and those wars are really supported by the United States government.'' They will take back memories of those they helped. Among them was a Honduran soldier who said he was beaten for refusing to torture prisoners, and a Guatemalan who said he fled after seeing soldiers shoot to death his cousin. Amnesty International said its ``Asylum Summer'' program tries to help asylum-seekers from being deported and becoming abuse victims. Critics, including some within the nearly 1 million-strong movement, worry that the group is departing too much from its traditional role of campaigning for people unlawfully imprisoned, tortured or facing the death penalty. The students, ages 18 to 23, trained in southern Texas with human rights organizations and helped prepare legal cases. In one case, a 17-year-old Salvadoran army deserter won asylum with help from students assigned to ProBAR, a legal aid office in Harlingen. Melissa Jameson, 19, a sophomore at the University of Redlands in Redlands, Calif., said the man was forcibly recruited, then ``made to torture and kill animals for training. They had to bite the necks of vultures and dogs.'' ``Then the trainers cut off the arm of a human body and played with it like a toy,'' Jameson said. ``They said this will make you more of a man, and when he cried they said you're going to have to get used to this.'' The man, whom she did not identify, claimed he would be tortured or killed by government forces or harassed by guerrillas if sent back. In another case, asylum was denied to a Honduran who said he was forcibly recruited into the army at 14 and was beaten and tortured when he refused to torture prisoners. The youth, who is appealing the denial of asylum, also said he feared being tortured if returned home. ``We had won an asylum case for a Honduran young man who had faced pretty much the same thing,'' said Mercedeh Momeni, 22, of Fredericksburg, Va. ``It just shows how arbitrary the system is, and how Amnesty is on the right track in this program.'' The interns complained that U.S. governments helped create the conditions that force people to flee Central America, and that those fleeing unfriendly countries seem to have a better chance of winning asylum than refugees from allied nations. The Immigration and Naturalization Service said each asylum case is treated on merit, without political bias. ``Isn't it logical that the United States would have better relations with countries that do not practice human rights abuses, than with countries that do?'' asked INS spokesman Duke Austin. ``To argue that there's no difference between Nicaragua, El Salvador, Cuba and Haiti is asinine. That's naivete in its highest form.'' The Border Association for Refugees from Central America in McAllen had three students assigned to its office. ``It's extremely important for young people in the United States to become more involved in justice-related issues,'' said executive director Ninfa Krueger. The students said they plan to step up their human rights activities in their schools. But, said Paula Couture, 21, a junior at Worcester State College at Worcester, Mass., ``People aren't going to understand us when we get back.''

DOC.HEAD: Pilots Used Credit Cards to De-ice Plane
DOC.TEXT: Crew members of a commuter plane that crashed last year, killing six people, used credit cards to scrape ice from the wings and propellers and declined de-icing equipment at least twice, investigators say. The report by the National Transportation Safety Board contained no conclusions about the cause of the Dec. 26 crash, said author Eric Sager of the NTSB in Washington. ``It's one small part of the investigation,'' Sager said Thursday in a telephone interview. ``That information may or may not end up in the report.'' A final report will be issued in several weeks. The United Express plane, en route from Seattle by way of Yakima, crashed about 400 feet short of the runway at Pasco, about 80 miles south of Yakima. Everyone aboard was killed. Ice can slow an airplane or force it down by increasing weight and drag. Sager said he did not think it unusual that the co-pilot and another United Express employee would be using credit cards to remove ice from the 19-passenger British Aerospace Jetstream 31 turboprop during the stop in Yakima. ``Ice is very frequent,'' Sager said. ``They were attending to it.'' The employees were looking at the wings and presumbably felt the buildup was not enough to warrant the use of de-icing equipment, Sager said. However, a United Express ramp agent in Yakima told investigators that she was surprised the captain had chosen not to de-ice. She said most other planes were undergoing the five-minute procedure that night because it was misting and cold. ``She noticed that chips of ice were blown back toward her in the propeller wash'' as the plane departed, the report said. Shelley Swanke, a United Express spokeswoman in Pasco, said company policy gives pilots the authority to decide when to use de-icing equipment. The report found no medical problems among the crew that might have contributed to the crash, and no traces of drugs or alcohol. United Express is a franchise name used by several airlines around the country with ties to United Air Lines. The commuter airline is owned by NPA Inc. of Fresno, Calif.

Victor Tsoi, lead singer of the popular Soviet group Kino, was killed in a car crash Thursday. His age was not immediately known. Kino, a hard-rock quartet whose name means ``cinema'' in Russian, first became popular in 1987 as an underground group that was not allowed to record by the authorities. Kino later received permission to record, and Tsoi became an idol for many Soviet young people. He recently participated in a series of successful concerts in Moscow and planned to release a new album and star in a film. In 1987, songs by Kino and three other popular Soviet groups _ Aquarium, Alisa and Strange Games _ were issued in the United States on a double album titled ``Red Wave.''

Mort Neff, host for 23 years of a hunting show on television called ``Michigan Outdoors,'' died Wednesday at age 86. Neff suffered a stroke Aug. 5 and died at Northern Michigan Hospitals in Petoskey. Neff began his broadcast career in 1942 with a weekly radio show for the Department of Conservation. In 1951, he was the last-minute replacement for the host of a new TV show on the outdoors. Neff, hired for two weeks, stayed at ``Michigan Outdoors'' until his retirement.

Norma Hendricks, a columnist and former mayor, died Wednesday at age 79 after a battle with emphysema. Ms. Hendricks was a reporter for the Daily Commercial in Leesburg and The Orlando Sentinel and also worked in radio. In 1962, she was elected the first woman on the City Commission. As mayor pro tem, she became the city's first woman mayor in 1965 when the mayor died in an accident. She lost her bid for election. In 1974, she returned to the Commercial and became a columnist.

Dr. John M. Walker, a surgeon and uncle of President Bush, died Thursday at age 81. The cause of death was not disclosed. Walker, the brother of Bush's 89-year-old mother, Dorothy Walker Bush, served on the staff at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York City from 1952 to 1959.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Restores Citizenship of Solzhenitsyn, 22 Others
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has apologized for two decades of political repression and restored the citizenship of 23 literary, scientific and cultural figures, including Alexander Solzhenitsyn, officials have said. The full list of those deprived of citizenship between 1966-88 and regaining it under the presidential decree will be published later this month, said Valentin Kulikov, a representative of Gorbachev's press office. The Soviet Media on Thursday published the names of 10 people whose citizenship was returned, including Solzhenitsyn, the Nobel laureate charged with treason in 1974. They included chess champion Victor Korchnoi; writers Vasily Aksyonov, Vladimir Voinovich, Lev Kopelev, Georgi Vladimov, and Valeri Tarsis, who died in exile in 1983; scientists Yuri Orlov and Valeri Chalidze; and artist Oskar Rabin. The names of the other 13 were not included in Wednesday's presidential decreee. There had been speculation the list would include Joseph Brodsky, a Nobel Prize-winning writer who emigrated to the United States in 1972 under threat of imprisonment for his political comments. ``These political repressions were justifiably condemned in this country and I believe it is now our duty to, if you please, absolve the (government's) guilt before our countrymen,'' said Gennady Cheremnykh, head of the citizenship and pardoning department of the Supreme Soviet's secretariat. ``The decree is a conveyance of apologies of sorts. Although it is belated, it is an apology,'' he said in an interview with the government daily Izvestia. Cheremnykh said 175 Soviets were stripped of their citizenship from 1966-88. About 60 of them are Armenians who emigrated to the United States and Canada. The rest are dissidents, he said. Under Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Kremlin revoked the citizenship of prominent authors and artists who spoke out against repression. Their work was barred from appearing in their homeland. Gorbachev continued the practice during his first three years in office, but then abandoned it. In individual decrees, Gorbachev has already restored the citizenship of many, notably cellist and conductor Mstislav Rostropovich and his wife, singer Galina Vishnevskaya; dissident historian Zhores Medvedev; and theater director Yuri Lyubimov. Of these, only Lyubimov has returned to live in the Soviet Union. No conditions were put on the citizens identified Thursday, Cheremnykh told Izvestia. It was not immediately clear how many would return. Cheremnykh said Solzhenitsyn, who lives with his wife Natalia in Cavendish, Vermont, had agreed to accept Soviet citizenship, but the writer's wife, denied that. ``Nobody has asked him _ absolutely nobody in any form has contacted us, not through writing, not through mediation,'' she said Thursday in an interview from their home. Solzhenitsyn, 71, has said he would not return unless all of his books were published in the Soviet Union and widely available. A number have been printed, but almost nothing is widely available in the shortage-plagued Soviet Union. Mrs. Solzhenitsyn said that a Soviet court charged her husband with treason and only a court can lift the charges. Anything else is ``wielding the same power as Brezhnev did,'' she said, adding that the expulsion order also must be reversed. Solzhenitsyn's ``The Gulag Archipelago'' depicted the horrors of Stalin's prison camps. His other well-known works include ``One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich,'' ``Cancer Ward,'' ``August 1914'' and ``The First Circle.'' He won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1970, but in February 1974 was arrested on a treason charge, which carried a possible death sentence. He was forced onto a plane to Germany and stripped of his citizenship the next day. Korchnoi, 54, said in an interview in Switzerland he welcomed the restoration of his citizenship as an ``important step,'' but the grandmaster said he would not return to the Soviet Union. Aksyonov, contacted about Gorbachev's decree by the Soviet Embassy, said from his home in Washington, it was ``the last hindrance to being accepted officially in Soviet cultural life. I accept it as a formal apology from the government.'' He said, however, he would not return to the Soviet Union to live. Chalidze, 51, said he was not sure if he would accept the invitation to be a Soviet citizen again. The decree is ``a correcting of unjust things that were done in the past,'' he said from his home in Benson, Vermont, but said: ``I am an American citizen and about this I am quite happy.'' Political exiles and Soviets who emigrate to Israel are automatically stripped of their citizenship. Cheremnykh said most of 400,000 Soviets in this category had left the country voluntarily and indicated there was no chance their citizenship would be restored.

DOC.HEAD: A Look at Former Soviet Citizens Whose Citizenship Is Restored
With PM-Soviet-Solzhenitsyn
DOC.TEXT: Following is a look at 10 of 23 Soviets whose citizenship has been restored by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The names of the 13 others affected by the decree were not announced. _Alexander Solzhenitsyn, 71, author of ``The Gulag Archipelago,'' a searing expose of the horrors of dictator Josef Stalin's prison camps. The winner of the Nobel Prize for literature in 1970, he was charged with treason in 1974, stripped of his citizenship and expelled. He was constantly harassed by the KGB secret police and finally was forced onto a plane to Germany and stripped of his citizenship the next day. ``The Gulag Archipelago'' was published in the Soviet Union last year. Other works include ``One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich,'' ``Cancer Ward,'' ``The First Circle'' and ``August 1914,'' a narrative of Russian life and the nation's stark unpreparedness for the military offensive launched against Germany in that year. _Valeri Chalidze, 51, a founding member of the Human Rights Committee whose citizenship was revoked while he was on a tour of the United States in 1972. He wrote, ``To Defend These Rights, about Human Rights,'' and now runs an emigre publishing house in Vermont. _Lev Kopelev, Solzhenitsyn's prison friend and a scholar of German literature who left the Soviet Union in November 1980 with his wife, Raisa Orlova. Both lost their citizenship in 1981 and moved to West Germany, where Kopelev lives. His wife died last year. Kopelev's writings include, ``To be Preserved Forever,'' a restrospective about the Soviet Union, and ``We Lived in Moscow.'' _Vladimir Voinovich, a satirist who emigrated to West Germany in 1980 after being expelled from the Soviet Writers' Union in 1974. He was expelled after the publication abroad of his World War II novel, ``The Adventures of Private Ivan Chonkin.'' Other works include, ``The Ivankiad,'' about an attempt to get an extra room in a Moscow apartment, ``Moscow 2042,'' a projection of the future, and ``The Fur Hat,'' a satire on privilege in Soviet society. He was invited back to the Soviet Union last year for a visit. _Victor Korchnoi, 54, one of the Soviet Union's leading chess players who defected in 1976 in the Netherlands. His matches against the official Soviet champion, Anatoly Karpov, became famous as duels on political, psychological and physical levels. He was twice an unsuccessful challenger of Karpov as titleholder in the World Championship finals and now ranks 12th worldwide. _Georgi Vladimov, 59, one of the leading writers of the magazine Yunost during the 1960s, he came into conflict with Soviet authorities over foreign publication of his works. One work is ``Faithful Ruslan,'' a short novel told through the eyes of a guard dog in a prison camp. _Yuri Orlov, a prominent member of the dissident movement, he was one of the founders of the Helsinki Monitoring Group in Moscow. Arrested and exiled for his human rights work, he was allowed to leave for the United States after the Soviets released American journalist Nick Daniloff. _Oskar Rabin, was one of the organizers of a non-conformist art exhibit in Moscow that was bulldozed in 1974. He was later forced to emigrate. _Vasily Aksyonov, author of the 1960 bestseller ``Kollegi,'' was criticized by Soviet authorities for his ``bad language,'' which actually was the slang of Soviet youth. He emigrated after a brush with the authorities in 1980. Other works include ``The Burn,'' about a young boy who grew up in Moscow and in Stalin's labor camps, the satirical novel ``The Island of Crimea,'' and ``In Search of Melancholy Baby,'' about his emigre life. He made his first trip back to the Soviet Union last year and plans another when his play ``Heron'' is produced in Moscow next year. _Valeri Tarsis, who was awarded citizenship posthumously, was a correspondent during World War II and a short-story writer. He demanded permission to emigrate in 1961, was detained in a psychiatric hospital under Nikita S. Khrushchev, and expelled from the Soviet Union in the late 1960s. He died in Switzerland in 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Deposed Military Ruler Begins Electoral Campaign for Presidency
DOC.TEXT: Retired Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, who took power after a 1982 military coup but was overthrown a year later, has signed up as a presidential candidate in a November election. His action Thursday conflicts with Supreme Court and congressional rulings that he is ineligible to run because of the military coup. Rios Montt, a born-again Christian who as military ruler sent more than a dozen convicted leftists before the firing squads, is campaigning as a law-and-order candidate. Human rights workers and others are worried that Rios Montt's eye-for-an-eye brand of justice will lead to further human rights abuses in a country already plagued with them. Polls show him among the leading contenders to replace President Vinicio Cerezo. Rios Montt took power after the coup ousted Gen. Romeo Lucas Garcia on March 23, 1982. Rios Montt, in turn, was removed by Gen. Oscar Humberto Mejia Victores on Aug. 8, 1983. The Supreme Court, in a non-binding opinion sought by Congress last year, said Rios Montt cannot be president or vice president because of a constitutional ban on the holding of those posts by people who assumed power in a coup. Last month, the Association of National Dignitaries, made up of people who drew up the current constitution, arrived at the same conclusion. Rios Montt is running with the backing of three of Guatemala's 19 registered parties. Nine candidates have signed up for the presidency, including Jorge Carpio Nicolle, a journalist defeated five years ago by Cerezo. There will be a runoff on Jan. 6 if no candidate wins a majority in the Nov. 11 election. If Guatemala's elections registry refuses to accept his candidacy, Rios Montt can appeal through the court system.

DOC.HEAD: Dominican President Defends Measures that Sparked Riots
DOC.TEXT: Setting out on his sixth term in office, President Joaquin Balaguer has asked Dominicans to cooperate with an austerity plan that touched off deadly protests this week. Balaguer, 83 and blind from glaucoma, defended his austerity plan during the ceremony Thursday. ``As I assume another term, I am obligated not to make promises, but to point out the changes that are needed to make the government work,'' the conservative president said in his inaugural address. The nationwide strike Monday and Tuesday brought this Caribbean nation of 7 million people to a near-standstill. Clashes between protesters and security forces left at least 11 dead and 50 wounded. Police arrested 2,000 protesters. Balaguer narrowly defeated his longtime leftist rival, Juan Bosch, in an election May 16. Bosch, 81, who accused Balaguer of widespread voter fraud, did not attend the inauguration. Nine major unions organized the 48-hour strike this week to protest against sharply higher consumer prices caused by the government last week. The austerity program is intended to bolster the country's ailing economy. Under the program recommended by the International Monetary Fund, the government cut subsidies and sharply increased prices for basic goods such as gasoline, flour and sugar. The government estimates the annual inflation rate at 50 percent, but some officials privately say it is about 70 percent. In his speech, Balaguer did not mention the protests specifically but said his economic policies were intended ``to improve the quality of life of the poor'' and ``to diminish or completely eliminate inflation.'' ``I ask for help and cooperation from all men and women of good will in this country because the task we will have in the next four years will be arduous,'' he said. Balaguer is beginning his second consecutive four-year term and his sixth over the past 30 years. He is founder and leader of conservative Social Christian Reformist Party. The president is also a lawyer and author of about 20 books. In his last term, Balaguer embarked on an ambitious $2 billion public works program that has been mostly financed by printing money. The construction project _ much of it timed for completion in 1992 to coincide with the 500th anniversary of Columbus' discovery of America _ created hundreds of jobs but worsened inflation.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Mr. President, aren't you sad as you boast about democracy that your allies are the retarded, thieves and liars among the Arabs, while the believers, the warriors and the elite be on the opposite side? But despite all that, we will continue to pray, and pray hard, that there will be no confrontation by which you will receive thousands of Americans wrapped in sad coffins after you had pushed them into a dark tunnel.'' _ President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, in an open letter to President Bush.

``The siege is winding down, but it's definitely not over. We still have a lot of firefighters on the lines and a lot of mop-up to do.'' _ California Department of Forestry spokeswoman Karen Terrill on the 1,300 forest fires that have broken out in the state since Aug. 3.

``The people who are fleeing their countries are fleeing because of human rights abuses there, or fleeing because of war there. ... But those human rights abuses and those wars are really supported by the United States government.'' _ Amy Voege, a 23-year-old student enrolled in a program in Harlingen, Texas, sponsored by Amnesty International to help asylum-seekers from being deported.

DOC.HEAD: Tens of Thousands Pay Tribute to Fallen Dictator
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of Pakistanis, reeling from 20 turbulent months of democracy, streamed today to the grave of Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq's to pay tribute to the fallen dictator on the second anniversary of his death. Mourners traveled by foot, cart and bus to the giant Faisal Mosque to offer prayers for Zia, who died Aug. 17, 1988, in a mysterious plane crash. All 37 people aboard, including several top generals and U.S. Ambassador Arnold Raphel, were killed. Zia's son, Ijaz ul-Haq, placed wreaths at the graves of the other generals today and then led a huge procession to the Faisal Mosque from the neighboring city of Rawalpindi, the headquarters of the army that has ruled Pakistan for more than half of its 43-year history. Mourners planned to offer prayers for Zia later today to mark the time his plane crashed in a desert in eastern Punjab province. Ijaz was to offer a tribute, using the occasion to launch his own political career. Zia's death anniversary comes less than two weeks after former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's government was dismissed on charges of corruption, nepotism and ineptitude. Ms. Bhutto, whose father was overthrown by Zia in 1977, claims a similar coup was staged against her but camouflaged by the constitution. Her father, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, was hanged in 1979 on charges of conspiring the murder a political enemy who was never killed. She blames Zia. While in power Ms. Bhutto proclaimed her father a martyr for democracy. Ijaz says his father was a martyr for Islam. Six-foot posters of the former military ruler line the wide boulevards of the capital. Giant banners proclaiming Zia a martyr flutter in the warm summer breeze. With the future of democracy uncertain, many Pakistanis are fondly remembering Zia as a humble, compassionate man and reminiscing about military rule. Hundreds of people make the pilgrimage to Zia's grave daily. Ijaz, a 38-year-old banker on the verge of running for office, insists that his father was a good model for a candidate. ``Benazir Bhutto's father was a civilian dictator and she came to power. Why can't the son of Zia ul-Haq?'' asked Ijaz. Elections are scheduled for Oct. 24, but speculation is rife that they will be postponed and that another round of military rule is inevitable. A four-foot framed picture of the former dictator dominates Ijaz's living room. Propped up at its side is a smaller picture of Zia, one hand on his heart, in front of the White House with former President Reagan, striking a similar pose. Zia's Hercules C-130 had been in the air less than five minutes when it weaved out of control and nosedived into the ground, according to witnesses. A technical report charged sabotage, but a criminal investigation was never pursued. Ms. Bhutto's government made a weak attempt at probing the crash and the U.S. government waited a year before sending investigators. Ijaz blames Al-Zulfikar, a group led by Ms. Bhutto's brother, Murtaza. It hijacked a plane in the mid-1980s, and Zia had said they were behind several failed assassination attempts. Ijaz also claims President Ghulam Ishaq Khan, the army and the United States staged a coverup.

DOC.HEAD: Aquino Murder Trial Ends But Still No Verdict
DOC.TEXT: The trial of 40 soldiers and civilians accused in the 1983 murder of President Corazon Aquino's husband ended today, but a verdict could take another year, a court official said. Former Sen. Benigno Aquino was assassinated Aug. 21, 1983 as he stepped from a plane at the Manila airport. He was returning from self-imposed exile in the United States to lead the opposition against the late President Ferdinand Marcos. Marcos alleged that Aquino was killed by a Communist assassin, Rolando Galman, who soldiers shot dead on the tarmac. Prosecutors argued Galman was part of a military conspiracy and that a soldier actually killed Aquino. Prosecutors today asked the court to render a guilty verdict ``with the qualifying circumstances of evident premeditation and treachery'' and taking advantage of their government positions. Aquino's slaying sparked massive protests that swept his widow to the presidency in February 1986 after a ``People Power'' revolt ousted Marcos and drove him to exile in the United States. Marcos died in Hawaii in September 1989. Under Mrs. Aquino's administration, the Supreme Court overturned a December 1985 acquittal of former Chief of Staff Fabian Ver, 24 soldiers and one civilian after the court found evidence that Marcos engineered the decision. Ver fled the country during the 1986 uprising. In April 1987, government prosecutors indicted 40 people for the murder of Aquino and Galman. The case was filed with the Sandiganbayan court, which tries state employees charged with civil and criminal suits. The 40 included Ver, two generals, 33 soldiers and four civilians, including former Tourism Minister Jose Aspiras, now a member of the House of Representatives, who was an alleged accomplice. Also charged as accomplices were former information minister Gregorio Cendana and former air and former transport minister Jesus Singson. The 3{-year-long trial culminated today after defense lawyers and prosecutors submitted summaries of their arguments to the three-member court. Clerk of Court Dolores Balajadia said that under Philippine law, the panel of judges has up to one year to make a final ruling. There are no juries in the Philippines, where a verdict is the responsibility of judges. During the trial, the court saw photographs, tape recordings and video footage of the seconds before and after Aquino slumped dead on the tarmac with a single bullet wound in the back of the head. It also heard the testimony of 51 defense and 79 prosecution witnesses, including four who claimed they saw a soldier kill Aquino.

DOC.HEAD: FCC Investigating News Broadcast of Mapplethorpe Photos
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Communications Commission is investigating complaints against a public TV station for showing some of Robert Mapplethorpe's most sexually explicit photos. WGBH showed the pictures in a 10 p.m. news broadcast July 31, the day before the opening here of an exhibit of the late artist's work, which includes homosexual and sadomasochistic images and child nudes. The FCC has not decided whether to take any action against the station, said Roger Holberg, an FCC attorney. The traveling exhibit, now on display at the Institute of Contemporary Art, has generated a storm of protests since it became a focus of Sen. Jesse Helms' crusade against federal funding of art deemed indecent. Later, the director of a Cincinnati gallery that exhibited the photographs was arrested on obscenity charges. He is awaiting trial. Leading the list of three complaints to the FCC was one by the Rev. Donald Wildmon, head of the American Family Association in Tupelo, Miss. A letter from Wildmon, a longtime critic of alleged indeceny in media, described the broadcast as ``nothing more than the sensational presentation of potentially obscene material.'' Eric Brass, attorney for WGBH, defended the broadcast. ``It just is not obscene,'' Brass said Thursday. ``I believe we have the right to do what we did in the context of a serious news program. We cannot be in the position of censoring debate about censorship.'' If material is judged to be obscene, it can be banned from being broadcast, Holberg said. But material deemed to be indecent is given more leeway as long as it is not shown before 8 p.m., when children are more likely to be watching. Congress told the agency last year to restrict broadcasting of indecent material 24 hours a day. The new rule was challenged by broadcasters and other groups, and a federal appeals court in Washington is studying whether it can be enforced. Mapplethorpe put together the exhibit shortly before he died of AIDS last year at age 42. The 124 photographs are mainly portraits and pictures of flowers, but about a quarter of them are sexually graphic. ``We wanted to let the public know what the controversy was about and let them decide for themselves,'' said Julie Eggleston, a spokeswoman for the TV station. WGBH, as a part of the Public Broadcasting Service, receives federal funds.

DOC.HEAD: Tux Tussle Has Towns at Odds
DOC.TEXT: A century after the Prince of Wales' tailor invented the tail-less dinner jacket, Saratoga Springs and Tuxedo Park are rolling up the sleeves of their pleated-front shirts over which town introduced the tux to America. Ed Hotaling, a part-time columnist for The Saratogian, stirred things up by suggesting that tuxedos be renamed ``saratogas.'' He contends the English creation made its debut in his summer resort hometown in upstate New York in the late 1880s. The exclusive community of Tuxedo Park, 40 miles northwest of New York City, says the origin is in its name. Tuxedo Park Mayor Cornelius J.J. Madera Jr. said Hotaling's claim, like Saratoga's famous racetrack, smells of horses. ``They're spending too much time in the barns,'' he said. Hotaling, who began his campaign nine months ago, wrote Wednesday of a day when ``all waiters will look down at you in their saratogas. Invitations to parties will note the required men's wear in tiny letters: `saratoga.' '' Hotaling claimed the semiformal evening jacket was first worn to a ball in Saratoga Springs' Grand Union Hotel by local playboy E. Berry Wall. He cites as his source the social historian George Waller, author of ``Saratoga: Saga of an Impious Era.'' But Tuxedo Park historian Albert F. Winslow said a more likely story is that one of Tuxedo Park's founders, James Brown Potter, brought the tuxedo back from England. The jacket was later picked up by Griswold Lorillard, son of one of the founders of Tuxedo Park, who wore a formal jacket with the tails cut off to a ball in 1886, Winslow said. ``You get a couple of department stores selling saratogas _ you'll get a change,'' growled Hotaling, who is also a producer for ABC News in Washington. But it's unlikely the dinner jacket will undergo a name change anytime soon. ``I just couldn't imagine it happening when a name's so entrenched in people's minds,'' said Nick Valentine, owner of Broadway Tailors in Newburgh. ``If you say tuxedo, you mean formal wear.''

DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices Plunge, Dollar Slumps
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to wrap up with comment; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Tokyo stock prices plunged today as hopes diminished for a swift settlement of the Middle East crisis, while the dollar drifted lower against the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average fell 762.72 points, or 2.77 percent, to 26,786.72 points by the close of the week's trading. Estimated volume was 300 million shares. Traders said many investors were disappointed with the outcome of the meeting between President Bush and Jordan's King Hussein at Bush's summer retreat in Kennebunkport, Maine. Optimism swept the market Wednesday on rumors that Hussein was carrying a letter containing a peace proposal from Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein, boosting the Nikkei average over 1,400 points. Iraq invaded its oil-rich neighbor Kuwait on Aug. 2. Iraq continues to control the territory, while the United States and other countries have begun ferrying troops to Saudi Arabia to guard against an Iraqi takeover of the world's largest oil reserves. Tokyo markets at first followed New York's downward trend in overnight trading. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks fell 66.83 to 2,681.44, its lowest close since the crisis began. Traders said that uncertainty over how events in the Middle East might change over the weekend depressed trading, and arbitrage traders were active in the falling market. Cheaper bonds also played a role, according to Kazuhiro Nomura, of the New Japan Securities Co. Brent Crude for October delivery continued to climb, meanwhile. It was valued at about $26.10-$26.20 a barrel in Tokyo this afternoon, up from the previous evenings price in New York of $26.00-$26.05 a barrel. In currency trading, the dollar closed at 147.35 yen. Trading moved between a low of 147.35 yen and a high of 148.10 yen. With the United States facing long-term economic problems, and Japan's economy relatively stronger in the short term, traders predicted that the dollar would remain in the 147-148 yen range. Although the dollar normally gains strength in times of crisis, the structural weaknesses of the U.S. economy have overwhelmed the dollar, traders said. ``The yen has strengthened a little,'' said Robert A. Feldman of Solomon Brothers Asia. On the bond market, the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed at 8.050 percent, up from Thursday's close of 7.985 percent. Its price fell to 83.24 points from 83.52 points the previous day.

DOC.HEAD: Businessman Who Escaped Iraq Wants to Help Those Still There
DOC.TEXT: Businessman Michael Saba was lucky enough to flee Iraq after it invaded Kuwait. Now he wants to help Americans trapped there and their worried families in the United States. Saba, who took a taxi from Baghdad to the Jordanian border on Aug. 8, formed the Coming Home Committee to gather information, raise money and prepare emergency transportation to get other Americans out of the Middle East. By Thursday, after appearances on TV talk shows, Saba said he had heard from about 50 people who escaped the region and from a similar number of frantic family members. ``A lot of them I'm talking to, if not hysterical, are close to it,'' said Saba, president of GulfAmerica International Business Services. When he got out of Iraq, Saba brought news to the families of 11 oil workers he spoke with that they were all right. Now he's gathering information on Americans in the Persian Gulf for a computer record, overseeing preliminary exit arrangements and organizing hoped-for charter air service and ground vehicles to reunite families faster. ``There have been windows of opportunity to leave,'' he said. ``If they open again, we better be ready to get them out.'' Saba also has served as a sounding board and shoulder to cry on for anxious relatives. ``I'm desperate,'' said Anna Morel of Waukegan. ``I'll go to any source I think can help,'' Mrs. Morel's daughter, Faith Abedin, was working in Kuwait as an English teacher when Iraq invaded early this month. She lost contact after the invasion. ``Michael Saba knows the people, the culture, the traditions. He's probably more in tune with them than anybody in Washington,'' said Mrs. Morel, who talked with Saba after seeing him on television. She said that Saba assured her the Iraqi soldiers ``are not as bad as we've heard,'' and that he took information about her daughter, son-in-law, and their two children, ages 4 and 5. Saba, whose company promotes trade between the U.S. and Arab nations, said he worries that an outbreak of fighting might prevent trapped Americans from getting out. ``To put the value of a barrel of oil over a human life is frightening,'' said Saba. ``Let's re-orient people on what our real values should be.'' Mrs. Morel had similar fears. ``Our government is caught up in a big showdown and I'm afraid our people will be caught in the cross-fire, sacrificed,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: State Wins $86,000 Claimed by Elvis Estate
DOC.TEXT: The state coffers are $86,000 richer thanks to a concert Elvis Presley never gave. As an estimated 8,000 fans attended a candlelight vigil in Memphis, Tenn., to mark Presley's death 13 years ago Thursday, a New York judge ruled that Presley's estate could not claim proceeds from a concert he was due to perform at the Nassau County Coliseum on Long Island on Aug. 22, 1977.
