Presley died six days earlier. While refunds were offered, many Presley fans held on to their tickets, leaving $86,000 in limbo. State Supreme Court Justice Eli Wager ruled that unclaimed proceeds of the concert belonged to the state, said Leslie Gersing, a spokeswoman for the state attorney general's office. The money, she said, will go into the state's Abandoned Property Fund. Anyone who decides now that they want a refund can get it through the fund, Gersing said. Presley died at Graceland, mansion in Memphis, at age 42. A medical examiner listed the cause of death as heart disease, but court testimony revealed Presley was addicted to prescription drugs.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Along Carolina Coast; Foggy in East
By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Showers and thunderstorms drenched the Carolina coastline early today before giving way to fog that shrouded much of the East Coast. Thunderstorms developed early today over central Iowa and west-central Montana. There were thunderstorms overnight in southwestern Idaho and central Wyoming. Rain also fell in southern Oregon. Thunderstorms were reported in Charleston, S.C., and rain fell along Cape Hatteras in North Carolina. The nighttime downpours were followed by early morning fog that blanketed large sections of the East and South. In parts of the West, anticipated thunderstorms could bring flash flooding, the National Weather Service said. Rain and thunderstorms were likely again today in the Rockies, and scattered showers and electrical storms were expected in many areas nationwide. The nation's high on Thursday was 104 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Convoy Truck Overturns, Spills Munitions
DOC.TEXT: Wreckage of an Army convoy truck that overturned on a highway and spilled munitions bound for the Middle East was cleared today amid reports that Stinger anti-aircraft missiles fell onto the roadway. Army officials said the vehicle that crashed on Interstate 95 was part of a convoy that left nearby Fort Stewart headed for docks near Savannah on Thursday night, fort spokesman Maj. Don Keeling said. Keeling refused to describe the types of munitions that spilled. Georgia State Patrol spokesman J.D. Coleman said the Department of Defense asked civilian authorities to block off both sides of the road and create a safe area about 1,000-feet-wide while awaiting explosives experts. WSAV-TV in Savannah quoted an unidentified Chatham County sheriff's department dispatcher as saying the vehicle carried Stinger missiles. The Savannah Morning News quoted an unidentified police officer as saying he was told by Army personnel that as many as four Stinger missiles were trapped underneath the vehicle. The munitions were packaged and ``at no time was there any danger of detonation,'' Keeling said. The wreckage was cleared early this morning by the Army and the highway was reopened, state patrol officials said. A soldier aboard the truck that crashed was treated at a hospital for a hand injury, officials said. Army officials said they have not determined the cause of the accident about 10 miles southwest of Savannah. The convoy was carrying equipment from the 24th Infantry (Mechanized) Division to load onto military ships destined for to Saudi Arabia as part of the U.S. response to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, the Army said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Sharply Lower; Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell sharply in Europe late this morning and was trading at a record low in Frankfurt as markets focused on the weakness of the U.S. economy. Gold prices rose $7 an ounce in London and $8.75 in Zurich on the dollar's weakness and tensions in the Gulf. Foreign exchange dealers said the dollar was pushed down by a growing market conviction that the U.S. economy will show increasing signs of weakness in the coming months. Traders said these considerations would overshadow any factors that could push the dollar higher. They said U.S. trade figures for June, to be released later today, could only push the dollar lower. The dollar was trading at 1.5528 marks late this morning, down from 1.5630 marks late Thursday. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 147.35 yen, down from 147.90 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted higher at 147.65 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Thursday: _1.5528 West German marks, down from 1.5630 _1.2865 Swiss francs, down from 1.3025 _5.2140 French francs, down from 5.2495 _1.7480 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7610 _1,144.50 Italian lire, down from 1,149.75 _1.1478 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1477 In London, the dollar fell against the British pound, which was quoted at $1.9135, compared with $1.8985 late Thursday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $413.75 a troy ounce and dealers later fixed a recommended price of $410.50. Both were sharply higher than Thursday's late bid price of $403.50. In Zurich, the bid price was $410.00, up from $401.25 late Thursday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $9.95 to close at a bid $410.96. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $5.23 a troy ounce, from Thursday's $5.13.

DOC.HEAD: Army Kills Two Guerrillas in South Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: Israeli troops killed two guerrillas today in southern Lebanon, the army said. The guerrillas were detected by a patrol two miles west of the town of Tayibah, which is three miles from the northern Israeli border, said an army spokeswoman. She cannot be identified by name under military regulations. The army did not say if the guerrillas were Palestinian or Lebanese, nor was there immediate elaboration on the circumstances of the killings. About 1,500 Israeli troops along with 3,000 Israeli-backed Lebanese militiamen regularly patrol Israel's self-declared security zone in southern Lebanon. The 2- to 10-mile-deep zone was carved out by Israel in 1985 when it withdrew the bulk of its troops after Israel's 1982 invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq And Iran Begins Trading POWS, Iraq Withdrawing From Iranian Land
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf after 5th pvs, `Iraqi President...' to ADD Saddam hoping to complete withdrawal in five days. Pickup 5th pvs, `Iraq, which...' ADDS two grafs with Iranian president urging Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: Iraq today began freeing Iranian prisoners of war and withdrawing troops from Iranian territory in an effort to settle one conflict while it faces growing world pressure over its occupation of Kuwait. Iran announced it also was freeing Iraqi POWs today to reciprocate for Baghdad's peace initiative, but it did not disclose their number. The first batch of freed Iranian POWs arrived in Qasr-E-Shirin, an Iranian border town decorated with the green Islamic Republic flag, portraits of the late Ayatollah Rughollah Khomeini and colorful ribbons. Iran's Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, did not say how many prisoners had arrived in Qasr-E-Shirin. But Baghdad and the International Committee of the Red Cross have said 1,000 Iranians were to be freed today. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein Wednesday offered to release Iranians captured in the eight-year war that ended in cease-fire in August 1988. Peace talks have bogged down since then, but Saddam's initiative could speed the process. Saddam also said he hoped to complete within five days the withdrawal from Iraqi-occupied territory in Iran. Iraq, which invaded Kuwait Aug. 2 and massed troops along that country's border with Saudi Arabia, faces a U.S. and Arab troop buildup in the Saudi desert and a growing world trade embargo. Neutralizing the Iraq's 633-mile eastern border with Iran, Iraq's longest frontier, frees an estimated 300,000 Iraqi troops who could be sent to Kuwait to face the military buildup in Saudi Arabia. The Red Cross has registered 19,000 Iranian POWs in Iraq and 50,000 Iraqis in Iran but estimates both sides actually hold a total of more than 100,000. Iran says Iraq occupies more than 770 square miles of its territory. But the United Nations says the size of the occupied area is half that amount. The all-Swiss International Committee of the Red Cross, which has been asked by Iraq to supervise the repatriation, said 1,000 was the maximum number its Baghdad delegation of 19 members could handle. Under the Geneva Convention, the delegates must make sure, in individual interviews, that no prisoner is sent home against his will. ``There have been no problems so far,'' Red Cross spokeswoman Martine Haemmerli said in Geneva. Inmates of an Iraqi camp at Mosul, near the Turkish border, were to make up the first release, and delegates began interviewing them Thursday. The Red Cross has said experience gained in the first phase is hoped to allow stepping up the pace to an eventual 2,000 daily. An increase of the Baghdad delegation is under review but no decision has yet been taken. Saddam made his peace initiatives in a letter to Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani. In the message, he also accepted Iran's demand that a settlement of the border dispute be based on a 1975 demarcation treaty. Saddam had rejected the 1975 agreement, which divided the Shatt-al-Arab waterway between them. He wanted sovereignty over the channel, a confluence of the Tigris and the Euphrates that is a major Iraqi outlet to the gulf. Iranian officials on Thursday welcomed Saddam's offer, but Rafsanjani said developments on the Iran-Iraq front were separate from the crisis triggered by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``We hold on to our view that Iraq must evacuate (its forces) from the Kuwaiti territory to create the necessary conditions for reestablishment of peace and tranquility,'' Iran's official news agency quoted Rafsanjani as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Nina Bara of TV's `Space Patrol' Series Dead at 70
DOC.TEXT: Nina Bara, who portrayed the reformed villainess Tonga on television's ``Space Patrol'' series in the 1950s, has died at age 70. Bara died Wednesday of cancer at Glendale Adventist Medical Center, said her husband, Ray Linke. As Tonga, Bara served on Commander Buzz Corey's crew in the low-budget predecessor to ``Star Trek.'' The ABC-TV series ran from 1950 to 1955. Miss Bara also appeared in the films ``Visa'' and ``Carnival in Rio,'' and on television's ``General Electric Theater.'' Linke said his wife left acting in the 1960s and studied library science, serving as a librarian at Blue Cross of Southern California until she retired in 1985, Linke said. Born in Argentina to an American father and an Italian mother, Miss Bara spoke fluent Spanish and was heard on radio programs in a variety of dialect roles. Besides her husband, she is survived by a daughter.

DOC.HEAD: Tornado Fighter Crashes 2 Days After 2 Others Collide In Midair
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with wreckage found, crew presumed dead. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A British fighter jet crashed into the North Sea during a training flight and the two crewmen were missing and presumed dead, the Defense Ministry reported today. Rescuers abandoned an air and sea search for the crew after the wreckage was discovered this morning. ``We've found the wreckage of the aircraft just a couple of miles away from the point the radar signals indicated last night,'' said a spokesman at the Royal Air Force rescue coordination center at Pitreavie, near Edinburgh, who by custom was not identified. ``From the evidence we have got at the moment it does not look as though there are any survivors,'' he added. The plane came down Thursday off Spurn Head on the northeast English coast. On Tuesday, two RAF Tornados collided three miles from the same site, killing a U.S. Air Force pilot on a training mission and two RAF crewmen. The Defense Ministry said in a statement that the cause of Thursday's crash, which involved only one plane, was not known. It said the plane suddenly disappeared from radar screens. It gave no distress call before crashing.

DOC.HEAD: Sailors Who Publicly Questioned Ship Safety to Be Reassigned
DOC.TEXT: Four sailors have lost their clearance to work on nuclear ships because they publicly questioned nuclear reactor program safety on the aircraft carrier Nimitz instead of telling superiors, Navy officials said. The sailors have been temporarily assigned to the ship's engineering department, received pay cuts, and will eventually be assigned to another post because the Navy no longer trusts them to work around reactors, Navy spokesman Cmdr. Bob Pritchard said Thursday. ``The commanding officer lost confidence in their ability to perform,'' Pritchard said. ``They would be made available for reassignment to another ship or installation, depending on their qualifications.'' But family members awaiting the Nimitz's arrival today at North Island Naval Air Station contend the Navy made scapegoats of the men without adequately investigating their complaints. ``There are too many questions they don't want answered. I wonder what the Navy is afraid of,'' said Rima Puma, the mother of machinist mate second class Steven Puma. Puma and three shipmates told a Seattle television station Aug. 2 that crew members cheated on exams to compensate for their inadequate training, that test results for radiation leaks were fabricated and that faulty hardware was installed on the Nimitz, based in Bremerton, Wash. The four also threatened to sabotage the vessel's reactors to draw attention to their complaints. The names of the other three sailors have not been released. A joint investigation by several naval agencies ``found no evidence to support the allegations made and concluded that the ship's reactors are safe and that the crew is qualified to operate them,'' Pritchard said. But the probe did reveal that some sailors cheated on exams that covered their technical knowledge of the Nimitz's nuclear reactor procedures. ``A handful of guys admitted they looked on their buddies' test paper during one exam,'' Pritchard said. ``However, there was no finding that would call into question the qualification and capability of the crew to operate the propulsion plant safely.'' Nimitz Capt. Robert C. Williamson ordered the four sailors into protective custody as the ship was leaving its home port. They were released Aug. 8 after the ship sailed, Pritchard said. The crewmen received a verbal reprimand from Williamson while at sea. The skipper later revoked their nuclear credentials, prohibiting them from working on any of the Navy's nuclear-powered ships. The demotion also reduces the sailors' merit pay for enlisting in the Navy's nuclear program. Officials said the crewmen were disciplined because they did not use military hot lines to air their concerns or take their complaints to supervising officers.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Hussein's Mug Used To Boost Bus Ridership, Car Pooling
With PM-Oil Prices-Cities, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Take a hike, Saddam Hussein. The Metropolitan Transit Commission is counting on public distaste for the Iraqi president to boost ridership on city buses and encourage car pooling. Saddam's picture and the words, ``Stop pumping him up,'' appeared in newspaper advertisements in the Star Tribune of Minneapolis and the Saint Paul Pioneer Press Thursday. The commission has had an advertising campaign since last spring encouraging Twin Citians to conserve energy by taking the bus and sharing rides. After Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2 and gasoline and oil prices began to rise, the wheels started turning at Grant & Palombo, an advertising agency. ``It's an opportunistic message that happens to tie into the campaign we have in place for the MTC,'' said John Palombo, the ad agency's chief executive officer. Below a head shot of Saddam, the ad reads, ``It's about time we showed this guy we don't need his oil. Take the bus or rideshare and you do just that.'' Phones at MTC headquarters were busier than usual Thursday, with callers asking for bus and car pooling information in reaction to the ads, commission officials said. ``People see it as a way of venting the frustration everyone seems to be feeling,'' Palombo said. It's too soon to tell if Iraq's invasion and rising gasoline prices are boosting ridership, but there are encouraging signs, said Todd Melby, MTC communications coordinator. A comparison of revenues for the first two weeks of this month and the same period in August 1989 shows revenues are even with last year's. That's good news, because revenues had been down this year. ``So we're actually saying we're up 2 percent,'' Melby said.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Arabia Said to Turn Away Iraqi Tanker
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia today turned away an Iraqi tanker seeking to break the embargo on Iraqi oil shipments, Persian Gulf shipping sources said. The tanker, identified as the 80,000-ton Al-Fao, arrived off the Saudi Arabian Red Sea terminal of Yanbu early this morning, but Saudi tugboats refused to pilot it into port, the sources said. The tanker sailed away in the early afternoon toward international waters where another Iraqi tanker, Al-Qadissiyah, anchored after it was turned away Monday, said the sources, speaking on condition of anonymity. The Al-Qadissiyah's arrival marked the first Iraqi attempt to break the embargo via the trans-Saudi Arabian pipeline. The pipeline has a capacity of 1.65 million barrels per day, and operated by Saudi Arabia's giant oil firm, Saudi Aramco. Iraq pumped crude oil through the pipeline at reduced capacity after the U.N. Security Council sanctions were imposed. By Monday, it had filled the storage capacity of about 10 to 11 million barrels. Pumping has since halted. Iraqi oil exports were choked off under U.N. sanctions imposed after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, and its annexation of the emirate six days later.

DOC.HEAD: Billboard Blasting Arts Censorship Torn Down
DOC.TEXT: A billboard criticizing Sen. Jesse Helms and arts censorship was taken down a week after it went up because the poster violates the billboard company's ban on controversial signs. The billboard, created by Los Angeles artist Robbie Conal, depicted the Republican from North Carolina with copy that read: ``Artificial Art Official.'' Helms, who has opposed National Endowment for the Arts grants to artists with sexual or other controversial themes, was depicted with a hole in his head in the center of a painter's palette. ``This is exactly an example of the issue I was trying to protest,'' Conal said. ``I'm saddened but I can't say that I'm shocked. I want the billboard back. I hope some billboard company still believes in the First Amendment.'' Conal said he signed a three-month lease for the billboard on heavily traveled Santa Monica Boulevard. The billboard, roughly 18 feet by 48 feet, was unveiled Aug. 8. A telephone message left with Helms' office in Washington was not returned. The billboard structure is owned by National Advertising, a subsidiary of Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing. The billboard unit has a policy prohibiting controversial subjects such as abortion, sex and birth control, said 3M spokesman Ken Froslid. He said the Helms billboard contained ``questionable copy.'' The decision to tear down the billboard was made by a national marketing director for National Advertising in Chicago, he said. ``Jesse Helms did not contact us or any of his people,'' Froslid said. ``It was strictly an internal decision.''

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Investigating Allegations Against Nazi-Hunting Unit
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department is investigating allegations that its Nazi-hunting unit withheld evidence on a former California resident convicted of war crimes by a Yugoslav court, according to a published report today. The department's Office of Professional Responsibility is conducting the investigation into the case of Andrija Artukovic, the Los Angeles Times quoted unidentified sources as saying. One official familiar with the probe said there was no evidence Artukovic was falsely convicted of ordering the deaths of hundreds of Serbs, Jews and Gypsies during World War II, the newspaper said. Artukovic served as a Cabinet minister in a Nazi puppet government in wartime Croatia that executed thousands. He emigrated to the United States in 1948 under an alias and resided in Seal Beach before he was identified and extradited to Yugoslavia in 1986. Two years later, he died at age 88 in a Yugoslav prison. Artukovic's son, Radoslav, alleges that the Nazi-hunting unit, the Office of Special Investigations, withheld evidence that might have cast doubt on two witnesses whose testimony was used against his father during extradition proceedings. Justice Department spokesman Doug Tillett declined to comment on the allegations and the investigation. Radoslav Artukovic said he had obtained conflicting affidavits by witnesses against his father and alleged that Office of Professional Responsibility officials withheld those less favorable to their case, the Times said. According to one affidavit, a former Serbian police chief, Fronjo Truhar, testified in 1952 that during the war, Artukovic had ordered an imprisoned lawyer to be killed. The execution was carried out in July 1941, Truhar said. But in a 1951 affidavit, Truhar never mentioned Artukovic's alleged order to execute the lawyer. That affidavit allegedly was not used as evidence at the extradition hearings, the Times said. Radoslav Artukovic obtained documents that contradict an affidavit obtained in 1984 from Bajro Avdic, who claimed he served as a motorcycle escort for Artukovic in 1941, the Times said. Avdic claimed he saw Artukovic order soldiers to massacre innocent civilians. But Radoslav Artukovic said the man had submitted three previous statements dating back to 1946 that differed substantially in details and recollections. ``He changed his story each time he told it,'' the younger Artukovic said. In addition, Radoslav Artukovic alleges it was the Office of Professional Responsibility, not Yugoslav officials, that initiated extradition proceedings against his father. Neal M. Sher, director of the Office of Special Investigations, has denied the allegation and said the Justice Department merely cooperated with a request by Yugoslav officials, the Times said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Reduces Curfew In Major Cities
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq today reduced the curfew in major cities in occupied Kuwait to seven hours a night, Iraqi media said. The official Iraqi News Agency said President Saddam Hussein's office ordered an 11 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew in Jahra, Nida' and Kuwait City. Iraqi authorities first clamped a 24-hour curfew on the cities after their Aug. 2 invasion, then reduced it to 12 hours from 7 p.m. to 7 a.m. Recent refugees from Kuwait said no one was circulating at night in any case, as Iraqi soldiers were cracking down on scattered acts of resistance. The reduced curfew appeared to indicate they were succeeding. Refugees who escaped from Kuwait earlier this week said the city crackled with gunfire when darkness fell as Kuwaitis staged hit-and-run raids against the invaders. They said the Iraqis have still not been able to stamp out resistance by citizens of the small oil-rich state. But some said the Kuwaiti underground is waiting for help from outside before launching a real offensive against the conquerors. ``When the sun shines you're gripped with the awesome silence and desolation, and after sundown there's the fear of violence and death,'' said one Kuwaiti, Saeed Hussein. ``Resistance has been reactivated, but only after dark,'' he added. A Kuwaiti woman, who declined to be identified, said some Kuwaiti men ``go out with machine guns every night and kill one or two Iraqis.'' There has been no independent confirmation of any significant resistance in the northern Persian Gulf state, and the extent of casualties in what clashes there may be is not known. Communications with Kuwait are still cut. Iraq has an estimated 120,000 troops in Kuwait. A growing U.S. force _ backed by an international fleet drawn from the British, French and other navies _ is mustering in Saudi Arabia to face the Iraqis massed along the kingdom's northern border. Kuwait's radio station, once the liveliest in the Persian Gulf region, broadcasts clandestinely, calling for resistance against the Iraqi invaders. ``Kuwait will ... never be part of Iraq,'' announcers stress in between nationalist songs. ``Today brave Kuwaitis in a speeding car hurled a grenade at a security base, killing a number of Iraqi soldiers and injuring others,'' it claimed in a broadcast Wednesday. Another traveler from Kuwait, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said: ``Resistance is spreading ... Young Kuwaitis don't know mercy any more. ``The slogan `kill an Iraqi and gain a dinar' is written on school buildings and everywhere, even on the sidealks and the tarmac of the streets,'' he reported.

DOC.HEAD: Americans in Baghdad Hotel Said Moved to Undisclosed Location
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 16 grafs to UPDATE with State Department, Solarz, British foreign secretary's comments. Pickup 13th graf pvs, `About 7,000...' U.N. panel to begin meeting at 10:30 a.m.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos XKNE2,3,112,XSAV1,2,BX1,2
DOC.TEXT: Fears for about three dozen Americans detained in Baghdad intensified today amid word they had been moved to an undisclosed location, and Saudi Arabia reportedly turned away an Iraqi tanker trying to break the oil embargo. As the Persian Gulf crisis caused by Iraq's invasion of its neighbor Kuwait entered its third week, officials in Washington said U.S. officials in the Iraqi capital were demanding access to the detainees. ``We understand the 35 Americans who were in the Rashid Hotel have been moved. We think we know where they are, but we have not seen them,'' a source at the State Department said today. President Bush also said there were reports ``about moving 30 Americans someplace'' from the luxury hotel where they had been confined in the Iraqi capital. But the president, vacationing in Kennebunkport, Maine, provided no details in his brief comments to reporters today. Iraq, seeking peace with its old enemy Iran in order to focus on the escalating confrontation with the United States, today began withdrawing troops from Iranian territory and freeing Iranian POWs. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney was bound for Riyadh today to visit American troops standing guard in the Saudi desert against a possible further thrust by Iraq's president, Saddam Hussein. Bush expressed pessimism Thursday that Iraqi forces would end their occupation of Kuwait. In the Persian Gulf, the military buildup and economic embargo intensified, but American efforts to squeeze Iraq with a trade embargo could run into trouble. The United Nations chief said military enforcement of U.N. sanctions against Iraq requires U.N. approval. A special Security Council committee on the embargo was to meet privately today, and Canadian diplomats said they intended to discuss how the committee would monitor compliance beyond official government statements. Bush has ordered U.S. naval commanders to use ``the minimum force necessary'' to interdict shipments to and from Iraq. That could include firing across the bow to halt a ship. Gulf-based shipping executives today reported that Saudi authorities refused to permit an Iraqi tanker to take on oil from Iraq's pipeline at the Saudi Red Sea port of Yanbu. The tanker was identified as the 80,000-ton Al-Fao, said the sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. Another Iraqi tanker tried to load up at the terminal Sunday night. The invasion stranded more than 2 million foreigners, including 3,000 Americans kept by Iraqi authorities from leaving Iraq and Kuwait. About 4,000 Britons and more than 450 Japanese also are trapped. On Thursday, Iraqi authorities in Kuwait ordered the 2,500 Americans to assemble at a hotel because of ``unspecified threats'' against them, but few complied, said a senior U.S. official in Washington. The Americans at the Rashid Hotel in Baghdad were brought to Iraq from Kuwait in the days following the invasion. But the Bush administration has been careful to avoid referring to the detained U.S. citizens as hostages. A U.S. congressman today warned Iraq would face American military retaliation if trapped Americans were harmed. ``If any U.S. citizen in Kuwait or Iraq is in any way brutalized or tortured or killed, the United States will retaliate...in a way that will result in the destruction of the military and economic infrastructure of Iraq,'' said Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., speaking to reporters at Israel's Ben-Gurion airport. Solarz is a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. Britain _ whose nationals in Kuwait were also ordered to assemble _ said it feared the order was a prelude to internment. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd accused Iraq today of using ``the tactic of the outlaw down the ages'' by intimidating foreign nationals. About 7,000 foreigners fled to Jordan from Iraq and Kuwait on Thursday, but only a handful of Westerners were among them. The British Foreign Office said today that Iraqi officials did not show up at the hotel by late Thursday. ``We have basically advised people to stay at home pending further information,'' a Foreign Office spokesman said. Iraq's repatriation of Iranian prisoners and its troop withdrawal followed Saddam's announcement Wednesday that Baghdad wanted to formally end the eight-year Iran-Iraq war and secure its eastern border. Peace would enable Iraq to transfer some of its estimated 300,000 troops on that front to Kuwait and the Saudi frontier. Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency said the Tehran government was releasing Iraqi prisoners today but did not say how many. In other developments: _Japan said today it was weighing new measures in response to the invasion of Kuwait. Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe suggested Japan might rethink its policy against deploying military equipment or personnel overseas, and could send Japanese minesweepers to the Persian Gulf region. _Refugees who escaped Kuwait earlier this week said Kuwait city crackled with gunfire when darkness fell as Kuwaitis staged hit-and-run raids against the invaders. They claimed that the Iraqi invaders still not been able to completely stifle resistance by the citizens of the tiny oil-rich state. _A West German prosecutor today said seven people have been arrested in connection with the alleged delivery of a poison gas plant to Iraq. The prosecutor said the arrests came after several years of investigation. Iraq has previously used chemical weapons against Iran and its own Kurdish minority. _An Iraqi cargo ship, reportedly carrying food, steamed through the Suez Canal toward the Red Sea today after being stranded at the waterway's entrance for three days, a canal authority official said. The 7,000-ton Zain al-Qaws was the first Iraqi vessel to transit the 100-mile-long channel _ the main route for European shipping to the region _ since the United Nations imposed sanctions on Iraq on Aug. 6. _Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said Iraq has pursued its armed forces buildup in Kuwait and its troops there now number about 160,000. The Iraqis have ringed Kuwait City with an air-defense system, a U.S. official reported, speaking on condition of anonymity. The United States and some Arab countries have poured thousands of troops into Saudi Arabia since Iraq invaded oil-rich Kuwait Aug. 2 in a dispute over land and oil and massed forces near the Saudis' northern border. Saddam wrote Bush an open letter Thursday calling Bush a liar and a shallow person, and warned any confrontation could lead to ``thousands of Americans wrapped in sad coffins.'' Jordan's King Hussein returned from the United States today and a Jordanian official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the monarch might fly to Iraq to brief Saddam on his talks with Bush. Bush said after meeting Thursday with the Jordanian monarch that ``I did not come away with any feeling of hope'' Iraqi forces will leave Kuwait. The president also said King Hussein assured him Jordan would close Aqaba, the last remaining free port to most Iraqi trade, as the economic embargo on materials to Iraq continued unabated. Foodstuffs are among the goods being blocked from entry; Iraq imports about three-quarters of its food. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said in Peru Thursday that the use of military power to enforce U.N. sanctions on Iraq violates the U.N. charter unless the world body's Security Council approves it.

DOC.HEAD: Seven People Arrested in Iraqi Poison Gas Plant Case
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to ADD that export laws were violated, plant produces mustard gas, background on Iraqi, details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Seven people have been arrested in connection with the alleged delivery of a poison gas plant to Iraq several years ago, a West German prosecutor said today. The prosecutor, Friedrich Hoffmann in Darmstadt, said that among those arrested was a man he identified only as Al Kadhi, an Iraqi specialist employed by the West German foreign intelligence service. Hoffmann said the arrests, which came after several years of investigation, took so long because evidence was needed to prove that the plant allegedly delivered to Iraq was constructed to produce poison gas. The arrests were based on violation of West German export laws, which limit and in many cases ban the sale or delivery of weapons of destruction to areas of conflict such as the Middle East, Hoffmann said. He said the plant produced mustard gas, among other deadly chemical agents. Among those arrested were employees of the Pilot Plant company in Dreieich, 12 miles south of Frankfurt; workers in the export section of the Preussag company in Hanover; and from the Walter Engineering Trading company in Hamburg, Hoffmann said. He emphasized that the accusations were directed at individuals and not at the companies he named. The West German news magazine Der Spiegel reported this week that dozens of German firms were helping Iraq produce rockets, chemical weapons and ``military nuclear technology.'' The report, coming in the middle of the Persian Gulf crisis and Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's threats to attack Israel with chemical weapons, angered an already anxious Jerusalem. Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy has demanded that steps be taken against West Germans and others allegedly involved in helping Iraq develop chemical weapons. He met with West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher on Tuesday in Bavaria to discuss those concerns. According to the Spiegel report, Al Kadhi had worked for the West German foreign intelligence in Iraq, where he was arrested by Iraqi officials and sentenced to death for spying several years ago. The report said that President Richard von Weizsaecker of West Germany interceded with Iraq for clemency. Following a visit by Genscher in 1987 for talks with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, Al Kadhi's sentence was reduced to life in prison. A short time later, Al Kadhi, whom Spiegel described as of German-Iraqi descent, arrived in West Germany. The 51-year-old Al Kadhi began working with the Walter Engineering Trading company in Hamburg, from where he allegedly shipped material for producing chemical weapons to Iraq, the magazine said. The material, which the magazine said was shipped to Iraq via Turkey, was allegedly used to contruct a poison gas plant in Iraq. The report did not say exactly when the materials for the plant were shipped to Iraq. Saddam has used chemical weapons in the past, both in the Iran-Iraq war and against Kurds in his own country, and officials in his government have threatened to use them against U.S. forces massing in Saudi Arabia. West German companies were also involved in developing a suspected Libyan chemical weapons plant, and possibly a second such facility. The disclosures in December 1988 raised a storm of protest. In June, Juergen Hippenstiel-Imhausen, head of the Imhausen-Chemie company, was found guilty of shipping materials for an alleged chemical weapons plant in Libya. He was sentenced to five years in prison. Prosecutors said earlier this month that Imhausen may have supplied plans for a second chemical weapons facility. The United States alleged that the first plant, in Rabta 50 miles from Tripoli, was intended to produce chemical weapons. Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi denied it and said the plant was for pharmaceuticals. In addition, Italy, Britain, Turkey, Greece and West Germany have all seized material in the last year meant for Baghdad and suspected of being components of a giant gun, capable of firing shells hundreds of miles.

DOC.HEAD: State, Learnfare Opponents Reach Agreement
DOC.TEXT: The state agreed to revise its ``Learnfare'' program, which cuts welfare benefits to families whose children skip school, in order to meet a judge's objections that it may be unfair in some cases. Critics and supporters of the controversial 2-year-old program should reach a final agreement by November, said Edward Marion, chief counsel for the Wisconsin Department of Health and Social Services. ``We have essentially agreed in principle on what is necessary to lift the injunction,'' Marion said Thursday following a hearing before U.S. District Judge Terence T. Evans. Last month, Evans ordered the suspension of Learnfare in Milwaukee, saying record-keeping errors had resulted in unfair treatment of some families receiving Aid to Families with Dependent Children. The advocacy group Legal Action of Wisconsin had sued on behalf of six families who claimed their AFDC benefits were wrongly cut because of errors in school attendance records. The injunction applied only to the 3,200 teen-agers attending Milwaukee Public Schools that have lost or were in danger of losing benefits. The program is still in effect elsewhere in Wisconsin. Anne DeLeo, a lawyer for Legal Action, told Evans that the state and her group have agreed that Milwaukee County and the state Department of Health and Social Services will verify students' attendance records before reducing their parents' welfare benefits. She said the state also will investigate teen-agers' reasons for skipping school to make sure the absences were not for legitimate reasons such as illness or death in the family. The state also agreed to issue notices to a teen-ager and the family when they are being monitored for possible sanction. ``We've got the agreement in principle that these things should be done,'' Ms. DeLeo said. ``How we do that and with what personnel we do it is still undecided.'' Learnfare, authorized by the Legislature in 1987, deducts about $100 a month for an average family receiving $517 a month in AFDC benefits if one of its teen-agers is consistently truant. Legal Action attorneys estimated that 1,600 to 2,000 Milwaukee students were sanctioned each month under the program. Of the 30,000 students subject to Learnfare, half live in Milwaukee County, and three-fourths of the sanctions have been levied there, according to state figures. Evans scheduled the next status hearing for Jan. 8, but said the injunction could be lifted sooner.

DOC.HEAD: More Foreigners Flee Iraq; Americans Said Moved; Britain Protests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE figures on foreigners entering Jordan, U.S. citizens in Baghdad reportedly moved, fresh British comment, other details, CORRECT that Jordan says it's enforcing U.N. sanctions. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Thousands more foreigners poured into Jordan today from Iraq, fleeing the crisis set off by Baghdad's takeover of Kuwait. Only a few Westerners were among them. A Jordanian border official said 6,500 foreigners, mainly Egyptians, crossed into Jordan from Iraq at the Ruweishid frontier post. They included eight French citizens, four East Germans and a Canadian, all of Arab origin, he reported. Officials estimate that about 16,300 foreigners in all have fled from Iraq into Jordan since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. In Baghdad, U.S. officials today demanded to see more than 30 Americans held in Iraq, following word they were no longer in the luxury hotel where Iraqi soldiers had detained them. ``We understand the 35 Americans who were in the Rashid Hotel have been moved. We think we know where they are but we have not seen them,'' a source at the State Department said today. The Americans were brought to Baghdad from Kuwait after the invasion. In Britain, Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd accused Iraq today of using ``the tactic of the outlaw down the ages'' by intimidating British nationals in Kuwait. The comment came one day after Iraqi military authorities ordered Britons and Americans to assemble at Kuwait hotels, but then failed to turn up to meet them. There are 4,000 Britons and 2,500 Americans in Kuwait. ``We are trying to clarify the situation both in Baghdad and in Kuwait,'' a British Foreign Office spokesman said. ``We have basically advised people to stay at home pending further information.'' Also today, Japan complained to Baghdad that it is violating international norms in refusing to permit the 500 Japanese citizens in Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait to leave, the Japanese Foreign Ministry said. In Amman, the visiting foreign ministers from Italy, Ireland and Luxembourg, warned that Iraqi refusal to let the 20,000 Westerners in Iraq and Kuwait leave might worsen the Persian Gulf crisis. They asked Jordan to intercede with Baghdad. The foreign ministers _ Gianni de Michelis of Italy, Gerald Collins of Ireland and Georges Wohlfart of Luxembourg _ addressed a joint news conference after meeting Thursday with Crown Prince Hassan and other Jordanian officials. Jordan, an ally of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, has tried to remain neutral in the crisis. King Hussein has committed himself to sanctions imposed by the U.N. Security Council on Iraq, but news reports have said that Iraqi imports and exports are still passing through the Jordanian port of Aqaba on the Red Sea. De Michelis said the Economic Commmunity might provide economic assistance to Jordan to help meet any hardships enforcing sanctions might entail. A U.S. Embassy diplomat said the evacuees reaching Jordan Thursday included three U.S. citizens of Indian origin. They crossed at Ruweishid, about 205 miles northeast of Amman, he said. The other Westerners were three Bangladeshis with dual British and Bangladeshi nationality, and a Frenchwoman, the official said. Most of the Arab evacuees were Egyptians.

DOC.HEAD: N.J. Casino Board Puts Off Ruling On Trump Financial Plan
Precede LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J.
LaserPhoto TN1 of Aug. 16
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with state panel putting off decision until Tuesday, add quotes from morning hearing. No pickup. A version moving on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: The state casino board today said it would hold off ruling on Donald Trump's financial restructuring until next Tuesday despite his attorneys' pleas that a quick ruling was needed to stave off a possible bankruptcy. Valerie Armstrong, acting chairwoman of the Casino Control Commission, said the panel realizes the importance of a quick decision but said it needed more time to look over the more than 1,000 pages of documents detailing a $65 million emergency loan granted to Trump in June by banks. ``As far as I am concerned, this is expedited,'' Ms. Armstrong said. On Thursday, Trump attorney Thomas Cerabino had said that if the panel delays making its ruling for a week, the plan could fall apart because the delay could trigger a string of defaults. But today, Ed Tracy, president of the developer's three Atlantic City casinos, played down any such talk. Asked about the effects of the delay until Tuesday, Tracy said ``Nothing specifically. It's merely a delay.'' Trump himself had no comment. After the flamboyant developer missed a June 15 bond payment on the Trump Castle casino, he entered into feverish negotiations with a group of seven banks. The bankers agreed to an emergency $65 million loan secured by equity in his three casinos. But the agreement isn't final until it is approved by the state casino commission. In its closing arguments today, the state Division of Gaming Enforcement recommended approval of the deal, but said it was doing so reluctantly and attached 13 conditions. Trump attorneys said the organization would have no trouble meeting the conditions, which were primarily reporting requirements. Thomas Auriemma, a deputy state attorney general, said the gaming division was recommending approval of the deal because ``the situation for the Trump Organization is critical. There are no easy or viable alternatives.'' ``The company has left us at this point with little alternative,'' Auriemma said. ``The Division reluctantly recommends approval.'' In his closing arguments, Trump attorney Nicholas Ribis pleaded with the commission to approve the deal, saying Trump has always honored his pledges and remains committed to Atlantic City. Documents released Wednesday show Trump's debt at $3.2 billion against assets worth between $2.9 billion and $3.5 billion. On Thursday, Auriemma had described the Trump organization as ``in dire straits'' and said the possibility of complete financial collapse ``is not out of the question.'' But Stephen Bollenbach, hired Thursday as the Trump Organization's chief financial officer, told the commission the Trump empire could shed its debt. ``Clearly, things need to change in this company,'' said Bollenbach. ``I don't think that means we're in dire straits but certainly somebody else might.'' Among the 13 conditions recommneded by the division are requirements that Trump return in three weeks after any commission decision to detail his plan for making a $47 million bond payment Nov. 15 on the Taj Mahal Casino Resort.

DOC.HEAD: S.C. Legislator Quits Race, Says He's Helping FBI Probe
DOC.TEXT: A state representative announced he was withdrawing his re-election bid and revealed he had been working undercover to help the FBI's investigation of corruption among fellow legislators. ``While some people might question the wisdom of assisting (the FBI) in their investigation, I can only say, `When the FBI wants you to cooperate, you will cooperate,' '' state Rep. Robert Kohn said, reading from a letter he said he was mailing to constituents. In his statement Thursday, Kohn acknowledged that in his 15 years in the Legislature, he had become part of the corrupt system he had intended to reform. He said he had been working for the FBI for several months. The Charleston Republican refused to answer questions, but a newspaper reported he had discussed a plea bargain with prosecutors. U.S. Attorney Bart Daniel also declined to answer questions about Kohn's statement, including whether it had been cleared with him. Sources have said the FBI videotaped legislators taking money. A federal grand jury looking into the case meets Tuesday. The investigation, dubbed ``Operation Broken Trust,'' also involves lobbyist Ron Cobb, a former House member. According to legislators, he offered them cash in exchange for their support on a bill that would have allowed pari-mutuel betting in South Carolina. Kohn reported accepting $150 from Cobb. In his letter, Kohn revealed little of the details of his participation with the FBI or how he got involved. ``When I first went to Columbia, I resolved to change the way business was done ... the good ol' boy system, if you will. I not only failed to do that, but I became a part of the system itself,'' Kohn said. ``The irony is that by cooperating with the FBI, I am indeed facilitating change, but in a much different and more drastic manner than I had ever imagined.'' He withdrew from his contest with Democrat Ida Morea for ``personal and business reasons,'' Kohn said, but he added his withdrawal will ``grant me the additional latitude I need to assist the FBI and the U.S. attorney in their investigation and prosecution of public corruption in South Carolina.'' The State newspaper quoted unidentified sources as saying that Kohn spent part of this week reviewing videotapes and working out a plea bargain with federal attorneys. Kohn, an insurance consultant, was the only one of the 16 lawmakers known to have been questioned by the FBI who faced opposition in the November election.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Board Overturns Ban on Rushdie Film
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Single ``r'' in Guerillas is correct
DOC.TEXT: An appeals board today overturned a ban on a film depicting author Salman Rushdie as a drunken sadist who murders Moslems. Rushdie had urged the Video Appeals Committee to lift the ban on ``International Guerillas.'' The ban was imposed last month on grounds that the work could be criminally libelous. In a passionate written statement, Rushdie said he did not seek the dubious protection of censorship. ``The banning of `International Guerillas,' however well intentioned, can only damage the process of reconciliation, and I urge the committee to reverse tnd offered to testify in defense of the video if the distributor ever faced a criminal libel suit. The committee, which had 21 days to rule, rendered its decision within a few hours of hearing testimony.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Ice Breaker Carries Tourists to North Pole
DOC.TEXT: The atomic-powered ice breaker Rossiya has taken scientists and tourists on the first Arctic cruise to the North Pole, the Soviet news agency Tass reported. Passengers were taken a short distance by helicopter to Hayes Island in the Arctic Ocean over a period of several hours, Tass said. The island is the site of the largest observatory in the northernmost latitudes. Tourists visited the bathhouse and homes on the island, where researchers from Canada and France recently studied the ozone layer, Tass said Tuesday. They also watched polar bears roaming near houses.

DOC.HEAD: Shortage-Plagued Moscow Now Out Of Ice Cream
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet capital, which often boasts of having the world's best ice cream, has a shortage in these waning days of summer, a newspaper reported Friday. Ice cream kiosks on street corners and city parks have been displaying ``No Ice Cream'' signs, although they continue to sell souvenirs, marshmallows, chocolates and other candies, Komsomolskaya Pravda reported. Ice cream is still available at foreign outlets, such as the Baskin-Robbins stores in the Rossia Hotel and on the Arbat pedestrian mall, or the Soviet-Swiss joint venture Pinguin. But lines are long and prices are high for Muscovites who have always taken pride in their own ice cream, which they buy in paper-wrapped slabs or on sticks, rather than in cones. Komsomolskaya Pravda quoted Mosgortorg, the Directorate for State-Run Trade in Moscow, as saying two of the three ice cream-making factories in Moscow are closed for repairs this summer. One might reopen early next month, it said.

DOC.HEAD: Balloonist Arrested in Connection With Fatal Accident
DOC.TEXT: A judge Friday refused to grant bail to the pilot of a hot-air balloon involved in an accident last year that killed 13 people. Michael Sanby, a South African native, was arrested Thursday while preparing to board a flight to Zimbabwe. He has not been charged in the accident near Alice Springs, in central Australia. But police issued a provisional warrant for unlawful killing. Alice Springs Coroner Denis Barrett heard a recommendation this week that Sanby face 13 counts of manslaughter. Sanby's attorney told a court hearing Friday he would not fight extradition. In applying for bail, Sanby offered to surrender his passport and take the first available return flight to Alice Springs. But police said they feared Sanby would try to reach his native South Africa, which has no extradition arrangements with Australia. Judge Kenneth Moore rejected the bail request. Frank Gaffy, a lawyer assisting the coroner in his investigation, said there was evidence Sanby deliberately collided with another balloon Aug. 13, 1989. The basket of Sanby's balloon hit and tore open a lower balloon carrying 13 people. All of them died when the balloon fell to the ground.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Kurdish Guerrillas Killed
DOC.TEXT: Security forces killed seven Kurdish guerrillas in a clash in southeastern Turkey, the regional governor's office announced Friday. The announcement said the guerrillas were killed in Sirnak province on Thursday. The guerrillas belong to the Kurdish Labor Party, a Marxist group fighting over the past six years to establish an independent Kurdistan in Turkey's southeastern provinces. So far, about 2,500 civilians guerrillas and security forces have died in the clashes tied to the independence bid.

DOC.HEAD: Police Disperse Armed Bands as Death Toll Hits 173
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with new death toll, injuries, ANC accuses government of destablization campaign. Pick up 12th graf pvs, `On Thursday...' ^By TOM COHEN
DOC.TEXT: Police fired tear gas today to break up groups of armed men as authorities tried to halt savage black factional fighting that has killed at least 178 people in the past five days. At least five people were killed today in Soweto, police said. Police in armored vehicles dispersed groups of Zulus armed with axes and spears in various parts of Soweto, witnesses said. The African National Congress today accused the South African security forces of inciting township violence in a bid to divide the black majority. ANC supporters have accused police of aiding Inkatha in the violence, a charge denied by authorities. ``It is a matter of record that the South African government has developed a well-known capacity for destabilization'' in neighboring countries, the ANC said. ``It is our conviction that these methods and tactics have been brought to bear on the home front'' to bring about ``insecurity, fear and a willingness to submit to draconian measures.'' The police again used tear gas to halt a late morning confrontation between a group of Zulus and Soweto residents, the witnesses said. At least 26 people were killed and 217 injured in Soweto in two days of violence between rival Zulus and Xhosas, police said. The Soweto deaths raised the overall toll to 178 in five days of fighting in several Johannesburg townships, where police were still finding bodies from clashes earlier in the week. ``Most were hacked to death,'' a police spokesman, Col. Tienie Halgryn, told the independent South African Press Association. Police said today that hundreds of people had also been injured in the five days of fighting. A family of six, including four children, was admitted to a hospital today after their home in the Kagiso township was firebombed, police said. A police spokeswoman said it was an isolated incident. The fighting pits Zulu supporters of the conservative Inkatha movement against mostly Xhosa members of the ANC led by Nelson Mandela. Nationalism is intense among the Zulus, the largest tribal group in South Africa. Many Zulus involved in the fighting say they would not accept Mandela and the ANC as a future government. Throughout the night, blacks erected street barricades in Soweto with burning tires and debris that police tore down. Police fired tear gas to disperse roaming bands, the witnesses said. The spreading unrest led to an unscheduled meeting Thursday between Mandela and President F.W. de Klerk. Mandela later met with Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok. The two sides agreed to form peace committees composed of police, ANC and Inkatha members in the troubled areas. But police said an initial meeting scheduled for today at a Soweto police station was delayed. On Thursday night, white right-wing protesters hurled a tear-gas bomb into a community hall in Vryheid in northern Natal where de Klerk was giving a speech. Police dispersed the pro-apartheid protesters, and de Klerk delivered the speech outside the hall. As dawn broke today, many of Soweto's 2 million residents began heading for work in nearby Johannesburg, and police said most areas were returning to normal. Many people stayed home Thursday to protect their homes. The fighting this week was considered some of the worst in five years of conflict that originated in South Africa's eastern Natal province. More than 5,000 blacks have died in the conflict. Inkatha and the ANC oppose apartheid, but are divided by leadership rivalry, tribal loyalty and differing visions of a future South Africa. The move of the conflict into Johannesburg and other parts of Transvaal Province indicates the struggle for power between the two sides is heating up while the white-led government moves toward majority rule. De Klerk has promised to end apartheid and share political power with the black majority.

DOC.HEAD: Japan May Take Unprecedented Military Step in Reaction to Gulf
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Japan is considering breaking with its long-held policy against deployment of military equipment overseas as it considers responses to the Persian Gulf crisis, a Foreign Ministry official said Friday. Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe told reporters he did ``not preclude'' the possibility the government was considering sending minesweepers to the Middle East. Asked about the constitutionality of this, he said: ``To make it a reality we have to go through various heated discussions among various agencies in the government as well as take into consideration the public opinion of Japan. ... If there is any difference of opinion on constitutionality, we go down to the roots of the discussion and find out whether it is constitutional or not. ``That is what we are doing right now.'' Japan's postwar constitution bars the use of force as a means of settling international disputes and forbids the maintenance of land, air and sea forces. Since the early 1950s, that has been interpreted as allowing a purely defensive military. Current law also restricts the Self-Defense Forces, Japan's military, to Japanese territory, except for participation in ceremonial occasions overseas. Changes in the law would likely bring a strong reaction from Japanese opposition parties and neighboring countries opposed to a greater role for Japan's military. Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama began a nine-day trip to the Middle East on Friday to visit countries affected by the Iraq-Kuwait crisis. His mission is to determine what actions Japan can take to help the international effort to punish Iraq for invading Kuwait, Watanabe said. Japanese news reports said the sending of minesweepers could be seen as a defensive act needed to protect Japan's oil supply. Japan imports 99 percent of the oil it uses and is more dependent on Middle East oil than any industrialized nation. Japan's military remains controversial here, and increases in defense spending are hotly debated. Asian nations invaded by Japan during World War II also have opposed increases in Japan's military strength. Japan previously has sent non-military personnel to join peacekeeping or monitoring forces in Nambia, Nicaragua and along the Afghan border. Watanabe said Japanese public opinion, once sharply opposed to any kind of military involvement overseas, has changed. ``That kind of opposition which I have seen before is much, much less these days,'' he said.
