DOC.HEAD: Japanese Ambassador Killed in Plane Crash
DOC.TEXT: The Japanese ambassador to Costa Rica was killed today when the light plane in which he was flying collided with another plane and crashed into a house, according to the director of civil aviation. The Costa Rican pilot also died in the accident. Civil Aviation Director Alvaro Escalante said the accident occurred at 7:55 a.m. shortly after the single-engine Piper 180 had taken off from Tobias Bolanos airport east of San Jose. Escalante said the ambassador, Chusaku Nomura was learing how to fly small planes. The Japanese Embassy confirmed the death of Nomura and said the ambassador was 56.

DOC.HEAD: Taylor's Departure for Talks Delayed; Marines Evacuate Hundreds
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Indian nationals brought to Sierra Leone, Pick up 8th graf pvs, `The United...'
DOC.TEXT: Rebel leader Charles Taylor suffered minor injuries in an auto accident, delaying his departure for peace talks with a rival rebel chief and an envoy to President Samuel K. Doe, an official said today. Tom Woewiyu, Taylor's spokesman and defense minister, said the accident occurred as the rebel chief prepared to leave Liberia for talks Monday in Banjul, Gambia on how to resolve Liberia's 8-month-old civil war. The accident was not serious, but Taylor returned to the Firestone Rubber plantation clinic for treatment and to arrange new transport, Woewiyu said from Abidjan, Ivory Coast. The plantation is 35 miles southeast of Monrovia. Woewiyu did not say when Taylor would leave Liberia for Banjul. The meeting was announced Thursday by Gambian government sources. Word of the talks could lead to further delays in the deployment of a six-nation West African force charged with halting the fighting. U.S. Marines today flew about 360 Indian nationals from the USS Saipan off the Liberian coast to Freetown, capital of neighboring Sierra Leone. They were airlifted Thursday from the U.S. Embassy in Monrovia to the warship. A U.S. Embassy spokesman in Freetown told reporters the Marines had evacuated about 700 people in the past week, mostly foreigners, and would continue evacuating the capital on Sunday. The United States has sent troops and ships to protect U.S. installations in Liberia but says it will not intervene militarily to end the conflict. The agreement on a Liberian meeting to end the war was being arranged between both rebel factions and a Doe envoy, said government sources in Banjul. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Taylor and rival rebel leader Prince Johnson were expected to attend talks Monday in Banjul. Nigerian and Guinean troops, meanwhile, are mobilizing in Freetown, Sierra Leone, with soldiers from Gambia, Ghana, Sierra Leone and Togo forming a force to exceed 2,500 men. The international force is charged with ending the civil war that has killed about 5,000 people, most of them civilians. Taylor's rebels had evacuated most foreigners _ but not scores of Guineans and Nigerians _ from Monrovia's battlefront in an 18-vehicle convoy on Wednesday. Woewiyu said Nigeria and Guinea, whose leaders are friends of Doe, are trying to use the West African force as a cover to get troops into Liberia to bolster the besieged president. Johnson controls most of the capital and Taylor the rest of this country of 2.3 million people. But Doe has refused to leave the presidential mansion, which is protected by government troops. Insurgents of Taylor's National Patriotic Front invaded from Ivory Coast on Dec. 24 to oust what they called the corrupt government of President Doe. Fighting between Taylor, a former Doe aide accused of embezzlement, and a splinter group led by former army officer Johnson has prolonged the conflict. The war has become a tribal conflict with rebels killing civilians of Doe's Krahn tribe and Mandingos accused of supporting him. Soldiers have slaughtered people of the Gio and Mano tribes, to which most rebels belong.

DOC.HEAD: Day 9 of Deliberations in Jogger Trial
DOC.TEXT: Jurors in the Central Park jogger case listened today to the testimony of the mother of one of three teen-agers charged in the brutal gang rape that left the runner near death. Jurors in their ninth days of deliberations listened to testimony given by Antron McCray's mother, Linda. Her tearful testimony included allegations that police investigators yelled at her son to induce him to say he had committed crimes. The panel on Thursday listened again to testimony given by McCray's father, Bobby, who testified that he encouraged his son to admit to things he did not do under the impression he was working out a deal to hlep his son avoid being charged. Antron McCray had said in a videotaped statement that he kicked the jogger and feigned having sex with her. McCray's lawyer, Michael Joseph, said the jury request's to hear testimony from his client's parents indicated that at least one person and possibly more were questioning whether the statements were taken properly. McCray, 16, Raymond Santana, 15, and Yusef Salaam, 16, are accused of raping and trying to kill the jogger on her nightly run in Central Park on April 19, 1989. In addition to the attack on the female runner, the three are also charged with attacking two male joggers in the park that night. The other charges against the youths include sexual abuse, riot, assault and robbery. Earlier Thursday, the jury reheard graphic testimony about the jogger's condition after the attack. She was taken to Metropolitan Hospital in a coma, with severe skull and facial fractures and three-fourths of her blood gone. The jogger eventually recovered and returned to her job as a Wall Street investment banker, but she testified that she still suffers from impaired balance, vision and smell. She said she doesn't remember the attack.

DOC.HEAD: Woman in Catholic Sex Scandal Says She Married Archbishop
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, Vicki Long, ...' to CORRECT Long claims to have been romantically involved with one other priest, sted two; SUBS penultimate graf `The Rev. ...' to clarify she denies having sexual relationship with 2nd priest.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AX1
DOC.TEXT: The woman at the heart of a clerical sex scandal claims she was married to former Atlanta Roman Catholic Archbishop Eugene Marino, and her lawyer says they were trying to have a baby. Vicki Long, who also claims to have been romantically involved with one other priest, spoke publicly Thursday for the first time since Marino's resignation in July as the nation's highest-ranking black Roman Catholic. Gloria Allred, charged at a news conference that church officials eager to split up the couple tried to convince Ms. Long that Marino is insane. A spokesman for Marino denied the charges and said the church does not believe Ms. Long and Marino were married. ``We are making no claims whatsoever that the archbishop was insane. We never have made such claims,'' the Rev. Peter Dora said. ``Archbishop Marino has made it clear that there was no marriage ceremony or vows and that he is not or never was married to Vicki Long.'' Marino, 56, resigned earlier this summer because of his two-year involvement with Ms. Long. Though Catholic priests take lifelong vows of celibacy, church officials acknowledge that the couple had an ``intimate relationship.'' Ms. Long said the relationship was not simply an affair. ``Archbishop Marino and I exchanged marriage vows in December (1988) and I have considered myself to be married to him since that time,'' she said, reading from a statement. Ms. Long, 27, of Riverdale did not answer questions at the news conference. She said the church supported her financially but damaged her relationship with Marino. ``I believe that people who are trusted by the archbishop and who benefited from that trust have now turned against him,'' she said. ``I encourage Archbishop Marino to be strong, to know that I still love him and that I stand by him.'' The archbishop ``seduced her, married her, lived with her as husband and wife and now has been taken away from her by her church,'' Ms. Allred said. The two ``spent almost every night together when he was in town'' and dated openly, Ms. Allred said. At the height of the romance, the couple tried to have a child, the lawyer said. In December 1988 Marino performed a wedding ceremony in which the two exchanged rings, the lawyer said. Ms. Allred said whether the marriage was legal will be ``determined at a later point,'' and she refused to say whether a marriage certificate had been filed. After Marino went into seclusion, ``he was calling Vicki six or seven times a day and telling her that the church was placing considerable pressure on him to resign and trying to convince him that he was sick and crazy,'' Ms. Allred said. Two persons close to Marino disputed Ms. Long's contention that she and the former archbishop spent significant amounts of time together. ``The week before he left, he worked 103 hours, and I was with him all the time,'' said Gerard O'Connor, Marino's administrative assistant and chauffeur. ``I never saw them together.'' Marino's housemate for about a year until May, the Rev. Don Kenny, director of vocations for the archdiocese, said he never saw Ms. Long in the house and that Marino stayed at the house virtually every night he was in town. Bishop James P. Lyke, acting administrator of the archdiocese, on Thursday denied a report by TV station WAGA that Marino, who church officials said was admitted to a psychiatric hospital a week before, had overdosed on pills and was under a suicide watch at St. Vincent's Hospital in Harrison, N.Y. Approached at his hospital room Thursday by a reporter from The Atlanta Constitution, Marino said he had no comment. The Rev. Michael Woods of Sandy Springs also resigned because of ``intimate'' ties to Ms. Long, but she denied she had a sexual relationship with Woods. She has filed a lawsuit against the church claiming the Rev. Donal Keohane, formerly of Columbus, fathered her 4-year-old daughter. Blood tests proved Keohane was not the father but the church is paying child support.

DOC.HEAD: US-Iraq Diplomacy: No Decorum in Mideast Crisis
DOC.TEXT: ``There's been a minimum of conviviality, I can assure you.'' One U.S. official used those words to sum up the trying times of the handful of American diplomats who deal directly with Iraqi authorities these days. Presidents Bush and Saddam Hussein have accused each other of lying but at least are able to exchange the insults at long distance. American and Iraqi diplomats don't have that luxury. For example, the officer in charge of the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad, Joseph Wilson, or a stand-in, goes to the Iraqi Foreign Ministry several times a day on behalf of the 3,000 Americans stranded in Kuwait and Iraq. He always comes back empty-handed. Less frequently, Iraq's ambassador to Washington, Mohammed Mashiq al-Mashat, is summoned to the 6th floor State Department office that deals with the Persian Gulf issue. ``He sits upstairs and tells us he doesn't know and then comes downstairs (to the press) and denies everything,'' said one official, articulating a widely shared frustration among U.S. diplomats. Al-Mashat's meetings at the State Department usually are ``short and heated,'' said another official. The Iraqi envoy was unavailable to give his account of the sessions. Wilson, aside from his discussions at the Foreign Ministry, also has been checking in with more than 30 Americans detained under armed guard at the Hotel Rashid in Baghdad, keeping them apprised of developments. Wilson, making his rounds in 100 degree plus heat, has yet to bring them good news. On Friday, the situation for the Americans may have taken an ominous turn with reports they had been moved. For the first time, embassy officials were unable to visit with them. As the U.S.-Iraqi military confrontation mounts, a six-year American effort to cultivate Baghdad is looking like one of the more futile diplomatic exercises of the past decade. Starting with the normalization of relations in November 1984, the United States has tried to woo the Iraqis through expanded trade and other ties. Since the events of Aug. 2, when Iraq invaded Kuwait, diplomats like Wilson have been left to pick up the pieces. At each meeting with Iraqi authorities, U.S. diplomats have stated in the clearest terms the U.S. demand that Iraq allow the stranded Americans to leave. As officials describe it, the Iraqi explanations for their actions have been increasingly unconvincing. More and more, the Americans look like pawns in the war of nerves between the two governments. Saddam's actions, according to some analysts, suggest that he sees the Americans on his turf as insurance against an all-out U.S. military attack. That he regards the Americans as bargaining chips seemed more evident on Thursday when Iraqi military authorities ordered all 2,500 Americans in Kuwait to report to a downtown hotel in Kuwait City. The order has been widely ignored. The Iraqis generally have given contradictory accounts of what they have in mind for the Americans. Al-Mashat has said the Americans will be free to leave ``in due course'' but other envoys have said flatly the Americans will be forced to stay put until the current crisis ends. In Baghdad, Iraqi Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs Nazir Hamdoon has been citing bureaucratic delays in explaining why the Americans have not been allowed to leave. ``We have told them that Iraqi credibility has been severely strained,'' one American official said.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Gives First Public Look at New Stealth Attack Aircraft
DOC.TEXT: The Navy today released the first artist's drawing of its A-12 Avenger attack airplane, the latest in a family of aircraft with stealth radar-evading technology. The plane, now under development, is designed as a bomber to replace the A-6E Intruder, which has been the Navy's main attack aircraft for the past 27 years. No details were provided on the exact dimensions and other features of the previously secret Avenger, which resembles a manta ray. The Avenger is designed to penetrate sophisticated missiles defenses to deliver bombs with exceptional accuracy against fixed and mobile targets on land and sea. The aircraft is in the full-scale development stage under a $4.78 billion contract held jointly by McDonnell Douglas Corp. and General Dynamics Corp. No estimate was given of the full cost of the program, but it has been reported that extended production could cost as much as $55 billion. The Navy said it plans to buy 620 of the planes. Money for testing and evaluating the first six Avengers is in the current Pentagon budget. The plane is named after the World War II attack aircraft that was the first such plane with radar.

DOC.HEAD: Part of Yosemite Park Slated to Open Today After Fires
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with fires in Yosemite 95-100 percent contained, fresh quote from park spokesman. Picks up 8th graf pvs, `Two other...'.
DOC.TEXT: Rangers cleared the way for the return of visitors to a section of Yosemite National Park today more than a week after the park was closed by forest fires for the first time in its 100-year history. Overall in California, crews mopped up after major blazes that scorched more than 400 square miles statewide. In Idaho and Washington, firefighters corralled stubborn fires that erupted after a rash of lightning storms. California state firefighter Kenneth E. Enslow, 20, was to be buried today. He suffered head injuries while fighting a blaze in the Mendocino National Forest. Sections of Yosemite served by Tioga Pass Road, a highway across the Sierra Nevada, were to open at midday today for the first time since Aug. 9. The park's most popular destination, Yosemite Valley, will probably not reopen until Monday, rangers said. ``They've got to mop up and make sure they're completely out and winds don't start up again,'' said National Park Service spokesman Mark Rabenstein. ``The fire crew actually touches the ground to make sure it is out.'' By this morning, California firefighters had virtually surrounded most of the major fires among the 1,300 that broke out since Aug. 3. ``The siege is winding down, but it's definitely not over. We still have a lot of firefighters on the lines and a lot of mop-up to do,'' said California Department of Forestry spokeswoman Karen Terrill. In Yosemite, 23,576 acres of timber land have burned. Of the two biggest fires in the 757,000-acre park, one was 100 percent contained this morning by fire lines, the other 95 percent contained, Rabenstein said. Two other Northern California fires that charred more than 144,000 acres of timber and brush were declared 90 percent contained Thursday night. The wave of fires burned nearly 262,000 acres, or about 409 square miles statewide, and destroyed 127 structures. There have been 37,532 recorded lightning strikes since Aug. 3. The cost of battling the blazes, with 15,500 firefighters involved, was estimated at $45 million. In Washington, cooling weather helped firefighters contain the state's largest wildfire, a 604-acre blaze in the rugged Cascade Mountain wilderness, said Corky Broaddus, spokeswoman for Wenatchee National Forest. In Idaho, 250 reinforcements joined the fight against a 1,500-acre fire in Boise National Forest. Air tankers pounded the blaze with chemical retardant, and authorities said the blaze could be contained by Sunday evening. The arrival of cooler temperatures and a rainstorm with only a limited amount of lightning overnight aided firefighters in the state, they said. In Alabama, a 50-acre forest fire forced the evacuation of 10 houses near Lillian and sent four firefighters on loan from Florida to a Pensacola, Fla. hospital with heat exhaustion.

DOC.HEAD: Education Secretary Says Students Who Don't Speak English Not Ready To Learn
DOC.TEXT: Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos told educators from this Texas-Mexico border area today that students who do not speak English are not ready to learn, and drew swift criticism. Cavazos, speaking to about 1,500 Laredo principals and teachers, urged them to get parents more involved in education and to make sure students have a command of English. ``Parental involvement and language competency are basic,'' Cavazos said. ``If that child cannot speak English the first day of school, that child is not ready to learn.'' In a panel discussion afterward, South Texas superintendents took issue with Cavazos' statement about language. ``The comment that we heard this morning that students who are not speaking English are not ready to learn is a disabling comment,'' Robert Zamora, superintendent of the La Joya school district, said to rousing applause. Zamora said students are capable of learning in other languages. Cavazos, a native of South Texas and former president of Texas Tech University, said he supports bilingual education, but said its goal should be to move the students into speaking English. Young people cannot take full advantage of all opportunities in the United States without speaking English, he said. Cavazos said the Bush administration favors giving educators more freedom because that helps ensure parental involvement and language competency. Throughout his speech, Cavazos emphasized his remarks referred to national education, not specifically to Laredo or Texas. That said, Cavazos again stated his position that spending more money is not the answer to education problems. He said how money is spent is more important. Earlier this year, Cavazos came under fire from some state lawmakers when he made that statement in a speech to the Texas Legislature, which was grappling with school finance reform. Cavazos today mentioned the Texas finance dilemma. ``Here in Texas, much of the attention has been on school finance, and there have been some inequities,'' he said. Later today, Cavazos was to cross the border to Nuevo Laredo to sign a first-ever binational education agreement with Mexico.

DOC.HEAD: Local Review Beginning in 1990 Census
DOC.TEXT: Local officials across the country are beginning to receive preliminary housing counts, the Census Bureau reports. Official population numbers won't be issued until at least the end of the year, though preliminary ones will be sent to state officials within a few weeks. The early housing reports are designed to allow local governments to challenge the Bureau's findings, pointing out areas where homes and people may have been missed, officials said. The census got under way in March with the mailing of nearly 100 million forms. In recent weeks workers have been going door-to-door to try to count people who were missed in the first phase. Sending the preliminary count to local officials does not mean that the effort is complete, Census Director Barbara Everitt Bryant said. The figures are open to challenge and workers will be sent out to double-check areas where officials question the totals. In addition to sending housing counts to city, county and town officials, preliminary population counts will be sent to state governors, state redistricting officials and members of Congress who has requested the information.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Eager to Relearn `Lost Talent' for Market Regulation
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Justice Minister V.F. Yakovlev said at the close of a week-long visit Friday that he looks forward to continued discussions on legal regulation of economic markets. ``We have simply lost the talent for market regulation and we have to relearn all this,'' Yakovlev said during a joint news conference with Attorney General Dick Thornburgh. The meetings resulted from similar sessions last October in Moscow when the two agreed to a regular exchange of information on legislation and judicial decisions regarding topics such as individual rights, the environment, organized crime, drug trafficking, trade and immigration. Thornburgh and Yakovlev signed another joint statement Friday agreeing to continue the discussions and expand them to include consumer protection, civil litigation, civil rights matters and federalism. In addition, they agreed to study development of a bilateral arrangement to help each other on civil and criminal cases as well as the formal establishment of working groups to address annually the administration of justice issues. As part of the U.S. exchange of legislative actions, Thornburgh said he had presented to the Soviets a Russian-language summary of the recently passed civil rights law, the Americans With Disabilities Act. Yakovlev said his country has made great advances in the last 18 months in establishing a separation of powers with individual executive, legislative and judicial branches similar to what exists in the United States. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, as part of perestroika, has expressed interest in developing a legal system that relies on due process rather than arbitrary decisions of bureaucrats. ``This is a very difficult process we're engaged in,'' Yakovlev said through a translator, but added later that development of such separate branches of government ``is becoming a reality in the U.S.S.R.'' Of particular interest to the Soviets meeting here was ``the details of the interaction between the three powers'' in the United States. Although the discussions didn't focus on particular legal cases, Yakovlev said he had heard about the savings and loan crisis in this country. Thornburgh commented, ``To have an S&L crisis, you have to have S&Ls first.'' ``We do have them,'' responded Yakovlev, ``perhaps not as well developed as in the United States.'' ``That kind of development you don't need,'' quipped Thornburgh. One aspect of the U.S. system that particularly interested the Soviets was the community services program that attempts to mediate disputes between people before they come into court. ``This is something we never had heard about before,'' Yakovlev said. ``These things are like terra incognita to us.''

DOC.HEAD: Roofer Finds Old Newspaper Where He Put It 45 Years Ago
DOC.TEXT: Marion Smith was putting a new roof on Howard Payne University's Mims Auditorium in May 1945 when he was distracted by newsboys yelling, ``Extra!'' on the street below. Smith was 18 and about to be drafted for service in World War II. What he found when he climbed down changed his life and set into motion what became a reunion of sorts earlier this week. The bold headline on the Brownwood Bulletin screamed ``Nazis Quit,'' and it was followed by a slightly smaller head: ``Unconditional Surrender Ends War in Europe.'' Smith went back on the roof, laid the paper down and placed shingles over it. ``I remember thinking that if and when the roof was redone, someone would find the newspaper,'' he said. Smith was recently given the job of reroofing the auditorium, and he found the old newspaper. ``The funny thing is that it wasn't where I had remembered putting it,'' he said. He said the discovery thrilled the roofing crew. ``It also pleased me to know that at 63, I'm still roofing,'' Smith said.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors Mull Case of Crew Charged with Flying While Intoxicated
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 2 grafs to UPDATE with jury finished for the day, to resume Monday. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `In giving...'.
DOC.TEXT: Jurors weighing the fate of three former pilots accused of flying a jetliner while under the influence of alcohol have instructions not to reach their verdicts solely on blood-alcohol content. The jury met for more than five hours Thursday and for three hours today in the case, the U.S. Justice Department's first prosecution under a 1988 federal law prohibiting operation of a passenger jet while under the influence of alcohol. Jurors were to resume deliberations Monday. In giving the jury the case, U.S. District Judge James Rosenbaum pointed out that there is ``no set standard as to the quantity of alcohol a person must consume before a person is regarded as being under the influence of alcohol.'' He set this definition for being under the influence: ``When a person is so affected by an alcoholic beverage that the person does not possess that clearness of intellect and control of himself as he otherwise would.'' The offense carries up to 15 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. The legal limit for driving a car in many states is .10 percent, but federal law does not specify an illegal blood-alcohol content for pilots. In tests, the Northwest Airlines pilots had blood-alcohol readings of 0.06 percent, 0.08 percent and, for the captain, 0.13 percent. Since the trial opened July 25, defense attorneys have argued that the pilots were not impaired, and that the proof is that the 40-minute Boeing 727 flight from Fargo, N.D., to the Twin Cities on March 8 was flawless. The pilots were arrested at Minneapolis-St. Paul Airport after a lumber salesman had reported to the Federal Aviation Administration that the pilots had been drinking in a bar outside Fargo at least six hours before the flight left with 91 passengers. First officer Robert Kirchner and flight engineer Joseph Balzer said they shared beer from at least six pitchers the night before the scheduled 6 a.m. flight. Captain Norman Lyle Prouse said he drank 15 to 20 rum and colas. A waitress said Balzer and Kirchner left about 10:30 p.m. and Prouse about 11:30 p.m. ``You don't have to find that they were totally smashed, just that they were under the influence,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Elizabeth de la Vega told the jury. A toxicologist estimated in-flight blood-alcohol levels for Kirchner and Balzer to be equal to about three beers each. Prouse had the equivalent of about eight mixed drinks in his system at takeoff, the toxicologist said. ``At those levels the defendants were under the influence of alcohol,'' de la Vega said. Prouse, 51, of Conyers, Ga., Kirchner, 36, of Highland Ranch, Colo., and Balzer, 35, of Antioch, Tenn., testified they were not impaired on the flight. Prouse, an alcoholic, said 35 years of drinking have given him a high tolerance for alcohol. Northwest fired the pilots for violating its 12-hour prohibition against drinking before flying, and the FAA has revoked their licenses.

DOC.HEAD: For the Call that Won't Wait, Town Installs Lavatory Phones
DOC.TEXT: Borough Manager Ed Treat thinks he has the solution for busy borough workers afraid to answer nature's call because a telephone might ring in their absence. He installed phones in the restrooms. It cost $500 to install the two lines _ one for men and one for women. But Treat saw the phones as necessary so people in this community of 3,200 in east-central Pennsylvania wouldn't think their borough, police and water department offices were empty. ``Sometimes two lines are ringing at the same time,'' he said. ``We're understaffed. People want to know if we're there.'' ``Some people are reluctant to use the phones,'' Treat admitted. ``But I use them. Nobody can see me in there.''

DOC.HEAD: Seven Arrested In Poison Gas Plant Case
DOC.TEXT: Police have arrested seven people, including an intelligence agent, in connection with the alleged delivery of a deadly poison gas plant to Iraq, a prosecutor said Friday. The arrests come as U.S. and other troops deploy in the Persian Gulf, braced for a possible chemical weapons attack from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's forces. Saddam has used chemical weapons in the past against Iranian troops and Iraq's own Kurdish minority. Prosecutor Friedrich Hoffmann in Darmstadt identified one of those arrested as a man employed by the West German foreign intelligence service in Iraq. He was identified only as Al Kadhi. Hoffmann said the arrests were the result of several years of investigation. The security policy spokesman for the Free Democrats, Olaf Feldmann, called for tightening of export laws in light of the developments. The Free Democrats are one of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's coalition partners. West German officials were embarrassed by an earlier chemical weapons scandal. Starting in December 1988, there were disclosures of widespread West German involvement in constructing one, and possibly two, chemical weapons plants for Libya. The latest arrests stemmed from violations of West German export laws, Hoffmann said. Those laws limit and in many cases ban the sale or delivery of weapons of destruction to areas of conflict, such as the Middle East. He said among those arrested were employees of the Pilot Plant company in Dreieich, a Darmstadt suburb 12 miles south of Frankfurt; workers in the export section of the Preussag company in Hanover; and from the Walter Engineering Trading company in Hamburg. Hoffmann stressed that the accusations of illegal shipments to Iraq were directed at individuals, not at the companies. The West German news magazine Der Spiegel reported Monday that dozens of German firms had helped Iraq produce rockets, chemical weapons and ``military nuclear technology.'' The report came in the midst of the crisis set off by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and followed threats by Iraq to attack Israel with chemical weapons if Iraq is attacked. According to the Spiegel report, Al Kadhi worked for the West German foreign intelligence in Iraq, where he was arrested by Iraqi officials and sentenced to death for spying several years ago. Werner Berghof, press spokesman for the West German intelligence service, said it was against agency policy to comment on personnel matters, such as its relationship with Al Kadhi. Berghof, reached by telephone at agency headquarters in Munich, repeated an earlier assertion that the service was not indirectly or directly involved with the transfer to Iraq of technology or products needed to make poison gas. The Spiegel report said West German President Richard von Weizsaecker interceded with Iraq for clemency for Al Kadhi. Following a visit by Genscher in 1987 for talks with the Iraqi leader, Al Kadhi's sentence was reduced to life in prison. A short time later, Al Kadhi, whom Spiegel described as of German-Iraqi descent, arrived in West Germany. The 51-year-old Al Kadhi began working with the Walter Trading company in Hamburg, from where he allegedly shipped material to Iraq, the magazine said. The material, which the magazine said was shipped to Iraq via Turkey, was allegedly used to contruct a gas plant in Iraq to produce mustard and other deadly chemical agents. The report did not say exactly when the materials for the plant were shipped. The Hamburger Morgenpost newspaper said that Iraq paid $10 million for the plant. Quoting a former employee of the Walter Engineering Trading company in Hamburg, the newspaper also said the plant could have gone into production at the beginning of this year.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Proposes Foreign Ownership of Enterprises
DOC.TEXT: The government has submitted a bill to parliament that would allow foreign companies to become sole owners of new enterprises in the Soviet Union, Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov said Friday. It would be the first time in at least 60 years that foreigners have been allowed to wholly own businesses here. Under current law, foreign companies must join with Soviet firms in joint ventures. ``It is impossible to move toward a market economy while the country is isolated from the world economy,'' Ryzhkov said in remarks carried by the official Tass news agency. ``One can no longer rely on joint ventures alone.'' Tass quoted a senior official of the State Foreign Economic Commission, who asked to remain anonymous, as saying the bill would encourage foreign investment by granting substantial benefits for joint ventures in which the share of foreign capital exceeds 30 percent. In a speech Friday, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said the main cause of the nation's economic crisis was ``the pervasive monopoly and domination of state property.'' ``We should carry out privatization, but do this within the framework of our choice,'' he said. Ryzhkov also appealed for the ``consolidation of efforts'' to move toward a market economy. The government is preparing a program for such a transition. A separate 12-member panel is developing a blueprint for moving toward a market economy. That panel was appointed by Gorbachev and Boris N. Yeltsin, president of the Soviet Union's largest republic, Russia. Yeltsin on Thursday criticized Ryzhkov and accused him of duplicating the commission's work by developing a parallel economic plan. He also said that if both plans are presented to the Soviet parliament, Russia would adopt its own plan. But Tass said Ryzhkov noted that his government began developing a plan at parliament's request. He expressed surprise that the Gorbachev-Yeltsin commission was developing an alternative program, but said his government would be willing to use everything valuable developed by the commission. If they disagree about how to proceed toward a market, ``that may have unpredictable consequences for the entire union,'' Ryzhkov warned. He also responded to Yeltsin's comment that ``the people do not trust the country's government.'' ``Yeltsin is right in one thing: No government will be able to work without the people's trust,'' Ryzhkov said. ``If Yeltsin's opinion turns out to be true, the government will have to quit.'' He said he was convinced that the plan developed by the government would be completed on schedule and submitted to parliament for approval.

DOC.HEAD: US Deployments to Gulf Go Beyond Purely Defensive Potential
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf area, code-named Desert Shield to suggest its defensive intent, is adding stealth fighter-bombers, Marine amphibious assault units and other forces normally used for offense. ``There's a very substantial offensive capability in that area now,'' said Joshua Epstein, a defense analyst at the Brookings Institution, a private research organization. He said the addition serves two purposes: to help dissuade Saddam Hussein from sending his army into Saudi Arabia, and to reassure the nervous Saudis. The clearest sign of a shift toward offensive capabilities was the departure Thursday from Langley Air Force Base, Va., of F-117A stealth fighter-bombers. The planes, which saw their first combat action during December's invasion of Panama, are designed to penetrate heavily defended areas to attack targets. In Iraq they could hit supply depots or key oil installations. Military sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said plans called for sending 22 of the radar-evading fighter-bombers to the Persian Gulf area. Additional signs of a shift toward offense: _President Bush on Thursday ordered U.S. naval forces in the gulf region to begin ``intercepting'' commercial shipping to and from Iraq and Kuwait to enforce UN economic sanctions against Iraq. The orders allow the Navy to use force against ships if necessary. _An armada of Marine Corps amphibious assault ships is heading for the Persian Gulf. The seaborne units, equipped with amphibious tracked vehicles that can travel on land at speeds up to 50 mph, are designed for offensive as well as defensive operations. They are supported by a variety of aircraft, including the F-A18 Hornet, a ground attack airplane also capable of air-to-air combat. _The Air Force said B-52 bombers have been sent overseas since the start of the gulf crisis. B-52s conducted massive bombing raids in the Vietnam war. Also moved to within striking range of Iraq are U.S. F-111 long-range bombers in Turkey. _The Marines are sending in 45,000 of their finest and deploying A6-E Intruder bombers used in the U.S. bombing of Libya in 1986. Among other weaponry the Marines are taking to Saudi Arabia: more than 100 M1 battle tanks and more than 150 fixed-wing aircraft, including Harrier vertical takeoff planes used for light attack missions and close air support of ground troops. Rear Adm. Steve Clarey told an American press pool in Saudi Arabia on Friday that the Marines will take up defensive positions but will be ready ``to defend as far forward as they can'' in the event Iraq's army attacks Saudi Arabia. ``We certainly have assault capability,'' he said. ``This is a mechanized capability with tanks, armored vehicles, light armored vehicles. They have that mobility and they have that firepower to go anywhere they're told to go.'' Bush on Aug. 8 described Desert Shield as ``purely defensive.'' He has said his ultimate goal was to get the Iraqi army out of Kuwait, which it captured on Aug. 2, and to restore the Kuwaiti royal family to power. While emphasizing an economic embargo, he has not ruled out the use of U.S. force to try to dislodge the Iraqi army. Asked whether the F-117A stealth planes had any defensive role in the gulf crisis, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said Thursday, ``I think this gets into the question of deterrence. Some of those forces that you have there would be deterrent by their mere presence.'' Williams was referring to the idea that by sending offensive weaponry and large numbers of troops to Saudi Arabia, the Bush administration could deter Saddam from launching an attack out of fear that his own country would suffer a devastating counterattack. Spicing the U.S. military deployments with several prominent offensive weapons such as the stealth fighter-bomber is part of an apparent Bush strategy to gain the psychological upper hand. The Iraqis are playing equally hard at the intimidation game. Saddam has strongly suggested he would use his chemical weapons against U.S. troops if provoked. Pentagon sources say contingency plans call for putting as many as 250,000 air, sea and ground forces in and around Saudi Arabia, depending on Iraq's military moves.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Deficit Hits Seven-Year Low, But Oil Seen as Future Problem
DOC.TEXT: Record exports and shrinking oil imports helped push the nation's merchandise trade deficit to a seven-year low in June, the government reported Friday. But analysts saw oil as a problem in coming months because of the Mideast crisis. The economists suggested that while exports may remain strong in the second half of the year, oil is likely to drive up the cost of imports as price hikes from the Middle East crisis are added to the bill. The Commerce Department said the deficit dropped to $5.07 billion, a 34.7 percent decline from May's $7.77 billion and the lowest since a $3.96 billion imbalance was posted in June 1983. Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher, who had joined many analysts earlier in predicting the deficit would drop below $100 million this year, was quick to note the record $34.29 billion in exports. ``While the month-to-month figures can be erratic, the strong, positive trend indicates increasing U.S. export competitiveness in the world marketplace,'' he said. The 4.6 percent increase in exports included not only $500 million in aircraft shipments, but gains in other business capital equipment as well. Bruce Steinberg, senior economist at Merrill Lynch, called the exports ``good news'' since that sector ``was the only part of the economy with any strength'' in June. Gilbert Benz, an economist at the Swiss Bank Corp. in New York, said the figure will boost the second-quarter gross national product which earlier had been estimated to have grown a meager 1.2 percent. ``It's the one component that might help us skate around a recession in the second half of the year,'' Benz said. Imports declined 2.9 percent to $39.37 billion, helped by a $631 million drop in oil costs. Oil imports in June fell 14.6 percent to $3.69 billion. Americans imported 8.40 million barrels a day, down from 8.95 billion in May. The deficit is the difference between imports and exports and, for the first six months, was running at an annual rate of $91.62 billion. If it ended the year at that pace, it would be the first deficit since 1983 under $100 billion. Analysts were quick, however, to toss in the Middle East caveat. ``The Persian Gulf crisis is already generating oil price increases which likely will contribute to a worsening trade deficit in the future,'' said John Howard, international finance director at the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. ``Unfortunately, the merchandise trade deficit has nowhere to go but up,'' suggested Barry K. Rogstad, president of the American Business Council. ``The price of oil is today nearly double what it was in June. Had the current price prevailed in June, the deficit would have widened by $3.5 billion.'' Indeed, Commerce said the average price per barrel in June was $14.64, compared with Thursday's $27.36 a barrel cost for the benchmark West Texas crude. As usual, the biggest deficit was with Japan, a $3.1 billion imbalance, up from a $3.0 billion deficit in May. Other deficits included Taiwan, $900 million; China, $800 million; Canada, $700 million; Brazil, $300 million; Korea, $200 million, and Hong Kong, $100 million. The United States posted a surplus with western Europe of $899 million.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinians Denounce Americans, Support Saddam
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Moslem worshipers chanted pro-Iraqi slogans and reportedly burned American flags after Friday noon prayers at Jerusalem's Al Aqsa Mosque, one of Islam's holiest sites. Riot police watched from rooftops but did not interfere. The crowd dispersed peacefully after half an hour. In the West Bank village of Beit Furik, reporters said about 400 Palestinians bearing the likenesses of PLO leader Yasser Arafat and Iraqi President Saddam Hussein chanted: ``Syrian President Hafez Assad and Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak are cowards for collaborating with the Americans!'' The demonstrations were the latest in a series of rallies in the occupied lands celebrating Saddam as the national savior of the Palestinians and condemning those Arab leaders joining the Western effort to stop Iraqi aggression. Both Egypt and Syria have denounced Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and sent troops to bolster the international force in Saudi Arabia. Saddam has always been liked by Palestinians for his aggressive stand toward the West, but his popularity began to soar after he said he would only pull out from Kuwait if the Israelis withdrew from the West Bank and Gaza Strip. About 10,000 worshipers attended noon prayers at Al Aqsa, which stands beside the Dome of the Rock Mosque on Haram a-Sharif, the site where Moslems believe the Prophet Mohammed ascended to heaven. The area is also venerated by the Jews as the site of the Jewish Temple. In his sermon, the Al Aqsa preacher sharply criticized Saudi Arabia for allowing American forces to land on its territory. ``The Arab leaders are giving Moslem lands to the Americans,'' he said. ``One day all Arab land will be in the hands of the Americans. This land is for Moslems and not for Americans.'' Saddam has tried to portray the gulf crisis as a jihad, or holy war, between Moslems and infidels. Mecca, Islam's holiest site, is in Saudi Arabia. Following the prayers, hundreds of worshipers carrying Palestinian and Islamic flags chanted ``With our soul, with our blood, we'll sacrifice for you, Saddam.'' Reporters were confined to a rooftop overlooking parts of Haram a-Sharif and could not see the Al Aqsa demonstrators. One of the protesters leaving the compound said American and Israeli flags were burned. The crowd responded by whistling and clapping, said the man, who would only give his first name, Jumma. Leaders of the anti-Israeli Palestinian uprising issued a leaflet condemning pro-Western Arab states and declaring the ``full support for the Iraqi people in confronting the imperialists.'' The leaflet, distributed throughout the occupied lands, set aside Saturday as a ``day of solidarity with Iraq through demonstrating and marching in every place in our land.'' The Israeli Peace Now movement condemned the Palestinian views in an ad placed in newspapers. ``We are disappointed by the enthusiastic Palestinian support for Saddam Hussein,'' the ad said. ``The path of Saddam Hussein is the path of violence, threats and war. Support for him is support for the resolution of disputes between nations through force.''

DOC.HEAD: Son Of Pakistan's Gen. Zia Blames Bhutto For His Death
DOC.TEXT: The son of Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq on Friday blamed ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto for the mysterious plane crash that killed his father two years ago, but he provided no proof. Ijaz ul-Haq called on the military-backed caretaker government that replaced Ms. Bhutto to open a new investigation into the crash on Aug. 17, 1988. It killed Zia, many of the country's top generals and U.S. Ambassador Arnold Raphael. Ms. Bhutto's own father, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, was overthrown by Zia in 1977 and hanged in 1979. She says Zia issued the execution order. The anniversary of Zia's death came less than two weeks after Ms. Bhutto's government was dismissed on charges of corruption, nepotism and ineptitude. Ms. Bhutto, who took power in November 1988, claims her ouster was a coup camouflaged by use of constitutional powers. A technical inquiry found the crash that killed Zia was sabotage, but a criminal investigation was never conducted. Ijaz, a 38-year-old banker, blamed Ms. Bhutto, her government and her Pakistan People's Party, saying that through ``criminal negligence'' it ``covered up any evidence.'' ``The former prime minister and her ministers actually ridiculed the tragedy, provided cover to the criminals and shut the door on any investigation,'' said Ijaz, speaking at a news conference following a brief memorial ceremony for his father. But he provided no evidence to support his claims. Neither Ms. Bhutto nor her spokesmen could be reached for comment, but they have dismissed similar allegations as baseless. Earlier, Ijaz promised to carry on Zia's dream of wielding an Islamic federation stretching from the Soviet Central Asian republics to western China. ``The dream is being fulfilled _ Pakistan, Afghanistan, Iran, Turkey,'' Ijaz told about 100,000 people who crowded onto the sprawling grounds of the Faisal Mosque and climbed its sloping roof and towering spires. ``A new movement, a new unity will start from here,'' Ijaz said. ``I swear by the grave of Zia ul-Haq.'' With the abrupt change of government and uncertainty over the future of democracy, many Pakistanis are remembering Zia's 11-year military rule, despite its harshness, in a more favorable light. Hundreds of people make the pilgrimage to Zia's grave daily. Elections are scheduled Oct. 24, but there has been speculation they will be postponed and that another round of military rule is in the works. The military has ruled Pakistan for more than half its 43-year history.

Here are the latest temperatures and weather conditions available for the Persian Gulf area, where U.S. troops are deployed:

DOC.HEAD: GOP Chairman's Brain Tumor Worsens
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts new graf 4 with White House reaction
DOC.TEXT: Doctors are ``uncertain but hopeful'' that renewed radiation treatment this week of Republican National Chairman Lee Atwater's brain tumor will halt its spread, a party official says. Doctors at George Washington University Hospital administered the treatment Wednesday after discovering that his tumor had worsened, according to a statement Thursday from GOP chief of staff Mary Matalin. ``Doctors are uncertain but hopeful of a positive response to the treatment,'' Ms. Matalin said. In Kennebunkport, Maine, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said President Bush is ``greatly concerned about Lee.'' The treatment was the first since Atwater, 39, received a radioactive implant April 3 at Montefiore Hospital in New York. He had been re-hospitalized Aug. 2 in Washington after running a fever. At the time, a GOP spokesman said ``the tumor is dying.'' But in the statement released Thursday, Ms. Matalin said: ``This week Lee underwent another diagnostic procedure at George Washington University Hospital under the supervision of Dr. Edward Laws, professor and chairman of neurosurgery at George Washington. ``Dr. Laws reported the biopsy `indicated tumor progression requiring additional treatment.''' Leslie Goodman, Atwater's press secretary, said Atwater was not in intensive care. She said she did not know additional details about the radiation treatment. Atwater remains ``alert, focused and as determined as ever to continue his battle,'' Ms. Matalin's statement said. Ms. Goodman said she did not know whether Atwater was able to walk or whether doctors had given a prognosis for his recovery. Atwater collapsed before a speech in March and received radiation treatment after doctors determined that his brain tumor was inoperable. He also has been receiving physical therapy. President Bush visited Atwater in the hospital last week. Charles Black, a Republican consultant and friend of Atwater, has been picked to be the party's chief spokesman during the chairman's illness.

DOC.HEAD: US Protests Iraqi Effort to Round Up Americans in Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new 10th graf, In fact... to UPDATE with State Department saying few Americans responded to Iraqi order, which not repeated today
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today protested attempts to move Americans trapped in Iraq or Kuwait ``against their will.'' The White House said Bush was considering a selective call-up of reserves to meet the military's needs for doctors and other specialists. U.S. ship commanders got orders to intercept all ships carrying goods to or from Iraq, but so far have not had to stop any vessels, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. The Pentagon has asked Bush to call up reserves and Fitzwater said, ``We'll try to keep this to the smallest possible.'' It is likely to be limited to calling up reservists who are doctors, cargo handlers and other specialists in short supply. U.S. officials are still trying to find out where the Iraqis have taken some 38 Americans removed from the Rashid Hotel in Baghdad, Fitzwater said. They are believed to have been taken to another hotel. ``Iraqi officials have told us they were safe, but have not given us any explanation as to why they were moved or where they are,'' the spokesman said. In Washington, the State Department reported U.S. diplomats had been prevented from entering another hotel, the Melia Monsour, to see if the Americans had been moved there. ``Clearly, we are very seriously concerned about the Americans,'' said State Department spokesman Richard Boucher. Boucher also reported that food available to Americans on open markets in Iraq and Kuwait was diminishing. On the 2,500 Americans trapped behind Iraqi lines in Kuwait, Fitzwater said, ``There are not signs that anyone has been rounded up in Kuwait, no signs of harassment.'' He said the Americans appeared to be ignoring an Iraqi call Thursday for Americans and other foreigners to gather in various hotels. In fact, the State Department said today only five Americans responded to the order, and when they got to the hotel they found no Iraqi officials. Boucher said the Iraqis did not repeat the demand today. On criticism from United Nations Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar that the United States may be overstepping its bounds in enforcing the naval blockage against Iraq, Fitzwater said, ``We obviously believe that Article 51 authorizes our intercept activities. We believe the U.N. understands that.'' Asked if the United States considered the moving of the Americans from the Rashid Hotel an act of provocation, Fitzwater said, ``We consider it a matter of serious concern.'' He said it is not known when Bush will decide whether to call up reserves. Fitzwater previously has noted that Bush has the authority to call up to 200,000 reserves for 180 days. But the spokesman said he did not expect ``any massive call-up.'' ``In recent years, Congress has allocated more and more of the support functions for the military to the reserve forces, so that you find a major aspect of our support in terms of cargo handlers and doctors and medical specialists and so forth are in the reserves,'' he said. ``The president has not made a decision on this yet, but he is looking at certain specialized categories that would be necessary to support the effort in the gulf,'' he said. Bush will return to the White House Sunday night and meet Monday morning with budget aides and Energy Secretary James Watkins. The session with Watkins is to discuss the impact of the Persian Gulf crisis on U.S. energy reserves. Bush will address the Veterans of Foreign War convention in Baltimore later Monday as previously planned. Bush, who put in a pre-dawn call to the White House situation room, said ``there was nothing new'' with the Americans in Kuwait. Asked what would happen if they were taken to Iraq, Bush said, ``I don't think anybody ought to be moved against their will in contravention of international law.'' He also said ``the Japanese were told that they cannot leave'' the country. Iraqi's ambassador to the United States, Mohamed Al-Mashat, today repeated his assurances that the Americans in Iraq and Kuwait wouldn't be harmed. Interviewed in ABC's ``Good Morning America,'' Al-Mashat said, ``I can assure you they are well treated and will be released in due time.'' Bush on Thursday signed the order instructing U.S. ship commanders in the Middle East to intercept ships carrying goods to or from Iraq or Kuwait, including shipments through Aqaba. ``To the maximum extent possible we will conduct operations without the use of force,'' the president's order said. A Pentagon source said earlier that those steps could include attempting to block the ship's passage or firing a warning shot across the bow. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney was bound for Riyadh today to visit American troops standing guard in the Saudi desert against a possible further thrust by Iraq's Saddam Hussein, whose troops overran Kuwait Aug. 2. The unprecedented deployment of U.S. military ground and air power in strategic areas of Saudi Arabia continued today with the unloading of tanks and other heavy equipment and arms. U.S. Marines are rapidly building to a force of 45,000 in the Middle East _ almost a quarter of their whole strength. Bush, after spending more than two hours with Jordan's King Hussein on Thursday, said, ``I can't say I am satisfied, but what I am is encouraged'' that Jordan intends to abide by the United Nations sanctions against Iraq. King Hussein's brother, Crown Prince Hassan, said on CBS ``This Morning'' that ``His majesty made it clear (to Bush) that we will adhere to the U.N. resolution.'' Pentagon sources said the Marines are building to a force of 45,000 to counter an Iraqi army now believed to have grown to 160,000 in overrun Kuwait. American military planners are preparing to put 250,000 soldiers on the ground if necessary. The U.S. Navy already has massed 27 ships, including three carriers, in the gulf, the nearby Arabian Sea and the Red Sea. The Pentagon put its first public price tag on Operation Desert Shield: nearly $1.2 billion for just the first 7{ weeks. The Pentagon said it could give no figure beyond Sept. 30 because the size and role of the U.S. forces ``are still evolving.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says he enjoys country music because it is ``real people singing real stories that we all can understand.'' In an essay in the September issue of Country America magazine entitled ``Why I Love Country Music,'' he says he hears a love for America in country lyrics. ``You can hear it in the line for the Lee Greenwood song that we all love: `And I'm proud to be an American, where at least I know I'm free . . .' '' Bush says. ``In a world where people everywhere are marching toward liberty and democracy, Lee's important message reminds us how blessed we are to be citizens of the country that stands as a model for so many others,'' he wrote. ``That's what country music comes down to: real people singing real stories that we can all understand.'' Bush has stereo speakers built into his desk in the White House office and says he listens to a Washington country music station. ``I find myself more relaxed with Reba (McEntire) coming over the airwaves,'' the president wrote. Country America magazine is published by the Des Moines-based Meredith Corp., which also publishes Better Homes and Gardens and Ladies' Homes Journal magazines.

Britain's Prince Charles, Princess Diana and their two sons ended a brief Spanish holiday Friday and flew home. The British holiday guests of Spain's King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia cruised in the waters of this Spanish Mediterranean archipelago aboard the Spanish royals' yacht, the Fortuna, during their stay. It was the third time in four years Charles, Diana and their two children, William and Henry, spent part of their summer holiday at the Spanish royals' Palma summer residence, Marivent Palace.

Mickey Rooney Jr. has endured some false starts in his career, but the autobiography he's writing and a couple of new country songs might give him break he's been hoping for. He remains cautious, even though his songs ``It Takes a Good Girl to Get Me'' and ``There's No Easy Way Out of This Love'' have been greeted enthusiastically by record companies in Nashville. ``The people there are very interested,'' he said, adding he expected to sign a recording deal in a few weeks. But he's quick to temper his optimism, citing past experiences. ``I've had eight record deals since I was a kid and it never went anywhere. I had no record company support,'' he said. The oldest of Mickey Rooney's 10 children, he resisted those who suggested he change his name to distance himself from his famous father. ``My father wanted me to change my name, but I like it,'' Rooney said. ``He loves me. He loves my career. But he hasn't been too thrilled about what doesn't happen with my career. ``This is a luxury trade, show business. If you hit, you're great. If you don't, it's horrible.''

The National Enquirer has asked a federal judge to dismiss a $12 million lawsuit filed by the father of model Marla Maples. The suit, filed against the tabloid by Stan Maples, is seeking damages for defamation, invasion of privacy and commercial appropriation as a result of an April 10 Enquirer article about his daughter's relationship with New York developer Donald Trump. In a motion filed this week in U.S. District Court in Rome, the Florida-based tabloid contends its article about Ms. Maples and her father did not defame Stan Maples or subject him to ``public hatred, contempt or ridicule.'' ``The statements and questions attributed to plaintiff would not be highly offensive to a reasonable person, even if they were false,'' according to the motion, asking for dismissal of the suit. It said the passages cited in Maples' complaint ``uniformly portray him as a concerned and supportive father.''

State and local law officers asked truck drivers to fall in behind buses carrying the New Kids on the Block and block as many as 85 cars trailing the rock 'n' roll sensations. The truckers fell in side-by-side on I-40 behind buses carrying the singers from a Thursday night concert in Nashville to a Friday night appearance in Knoxville. The drivers of the 18-wheelers, alerted by citizens band radios, formed a slow-moving roadblock, allowing the Boston group to speed forward. Police said fans had begun pulling their cars perilously close to the buses carrying the singers. ``The bus drivers were having a little trouble with fans darting in and out in front of them trying to get a look inside the buses,'' said Roane County sheriff's Deputy Dowell Isham. ``They weren't trying to wreck the buses or anything. They were just trying to get a glimpse inside.''

DOC.HEAD: Confrontations Between Federal Army, Croatian Police
DOC.TEXT: Federal army units moved into the streets of a town in Croatia today amid rising tension over plans to ban a referendum on Serb autonomy in the republic, the state news agency reported. The Tanjug news agency said the army took up positions in the Croatian town of Knin at 6:30 p.m. local time, less than 30 minutes after the mayor declared a ``state of war.'' Earlier, army jets intercepted three Croatian government helicopters and forced them to return to their bases, Tanjug reported. The army is dominated by Serbs, traditional rivals of Croatians. The unprecedented army moves in the air and in Knin followed requests for assistance in dealing with Interior Ministry armored vehicles heading toward the town of Obrovac, where large crowds had gathered. The news agency did not say who had asked for the army's help and what kind of assistance was requested. `In Obrovac and Benkovac, large crowds of citizens are in the streets, hindering and stoppic traffic,'' Tanjug said, citing a statement by the Croatian Interior Ministry. The news agency also reported that hundreds of Serbs living in Croatia, infuriated that authorities planned to ban an unofficial referendum on Serb autonomy within Croatia, broke into a police station in the town of Grachc. While the statement did not specify to which ethnic group the demonstrators in Obrovac and Benkovac belonged, they appeared to be Serbs angered by the ban. Croatian authorities earlier today vowed to prevent the unofficial referendum, saying it was aimed at undermining democratic reforms in Croatia. Leaders of the 400,000-strong Serb minority in western Croatia had been scheduled to start a two-week referendum Sunday in which Serbs were to choose whether they want some degree of self-government within Croatia. Serbia and Croatia have been traditional rivals since they were united within Yugoslavia in 1918. Serbs say hundreds of thousands of their compatriots were murdered in Croatia in World War II by Nazi-like Croatian nationalists. Serbs in Croatia claim they are being systematically discriminated against by what they allege are extremists in the Croatian Democratic Union, a center-right political party which last spring overwhelmingly won the first free elections in Croatia in over 50 years. The Serbs are strongly supported by the state-run media in neighboring Serbia, in which the Communist party has refused to hold western-style elections and has described the CDU government as ``fascist and racist.'' Croatian authorities have said the planned ballot is not legal because it is unclear who is organizing it and because Croats living in the Serbian region will be denied the right to participate. Croatia's new government advocates turning the Yugoslav federation into a loose association of semi-independent states in which national minorities would be guaranteed full political and national rights.

DOC.HEAD: Group of Americans and Britons Flee from Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Ms. McGhee...' with 1 graf to fix number of Americans. Pick up 6th pvs. `She said...'
DOC.TEXT: A group of nine foreigners, including three Americans, bolted across the Kuwaiti desert to this border town today in an effort to avoid an Iraqi order to gather at a downtown hotel. ``No one responded to the Iraqi call, as far as I know, but everyone is making a rush to get out of Kuwait,'' said Stephanie McGehee, an American stringer for The Associated Press who was in the group. Contact with Ms. McGehee was lost two days after the Aug. 2 invasion as the Iraqis gradually cut off all telephone and telex lines. On Thursday, Iraqi military authorities ordered Britons and Americans to assemble at Kuwait hotels, but then failed to turn up to meet them. There are 4,000 Britons and 2,500 Americans in Kuwait. Ms. McGehee, speaking from a telephone booth for only a couple of minutes at the Saudi border post of Khafji, said she escaped along with two other Americans, a Briton, a Canadian and four Indians. She said she had heard that only two Britons showed up at the Regency Palace hotel in response to the Iraqi order and were told, ``We have no room for you, stay in the ballroom.'' ``We believe it was all only an Iraqi show, but everyone is trying to get out,'' she said. The group included both men and women. Ms. McGehee said that in order to escape, she and the others had all dressed as Kuwaitis. Since she spoke Arabic she sat next to the driver. She carried the identity card of a Lebanese friend. ``As soon as we left the paved road, we ran into Iraqis and they said we had to go back,'' she said. ``We moved away and then took another turn through the desert sands and made a dash for it,'' she said. ``It was very, very terrifying,'' she added. McGehee identified the Canadian with her as Kathy McGregor. Other travelers who reached Khafji today said that a a Kuwaiti woman was shot in the foot in one of the latest convoys of escaping nationals. The travelers were quoted by friends in Bahrain as saying that the incident occurred when a convoy of 11 cars was crossing the border Thursday night. They said the Iraqis began shooting at the convoy as it sped across the border at Khafji. They did not know how the woman was injured.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian POWS Return Home, Iraqis Pull Back from Iran's Land
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: One thousand Iranian prisoners of war returned home to an ecstatic welcome Friday, part of the Iraqi campaign to settle the war with its eastern neighbor and focus on the escalating confrontation with the United States. Iraqi troops also started pulling back from the Iranian border. The first batch of prisoners arrived in the Iranian border town of Qasr-e-Shirin just after noon. ``We welcome your blessed arrival,'' said President Hashemi Rafsanjani in a message. Tehran radio called on all Iranians to go to their rooftops and together shout ``God is great!'' to give thanks. Tehran Television, monitored in Nicosia, showed hundreds of jubilant soldiers mingling with friends and relatives clamoring to embrace and kiss the freed prisoners. Men carrying boxes of sweets stuffed goodies into the mouths of the arriving POWs, the traditional Iranian manner of celebration. A shopkeeper broke down and wept with joy when asked how he felt. Another shopkeeper, asked why the shelves of his confectionary were empty, replied: ``People are happy, and I am happy. Today, we eat sweets.'' As the first batch of ex-prisoners arrived home, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said Tehran would repatriate an equal number of Iraqi prisoners. Tehran radio said the Iraqi POWs had been dispatched to the border to complete formalities. These include being interviewed individually by the Red Cross to guarantee no prisoner is sent home against his will. Iraq said it would release all Iranian POWs in daily batches of 1,000 starting Friday, the most the Red Cross can cope with at one time. No deadline was set for the completion of the release. The Red Cross has registered about 19,000 Iranian POWs in Iraq and about 50,000 Iraqis in Iran. The United Nations estimates that both sides actually hold more than 100,000. Tehran Radio interrupted its normal morning program to announce that Iraqi troops had begun withdrawing from Iranian territory. It said Iranian officers monitoring the development reported the withdrawal got under way at 5 a.m. Morteza Sarmadi, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, reported 10 hours later that the Iraqis had withdrawn from 164 square miles of Iranian territory in the Ilam region, on the central sector of the Iran-Iraq border. Iran says Iraq occupies more than 773 square miles of its land. The United Nations says the size of the occupied area is half of that. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has said he hopes to complete within five days the withdrawal from territories occupied in the closing weeks of the Iran-Iraq war. A U.N.-sponsored cease-fire took effect Aug. 20, 1988, but peace talks stalled immediately afterward over disagreement on various issues, particularly control of the Shatt-al-Arab waterway along the countries' border. On Wednesday, Saddam agreed to drop demands for full control of the waterway and made other concessions to Iran to end their differences. He promised to begin withdrawing troops from occupied territory in Iran and returning POWs. Neutralizing the border with Iran allows Saddam to focus on the conflict with the United States and its Western and Arab allies, triggered by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The withdrawal from Iranian territory frees some 300,000 Iraqi troops who could then be sent south to Kuwait to face the military buildup in Saudi Arabia. Iran has criticized Iraq's occupation and annexation of Kuwait. But it also has attacked the U.S.-led Western intervention in the Persian Gulf. In a prayer sermon in Tehran on Friday, Iran's former chief justice, Ayatollah Musavi Ardebili, called on Saddam to defuse the crisis before a confrontation with the United States. ``If you (Saddam) withdraw, the imperialists will have no pretext for starting a war. ``If the United States gets a foothold in the region, it will never leave,'' Ardebili said in the sermon broadcast by Tehran Radio. Before now, repatriations of POWs had been largely limited to the sick, wounded or aged. Angelo Gnaedinger, the Red Cross chief delegate for the Middle East, said a total of 969 Iranians and 1,343 Iraqis had been repatriated before Friday. He said both sides were known to hold more of these hardship cases.

DOC.HEAD: Sam Donaldson Goofs, Draws Warning in Gulf Reportage
DOC.TEXT: ABC's Sam Donaldson accidentally violated Pentagon rules by specifying the location of an air base used by U.S. warplanes in Saudi Arabia and got a warning from his U.S military escort, an ABC official said Friday. ``He made an honest mistake,'' ABC News vice president Robert Murphy said. It occurred Wednesday night during his live ``Nightline'' report from the air base in Saudi Arabia. ABC said a tape of his report, with the location bleeped out, aired Thursday night on ``PrimeTime Live,'' which Donaldson co-anchors with Diane Sawyer. Under U.S. press pool rules for print and broadcast reporters in Saudi Arabia, no locations of military bases used by U.S. forces can be given in journalists' reports. Murphy said Donaldson, who went on ``Nightline'' shortly after arriving in Saudi Arabia, ``hadn't been briefed on the ground rules.'' After a warning from his military escort, Donaldson then was given a full tour of the military base, Murphy said. He said ABC got no complaints from the U.S. government. Donaldson told viewers Thursday night that he had ``made the mistake of saying exactly where I am, and it turns out that's a no-no, and so we had to bleep it out. It's not that this is such a secret location. . . . It's that the Saudis are so sensitive about the (U.S.) troops being here that they simply don't want the location published.''

DOC.HEAD: Secret Police Recruited Children as Informers, Paper Says
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's secret police recruited and paid 14-year-old children to spy and inform on dissident groups under the country's old Communist government, an East Berlin newspaper reported Friday. Der Morgen newspaper said that former secret police chief Erich Mielke personally ordered that ``operatives should be chosen from among the 14- and 15-year-olds,'' to spy on dissidents in East Germany. The newspaper cited a secret police document from the East German city of Leipzig. The secret police force, or Stasi as it was known, has been dismantled since the fall of the Communist government in last fall's revolution. According to reports emerging since then, one of every eight of the country's 16.1 million citizens worked at some point for the Stasi. Several high-ranking East German politicians were forced to resign from their posts following rumors or disclosures that they had worked for the dreaded Stasi. The most recent official accused of having close Stasi contacts is Martin Kirchner, secretary-general of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere's Christian Democratic Union party. Kirchner has been suspended from his post pending an investigation. He has denied reports he worked for the secret police over a 15-year period.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Government To Appeal Extradition of Doctor In Camarena Case
DOC.TEXT: Federal prosecutors said today they will appeal a judge's order that a doctor abducted in the Enrique Camarena murder case be returned to Mexico. A motion was filed for a stay pending appeal in the case of Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain, saying they believed the judge had committed ``several clear errors of law.'' The brief also said U.S. authorities would have ``virtually no chance'' of getting Alvarez back into custody if he is repatriated. However, U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie told prosecutors that the stay was unnecessary because they planned to file the appeal later in the day. He also set an Aug. 24 bail hearing for Alvarez. A week ago, Rafeedie ruled that the U.S. abducted Alvarez in violation of an extradition treaty with Mexico, that the kidnapping was an offense to Mexico's sovereignty, and that his court lacked jurisdiction to try the physician. Alvarez was charged with violent crimes in aid of racketeering, conspiracy, kidnap and murder in the slaying of Camarena, a U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agent who was killed in 1985. He is accused of administering drugs to keep Camarena, 31, alive while he was being tortured. The doctor, who faces a possible life prison term if convicted, was spirited out of Mexico in April, and the Mexican government strongly protested the action. In hearings on the issue, the DEA acknowledged it had paid $20,000 in DEA funds plus $6,000 a week in expenses to people who brought Alvarez to the United States to face charges.

DOC.HEAD: Sullivan Meets Bush in Effort To Move Civil Rights Bill
DOC.TEXT: Health Secretary Louis Sullivan, the only black in President Bush's Cabinet, journeyed to Bush's oceanfront home Friday for talks aimed at averting a veto of a major civil rights bill. Sullivan and Constance Newman, director of the Office of Personnel Management, met with Bush, White House chief of staff John Sununu and counsel C. Boyden Gray to discuss the job discrimination bill that passed the House and Senate in the last month. Reporters were not allowed onto Bush's Walker's Point compound to question Sullivan or the other participants in the meeting. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater reiterated Bush's threat to veto the legislation unless it is changed in a House-Senate conference. The Bush administration has said the bill would force employers to resort to hiring quotas for minorities in order to avoid job discrimination suits. Sununu has spearheaded repeated efforts to negotiate a compromise with Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., and civil rights groups backing the Democratic-crafted measure, which would reverse a string of five Supreme Court rulings in 1989 that narrowed protection against job bias. Civil rights groups deny that the bill would force quotas, and they have been unwilling to accept the White House's ``corrective'' language. ``We are still hopeful that we can get some changes,'' said Fitzwater. But he added, ``There's no change in our veto threat.'' While Sullivan has not been involved in those negotiations, Fitzwater said that in addition to running a huge government department with major civil rights responsibilities, Sullivan ``is a black man and has very strong personal interests and concerns in this bill.'' He called Sullivan ``a leader in the civil rights movement for many years (who) feels very strongly about this issue and he simply wants to talk to the president about it.'' Newman is also one of Bush's highest ranking black appointees. In Washington, Campbell Gardett, a spokesman for the Department of Health and Human Services, said Sullivan was searching for ways ``to get Congress and the black community to work together to get legislation the president can sign.'' Gardett said Sullivan shares Bush's concern about quotas. The House approved the bill 272-154 on Aug. 3 and the Senate passed the measure 65-34 on July 18. Both were less than the two-thirds margin needed to override a veto. Congress has failed to override any of the 13 vetoes Bush has cast.

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll in Six Days Of Black Factional Fighting Reaches 183
LaserPhotos JOH2, JOH4, JOH5, JOH7
DOC.TEXT: Roving bands with makeshift shields, guns and spears rampaged through Soweto and other black townships Friday, clashing in sporadic battles that have killed 183 people in six days. Police in armored vehicles rolled over streets barricaded with boulders and burning cars. They used tear gas to disperse shouting mobs and fired shotguns at combatants fleeing through narrow shantytown streets. Police said at least 31 people had been killed and 217 injured in two days of savage hand-to-hand fighting in Soweto, South Africa's largest black township. The fighting pits Zulu supporters of the conservative Inkatha movement against mostly Xhosa members of the African National Congress, led by Nelson Mandela. The ANC accused the government's security forces of plotting to use the Zulu-based Inkatha party to stir up tribal rivalry in the townships. More than 5,000 people have died in fighting between Inkatha and ANC supporters in the eastern Natal province in the past five years. Their bloody conflict spread to the township of Thokoza east of Johannesburg on Sunday, and later to four more areas, including Soweto, southwest of Johannesburg. Groups of up to 100 armed men waved sticks, knives, bayonets and shields fashioned of trash-can lids as they marched. Most of the combatants were Zulu migrant workers from the Inkatha stronghold of Natal, or Xhosa residents of Soweto. On Friday afternoon, hundreds of Inkatha supporters moved out of their compounds and stood on the railway track with guns and sticks, waiting for the trains to bring black commuters home from Johannesburg, the South African Press Association reported.
