Police and residents also reported looting, random gasoline-bombing of homes and indiscriminate gang attacks on individuals. A family of six, including a 5-month-old baby and three other children, were badly burned when someone threw a firebomb into their shack in Kagiso township, north of Soweto. The ANC said state security forces, in collusion with Inkatha, were trying to ``spread a climate of fear and terror'' in towns that are ANC strongholds. ``They want to provoke a mass backlash among blacks and whites in support of tough repressive measures by the government in order to undermine the process towards peace,'' the ANC statement said. The spreading unrest led to an unscheduled meeting Thursday between President F.W. de Klerk and Mandela, who have been holding discussions to clear the way for formal negotiations on ending white minority rule. Inkatha President Mangosuthu Buthelezi said ANC supporters ``frequently insult, denigrate and attack Inkatha members on the trains, in the buses, and other places.'' He said that had sparked the conflict. Buthelezi, making his statement in Ulundi in Natal province, said Inkatha was committed to democracy and opposed to violence. But he said ``until respect for one another is observed, it will be difficult to obtain peace.'' Many Zulus involved in the fighting said they would not accept Mandela and the ANC as a future government. Free-lance photographer Sabastian Balic described one killing at a migrant workers hostel in Soweto on Friday. ``When I arrived, there was a crowd around outside the dormitory. They were poking through the windows with these spikes trying to get this person to come out,'' he said. The crowd eventually broke the lock and kicked the door in, he said. ``I could hear sounds of fighting inside. The person broke free and ran outside. He must have made 50 yards before he was brought down,'' said Balic. ``Then the crowd laid into him with axes. I would say a blow with an axe to the head killed him. It opened up his skull. The people were just stabbing and hitting him on the ground for three minutes.'' When it was over, the Zulu crowd searched the man's pockets, found his identity book and his name _ Sandile Gugudu. ``He's a Xhosa,'' they said. Then a police van drove by, and they scattered.

DOC.HEAD: Council Expresses Concern Over Foreigners
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with council expressing concern over foreigners. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `His comments...'
DOC.TEXT: The Security Council today expressed ``concern and anxiety'' over the fate of foreigners trapped in Kuwait and Iraq and asked the secretary-general to take all necessary steps to help them. The statement was made by Council President Aurel Dragos Munteanu of Romania after a closed council session. ``The members of the council express their concern and anxiety over the situation of foreign nationals in Kuwait and Iraq and ask the secretary-general to take all steps considered appropriate,'' he said. Several thousand Americans and Britons were ordered to hotels in Kuwait on Thursday and at least 35 Americans were removed today from a hotel in Baghdad. Earlier today, a three-country committee, in closed session, discussed an interim report on compliance with an embargo on Iraq by more than 40 of the 159 member states. It also was expected to discuss violations and enforcement, but was not expected to call for a U.N. blockade at this time. The committee, headed by Finland and joined by Colombia and Canada, also was consulting with the rest of the 15-member council. Perez deany blockade has to have U.N. Security Council approval. ``As long as that is not the case,'' he said, ``any intervention, whatever the country, would not be in accordance with the letter or spirit of the United Nations Charter.'' Perez de Cuellar, a Peruvian, returned to his homeland on a visit. The Soviet Union has been pressing for a broader U.N. role in controlling regional conflicts and has said it would only participate in a military operation in the Persian Gulf under the U.N. flag. The sanctions were imposed following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Though the embargo is intended to be binding, U.N. members voted no specific measures to enforce it. Thirty-two of the 159 U.N. members had filed compliance reports by Wednesday, and all were honoring the sanctions. A full U.N. report is due by the end of the month. Jordan, which allows its port of Aqaba to supply Iraq, did not respond. Jordanian diplomats declined comment. The five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council met privately Thursday to discuss Iraq's order that Americans and Britons in Kuwait assemble in hotels. Iraq ordered the gathering because of what they called unspecified threats. In Washington, the U.S. State Department said it was protesting the order. Diplomats had said the five permanent Security Council members _ the United States, Britain, China, France and the Soviet Union _ also were discussing the situation of those already detained. Also Thursday, Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi, in a letter to the U.N. chief, called for an emergency Security Council meeting in Geneva to remove U.S. forces. There was no decision on a meeting, but consultations were under way. Gadhafi said U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia should be replaced by Arab League forces and U.S. naval personnel in the Persian Gulf should be replaced by U.N. forces.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Union to Send Troops if Security Council Votes for Military Action
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UDPATE with Gorbachev comment, background on Soviet military aid to Iraq. Pick up 9th graf pvs, `Shevardnadze said..'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze said Friday the Soviet Union would send troops to the Persian Gulf if the United Nations calls for a multinational military force to solve the Persian Gulf crisis. Shevardnadze's statement took the Soviet Union one step closer to agreement with the United States on an armed, united front to halt Iraqi aggression. It could put American and Soviet soldiers on the same side for the first time since World War II. Meanwhile, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev accused former ally Iraq of ``treachery'' in using Soviet-provided weapons to seize Kuwait. He called for international cooperation to keep the conflict from becoming ``a full-scale military confrontation.'' The Soviet Union was Iraq's major weapons supplier for more than a decade, providing it with modern jet fighters and licensing an entire factory for building its top-of-the-line T-72 tank. Moscow halted arms shipments to Iraq the day after the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and joined the United States in a call for a worldwide arms embargo. However, the Kremlin refused to join a U.S.-led multinational military force against the Iraqis. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh said last week that if the United Nations approved a military force, ``then we would think about it and would take our own sovereign decision about what to do.'' ``At this stage, we do not consider the possibilty of participating in either the international force or naval blockade,'' the spokesman said then. On Friday, correspondents crowded around Shevardnadze at a press conference to ask if Soviet troops would be sent to the gulf. ``Yes, if there is a decision by the Security Council,'' Shevardnadze said. He would not say how the Soviet Union would vote on such a proposal in the U.N. Security Council. But he said, ``If the Soviet Union votes for that decision, it certainly will take part.'' Gorbachev told Soviet military men in Odessa on Friday that Iraqi use of Soviet weapons to attack Kuwait gave the Soviet Union a special responsibility to solve the crisis. ``We have witnessed an act of treachery,'' he said in remarks carried by the official news agency Tass. Iraq's action was ``a violation of everything the world community now pins its hopes on as it seeks to put civilization on the tracks of peaceful development,'' Gorbachev said. ``The use of force to redraw borders, especially in order to annex a sovereign country, threatens a perilous chain reaction endangering the whole world community,'' said the Soviet president. Shevardnadze said he was discussing the gulf crisis with Secretary of State James A. Baker III almost daily by telephone. The Soviet foreign minister laid heavy emphasis on U.S.-Soviet agreement to revive a U.N. military staff committee under the jurisdiction of the Security Council. American officials said earlier such a committee would coordinate the defense of the U.S., British, French and other warships in the gulf should they come under Iraqi fire. U.S. officials also have said the Soviet Union suggested the warships carry a U.N. flag. ``When this staff committee is created, the military should get together and determine what collective action is needed: Should force be used or not? That should be determined at an expert level _ what measures and what actions are needed,'' the foreign minister said. In answer to a Kuwaiti reporter's question on whether the Soviet Union would concede to Iraq's demand for closure of all embassies in Kuwait, Shevardnadze said he wants to avoid such action.

DOC.HEAD: Mubarak Urges Iraq To Compromise
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Hosni Mubarak said Friday there is still time to find a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf conflict and appealed to his Iraqi ``brothers'' to steer away from confrontation and bloodshed. Mubarak has spearheaded Arab diplomatic efforts to defuse the crisis, which began with Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``I made so many contacts to several mediators to find a peaceful solution,'' the Egyptian president told reporters. ``I reached nothing.'' But he said he would continue his efforts and hoped others would do the same. ``I am calling our brothers in Iraq to respond to the voice of peace, to avoid confrontation and bloodshed which may take place in case of being obstinate,'' said Mubarak, who spoke after a meeting on the crisis with three European Community foreign ministers. The Egyptian leader mediated contacts between Iraq and Kuwait just before the invasion and gathered Arab League nations for an emergency summit eight days after Iraq's conquest of Kuwait. Mubarak has been the target of Saddam's wrath for sending Egyptian troops to join the multinational force deployed to defend Saudi Arabia from further Iraqi aggression. He was the first Arab leader to send a contingent. But Mubarak said he hoped to avoid a military clash with Iraq. ``We must not reach the edge of the abyss. War and its consequences are very bad, so let's give a chance to whoever can mediate,'' he said. Mubarak said Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi had sent him a message urging that foreign forces in the region come under a United Nations umbrella. He said he agreed a U.N.-headed force would be better than separate forces. Mubarak said the Egyptian force in Saudi Arabia would probably number no more than 2,000 men and said it, like Moroccan and Syrian contingents, would come under Saudi command. But figures from military sources had placed the number of Egyptian troops already deployed at about 4,000, and another group is scheduled to leave next week. The Arab troops were deployed after Arab League nations held their summit in Cairo a week ago. A dozen of the 20 members present voted to send troops. Mubarak was asked about U.S. moves to monitor shipping in the Gulf of Aqaba and the Red Sea, both adjacent to Egypt, which Washington says is necessary to enforce the U.N.-approved economic embargo against Iraq. ``I am with the international embargo,'' he said. ``It may put us in a position to avoid all confrontations.'' The Egyptian president said he hoped Saddam would act more speedily to settle the Kuwait conflict than he did in seeking peace with Iran. Eight years of fighting between Iraq and Iran ended in 1988. Saddam announced a peace initiative this week, and Iraq on Friday began pulling out of Iranian territory it had seized and repatriating prisoners of war. ``I hope with all my heart that ... we don't have to wait so many years for Kuwait,'' Mubarak said.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantic Skies Crowded with Military Planes
With AM-Gulf-US Forces, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS NOTE: U.S. air power heading to the Middle East is turning sections of the Atlantic sky into crowded midair service stations. National Writer Fred Bayles was aboard an Air Force tanker to view the busy refueling operations off the East Coast.

This usually lonely patch of air is suddenly buzzing with the hum of faraway crisis. The ocean below is empty except for the shadows of clouds. Five miles above, the sky is filled with planes. Echelons of thirsty dart-shaped fighters chase matronly tanker planes loaded with fuel. Radio channels crackle with curt instructions. The deployment of U.S. military air power to the Middle East has turned the skies off the East Coast into busy service station stops, where fighters hook up to transport planes for a fill-up at 530 mph. ``There's considerably increased activity in tanking operations,'' said Lt. Col. George Peck, a spokesman for the Strategic Air Command, which operates the Air Force tankers. ``It is an integral part of this operation.'' The increased activity was obvious from aboard a KC-135 tanker based at the Plattsburgh, N.Y., Air Force Base which took part in a refueling operation Thursday. The tanker was one of 16 from Plattsburgh, Griffiss Air Force Base in New York and Pease Air Force Base in New Hampshire that formed an air bridge across the empty ocean for a flight of 24 F-4 Phantom fighters. Pairs of tankers, called cells, could be seen spread across the horizon. Each plane was followed by three fighters. ``It was a big operation,'' said the captain who piloted the tanker, a military cousin of the old 707 airliner. ``Three cells were operating pretty close in the same area and we were hearing on the radio of other cells coming up. It was a continuous operation.'' The captain, whose name was not disclosed for security reasons, said it was an example of what the tankers can do. ``That's what our job is. We can get where we need to be, unload the gas and let the bombers, fighters and cargo airplanes go off and do their mission,'' she said. The increase in military air activity has had only slight impact on commercial air travel. ``There have been minor delays in some traffic, but not any big disruptions,'' said Jo Ann Sloane, a spokeswoman for the Federal Aviation Administration. The tankers in Thursday's mission traveled across New England to a point 190 miles east of Cape Cod where they rendezvoused with the day's ``receivers,'' a squadron of fighters taking off from Seymour Johnson Air Force Base in North Carolina. The F-4G Phantoms, based at George Air Force Base outside Los Angeles, were ``Wild Weasels,'' specially equipped with electronics and armaments for the dangerous task of disrupting and destroying enemy radar and anti-aircraft installations. The gleaming white missiles under their wings highlighted the fact this was no practice mission. Inside the hot, noisy tanker, which flew its first mission before any of its crew was born, an airman first class took her position in the tail of the plane, lying on a platform to maneuver the 20-foot refueling boom into a port just behind the fighter's canopy. She nursed the jet into place with brief directions over the radio and a series of red, green and white directional signals flashing from the tanker's belly. ``With this many planes operating in the area, you don't want to have a lot of chatter,'' she explained. She repeated the delicate maneuvers for more than an hour, loading three fighters with 900 gallons of JP-4 fuel, then adding another 400 gallons to top off the fighters' already emptying fuel tanks. The process, which covered another 560 miles to the east, is known in Air Force slang as ``dragging them across the pond.'' When the job was done, the KC-135, turned for home. Other tankers were waiting to escort the fighters the rest of the way across the ocean. ``Good journey,'' said the boom operator as the fighters veered away. Their mission done, there was little emotion over the prospect of where the fighters were headed. ``We train to do this all the time,'' said the boom operator. ``But it makes it a little more urgent when it's the real thing.''

DOC.HEAD: Miss America Pageant Orders Investigation of Texas Pageant Chief
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT to Hall sted Hand.
DOC.TEXT: The Miss America Pageant Organization ordered Texas pageant officials to investigate allegations that their longtime chief executive has a history of making lewd remarks to contestants, a newspaper reported today. The Press said the pageant organization's executive director, Leonard Horn, ordered the Miss Texas Scholarship Pageant to investigate B. Don Magness after Life magazine quoted Magness as yelling, ``Come on in, sluts!'' to a group of Miss Texas contestants, and with making other sexually pointed comments. Texas Pageant President Barry Hall hopes to deliver the results of the investigation to Horn by the end of next week, the newspaper reported. Magness did not return telephone calls to his office earlier this week and again this morning. He told the magazine he made sexy comments only in jest. The 70th edition of the pageant will be held Sept. 8. In Magness' 20 years at the helm of the Texas pageants, its winner has been among the 10 finalists in Atlantic City 17 times. Jonna Fitzgerald, Miss Texas 1985, told the newspaper she modeled swimsuits alone for Magness and alleged he was ``always making dirty jokes, lewd comments, comments about my figure.'' ``Suffice it to say that the Miss America organization will not accept, nor will it tolerate,'' the types of conduct attributed to Magness, Horn said in a statement. Horn and his board of directors have the power to strip the Miss America franchise from any pageant. The Texas pageant is the nation's biggest. In the Life article, Magness said he acts the part of a ``dirty old man'' to loosen up the women and have fun, but said he has never touched any contestant in an improper way. ``While I make an attempt at appearing to be a dirty old man, I make double that attempt to make sure I'm not,'' Magness told the magazine. ``Some of the girls just need to be dirtied up a little,'' he was quoted as saying. ``It's just a continuance of their education.''

DOC.HEAD: 367-Pound Woman Proves She Is Not Too Fat Too Drive
DOC.TEXT: A woman who was required to take a driving test because authorities thought she might be too fat to drive safely proved Friday she can operate a car even though she weighs 367 pounds. Using a borrowed, beat-up Dodge Aspen that she had only driven once, Regina Guy passed the test with more than 75 people watching from a distance. A state motor vehicle hearing examiner ordered Friday morning that she pass the test or forfeit her license. ``That's it. I'm legal, guys,'' Guy said afterward. But she remained angry that she had to prove that her weight doesn't stop her from being a safe driver. ``Fat people are human. We deserve equal treatment,'' said Guy, 25. ``Because of my size, I should not be discriminated against.'' The Baltimore woman's problems began July 13 when she was stopped because the lights were not working properly on another car she had borrowed from a friend. The officer wrote on his report to the Motor Vehicle Administration: ``Due to this person's obesity, she was unable to sit behind the wheel of the car.'' Guy was sitting in the center of the seat and was using her left hand and left foot to drive the car, the officer said. ``I feel that this driver should have special equipment on her car,'' the officer wrote. Guy denied she was sitting in the center of the seat or was driving abnormally. ``How could I sit in the center? I couldn't possible drive from the center,'' she said. Friday, Guy sat behind the wheel of the normally equipped car. She said she was unhappy that the officer was absent from the hearing Friday morning. ``I still would like a chance to face my accuser,'' she said. Several members of the National Association to Advance Fat Acceptance showed up to support Guy at the hearing. Among them: Peggy Williams, owner of the station wagon Guy was driving when she was stopped. ``It's not fair. It's just not fair,'' Williams said. ``Why is she being singled out to take a test when she did nothing to indicate she was a bad driver?'' Guy's lawyer, Christopher Brown, said it was a clear case of discrimination against fat people. ``The only reason she was singled out was because of her weight,'' he said. Williams said she can fit behind the wheel of her car even though she weighs 450 pounds, almost 100 pounds more than Guy. ``It's not a question of her not having enough room. She has to pull the seat closer than I do to drive,'' Williams said.

DOC.HEAD: Space Engineers Briefly Regain Contact With Magellan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with radio contact lost again, intermittent problems predicted until spacecraft reprogrammed from Earth. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `Wall said...'.
DOC.TEXT: NASA scientists rejoiced at ``pretty damn good'' test photos from the Magellan probe today but also grappled with communications difficulties as the spacecraft circled Venus. Fifteen hours after the spacecraft lost contact with Earth on Thursday evening, the signal was re-established. But the signal failed again at midday and was expected to continue to be a problem until scientists could send Magellan new instructions on how to properly aim at Earth, officials said. Meanwhile, project manager Tony Spear said the test pictures collected from the spacecraft's radar mapper before the problems developed had produced ``some raw images that looked pretty damn good.'' He said NASA will release the first pictures on Monday instead of waiting until September. Thursday's test returned far more pictures than expected, including several so-called ``noodles,'' or areas of the planet about 1,000 miles long by 15 miles wide, project scientist Steve Saunders said. The pictures show ``lava flows and faults and fractures and cinder cones with craters in the top,'' Saunders said. Scientists at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory were concerned when they did not hear from Magellan as expected at 8:32 p.m. Thursday. But they stressed that the spacecraft is loaded with computer programs that automatically help it find Earth if contact is lost. Originally, scientists had expected that the outage would continue until this evening. But late this morning, as scientists were were conducting a news conference about the problem, Magellan manager Steve Wall rushed in with word that NASA's Deep Space Network station at Goldstone, Calif., had re-established contact with the spacecraft and locked onto its signal. ``It is Magellan,'' Wall said. ``The spacecraft looks healthy.'' The second loss of contact a short time afterward was not entirely unexpected, Spear said. Scientists now expect the spacecraft to be in and out of touch until controllers can send it new instructions on how to properly aim at Earth, he said. However, the second signal loss blunted some of the sense of relief at hearing from Magellan after the overnight silence. Wall said engineers had been out of contact with the spacecraft Thursday night as it fixed on two stars, a procedure Magellan routinely performs to make sure it is pointed properly. NASA should have heard from Magellan at 8:32 p.m. PDT Thursday when this ``star calibration'' was completed, but ``we did not re-establish contact,'' JPL spokesman Jim Doyle said. The last previous radio contact with the craft had been at Deep Space Network stations at Goldstone and in Australia. ``The assumption is that after it made a star calibration, it looked at the wrong star and then couldn't point back to Earth accurately,'' Doyle said. ``Then, the contact was lost.'' Project officials believe the spacecraft detected an unknown onboard problem and entered a protective ``safing mode'' in which it orients itself toward the sun so its solar array will continue to receive power and find a guide star, said Doyle. From that position, it was programmed to automatically start a routine of locating the sun, then searching for Earth, Wall said. The problem with Magellan comes in the wake of NASA's troubles with the flawed Hubble Space Telescope and with hydrogen fuel leaks that temporarily grounded the space shuttle fleet. Magellan's formal mission to map the surface of Venus is supposed to start Aug. 29. Contact was lost after Magellan started a two-day test meant to make sure the spaceship's radar can make pictures of Venus and to adjust the radar waves so the pictures are focused, said lab official Ed Sherry. Venus, the second planet from the sun, is covered by thick clouds that prevent optical cameras from seeing its rugged landscape. Magellan's $744 million mission will use radar to penetrate the clouds, then collect the reflected waves to make the best maps and pictures yet of Earth's nearest planetary neighbor. The spacecraft was launched from the shuttle Atlantis 15 months ago and went into orbit around Venus a week ago after a roundabout 948-million-mile journey. At least 20 U.S. and Soviet spacecraft have visited Venus, including some that landed and photographed a small area of landscape. Magellan will yield a global map. Its radar was designed to distinguish surface features as small as two football fields, a level of detail 10 times better than in pictures made by radar on two Soviet spacecraft that were launched in 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Sets Speed Record on Golf Course
DOC.TEXT: President Bush broke his own speed record on the Cape Arundel Golf Course Friday. Bush, teeing it up at 6:54 a.m., hustled around the par-69 links course in 1:42, clipping nine minutes off his previous best. ``I understand he set a new aerobic golf record,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. There were only three in the presidential party: club pro Ken Raynor Jr. and Bush's eldest son, George W. Bush, part-owner of the Texas Rangers. ``We could set a record today,'' Bush predicted as he set out on the dew-soaked, deserted course. He even provided a sports monologue for the reporters out to watch him. ``Silence on the first tee,'' decreed the president as he stepped up to address the ball. ``Mr. Smooth is back. They're all wondering how this one will go.'' Whack! ``... And he's not happy. Or is it up, Kenny?'' said Bush, turning to his pro for a second opinion on the drive. By the time he got out of his golf cart on the 18th green, Bush was not a happy man, speed record or no. ``I'm out of it. I did lousy,'' he confessed. It was his fourth golf outing since arriving in Maine Aug. 10 on a vacation interrupted repeatedly by the gulf crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Leaders of `Maple City' Debate Tree Requirement
DOC.TEXT: If a city councilman has his way, the town that calls itself ``Maple City'' will prune back or uproot entirely a 90-year-old law requiring property owners to plant trees. The law, passed in 1900 by the city council, assesses residents $500 fines if they don't plant trees in front of their houses. But Councilman Tom Stump says that's going out on a limb. ``It's not the city's business to demand that people plant trees on their property,'' Stump said at a recent meeting. At the least, the fine should be trimmed to $50, he said. Stump favors a separate ordinance that would recommend residents plant certain trees, such as cottonwoods, elms and gingkos. The council will debate the proposal Sept. 4. Mayor Mike Puro supports the current law, saying the trees that line the streets of this northern Indiana city of 20,000 improve the quality of life.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Revises Food Price Hikes Upward for 1990, Partly Blames Oil Crunch
With AM-Economy Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Consumer food prices are going up 5 percent to 7 percent this year, sharply more than had been predicted and perhaps slightly because of the Mideast oil crunch, the Agriculture Department said Friday. The new forecast compared with the 3 percent to 5 percent price hike the department has been predicting for 1990 since December. Double-digit price gains in the first half of this year for fresh fruits, pork, eggs and dairy products, along with ``uncertainties about future energy prices,'' are mostly to blame for the upward revision, said the department's Economic Research Service. ``However, most of the year's price increases probably took place in the first half,'' the agency said. ``Gains in the second half are expected to be more modest.'' But the report added that this assumes most of the evolving oil price shock will take until next year to spill over into the grocery store. Retail food prices rose an average of 5.8 percent in 1989, the sharpest year-to-year increase since 1981. Much of that gain was fallout from the 1988 drought that hit much of the nation. One USDA official who spoke only on condition of anonymity said that without the Mideast crisis and rising energy costs, the new food price estimate for 1990 would have been in the range of 5 percent to 6 percent. Thus, the official said, an allowance of only one percentage point was made at the upper end of the estimate to allow for higher oil prices. Further, the source said, some department analysts had wanted to hold the new 1990 food price increase to less than what was decided. Most felt the oil pinch is not going to hit this year, the source said. In its official report, the agency said rising oil prices will increase the cost of growing, processing, packaging and distributing food. ``Because of the rapidly changing situation, it's unclear how much and how fast the increases will ripple through food prices,'' the report said. ``While food transportation costs probably will rise in coming months, rail costs are partly shielded from short-term movements in fuel prices,'' the report said. ``Railroads often hold significant inventories of diesel fuel and buy fuel under long-term contracts.'' For river barges, lower freight rates this summer were said to ``suggest competitive pressures'' will hold down rate increases this fall when the big crops of corn, soybeans and other commodities head for market. The report, which is prepared with a team of analysts and reviewers within the USDA agency, said the general trade embargo will ``significantly cut'' food supplies going to Iraq. About one-fourth its caloric food needs come from imports. ``Last year, about one-fourth of Iraq's agricultural imports came from the United States,'' the report said. ``Other major suppliers have been Australia, Canada, the EC (European Community) and Turkey.'' The agency said Iraq's agricultural import situation is being monitored and that ``implications for trade are being reevaluated'' on a continuous basis.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Announces Cuts in Local Aid, Retirement Fund
DOC.TEXT: Gov. L. Douglas Wilder said Friday he plans to cut $333 million in local aid to help balance the state budget, and those reductions also will hurt school budgets. ``Although we tried to address the revenue shortfall without affecting aid to public education, it was not possible to do so,'' Wilder said. ``If our revenue situation improves, I will seek to mitigate these funding reductions as the first order of business,'' he told a meeting of the Senate Finance, House Finance and House Appropriations committees. Wilder's budget director, Karen Washabau, said other cuts the governor has proposed in state agency spending could cause 400 to 1,500 layoffs. But she said those figures were tentative until the governor decides Sept. 14 what specific cuts he will order. Wilder elaborated on cuts he announced during a statewide televised address Thursday night to deal with a projected $1.4 billion shortfall in the state's $26 billion, 1990-92 budget, which is biennial. He said tax collections are expected to drop because of a slowing state economy. Wilder said he will also order $375 million in state agency cuts, withdraw a 2 percent state employee raise set for December and use more than $300 million in lottery profits for operating expenses instead of building projects. He also proposed cutting $11 million in state money for private museums and attractions and eliminating several minor agencies that are budgeted for about $5 million. Several legislators complained they were left out of the budget-cutting plans and still had little idea how Wilder's proposed cuts will affect services in their districts. Legislators and education officials also said they were worried that cuts in school aid could force localities to raise taxes. State Sen. Stanley C. Walker, a former Norfolk School Board member, said local school budgets are already tight. ``The least setback can be meaningful and knock you down,'' he said. Local governments ``are going to feel the pinch,'' said Madeline Wade, president of the Virginia Education Association, a teachers' organization. ``They're going to have to make some tough decisions.''

DOC.HEAD: Navy Offers Limited Peek at New Stealth Plane
LaserPhoto WX9
DOC.TEXT: The Navy partially lifted the veil of secrecy Friday from the A-12 Avenger stealth airplane being developed as its main bomber for the early 21st century. The Navy released an artist's drawing of the plane, which resembles a manta ray. The two air intakes on the front underside of the aircraft look a bit like gills. No details were provided on the exact dimensions and other features of the previously secret aircraft. The Avenger is the latest in a family of new-generation aircraft with stealth radar-evading technology. The Air Force is building B-2 stealth long-range bombers and F-117A stealth fighter-bombers using composite materials that limit radar reflections. The Avenger is still under development and has been the subject of growing controversy since the Navy announced earlier this year that it was a year behind schedule. Both the Defense Department and the Navy are investigating the delays, which came to light after the department had completed a months-long review of its main aircraft programs. The problems reportedly involve the manufacture of stealth composite materials. Last April Defense Secretary Dick Cheney announced he was cutting the Avenger purchase from 858 to 620 planes. The Navy has not released figures on the Avenger's full production cost but it has been reported that it could reach $55 billion. The plane currently is in the full-scale development phase under a $4.78 billion Navy contract held jointly by McDonnell Douglas Corp. and General Dynamics Corp. The Bush administration requested $1.1 billion in production funds for the Avenger for the 1991 budget year starting Oct. 1, but both the House and Senate have eliminated all production funds for the coming year, leaving only a smaller amount for research and development. The Avenger is designed to replace the A-6E Intruder, which has been the Navy's main attack aircraft for 27 years. The Avenger is designed to penetrate sophisticated missiles defenses to deliver bombs with exceptional accuracy against fixed and mobile targets on land and sea. Its automated electronic cockpit includes a missile warning system for early identification of enemy radars and guided missiles. The plane is named after the World War II Avenger that was the first attack aircraft with radar.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's effort to settle its war with neighboring Iran appears aimed at securing the use of an Iranian pipeline to ``punch a hole'' in the U.S.-enforced U.N. embargo on its oil exports, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee said Friday. ``There's something very strange about this deal ...,'' said Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis. ``It is essentially a total capitulation by Iraq. There's a possibility we're going to see Iran exporting Iraqi oil.'' A United Nations Security Council resolution prohibiting trade with Iraq over its conquest of Kuwait has stopped the flow of nearly 4.5 million barrels of oil daily from the two countries, sending world oil prices up by more than $7 a barrel. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein offered Wednesday to withdraw all troops from Iranian territory and give up control of the Shatt-al-Arab waterway along the countries' border. Aspin said he is ``skeptical that the real reason'' Saddam made the offer was to free Iraqi troops to face a U.S. military buildup in Saudi Arabia. ``That deal has to go down very hard with his military,'' Aspin said of Saddam. ``They just spent eight years fighting a war there. We're looking at some other deal here. I'm concerned he's going to try to use it to punch a hole in the sanctions and embargo.'' One of Iraq's major pipelines runs along the Shatt-al-Arab. And at one point, it is just five miles and across the waterway from Iranian pipelines leading into and out of its refinery at Abadan. Although the Abadan refinery was blown up in the Iran-Iraq war, Iran still moves much of its 3 million barrels of oil a day through the pipeline to its main export terminal at Kharg Island. ``It would only take a matter of weeks'' to bridge the two pipelines, Aspin said. He estimated that Iraq could then move as much as 1 million barrels a day, or roughly more than one-third of its pre-embargo oil exports through the pipeline to Kharg Island. ``The secret of the potential success of the embargo and the sanctions is the oil,'' Aspin said. ``There might still be food and other things coming in from Jordan or Iran, but it's going to be limited unless you have the money to pay for them.''

DOC.HEAD: Feedlot Cattle Inventories Up 4 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Cattle being fed for the slaughter market as of Aug.1 in the seven major beef states totaled 7 million head, up 4 percent from a year ago but down 2 percent from two years ago, the Agriculture Department said Friday. Feedlot inventories were up from a year earlier in Arizona, Iowa and Texas. But they declined in California, Colorado and Kansas. They held steady in Nebraska. Marketings of ``fed'' cattle in July totaled 1.75 million head, up 3 percent from a year ago but 2 percent fewer than two years ago. The placement of new cattle and calves in fattening pens last month was reported at 1.52 million head, up 18 percent from a year ago and 22 percent more than in July 1988, the report said. State feedlot cattle inventories are listed here for the seven states, which account for about three-fourths of the nation's beef. The first number is the number of cattle, in thousands, as of Aug. 1, and the second number is the percentage of a year earlier.
Arizona 158 103 California 420 94 Colorado 680 93 Iowa 775 110 Kansas 1,360 97 Nebraska 1,580 100 Texas 2,030 116

DOC.HEAD: Georgian Lawmakers Debate Shape of Multiparty Elections
DOC.TEXT: The parliament of Soviet Georgia on Friday debated details of multiparty elections set for October, the first such balloting in the republic's history, Tass reported. Last month, radicals blocked a key railway junction for about a week to protest what they saw as official attempts to block the republic's elections. The blockade disrupted passenger and freight service and cost the republic an estimated $6.4 million, the official Tass news agency said. The parliament, which convened Friday in Georgia's capital of Tbilisi, intends to adopt one of three election bills, according to the Interfax independent news service. One bill was drafted by the Communist Party and one by the opposition. A third combines elements of both proposals. The opposition draft calls for a system of proportional representation, a five-year residency requirement for voters, and a 10-year residency requirement for candidates, Interfax said. It also reportedly calls for barring parties in the Soviet system from participating in the elections, which are set for Oct. 28. Interfax said speakers at a demonstration in Tbilisi on Thursday threatened civil disobedience unless the parliament passes the more radical measure. On March 9, the Caucasus republic of Georgia joined other republics bent on breaking with the Kremlin when its parliament condemned what it called forcible Soviet annexation in the 1920s. It demanded negotiations on restoring independence. Several small pro-independence parties in Georgia have been pressing hard for secession for more than a year.

DOC.HEAD: More Heavy Rains Threaten Flooding in Texas and Iowa
DOC.TEXT: Texans and Iowans, already up to their hip pockets in rain, braced for more heavy downpours and flash floods Friday. Showers and thunderstorms moved northward from Mexico into southwest Texas Friday afternoon. Heavy rain has saturated the ground in the area, and any additional rain could result in flash flooding. A flood warning remained in effect for the Rio Grande River from Presidio, Texas through Big Bend National Park to the mouth of the Pecos River near Langtry, Texas. The Rio Grande River was out of its banks near Presidio and Lajitas, and was still rising at several other locations. Thunderstorms deluged parts of Iowa and Illinois Thursday night and Friday morning. Rainfall totals included 4} inches at Lowden, Iowa; 3{ inches at East Moline, Ill, and more than 3 inches at Tipton, Bettendorf, and Dubuque, Iowa. Strong thunderstorms erupted across southeast Idaho Friday afternoon. A tornado touched down southwest of Pocatello, Idaho, and funnel clouds were observed in Power County, Idaho. Showers and thunderstorms were also scattered from south Texas across the Gulf Coast, over Florida and eastern North Carolina, and from the northern Plains and the upper Mississippi Valley southeast to the lower Ohio Valley. Scattered showers and thunderstorms extended from the north Pacific Coast to the northern Rockies, and over the central High Plains. Hot and humid weather was the rule from the Southeast across the middle and lower Mississippi Valley to much of the Plains. Readings had climbed into the 90s from Georgia and Florida across the lower Mississippi Valley to eastern sections of Kansas, Oklahoma and Texas. Temperatures also were in the 90s over South Dakota and northeastern Nebraska, in southeast California, southern Nevada and southern Arizona. Temperatures were in the 60s over Oregon, northeast Montana and along the Northern California coast. The low for the Lower 48 Friday morning was 35 degrees at Truckee, Calif. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 59 degrees at Redmond, Ore., to 102 at Meridian, Miss.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Mayor Vacationing in Caribbean
DOC.TEXT: With his drug trial behind him, Mayor Marion Barry is getting away from the pressures of Washington with a Caribbean vacation. The mayor and his mother, Mattie Cummings, along with several assistants and security people, are staying at an exclusive villa on Jamaica's trendy northern coast. They arrived Wednesday for a weeklong stay in the Montego Bay area. Local police reportedly balked over allowing the mayor's security people to bring firearms into the country, but eventually agreed. Barry was convicted Aug. 10 of one count of cocaine possession, a misdemeanor. The jury was unable to reach a verdict on a dozen other charges against him.

DOC.HEAD: Police Move to Prevent Serb-Croatian Flareups in Yugoslavia
DOC.TEXT: Police and police reserves took up position Friday in Knin to prevent flareups between Croats and Serbs agitating for automony within Croatia, the state Tanjug news agency reported. Earlier, army jets intercepted three helicopters of the Croatian Interior Ministry and forced them to return to base, Tanjug reported. The ministry is in charge of police. The army is dominated by Serbs, traditional rivals of Croatians. But Gen. Bozidar Adzic, chief of state of the federal armed forces, played down the encounter, telling Croatian TV the jets scrambled only because the helicopters strayed from proper flight corridors. Traditional rivalry between the two ethnic groups was aggravated by the Croatian government's decision to bar a referendum of Serbs in the republic on Serbian autonomy within Croatia. The Serb minority of 400,000 in western Croatia had been scheduled to start two weeks of voting Sunday on the issue. Serbia and Croatia have been rivals since they were united within Yugoslavia in 1918 as two of the nation's six republics. In Knin, a town of about 10,000 with a large Serb population, police with rifles stood guard around strategic buildings, said witnesses contacted by telephone. ``In Obrovac and Benkovac, large crowds of citizens are in the streets, hindering and stopping traffic,'' Tanjug said Friday, citing a statement by the Croatian Interior Ministry. Tanjug said hundreds of Serbs broke into a police station in the town of Grachc. Authorities in Croatia had anticipated trouble. On Thursday, they ordered the disarming of the army reserve in Benkovac, which is dominated by Serbs. Croatian authorities attacked the plebiscite, saying it was aimed at undermining democratic reforms in Croatia. Croatia's interior minister, Iosip Bojkovac, said, ``The situation is very tense and has been artificially inflamed'' by the Communist government and news media in neighboring Serbia, the nation's largest republic. The Serbs in Croatia are strongly supported by the state-run media in Serbia, where the Communist party has balked at holding Western-style elections and has described the government in Croatia as ``fascist and racist.'' The center-right Croatian Democratic Union political party this year overwhelmingly won the first free elections in Croatia in more than 50 years. Tanjug contradicted earlier reports Friday that federal army units moved into Knin, in a poor farming region, after Mayor Milan Babic declared a ``state of war.'' It said no soldiers were in the streets. Serbs say hundreds of thousands of their compatriots were murdered in Croatia during World War II by a Nazi-type unit of Croatian nationalists. Serbs in Croatia claim they are being systematically discriminated against by those they describe as extremists in the CDU. Croatia's new government advocates turning the Yugoslav federation into a loose association of semi-independent states in which national minorities would be guaranteed full political and national rights. ``If Croatia is going to opt for confederal status within Yugoslavia, the Serb minority will demand full political self-government,'' Jovan Raskovic, head of the Serbian minority, said in an interview. About 5,000 Serbs gathered in Nova Pazova, a Serbian town north of Belgrade, late Friday in noisy support of their brethren in Croatia. About 1,000 Serbs attended a similar rally in Belgrade hours later. No incidents were reported.

DOC.HEAD: US Ships Intercept Two Iraqi Ships off Kuwaiti Coast
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with location, subbing 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Navy ships on Friday intercepted two Iraqi vessels in the Persian Gulf but allowed them to proceed after determining they carried no goods, the Pentagon said. The USS England, a guided-missile cruiser, and the frigate USS Bradley intercepted the Iraqi vessels off the coast of Bahrain at 8:17 p.m. local time (1:17 p.m. EDT), the Pentagon said. The ships were not boarded. President Bush on Thursday ordered U.S. naval forces in the gulf area to begin intercepting all commercial shipping to and from Iraq and Kuwait to enforce the United Nations' economic sanctions against Iraq. The sanctions are aimed at throttling Iraq's economy to force a withdrawal of the Iraqi army from Kuwait. Bush's orders allow the Navy to board and search cargo ships and tankers and, if necessary, take them into custody to prevent them from reaching their destinations. The orders also allow ship commanders to use force to stop vessels that resist.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Forces Continue to Build
With AM-Gulf-Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is look at the forces buildup in the Persian Gulf region. In line with Pentagon practice, the numbers of U.S. aircraft or troops arriving in the gulf are imprecise, as are their locations.
DOC.HEAD: NAVAL FORCES
DOC.TEXT: United States: _ 24 ships, 17,000 men, 200 aircraft and three aircraft carriers around the gulf, the Arabian Sea and the Red Sea. Warplanes from the carrier Independence, just outside the gulf, fly nightly missions over that strategic sea. _ The U.S. Navy's hospital ships, the USNS Mercy and Comfort, have left the United States for the Persian Gulf. _ The Marines are sending in 45,000 troops and an armada of Marine Corps amphibious assault ships is heading for the Persian Gulf. The seaborne units, equipped with amphibious tracked vehicles that can travel on land at speeds up to 50 mph, are designed for offensive as well as defensive operations. They are supported by a variety of aircraft, including the F-A18 Hornet, a ground attack airplane also capable of air-to-air combat. _ Among other weaponry the Marines are taking to Saudi Arabia: more than 100 M1 battle tanks and 150 fixed-wing aircraft, including Harrier vertical takeoff planes used for light attack missions and close air support of ground troops, and A6-E Intruder bombers used in Libya in 1986. France: _ The aircraft carrier Clemenceau, guided-missile cruiser Colbert and supply ship Var on Monday were headed for the Suez Canal, French defense sources said. Britain: _ Three minesweepers; the destroyer HMS York; the frigate HMS Jupiter; the frigate HMS Battleaxe. Australia: _ Two frigates and one supply ship. Canada: _ Three ships and 800 sailors. Soviet Union: _ Two warships. West Germany: _ Four to five mine sweepers.
DOC.HEAD: LAND FORCES
DOC.TEXT: United States: _ Some elements of the 101st Airborne Division from Fort Campbell, Ky. The 101st has a total of 15,400 soldiers and includes two attack battalions, each armed with 18 AH-64 Apache helicopters and 18 AH-1 Cobra anti-tank helicopters. It also has two assault helicopter battalions, each with 45 Blackhawk copters. The division also has one medium-lift helicopter battalion equipped with 18 CH-47 Chinook helicopters, and one air cavalry squadron, which performs reconnaissance with 12 AH-1 Cobra helicopters and 12 OH-58 observation helicopters. _ Elements of the 24th Infantry Division (Mechanized) from Fort Stewart, Ga. The 24th has a total of 16,600 soldiers and includes three M-1 tank battalions, each with 58 tanks, and three FVS battalions, each with 54 Bradley Fighting Vehicles, plus reserve units. It also has two active artillery battalions equipped with 155mm self-propelled artillery, and one active battalion equipped with nine multiple-launch rocket systems. _ Elements of the 82nd Airborne Division from Fort Bragg, N.C., a paratroop division with 12,800 soldiers. Each of its nine battalions is equipped with 20 TOW anti-tank weapons. _ An Army source said troops from Fort Hood, Texas, also were to be deployed. News reports said 1,000 soldiers had been readied for deployment. Five batteries from the 11th Air Defense Artillery Brigade at Fort Bliss, Texas, have been ordered to prepare for departure to the gulf. The 229th Aviation Regiment, Fort Rucker, Ala., left Wednesday for the gulf. A typical ``attack'' regiment has about 300 soldiers, 18 Apache helicopters, 13 UH-58 scout choppers, and three Black Hawk aircraft used to transport supplies and machinery. _ Elements from the 3rd Armored Cavalry Regiment at Fort Bliss are being deployed to the Middle East. The regiment has 4,200 soldiers and is among the Army's best desert-warfare units. A spokesman confirmed the deployment but refused to give any details. Elements of another Fort Bliss unit, the 11th Air Defense Artillery Brigade, were sent to Saudi Arabia Sunday. Egypt: _ Approximately 5,000 troops. Syria: _ Some troops began arriving August 14. No details were available on the size or kind of unit involved. Morocco: _ 1,200 troops deployed. Pakistan, Bangladesh: _ Sending troops if needed.
DOC.HEAD: AIR FORCES
DOC.TEXT: United States: _ 22 F-117A Stealth fighter-bombers _ At least 48 F-15 fighters from the 1st Tactical Fighter Wing at Langley Air Force Base, Va., and A-10 attack jets from the 354th Tactical Fighter Wing at Myrtle Beach Air Force Base, S.C. The A-10 is armed with a six-barrelled 30mm anti-tank cannon said to make it the best anti-tank weapon in the world. _ An unknown number of F-16 Fighting Falcon planes began arriving in Saudi Arabia on Friday, and the Pentagon announced Saturday that F-16s were continuing to arrive from Shaw Air Force Base, S.C. _ Fourteen F-111 bombers have been flown to Incirlik, Turkey, 425 miles from the Iraqi border. _ An unspecified number of KC-10 and KC-135 tanker aircraft and RC-135 reconnaissance aircraft, as well as Airborne Warning and Control System radar planes have arrived in Saudi Arabia. _ The Air Force says B-52 bombers also have been sent overseas since the gulf crisis started. Britain: _ 12 Tornado fighter jets; 12 Jaguar warplanes; three Nimrod maritime patrol aircraft.

DOC.HEAD: Driver Killed When Gasoline Tanker Truck Crashes, Explodes
DOC.TEXT: A truck hauling 9,000 gallons of gasoline overturned and exploded Friday, killing the driver and igniting a fire so intense firefighters were blistered through their protective clothing, authorities said. ``It looked just like a small nuclear explosion,'' said Tony Eastman, a teacher visiting his parents a few miles from the accident on Maine Route 25. The accident occurred in an unpopulated area near this southwestern Maine town. The driver, identified as Kyle Letterman, of Manchester, N.H., was going down a hill and around a curve Friday morning when the truck's load shifted and he lost control, said state police Lt. Brad Cochran. The explosion caused a fire that ignited some trees across the road and took firefighters about an hour to control, police said. Two firefighters were treated for blisters caused by the heat, which reached 500 degrees, said Leonard Drowns, fire chief in neighboring Kezar Falls. No other injuries were reported.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Plans Review of Military Structure
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, saying the Cold War is over, pledged major military changes next year that could include switching to an all-volunteer force and eliminating some armed services. The Soviet leader spoke at the Black Sea port of Odessa, where he reviewed Soviet troops involved in mock combat. The nightly television news program ``Vremya'' showed him in shirt sleeves shaking hands with soldiers taking part in the exercise. ``Our armed services were established to handle tasks of the Cold War,'' Gorbachev said. ``This war is now over.'' Gorbachev, quoted by the Soviet news agency Tass, said a panel next month will begin drawing up recommendations on military reform and will submit them to parliament. The changes will decide the strength and quality of the armed services in the 1990s. He said planners will determine whether it is necessary to maintain all five branches of the Soviet armed services _ the army, navy, air force, air defenses and strategic rocket forces _ and what role each should play. Gorbachev said officials must decide whether the Soviet Union can abandon conscription and create an all-volunteer force. He indicated that officials should decide whether to give Soviet republics a greater say in how and where troops should serve. Soviet army officers interviewed on a recent press tour of four army bases said they expected a gradual switch to a volunteer army and welcomed it.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Police Refuse to Clear Indian Rail Blockade
DOC.TEXT: The Canadian government ordered the removal of Indian protest barricades blocking the country's main east-west rail link, but provincial authorities on Friday balked at intervening. The Long Lake Indians say they are trying to attract the federal government's attention to a land ownership dispute dating to 1915, when the railway was put through an Indian reserve. On Thursday, the federal government told Canadian National Rail to remove protest blockades erected Monday in northern Ontario. But provincial police Constable Bob Gilman said Friday, ``No enforcement action will be taken as long as a negotiated settlement is possible. ``We're monitoring things, but that's all we intend to do for now.'' Gilman spoke in Long Lake, about 185 miles northeast of Thunder Bay on Lake Superior. The Long Lake band is blocking the main line of government-owned CN Rail. CN spokesman Roger Cameron said officials asked for police help because the railway believes it has a legal right to clear the blockade. ``It's affecting operations and our ability to serve our customers,'' he said from Montreal. ``We have the legal right to operate where we do.'' About 120 miles south of the Long Lake barricades, band members used steel rails and railway ties Thursday to block a CP Rail line through the Pic Mobert Indian reserve. That barrier will stay put, said band Chief James Kwissiwa, until federal Indian Affairs Minister Tom Siddon or Health and Welfare Minister Perrin Beatty visit the reserve to discuss an unsettled land claim and improvements in housing conditions, roads, sewers and water service. Siddon told the Canadian Broadcasting Corp. on Thursday he won't meet band leaders until the blockades come down. ``We will not deal in the face of roadblocks and intimidation. That's not the way that we do business,'' he said in Vancouver, British Columbia. Federal officials have also been trying to settle a 5-week-old armed standoff between Quebec provincial police and Mohawk Indians at Oka, 18 miles west of Montreal. The Mohawks are trying to block a golf course extension on land they claim as ancestral.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Arabian Prince Calls for Swift Action Against Hussein
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhotoBX7
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabian Prince Turki Bin Abdul Aziz, a brother of King Fahd, said Friday a boycott against Iraq will not work and that swift action is necessary to drive Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait. ``I believe that this embargo, this boycott, is not going to be useful because you know there are many merchants of war who make their living by contributing to the escalation of war among nations,'' Turki said through an interpreter. The prince said the best course would be for an international force to take swift military action to end Hussein's rule. ``I think if they want to put a quick end to it, the United States knows how to do that,'' Prince Turki said. ``I am not talking about eliminating him physically or assassination, but they should put an end to his rule _ to his regime because he is a bloodthirsty person and that's his trade, he lives off blood.'' The prince, 53, made his remarks at a news conference in a lavishly decorated hotel ballroom near Harvard Square, where he and his entourage have been staying for the past two weeks. Turki said he came to Cambridge to talk with Harvard University about ways he could help enhance the school's educational programs in medicine and human rights. The prince, one of the king's seven full brothers, said he did not have a clear idea how many Arab troops have joined American forces in the region. But his political adviser, Mustafa Aziz, had said in an interview before the prince arrived at the conference that he understood about 5,000 Arab troops were there, mostly Egyptians but also Syrians and Moroccans. In an exchange that required several attempts at clarification, the prince said that if Saddam Hussein had been at all concerned about vengeance he should have moved on the West Bank nine years ago when Israel bombed an Iraqi nuclear plant. His translator, Zaki Aslan, said the prince was not calling for an assault on Israel, just pointing out a lack of logic in Saddam Hussein's rationale for moving on Kuwait because the two countries were once part of the same empire. Prince Turki said Saddam Hussein ``is a sadist and a psychotic. He enjoys killing people.'' He called him a liar for several reasons, including his overture to Iran after the deaths of thousands of Iranians in the eight-year Iran-Iraq war. The prince, former deputy minister of defense, also said he was disappointed in King Hussein of Jordan, who met with President Bush Thursday. ``I was hoping that King Hussein would not go down and lower himself to come to the United States as an emissary of Saddam Hussein,'' he said. `` I thought he would honor himself further if he hadn't done so.'' King Hussein originally was believed to be carrying a message from Saddam Hussein, but he said after his meeting with Bush that he had brought no such message. The prince was joined at the news conference Friday by his wife, Princess Hend, a son, and a daughter. They sat with dozens of reporters at a breakfast press conference, held in a ballroom decorated with elaborate flower arrangements. The princess, who speaks English and who studied in the United States for a year, broke in pointedly two times during the news conference to demand what she thought were necessary clarifications of the translation. Princess Hend also talked briefly with reporters. Although she declined to discuss political questions, the princess said several times that the people in her country were shocked by the invasion of Kuwait. ``Friends are worried,'' she said. ``They're in shock. They are in a state of standby.''

DOC.HEAD: Study Shows Kids Can Cause Parents to Drink
DOC.TEXT: Disruptive children can cause parents to drink more, a Florida State University study released Friday shows. ``I'm not suggesting we blame children for the alcoholism of their parents, because those who grow up in alcoholic homes have suffered enough already,'' said Dr. Alan Lang, an associate professor of psychology at Florida State. ``Nonetheless, particularly difficult children can cause distress for parents and, in some cases, this may contribute to increased alcohol use.'' Contrary to the teachings of self-help groups, who place the onus on parents and tell children of alcoholics they aren't to blame, the Florida State study may provide the first documented evidence that children actually can cause their parents to drink more. Lang teamed with Dr. William Pelham of the University of Pittsburgh to conduct the research. ``Our studies show how the destructive role of alcohol in parent-child interactions is a two-way street,'' Lang said. ``Problem drinkers make poor parents, but problem children may also drive parents to drink.'' He said the findings are similar to those of studies that show children who are mentally retarded or have serious behavioral problems are abused more often than normal, obedient children. ``The point is that while we usually think of parents as influencers of children, children can affect parents as well,'' Lang said. ``And the outcome is not always favorable.'' Dr. Robin Room, scientific director of the Alchohol Research Group of the Medical Research Institute of San Francisco, wasn't surprised by the findings but said it was important to look into the cause of drinking among parents, ``rather than give in to the bumper sticker-type humor that says children cause their parents to drink. ``It's important to understand that parental drinking patterns can later influence their children's drinking patterns,'' Room said. The Florida researchers, under a grant from the National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, asked 120 parents with 5-to-12-year-old sons to interact with an unfamiliar boy of a similar age. The parents were then given an opportunity to drink as much or as little alcohol as they wanted, while anticipating a second interaction with the same child. Half of the parents in the study had difficult children of their own with short attention spans, hyperactivity, conduct disorders, or some combination of the three. The other half had only children without behavior disorders. But the researchers stacked the deck. Half the parents had initially interacted with boys who behaved normally, while half had faced boys trained by the researchers to behave in an overactive and disruptive way. Among parents of normal children, those who interacted with disruptive boys drank one-third more than those who interacted with a cooperative child. ``I feel justified in suggesting that these results indicate that drinking is a parental behavior that can be influenced by the characteristics and behaviors of children,'' Lang said. Parents with disruptive children at home responded differently to the study, however, depending on the drinking patterns of their own parents. Those who had a family history of drinking problems drank 50 percent more after interacting with a deviant child-actor, while those with no such family history drank less. ``This suggests that people differ in their vulnerability to increased drinking in response to the stress of interactions with a difficult child,'' Lang said.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Ambassador, Instructor Die in Air Collison in Costa Rica
DOC.TEXT: Japanese Ambassador Chusaku Nomura and his flight instructor were killed Friday morning when their plane collided with a second aircraft and crashed into a house, aviation officials said. A Japanese Embassy official confirmed the death of Nomura, 56. Also killed was instructor Albert Jensen. The other plane, carrying one man, sustained minor damage but landed without incident. Authorities said they do not know who was piloting the plane Nomura was in. A household employee said Nomura had been taking flying lessons for about three months. ``On one occasion, I believe it was last week, the ambassador told me he now could fly solo,'' said the housekeeper, who identified herself only as Maria. Television reports quoted a civil aviation official as saying the planes had been ordered to change course but that one of them did not do so. Alvaro Escalante, director of Costa Rica's Civil Aviation, said the crash occurred at 7:55 a.m. shortly after the plane took off from Tobias Bolanos Airport, west of the capital. Parts of the ambassador's plane fell on an empty house about a mile from the airport, Escalante said. Nomura, who arrived in this Central American nation last December, had 30 years' diplomatic service.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba Rejects Import of Beds For Asylum-Seekers
DOC.TEXT: Cuban officials refused Spain's request to import cots for 18 Cuban asylum-seekers who have been holed up since late July at Madrid's embassy in Havana, Cuba's official news agency Prensa Latina said Friday. It marked the latest escalation in the dispute over Cubans who have invaded embassies in Havana in recent months, seking asylum. The wrangle has soured relations between Communist Cuba and Spain, traditional allies. In its report, monitored in Mexico City, Prensa Latina said a Foreign Ministry spokesman expressed Cuban suspicions that Spanish officials lack ``a real will . . . to search for a solution to the problem.'' The report quoted unidentified high-level sources at the ministry as saying Cuba refused to allow cots and mattresses to be brought in for the refugees. Cuba has refused to let the refugees leave the country. Spain has allowed them to stay in the embassy, which Cuban officials cannot legally violate. Similar incidents at the Czechoslovak, Swiss and Italian missions ended when the asylum-seekers returned home after Cuba promised not to prosecute them. However, nine more asylum-seekers entered the Belgian ambassador's residence this week.

DOC.HEAD: Education Secretary's Remark Irks Border Educators
DOC.TEXT: Swift criticism Friday did not keep Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos from repeating his assertion that students who don't speak English are not ready for public education. ``Parental involvement and language competency are basic,'' Cavazos told about 1,500 teachers and principals in this city on the Mexican border. ``If that child cannot speak English the first day of school, that child is not ready to learn.'' In a panel discussion later, South Texas superintendents criticized Cavazos, saying students were capable of learning in other languages. ``The comment that we heard this morning that students who are not speaking English are not ready to learn is a disabling comment,'' said Robert Zamora, superintendent of the La Joya school district. Later Friday, during a news conference across the border in Nuevo Laredo, Cavazos repeated the comment and added: ``We work with the parents, with the schools to prepare the youngsters in English so they will learn ... My final point that I always make is that they not forget that other language and that culture.'' Cavazos, former president of Texas Tech University, said he supports bilingual education, but that its goal should be encouraging students to speak English so they do not miss opportunities in the United States. It was not the first time Cavazos drew criticism from fellow Hispanics for his comments on Hispanic education. In April, the League of United Latin American Citizens criticized him for blaming Hispanic parents for the high dropout rate among their children. In March, he angered some Hispanic lawmakers when he told the state Legislature that money was not the answer to education problems. Cavazos repeated that stance Friday, saying that education could be improved by giving teachers more freedom and allowing local schools more control. ``The new bottom line in education is not how much do we need to spend by how much are our students learning,'' Cavazos said. He stressed that he was referring to public schools across the nation, not just in Texas, and acknowledged ``there have been some inequities'' in school finance in the state. In Nuevo Laredo, Cavazos and Mexican Education Secretary Manuel Bartlett Diaz signed an agreement calling for closer educational ties between the two countries. The agreement paves the way for a ``border conference'' on education next winter.

DOC.HEAD: `Big Five' Meet on Expanding U.N. Military Role in Gulf Crisis
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Ambassadors of the five permanent members of the Security Council held an unprecedented joint meeting with senior military aides Friday to discuss an expanded U.N. military role in the Persian Gulf crisis. ``The purpose of this gathering was to exchange information on the naval activities in the gulf and in the area,'' French Ambassador Pierre Louis Blanc told reporters after the meeting at the French mission. The session was attended by U.N. envoys of the United States, Britain, China, France and the Soviet Union and by military advisers of the five governments, together known as the Security Council's Military Staff Committee. The committee was created 44 years ago when the United Nations was new, but has been inactive, meeting on a perfunctory basis two times a month. Diplomats emphasized that Friday was no ordinary meeting. It included senior U.S., British and French officers. A senior Soviet official was unable to attend and the level of the Chinese military was not known. Blanc said consultations were informal and further meetings could follow if the need arises. No immediate indication surfaced that the five were moving to form a joint U.N. military command in the gulf or to fly the U.N. flag. But Western observers said the five had moved with extraordinary speed to discuss coordination for the first time and reactivate a U.N. military role. ``We won't have a U.N. army tomorrow,`` one said, ``but we could have exchange of information and coordination, letting each other know about rules of engagement. And that is quite significant. ``By U.N. standards, that is whirlwind progress.'' The observers spoke on condition of anonymity. Under the U.N. Charter, the Military Staff Committee is charged with coordinating all U.N. military actions of an enforcement nature, excluding peacekeeping. It is intended to organize and command joint military operations, which never have come into existence. The last time the U.N. flag was flown in a U.N. enforcement operation was during the 1950-53 Korean War. That war was not strictly a U.N. operation, however, and was handed over to the United States. Moscow has been pressing for an expanded U.N. peacekeeping role and for revival of the U.N. Military Staff Committee. Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze said Friday the Soviet Union would send troops to the gulf if the United Nations calls for a multilateral military force. The Soviet Union has said it would not participate except under a U.N. flag. The United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union are especially interested in some kind of coordination, but China is wary, diplomats said. They said Beijing wants to see what action the Arab states take in the crisis before committing itself to outside military action. The five permanent members began meeting on the military question on Tuesday in Washington and met again Thursday in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Official Says Baghdad to Keep All Foreigners
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 3 `The statement' to UPDATE that statement monitored in Nicosia. `The people...'
DOC.TEXT: A top Iraqi official said Friday that Baghdad will keep all foreigners from ``aggressive nations'' until the threat of war against Iraq is lifted. About 3,000 U.S. citizens are being held in Iraq, most of them taken from occupied Kuwait following the Aug. 2 invasion by Iraqi forces, as well as at least 4,000 British citizens. The statement, carried by the official Iraqi news agency, was monitored by the British Broadcasting Corp. in Nicosia. ``The people of Iraq have decided to play host to the citizens of these aggressive nations as long as Iraq remains threatened with an aggressive war,'' said Iraqi's parliament speaker Sadi Mahdi. Iraq's invasion prompted an international embargo on goods in and out of Iraq. Tens of thousands of U.S. and foreign forces have massed in the area, mostly in Saudi Arabia, to oppose further Iraqi military action. ``This measure will remain in force until such time as tangible and sufficient guarantees are forthcoming fro the people of Iraq that the danger of oppressive aggression has passed,'' Madhi said. He singled out the U.S. government among all Western governments for what he called ``going out of their way to take hostile and unjust stands toward Iraq.'' He said these governments had lied repeatedly about the issue, which he referred to as ``precautionary measures taken to keep the nationals of these countries in Iraq.'' Baghdad holds an estimated 14,000 Westerners, apart from 2,500 Americans and 4,000 Britons trapped in Kuwait during the invasion. About 500 other Americans were in Iraq at the time of the invasion. The decision announced by the parliament speaker came after a meeting of the Revolutionary Command Council chaired by President Saddam Hussein. This week, the government had said foreigners in Iraq and occupied Kuwait were considered ``restrictees.'' Saddam on Thursday called President Bush a ``liar'' for sending troops to the region and acting in a warlike manner. INA carried a separate, brief dispatch saying only that the Council met to discuss Iraq's peace moves toward Iran, which included the start of releasing prisoners of war during the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq conflict and troop withdrawels from the border Friday. The Council controls the ruling Arab Baath Socialist Party, which handpicks most of the members of Iraq's parliament.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaragua's President Asks Pardon for Husband's Assassins
DOC.TEXT: President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro has asked the National Assembly to pardon five men accused of assassinating her husband, the opposition Sandinista party newspaper Barricada said Friday. The victim, Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, was a prominent and highly respected newspaper publisher whose death in January 1978 helped ignite the revolution that overthrew the right-wing dictatorship of Anastasio Somoza in 1979. Sandinistas, now Mrs. Chamorro's political foes, have praised her husband as a ``martyr for public freedoms.'' Barricada said the president sent a letter to the speaker of the national legislature asking the pardon, but officials contacted by The Associated Press neither confirmed nor denied the report. Mrs. Chamorro said in June she would seek such a pardon. Barricada said a government source gave it a copy of her letter and quoted it as saying, ``As the offended party, I have demonstrated to the National Assembly my feelings to forgive and forget toward those who were the material authors of the assassination and other related crimes. ``Therefore, I ask the pardon within the spirit of reconciliation which motivates me.'' No one answered repeated telephone calls to the presidency. After Chamorro's assassination, the Somoza-era police arrested men described as hired gunmen: Silvio Pena, Domingo Acevedo, Silvio Vega, Harold Cedeno and Juan Ramon Acevedo. All remain in prison, but were never formally convicted. According to Barricada, Mrs. Chamorro asked that they be pardoned along with 82 other common criminals. After the Sandinistas took power in 1979, the Chamorro family brought a court case accusing Anastasio Somoza Portocarrero, a son of the dictator, along with Somoza official Fausto Zelaya and Cuban exile Pedro Ramos of being authors of the plot to kill Chamorro. The newspaper said Mrs. Chamorro's petition did not say whether those men should be included in the pardon. All fled into exile after Somoza fell. Her husband, publisher of La Prensa and long a vocal critic of the Somoza dictatorship, was ambushed and shot on a Managua street. For decades, La Prensa was Nicaragua's only opposition newspaper. His death touched off violent demonstrations and rallied the Nicaraguan opposition to back the Sandinista revolution. The leftist Sandinistas governed the country until April 25, when Mrs. Chamorro took office after winning February elections in a landslide.

DOC.HEAD: Marine Refuses to go to Middle East
LaserPhoto HU1
DOC.TEXT: A Marine opposed to ``interventionist'' U.S. foreign policy sought conscientious objector status Friday and was transferred to a unit that won't be deployed to the Persian Gulf for operation Desert Shield, his lawyer said. Cpl. Jeffrey Paterson, stationed at Kaneohe Marine Corps Air Station on the island of Oahu, said he would not fight to protect oil prices and opposed ``interventionist'' policies in the Mideast. Paterson, 22, of Hollister, Calif., is reportedly the second Kaneohe Marine to seek conscientious objector status. Eric A. Seitz, Paterson's attorney, said the soldier's application was accepted for processing Friday, but that a decision could take ``some time.'' Paterson, who had worked as a supply clerk and in field artillery, was transferred to a non-deployable unit, Seitz said. However, Capt. Leonard Ryan, public affairs officer at the base, would not confirm that Paterson had changed units. Ryan said Paterson had been charged with unauthorized leave for being away from his unit Thursday, but no other charges were planned. A Marine Corps spokeswoman in Washington said officials there were unaware of the case and would not comment. Paterson said he had been tentatively scheduled to leave for the Middle East on Sunday. Base spokesmen would not discuss planned deployments. ``I can't fight for the military at all anymore,'' he said. ``If I was going to El Salvador, I'd do the same thing.'' Paterson, who has seven months left in the Marines, said he belongs to ``La Casa,'' a group that objects to U.S. ``interventionist'' policies. There are ``very few people who want to go to Saudi Arabia and fight for the price of oil,'' he said. ``All wars are in the objectives of leaders and corporations and not the people.''
