Paterson said he joined the Marines in 1986 but two years later joined organizations opposed to U.S. policy in Central and South America and the Middle East. He said he hoped the media attention about his case would make the Marines ``want to get rid of me as soon as possible.'' Seitz said the soldier told him Marine officials were considering charging him with a number of violations under the Uniform Code of Military Justice. Among the possible charges were unauthorized leave, releasing classified information and inciting others to resist orders, Seitz said. But Ryan said no further charges were planned because Paterson returned to his unit Friday. Christopher Marler, another Marine stationed at the base, filed a lawsuit Aug. 10 seeking a court order to prevent his deployment to the Middle East. Marler had filed for conscientious objector status in April, citing his Protestant religious beliefs. The government said it agreed not to send Marler into combat because his application was filed months ago. Marler was unavailable for comment Friday.

DOC.HEAD: States Want Control Over Wetlands
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS Lead to delete reference to environmentalists; SUBS penultimate graf to CLARIFY that environmentalists not necessarily opposed to state management; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The country's wetlands are so diverse that a national policy to save them should be managed by the states, a federal task force was told Friday. The Domestic Policy Council's Wetlands Task Force held the first of six public hearings around the country to discuss how to meet President Bush's ``no net loss'' goal. Meetings will also be held in Illinois, Louisiana, Washington state, Alaska and Rhode Island. ``I think there are many areas where this country has to have a uniform policy, but not in this kind of area where you have so much diversity and so much local color and so many local ramifications,'' said North Dakota Gov. George Sinner. Environmentalists say development _ mainly agriculture _ has claimed about 55 percent of the nation's wetlands. In addition to providing a home for wildlife, the country's remaining 99 million acres of wetlands help control erosion and recharge groundwater. Last year, Bush pledged to create a federal policy requiring that any wetlands developed equal the number of acres reclaimed. In 1987, North Dakota passed the country's first no-net-loss wetlands law, which established a land bank to replace swamps and marshes acre-for-acre. David Sprynczynatyk, engineer for the state Water Commission, said North Dakota has added 632 acres of wetlands since the law took effect. It has about 2 million acres of wetlands, the most in the contiguous United States. ``I just can't see how the policy can work with a myriad of federal agencies coming in with new regulations, sometimes overlapping, sometimes conflicting,'' said Sinner. Officials from other Western states agreed. ``State boundaries are too artificial. They don't respect the boundaries of wetlands or drainage basins,'' said Robert Hall, of the Denver Water Department. ``Give the state or states the flexibility to do that to meet an overall goal. But let us do the balancing.'' Western farmers said they should be able to help decide which land should be protected. ``The bitter hostility caused by the total disregard of the landowners' wishes and constitutional rights has resulted in a wetlands war in which wildlife has been caught in the crossfire, and nobody wins,'' said Wes Tossett, co-chairman of the North Dakota Agriculture Coalition. Environmentalists at the meeting said a national policy _ even if managed by the states _ should take effect right away. Wayne Baron of the National Wildlife Federation estimated 600,000 acres of wetlands have been lost nationwide since President Bush announced the no net loss goal. ``Quite frankly, we're waiting for the action,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Yosemite Fire Eases; Part of Park Reopened
DOC.TEXT: Cool weather washed over much of fire-scarred areas of California on Friday and officials partially reopened Yosemite National Park, which had been closed to tourists for more than a week. Yosemite spokeswoman Pat Tolle said Highway 120 reopened Friday into the high country over Tioga Pass, about 180 miles east of San Francisco, for the first time since Aug. 9. But the road leading into Yosemite Valley remained closed because of slides and burning snags. The valley, the park's most popular destination and site of Half Dome, El Capitan and other marvels, was not scheduled to be available to visitors until Monday, Tolle said. National Park Service spokeswoman Claudine Gale said firefighters had nearly contained the 18,100-acre ``A''-Rock fire, of which 6,490 acres were in Yosemite and 11,610 acres in Stanislaus National Forest. The other major Yosemite fire, the 5,280-acre Steamboat blaze, was contained Thursday. In all, the California fires have burned about 270,000 acres, or more than 400 square miles, and destroyed 127 structures. The cost of fighting the fires has grown to about $45 million. By Friday, most of the army of 15,500 firefighters amassed against the onslaught had been sent home. Thunderstorms _ which ignited nearly all the 1,300 fires across the state by spawning 37,532 lightning strikes in two weeks _ are likely to recur when the cooling trend ends Monday, said Milo Radulovich, a National Weather Service fire expert. ``Once this pattern is over, we're going to go back to where we were. It'll be hot and dry, especially in September. It will be critical fire weather,'' Radulovich said. Many of California's worst wildfires have occurred in late August and September, said California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection spokeswoman Karen Terrill. A series of lightning-sparked fires that began Aug. 31, 1987 burned 740,000 acres and 38 homes. Ten firefighters died. A blaze that at one time endangered 1,600 homes in Northern California's Tehama County, the Finley fire, was 95 percent contained after burning 22,980 acres. It was expected to be fully contained by Friday. Forestry Department fire investigators said the largest blaze of the siege, the 130,000-acre Campbell fire in Tehama County, may have been ignited by a pine tree branch brushing a high-voltage power line Aug. 6. Since utilities are required by law to keep trees away from lines, state officials were considering action to recover about $10 million in fire suppression costs from the companies, including Pacific, Gas & Electric Co., which use the line.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Calls In Civilian Air Fleet
DOC.TEXT: Up to 38 commercial airliners are being turned over to the military to haul troops and cargo, the first time in history part of the U.S. civil air fleet has been diverted for this purpose, the Pentagon announced Friday night. The decision was made by the commander-in-chief of the U.S. Transportation Command and Military Airlift Command, Gen. H.T. Johnson, to meet the ``growing airlift requirements'' for U.S. forces deployed in the Middle East, a Defense Department statement said. The move means that as many as 38 civilian airplanes may be turned over to the Pentagon to use as cargo and troop transports. Those planes are owned by 16 airlines, which also will be providing the crews to operate them. The airlift support is expected to be needed for several weeks, the Pentagon said. This is the first use of the Civil Reserve Air Fleet since the program was conceived in the 1950s. Under the program, airlines prepare and commit specific aircraft that can be used to carry troops and military cargo in times of crisis. The airlines are reimbursed. The program includes 29 airlines but in this first initial stage of the program only 16 carriers are involved, the statement said. It did not identify the airlines involved. Johnson's action activates the lowest stage of the program. The program is designed with three stages so the airlift command can ``tailor the airlift force needed for any contingency,'' the Pentagon statement said. The initial stage calls for the civilian airlines that are part of the program to provide planes within 24 hours of the request. The planes will be used to augment the Military Airlift Command's routine overseas missions as well as for operations in the Middle East, the statement said. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams, asked why the Pentagon was forced to make the move, said Gen. Johnson ``needs more planes.'' Military commanders at the Pentagon had begun to complain that they weren't capable of moving enough of their troops quickly because of transportation shortages, even though the troops were fully ready to go to Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: in Lebanon.
DOC.TEXT: When Bush announced the U.S. military operation in the gulf Aug. 8, he said it was ``purely defensive'' and aimed at protecting America's vital interest in the Saudi oil fields, which provide 15 percent of U.S. oil imports. Bush said his ultimate goal was to get the Iraqis out of Kuwait and restore the Kuwaiti royal family to power. But he has not ruled out the use of U.S. force to try to dislodge the Iraqi army from Kuwait. Iraq's statement that it intended to hold onto citizens of ``aggressive nations'' also could change the American game plan. When U.S. troops invaded Panama in December, Bush cited, among other things, reports that Panamanian troops were harassing Americans. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, who helped persuade Saudi Arabia to accept a U.S.-led force on its soil, was bound for Riyadh on Friday to visit U.S. troops standing guard in the Saudi desert against a possible thrust by Iraq. Saddam massed tens of thousands of troops on Kuwait's southern border after invading the emirate, prompting fears that he intended to invade Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter. In addition to the thousands of American soldiers now in Saudi Arabia, Pentagon sources say the Marines are building to a force of 45,000 to counter an Iraqi army now believed to have grown to 160,000 in Kuwait. U.S. military planners also are preparing to put 250,000 soldiers on the ground if necessary. For many of the U.S. soldiers, the intense heat of the Saudi desert is difficult to cope with. ``The guys sure would like a cold one,'' an Air Force captain said Thursday from the sun-drenched tarmac of a Saudi air base. ``Tell the folks back home to send in the Budweiser plane,'' an Army tank gunner said. In addition to the U.S. soldiers flooding the region, American naval and Air Force firepower is growing beyond the strictly defensive role that Bush described when he offered to protect Saudi Arabia. The clearest sign of a shift toward offensive capabilities was the departure Thursday from Langley Air Force Base, Va., of F-117A Stealth fighter bombers. The Stealths are designed to penetrate heavily defended areas to attack vital targets. In Iraq, they could hit supply depots or key oil facilities. Military sources in Washington say plans called for sending 22 of the radar-evading fighter bombers to the Persian Gulf area. An armada of Marine Corps amphibious assault ships also is heading for the region. The seaborne assault units, equipped with amphibious tracked vehicles that can travel on land at speeds of up to 50 mph. The Air Force says B-52 bombers, which conducted massive bombing raids in the Vietnam War, also have been sent overseas since the gulf crisis started.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Probed Drug Allegations Against Thornburgh's Son
DOC.TEXT: The FBI investigated allegations that the son of U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh used marijuana and cocaine as recently as 1988, but the Justice Department said Friday the allegations were ``unsubstantiated.'' Justice Department spokesman Dan Eramian said the FBI investigation was closed earlier this week after two friends of William Thornburgh were questioned about allegations that they had seen him use drugs. ``Both people who were interviewed said they never used cocaine with Bill Thornburgh. That's from the FBI reports,'' Eramian said, in an unusual public statement about the status of an investigation. He added that the probe also found no evidence of marijuana use. Referring to the allegations, Eramian said, ``Appropriate inquiry found them to be unsubstantiated. Bill Thornburgh is not the subject of an investigation. The matter is closed.'' Eramian also criticized former state Auditor General Don Bailey, who first made the allegations, and accused him of having a political motivation stemming from disagreements when Dick Thornburgh was Pennsylvania's governor. He said Bailey was not interviewed by the FBI. Sources familiar with the case said investigators interviewed the two friends one time each during the last week. Eramian said the two men were apparently the only people interviewed by the FBI after the case was referred to the Harrisburg office by the Justice Department's criminal division. The investigation grew out of a 15-month-long drug probe that has resulted in guilty pleas to cocaine charges by two former deputy state attorneys general and the indictment on four cocaine-related charges of Henry Barr, a former top aide to Thornburgh in Harrisburg and at the U.S. Justice Department. The allegations against the younger Thornburgh were first made by former Pennsylvania Auditor General Don Bailey in a July 17 letter to U.S. Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa. In his letter, Bailey identified the two men who allegedly used drugs with Thornburgh, and asked that a special prosecutor be appointed to study the entire drug investigation. Specter made the request for an independent prosecutor but earlier this week the Justice Department rejected it. The allegations in Bailey's letter include cocaine use during a Harrisburg party in December 1988. At the time, William Thornburgh was in the Navy and his father was President Reagan's attorney general. Thornburgh has continued serving as attorney general for President Bush and has been a hard-liner in the war against drugs. William Thornburgh, still in the Navy, could not be reached Friday. Eramian said Attorney General Thornburgh was not aware of the inquiry because he recused himself from the case when Barr first surfaced as a target earlier this year. He said the probe of Bailey's allegations was thorough. He added it was not unusual to close an investigation after only one week and two interviews that found no evidence of wrongdoing. He also lashed out at Bailey for making the allegations. ``For a number of years, Mr. Bailey has engaged in personal, vicious, reckless and unfounded allegations against a number of persons with whom he has been at odds on a personal and political basis, including (former) Governor Thornburgh,'' Eramian said. ``But to spread a reckless story about a person's child is beyond all bounds of decency.'' In a related matter, Eramian said FBI agents questioned Dick Thornburgh about Barr last week. Other Justice Department officials who were also questioned said agents asked about Barr's work at the department and whether there were any signs of drug use. Gordon Zubrod, the federal prosecutor heading the drug investigation, said he could not comment on any of the developments.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Limits Case Against Secord, Southern Air
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Friday threw out a major portion of the claims by former Contra supply courier Eugene Hasenfus and said he may consider additional changes before the case goes to the jury. The decision by U.S. District Judge C. Clyde Atkins leaves only certain financial claims in the case. Atkins said he may consider additional directed verdict motions by lawyers for defendants Southern Air Transport and Iran-Contra figure Richard Secord. The jury is expected to begin deliberations Monday. Atkins ruled that jurors cannot consider damages for mental stress suffered by Hasenfus or his wife, Sally. He also removed claims of negligence and misrepresentation by Hasenfus and the family of the late Wallace Sawyer Jr. Atkins threw out punitive damage claims by Hasenfus and Sawyer, but said he could consider whether to reinstate the claim by Mrs. Hasenfus. Hasenfus and Sawyer were aboard a cargo plane shot down over Nicaragua in October 1986 while on a covert flight to supply Contra rebels. Hasenfus, of Marinette, Wis., was the only survivor and was jailed by Nicaraguan authorities. The judge let stand claims by Hasenfus for back salary, as well as the issue of whether Sawyer's family should receive death benefits. Also remaining in the case is the question of whether the defendants should pay for Mrs. Hasenfus' legal expenses to free her husband in Nicaragua and reimburse her for travel expenses. But Thomas Spencer, an attorney for Secord, said he was confident a jury would find there was not an official employee contract with Hasenfus or Sawyer of Magnolia, Ark. ``There was never any proof they were the employers,'' he said. ``Our position is that the employer is Ronald Reagan.'' Secord, who helped former National Security Council aide Oliver North organize the Contra supply network, pleaded guilty to lying to Congress for his part in the Iran-Contra affair and is serving two years probation.

DOC.HEAD: Magellan In and Out of Touch With Earth; Sends `Damn Good' Venus Pictures
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs with contact restored; picks up 10th graf pvs, ```I have...'
DOC.TEXT: NASA engineers successfully capped a daylong battle to stay in touch with Magellan on Friday after the balky spacecraft's first pictures of Venus showed old lava flows, cinder cones and faults created by ``Venusquakes.'' After repeatedly losing and regaining contact with Magellan, engineers sent a computer command to the spaceship Friday night that restored regular communications at 7:11 p.m. PDT, said Tommy Thompson, Magellan science manager at the agency's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. ``We jumped up and clapped,'' he said. `It was just like the home team scoring a touchdown.'' Thompson said engineers expected to remain in touch with Magellan except when it flys behind Venus, when it normally is unable to send or receive radio signals from Earth. An unknown problem made Magellan lose its radio link with Earth on Thursday night as it orbited Venus 147 million miles from Earth. Almost 15 hours later, as engineers held a news conference, Magellan official Steve Wall rushed into the room to announce contact had been re-established. But as the hours passed, NASA tracking stations in California, Australia and Spain lost and regained Magellan's radio signal because of built-in safety programs in the spacecraft's computers. When Magellan first dropped out of contact, sophisticated computer programs put it in a protective ``safing mode'' so that its solar panels pointed to the sun to draw power. Hours later, the safety system made the spacecraft rotate until its antenna located Earth and resumed communications, JPL spokesman Jim Doyle said. The spacecraft was programmed to keep rotating, which explained why controllers kept losing and regaining contact, Doyle said. The command sent to Magellan on Friday night stopped the spacecraft from rotating and kept its secondary antenna in continuous communication with Earth except when the spacecraft is behind Venus, Thompson said. Thompson said Magellan will be kept in its protective mode until the cause of the initial loss of contact is understood and fixed. Magellan project manager Tony Spear was optimistic the problem wouldn't seriously affect Magellan's $744 million mission to use radar to make the best pictures and maps yet of Venus' cloud-covered landscape. ``I have faith in the spacecraft,'' he said, admitting he was surprised by the trouble. The communications problem developed shortly after Magellan bounced radar waves off Venus for its first test pictures of Earth's nearest planetary neighbor. The information used to make the pictures was sent to Earth before contact was lost. ``We've got some raw images that look pretty damn good,'' Spear said, adding the pictures would be released early next week despite NASA's initial plans to wait until September. Project scientist Steve Saunders, who examined the pictures, said they show old, hardened ``lava flows and faults and fractures and (volcanic) cinder cones with craters on top.'' ``The kind of faulting we see would certainly mean there are Venusquakes,'' Saunders said. Earlier Soviet and U.S. spacecraft also revealed volcanic features on Venus, although Magellan's images are supposed to be 10 times more detailed. Magellan won't be able to learn if any Venusian volcanoes are active for at least eight months. That's because it must pass over the same area of Venus twice before it can determine if the landscape has been altered by an eruption. Saunders said Thursday's radar test returned far more pictures than expected, covering several areas of the planet about 1,000 miles long by 15 miles wide. During normal mapping, which had been scheduled to start Aug. 29, Magellan will make pictures of noodle-shaped swaths of Venusian landscape about 10,000 miles long by 15 or 16 miles wide. Those will be assembled into bigger pictures. Magellan's headaches were the latest for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, which recently grounded its shuttle fleet temporarily because of hydrogen leaks and had its Hubble Space Telescope seriously impaired by a focusing flaw in a mirror. Magellan was launched from the shuttle Atlantis on May 4, 1989, and went into orbit around Venus on Aug. 10 after a roundabout 948 million-mile journey. Wall said engineers were out of contact with Magellan on Thursday night as it turned away from Earth to get a fix on two stars, a calibration the spaceship routinely performs to make sure it can point properly. Magellan's radio signals are tracked by 230-foot-wide, dish antennas at Goldstone, Calif., and in Australia and Spain. ``The assumption is that after it made a star calibration, it looked at the wrong star and then couldn't point back to Earth accurately,'' said Doyle. ``Then, the contact was lost.'' Engineers believe Magellan detected some onboard problem, then went into its protective mode. Spear said the spaceship probably tried to get a fix on a ``guide star'' so it could figure out which way it was pointing, but may have picked the wrong star or been confused by stray sunlight reflecting off Venus. ``Most of us have been up most of the night'' dealing with the problem, Spear said Friday. Venus is covered by thick clouds that prevent optical cameras from viewing its landscape. Magellan radar is designed to send radar waves through the clouds, then collect the reflected radar echoes and send them to Earth in digital form. Computers at JPL then can assemble them into maps and pictures. The spacecraft's radar was designed to distinguish surface features as small as two football fields.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Decides to Call Up Reserves; Iraqi Ships Stopped
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new 5th graf, The Pentagon, with airliners turned over; inserts new 7th graf, The Washington, with report of possible callup total; inserts new 15th graf, Later in, with new Iraqi assertion and no comment by White House
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has decided to call up military reserves to meet shortages of doctors, cargo handlers and other specialists in the Persian Gulf crisis, officials said Friday. In the tense gulf, Navy commanders operating under new orders to intercept ships carrying goods to or from Iraq stopped two Iraqi vessels off the coast of Bahrain, the Pentagon reported. The ships were allowed to proceed after U.S. forces determined they carried no goods, the statement said. The ships were not boarded. Separately, Bush protested that Iraqi attempts to move American civilians around Iraq and Kuwait violated international law. The president made his decision to draw on some of the nation's 1.2 million reservists as the U.S. military continued a massive troop and hardware movement to the tense gulf region. The Pentagon, meantime, announced that up to 38 commercial airliners owned by 16 carriers are being turned over to the military to transport troops and cargo to the gulf region. The move is unprecedented in U.S. civil aviation history. One administration official said of the decision on reserves, ``In principle it's been decided, but the details are still being worked out. ... It's just a question of how many folks they're going to call up and who they are. They're wrangling about that right now.'' The Washington Post reported in Saturday editions that up to 80,000 Army reservists and smaller numbers of personnel from other military reserve branches could be called to active duty if recommendations to Bush were followed. Announcement of the decision was delayed because paperwork had not yet arrived at Bush's vacation home from the Pentagon, where military officials had requested the call-up. The administration brushed off criticism from United Nations Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar about the U.S. use of a barricade to enforce sanctions against Iraq. ``We believe it's fully authorized,'' presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Fresh concerns were raised about the safety of Americans after 35 U.S. citizens were removed from the Rashid Hotel in Baghdad and taken to an undisclosed location, most likely another hotel. Fitzwater said there was some indication the Iraqis wanted to keep them away from the news media. ``We consider it a matter of serious concern,'' Fitzwater said. The vacationing Bush, teeing up for a 7 a.m. golf game, told reporters, ``I don't think anybody ought to be moved against their will in contravention of international law.'' American diplomats in Baghdad believe the Americans may have been taken to the Melia Monsour, a hotel where British citizens are being detained. But Iraqi authorities prevented the embassy officials from entering the hotel to check, Richard Boucher, a State Department spokesman, said in Washington. Asked whether a hostage situation was developing, Boucher said ``I can't speculate at this point.'' Later in the day, the White House declined comment on an assertion by the speaker of Iraq's parliament that Iraq will hold all foreigners from ``aggressive nations'' until the threat of war against his country ends. He said they would be spread throughout the country, housed in military and civilian targets. Meanwhile, a group of nine foreigners, including three Americans, bolted across the Kuwaiti desert to the Saudi Arabian border town of Khafji in an effort to avoid an Iraqi order to gather at a downtown hotel, reported Stephanie McGehee, an American stringer for The Associated Press, who was in the group. The State Department said food available on open markets to the 3,000 or so Americans in Iraq and Kuwait was diminishing. Iraq's ambassador to the United States, Mohamed Al-Mashat, repeated that the Americans in those countries wouldn't be harmed. ``I can assure you they are well treated and will be released in due time,'' he said. The massive buildup of American military power in the gulf continued in response to Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and to what the administration sees as a threat to the oil-rich kingdom of Saudi Arabia. The deployment now includes stealth fighter-bombers, Marine amphibious assault units and other forces normally used for offense. Fitzwater said the Pentagon had asked Bush to authorize a selective callup of reservists. The president is authorized to put a maximum of 200,000 reservists on active duty for 180 days, but Fitzwater said a massive callup was not anticipated. ``We'll try to keep this as small as possible,'' the spokesman said. ``In recent years, Congress has allocated more and more of the support functions for the military to the reserve forces, so that you find a major aspect of our support in terms of cargo handlers and doctors and medical specialists and so forth are in the reserves,'' he said. The movement of Americans from the Rashid Hotel in Baghdad followed a threatened roundup of U.S. citizens in Iraqi-occupied Kuwait a day earlier. Fitzwater said the idea of gathering the Americans in one location appeared to have fizzled. A handful of Americans, five or six, showed up at the appointed hotel but were told by the staff there ``they had no idea what this was all about.'' To this point, the Bush administration has challenged any suggestion the 3,000 Americans trapped in Iraq and Kuwait were hostages. Fitzwater said that Iraqi officials, when questioned about the 35 Americans in Baghdad, ``told us that they are safe but have not given us any explanation why they were moved or where they are.'' He said, ``We are also discussing this matter with the other nations who have people in Baghdad ... to try to get everyone to work in concert in bringing diplomatic pressure on Baghdad to make sure that these citizens are safe and accounted for.'' Fitzwater said there are as many as 3 million foreigners in Kuwait and Iraq from many countries. ``They all are essentially in the same situation, which is that they have freedom of movement, they are being treated relatively well under the circumstances or at least have not been singled out for harassment but they have not been allowed to leave.'' Bush will return to the White House Sunday night and meet Monday morning with budget aides and Energy Secretary James Watkins to discuss the impact of the Persian Gulf crisis on U.S. energy reserves. Bush will address the Veterans of Foreign War convention in Baltimore later Monday and make a campaign trip to Rhode Island before returning to Kennebunkport. In military deployment announcements, the Pentagon said Friday: _Elements of the Army's 1st Cavalry Division and 2nd Armored Division from Fort Hood, Texas, have begun preparing to leave for the Middle East. _Nine of the Military Sealift Command's Ready Reserve Force ships have been activated and are moving to loading ports in support of the Saudi operation. _The Air Force has sent four Air Transportable Hospitals to the Persian Gulf area. Medical personnel and equipment have come from MacDill Air Force Base, Fla., Langley Air Force Base, Va., Shaw Air Force Base, S.C., and Seymour Johnson Air Force Base, N.C. An Air Transportable Hospital from Myrtle Beach Air Force Base, S.C., also is preparing to leave.

DOC.HEAD: Nervous SoCal Residents Snatch Up Gas Masks
DOC.TEXT: Army-Navy surplus stores are reporting a run on gas masks by Southern Californians apparently fearful that Iraq could extend its use of poison gas to the United States. ``Most are afraid that Iraq is going to send terrorists over to this country and they want to be prepared for any chemical warfare,'' said Michael Sherman, owner of South Coast Army and Navy Surplus in Newport Beach. His store usually sells about two to three masks a week, mostly to people who work with spray paint or pesticides. ``Lately, we've been selling about 20 a week,'' Sherman said. The masks are Israeli army issue, sell for $9.95 _ and don't come with any guarantees of effectiveness against poison gas, he said. ``We can't say they're going to do anything because of the liability situation. We sell them as novelty items,'' Sherman said. A more serious, and expensive, model is available at Orange Army Navy store. The $115 mask is chemical resistant and is the same type the military uses, said store manager Dave Tipple. Tipple said sales jumped immediately after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Iraq used poison gas in its conflict with Iran and also against ethnic Kurds in Iraq. Jeff Miller's HQ Army Navy Store in downtown Los Angeles has been bombarded by callers asking for gas masks. But Miller said restraint was in order. ``Unless the Iraqi government decides to send a fleet up to Marina del Rey, we don't think anyone will need it. I haven't seen the Iraqi flotilla off the marina,'' said Miller.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Urges Help For Foreigners Stranded in Iraq, Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8 grafs for 3-8 bgng `The position...' to UPDATE with Iraqi announcement that some foreigners will be held, edits to conform. Pickup graf 9 pvs, `He said...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Security Council on Friday expressed ``anxiety'' over the fate of foreigners trapped in Kuwait and Iraq and called on the U.N. secretary-general to take all necessary steps to help them. Hundreds of thousands of foreigners, including about 4,000 Britons and 2,500 Americans, were stranded when Iraq overran Kuwait on Aug. 2. Another 500 Americans were in Iraq. Late Friday, the speaker of Iraq's parliament, Sadi Mahdi, said Iraq will hold all foreigners from ``aggressive nations'' until the threat of war against his country ends. His statement was carried by the official Iraqi news agency and monitored in Nicosia. He said those foreigners would be spread throughout the country, housed in military and civilian installations. On Thursday, Iraqi military authorities had ordered Americans and Britons in Kuwait to assemble in hotels there and implied they would be rounded up if they did not comply. Both Britain and the United States protested the order. In addition, U.S. officials are trying to find out where the Iraqis have taken about three dozen Americans removed from a luxury hotel in the Iraqi capital of Baghdad. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said they were believed to have been taken to another hotel. ``Clearly, we are very seriously concerned about the Americans,'' said State Department spokesman Richard Boucher. He spoke before Mahdi's announcement. Also earlier Friday, the U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations, Thomas R. Pickering, said after a Security Council meeting that U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar ``should become immediately engaged in this humanitarian crisis having to do with foreign nationals represented in Iraq and Kuwait.'' British Ambassador Crispin Tickell told reporters: ``We want the secretary-general to do all he can in a private way.'' He said more than 1 million nationals of other countries are living and working in Iraq and Kuwait and ``find themselves in ... painful circumstances today.'' The Security Council, after meeting in closed session, said its members ``express their concern and anxiety'' over the foreign nationals' status and asked the secretary-general to take ``all steps considered appropriate.'' The statement was given by the Security Council's president, Aurel Dragos Munteanu of Romania. Perez de Cuellar has already been asked by the European Community to send an envoy to the region to investigate and help secure the release of foreigners. In other action at the United Nations on Friday, a special Security Council committee convened to discuss compliance with the U.N. embargo against Iraq. A three-country committee, meeting in closed session, discussed an interim report on compliance dozens of the 159 U.N. member states. It also was expected to discuss violations and enforcement, but was not expected to call for a U.N. blockade at this time. The committee, headed by Finland and joined by Colombia and Canada, also was consulting with the rest of the 15-member council. Perez de Cuellar said the use of military power to enforce U.N. sanctions against Iraq violates the U.N. charter unless the Security Council approves it. His comments Thursday challenged the reason for the U.S.-led naval barricade of Iraq. American officials have said the U.S.-led multinational force is acting in line with the U.N. sanctions. In response to Perez de Cuellar's challenge, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Friday, ``We obviously believe that Article 51 (of the U.N. Charter) authorizes our intercept activities. We believe the U.N. understands that.'' President Bush on Thursday signed an order instructing U.S. ship commanders in the Middle East to intercept all ships carrying goods to or from Iraq or Kuwait. He authorized ship commanders to use the ``minimum force necessary'' to stop any ship suspected of carrying goods to or from Kuwait or Iraq. If the three-nation committee decides the boycott is not being honored, the Security Council can declare a military blockade and appeal to member states to enforce it. The Soviet Union has been pressing for a broader U.N. role in controlling regional conflicts. It said Friday it would participate in a military operation in the Persian Gulf under the U.N. flag.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Blocks Jordan-Bound Munitions Cargo
DOC.TEXT: Britain on Thursday blocked the departure of a munitions cargo bound for Jordan. The Yugoslav-registered Tara, a heavy-duty merchant ship, was being loaded in Hull, northeast England, and was to have sailed within days for Aqaba, Jordan. But a spokeswoman for Britain's Department of Trade and Industry said Thursday the export license for the cargo was revoked pending investigation. The department asked customs officers to review paperwork ``to make double-sure that everything is in order.'' The investigation will ``take as long as it takes'' and no date for renewing the license has been set, the spokeswoman said. Aside from its being a munitions cargo, the department gave no details. Peter Mann, spokesman for London-based shipping agent Cowell Nicola, which is handling the consignment, confirmed earlier that the cargo was cleared and licensed for export to the Jordanian government. Aqaba is now Iraq's only outlet. President Bush indicated the U.S. Navy will bar Aqaba to Iraqi ships following Iraq's Aug. 2 conquest of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Agrees To Change `Accident' to `Crash' In Victory For MADD
DOC.TEXT: It's no accident when a drunken driver gets into a car wreck, Florida officials have conceded in a war-of-words victory for Mothers Against Drunk Driving. It's a crash. Florida state troopers and the Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles will no longer refer to collisions between vehicles as ``accidents.'' Partly because of pressure from MADD, they're now known as ``crashes.'' ```Accidents' implies that the vehicles are out there acting independently through some unseen forces,'' said department spokesman Ed Birk. ``There's almost always a human factor and a human reason behind the crash.'' The department has begun referring to all collisions as ``crashes,'' not just those involving drunks, Birk said. But he conceded that years of coaxing from MADD played a big part in the decision. The anti-drunken driving organization has long sought to convince governments and news reporters that wrecks involving alcohol aren't accidents. ``It is important that people not think of it as something that couldn't be helped,'' said Betty Jane Spencer of Florida MADD. ``Some of them are accidents, but not drunk driving.'' Florida state troopers were told in a July 18 memo from Director Bobby Burkett to begin using the word ``crash'' in all correspondence and when they speak about a collision publicly. The just-published book of statewide statistics on wrecks has been retitled ``Florida Traffic Crash Facts'' and the former Traffic Accident Report forms used by police agencies across the state will soon be known as Traffic Crash Report forms. ``A vast majority of crashes are not accidents,'' Birk said. ``There's a human being behind the wheel that's got to be responsible.'' The only other state to adopt ``crash'' as the official word for a car wreck is Missouri, said MADD national President Mickey Sadoff. ``For 10 years we've fought for this word change, because to call it an accident seems to absolve people of responsibility,'' she said. ``By calling it a crash, you are elevating it to show it's a preventable violent crime.'' Mrs. Spencer, who lost four children in a drunken-driving wreck, said MADD members often write letters to newspapers and TV stations when reporters refer to such collisions as accidents. ``It's very offensive to people who have lost loved ones to call it an accident,'' she said. ``I think now that the state is starting to use `crash,' the news people will start feeling more comfortable with it.'' There were 36,312 alcohol-related collisions in Florida in 1989, down from 37,800 the year before, according to the new ``Crash Facts'' book. Almost 1,500 people died in those collisions, which represented 14.4 percent of total wrecks.

DOC.HEAD: Government, Mohawks Hold First Talks in Canadian Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Government and Mohawk negotiators opened their first formal talks Thursday to settle a territorial dispute that has prompted the Indians to take up arms and touched off protests nationwide. The Indian negotiators slipped out a back door after Thursday's talks, and government negotiators were tight-lipped. However, federal negotiator Bernard Roy told reporters ``nothing nefarious'' should be read into the meeting's mid-afternoon termination. ``It simply has to do with the fact that the Mohawks have certain customs and they are not to conduct negotiations after sundown,'' Roy told reporters. The talks are aimed at defusing a five-week-old standoff between Indians and authorities at Oka, a town 18 miles west of Montreal. The Indians are trying to block a golf course addition on land they claim as ancestral. On July 11, Quebec provincial authorities stormed a Mohawk barricade at Oka, and an officer was killed in the shootout. It has not been established who shot the officer. In sympathy with the Indians in Oka, other Mohawks blocked a bridge between Montral and its southern suburbs. That blockade has angered thousands of commuters bereft of their main link to Montreal and ignited angry protests by local residents. Neither Mohawks nor government officials commented on the substance of the talks Thursday at a hotel in suburban Dorval. Roy, the federal negotiator, said the three parties agreed to impose a news blackout on negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: Europe Seeks Jordan's Help to Get Westerners Out of Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About 7,000 evacuees crossed overland into Jordan from Iraq and Kuwait on Thursday, as three European foreign ministers warned here that Iraqi refusal to let Westerners leave may worsen the Persian Gulf crisis. The visiting ministers asked this kingdom to intercede with Baghdad to allow up to 20,000 Westerners to leave Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. Egypt's official Middle East News Agency meanwhile quoted people fleeing Iraq as reporting an abortive assassination attempt was made against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, followed by mass arrests. Iraq denied the report. The great majority of evacuees reaching Jordan Thursday were Arabs, mainly Egyptians, but included three U.S. citizens of Indian origin, three Bangladeshis with dual British and Bangladeshi nationality, and a Frenchwoman, a senior Jordanian security official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The seven were the first Westerners to be allowed to leave since Saturday, when Iraq said Westerners were ``restrictees'' until the situation clarifies. Included among the Westerners stranded by Iraq's blitz takeover of Kuwait on Aug. 2 are roughly 3,000 Americans. Italy's foreign minister, Gianni de Michelis, addressed a joint news conference at the Royaopen to Iraq-bound goods and to evacuees. King Hussein met President Bush in Maine for two hours Thursday on a possible diplomatic settlement of the crisis. De Michelis said the EC would be ready to provide economic assistance to Jordan to help it meet any hardships the sanctions might entail. A U.S. Embassy diplomat confirmed that three U.S. citizens crossed at Ruweishid, about 205 miles northeast of Amman, Thursday. The diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity, identified one of the three as Bassem T. Hajbeh. He declined to identify the other two, saying they cited the privacy act. The Jordanian security official said the three were transitting Baghdad Airport for India when Iraq invaded Kuwait and closed its airspace.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty Says Iranian Dissident Could Face Execution
DOC.TEXT: Iranian dissident Farhad Behbehani could face the death sentence after making a purported confession on TV, Amnesty International said Thursday. It said it believed he was coerced into making the Aug. 6 statement. Behbehani was detained with more than 20 others in June by Tehran authorities, and Amnesty said in a statement it feared that others held with him may be forced to make similar televised statements. Some of them were reported in poor health, the international human rights organization added. Behbehani belongs to the opposition Association for the Defense of Freedom and Sovereignty of the Iranian Nation and is a signatory to an open letter critical of Iran's President Hashemi Rafsanjani. Amnesty said Behbehani talked at length in the televised statement about alleged connections between the association and foreign governments, including purported cooperation with the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency. The organization this month called for the release of Behbehani and other prisoners it said were arrested solely for peacefully exercising basic rights.

DOC.HEAD: B-52 Bombers, Convoys Head Overseas
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 6 grafs after 19th graf, `Among other ...' to UPDATE with other troop movements.
DOC.TEXT: B-52 bombers left a California air base for an overseas assignment as the Middle East crisis continued, and an Army convoy headed for Saudi Arabia was saluted by hundreds of flag-waving Americans standing along a highway. A second Navy hospital ship headed out to sea en route for the Mideast. Four more warships left military harbors in Virginia on Thursday. The guided-missile cruisers USS Mississippi and USS San Jacinto left the Norfolk Naval Base to catch up with the six other ships of the John F. Kennedy carrier battle group, which left Wednesday, according to Lt. Cmdr. Carrie Hartshorne, an Atlantic Fleet spokeswoman. In other military movements Thursday, the tank landing ship USS Saginaw and the dock landing ship USS Pensacola left Little Creek Amphibious Base near Norfolk. The B-52 deployment was confirmed by Col. Eugene Famulare, commander of the 93rd Bombardment Wing at Castle Air Force Base at Merced, Calif. ``We have deployed several bombers overseas from Castle,'' Famulare said Wednesday in response to a reporter's question. ``We have deployed B-52 aircraft and will deploy the first tanker tomorrow (Thursday) and will deploy people and equipment.'' The tanker _ a KC-135 normally used to fuel B-52s _ was to fly up to 50 airmen overseas to an unspecified site. ``The locations we deploy troops to, at this point, are classified,'' Famulare said. He also refused to specify the destination or number of B-52s dispatched from the base about 120 miles southeast of San Francisco. However, Famulare did say that enough bombers had left to temporarily reduce Castle's ability to train crews, one of its primary functions. On the ground, hundreds of people lined Interstates 24 and 75 from Monteagle, Tenn., to Dalton, Ga., at the urging of a local radio station Wednesday, waving flags and carrying banners while members of the 101st Airborne Division passed. The troop convoy was passing through on its way to Florida and Saudi Arabia. At a refueling stop in Monteagle, Sgt. Roger Roe from Massillon, Ohio, said he was surprised by the response. ``People have really been supportive. It makes me think about Vietnam. Of course, I was too young to go then, but this seems to be just the opposite,'' Roe said. After several delays, the Navy hospital ship Mercy weighed anchor Wednesday night at Oakland, Calif., en route to the Persian Gulf. The 69,360-ton ship's carried some 70 military airlift personnel and 800 people from the Oakland Naval Hospital, said Robert Borden, military sealift command spokesman. About 1,200 medical personnel were originally scheduled on the mission, but a staffing shortage at the Oakland hospital prevented them from heading toward the Mideast. The Navy said additional hospital workers might be flown to the ship after it reaches the Mideast. Another Navy hospital ship, the Comfort, left its home port of Baltimore on Aug. 11 and set out from the Navy base at Norfolk on Wednesday. A ``gung ho'' attitude is surfacing among some standby forces. Thousands of Georgia's military reservists are patiently waiting for a possible call-up but others have been less patient. ``We've had a hell of a lot of reservists calling saying, `I'll volunteer if you are looking for anybody.' We call it the Rambo list,'' said Lt. Cmdr. Bill Schubert, spokesman for the Naval Reserve Readiness Command Region 8 at Jacksonville (Fla.) Naval Air Station, which supervises Naval Reserve forces throughout southern Georgia and Florida. President Bush and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney met Tuesday to discuss activating part of the nation's military reserve. No decision was made, a Pentagon spokesman said. Among other military unit activity: _ In Alabama,one of four ships being prepared to help ferry troops and equipment to the Persian Gulf region sailed out of Mobile Bay on Thursday to an unknown destination. _ The Air Force said its 94th Tactical Airlift Wing based at Dobbins Air Force Base in Marietta, Ga., would be deployed over the next few days to Southwest Asia to provide tactical airlift support to the U.S. military operation in the Middle East. _ North Dakota's two Air Force bases were called to support the U.S. military move into the Middle East. Troops and KC-135 planes were deployed from the Grand Forks Air Force Base, said spokesman Lt. Lindsey Borg. The Minot Air Force base also was mobilizing personnel and KC-135s as well, according to a statement, which did not disclose other details. _ Members of the 3rd Armored Cavalry Regiment at Fort Bliss in El Paso, Texas, were being deployed to the Middle East, a post spokesman said Thursday. _ At Camp Lejeune, N.C., about 17,000 Marines were being moved to the Middle East, the largest deployment of troops since the mid 1960s, said Lt. Gen. Carl Mundy, a three-star general. _ The 197th Infantry Brigade from Fort Benning, Ga., also is headed for the Middle East, the Pentagon confirmed late Wednesday. _ The 314th Tactical Airlift Wing at Little Rock Air Force Base has sent both personnel and supplies to the Middle East, officials say, forcing postponement of an open house the base had scheduled for Sept. 8-9. _ Marines at Marine Corps Air Station Beaufort in South Carolina were stacking and loading equipment Thursday in preparation for going to the Middle East. It was announced Wednesday that elements of the 2nd Marine Air Wing and the 2nd Force Service Support Group at the air station were going.

DOC.HEAD: Nuclear Regulatory Commission Investigating Seabrook Licensing
DOC.TEXT: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission is investigating its decision to license the Seabrook nuclear plant amid claims that its licensing board was pressured to overlook safety concerns. Seabrook opponents welcomed the move as long overdue. ``I think it's a great idea,'' Sen. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H., said Thursday. ``I have long felt that the licensing process has been corrupted by political pressures and that some decisions have not been objective.'' Roy Morrison, a spokesman for the anti-nuclear Clamshell Alliance, said Seabrook opponents hope the investigation will turn up the corruption and misconduct they long have alleged. ``The whole process has been a scandal. We have an agency that's been in a moral vacuum,'' Morrison said. ``The reasonable thing that should be done is the license should be suspended until a full investigation is completed.'' Seabrook spokesman Ron Sher said plant officials are confident the investigation will turn up no improprieties. ``Seabrook Station has been the most closely scrutinized nuclear plant ever licensed with respect to the safety of the plant and the adequacy of the emergency response plans,'' he said. David Williams, the NRC's inspector general, is investigating the Atomic Safety and Licensing Board's decision to recommend Seabrook's licensing, according to documents made public Wednesday. The recommendation, long delayed by concerns about evacuation plans for nearby communities, paved the way for the NRC to grant a commercial operating license on March 15. The board recommended licensing even though appeals by anti-nuclear activists had not been decided. The opponents claim there is no way to evacuate the area adequately in an emergency. The Seabrook opponents' appeal did not preclude the atomic safety board from issuing the operating license, according to Ivan Smith, chairman of the licensing board. But state House Minority Leader Mary Chambers, a Democrat, said the investigation should center on what occurred between Nov. 9, when by some accounts the licensing board was not ready to go ahead, and Nov. 13, when it announced its favorable decision. ``They don't believe it's possible to evacuate the area and then four days later change their minds? Something happened there,'' she said. Chambers said she doesn't know ``whether it was corruption or not, but it clearly looks like there was some pressure brought to bear.'' Morrison was more blunt. ``It's pretty obvious that through the whole process the NRC was in the tank and that Ivan Smith took a dive,'' he said. ``(Smith) did have some concerns until he got talked to. We want to know who talked to him.'' Anti-nuclear activists have speculated that White House Chief of Staff John Sununu, an ardent Seabrook supporter while New Hampshire governor, exerted some clout. Sununu has denied having any influence over the decision. Leo Norton, the NRC's assistant inspector general for investigations, wouldn't comment on what prompted the investigation other than ``some very sensitive issues'' are involved. Smith refused to comment on details, but acknowledged that Williams' investigation is highly unusual. ``I have never heard of any such thing as this in almost 40 years of law practice,'' he said. In a memo, Smith wrote that Williams seems to be trying to determine whether ``the change was corruptly induced by NRC officers and corruptly made by members of the licensing board.'' If he finds wrongdoing, Williams can recommend action to the full commission.

DOC.HEAD: Interior Secretary Asks Americans to Conserve Fuel
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. said Thursday that Americans are unlikely to consume less fuel unless they are hit by the likes of the 1973 oil crisis, when motorists waited in long lines to fill their tanks. ``I think that's what does it,'' he said. ``I don't really believe that the increase in price at this point has discouraged anyone from going anywhere.'' Lujan, who was in Albuquerque to present awards to three oil companies, said the United States should cut its reliance on foreign oil by easing regulations so that more domestic oil can be extracted. The Bush administration has announced it will use the Persian Gulf crisis and resulting gasoline price increases to push for oil exploration in an Alaskan wilderness, the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. Lujan also said drilling should be allowed at the $2.5 billion Point Arguello project, a $2.5 billion development about 150 miles north of Los Angeles that has been blocked by concerns of ecological damage. Lujan presented the Interior department's Payor-Reporter Award, for diligent production reports and royalty payments, to Conoco, the Santa Fe Energy Co. and the Williston Basin Interstate Pipeline Co.

DOC.HEAD: FAA: Budget Crunch May Force 35 Percent Cut in Flights
With AM-Federal Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: Airlines may have to cut flight schedules up to 35 percent starting in October because of mandatory budget cuts, the head of the Federal Aviation Administration warned Thursday. FAA Administrator James B. Busey IV said he is planning on drastic cutbacks if the budget impasse isn't broken by Oct. 1. At that time, the government would implement the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law, he said. If Gramm-Rudman goes into effect, the FAA would have to slash spending about 32 percent, Busey said while speaking at the Atlanta Aero Club. ``That means I will have to begin furloughing members of the work force to the extent that we will have approximately 30 percent of our work force on furlough on any given day,'' he said. ``That will cause a corresponding reduction in our ability to control air traffic ... between 25 and 35 percent.'' The administrator said he notified his work force of about 50,000 on Monday about the prospect of furloughs. Each worker would have to take off up to 2{ normal working days each two-week pay period. Memos sent this week by the Office of Personnel Management are telling the nation's 2.4 million federal workers they could face up to 22 days off without pay in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, or about one day in each two-week pay period. Busey said the furloughs would apply across the board to air traffic controllers, maintenance inspectors, equipment specialists and security officials. ``I don't know how to prioritize between those responsibilities,'' he said. ``Therefore, an across-the-board furlough mechanism is the only way I know how to manage.'' He said he intends to discuss the contingency plans next week with the Air Transport Association, a trade group that represents virtually all U.S. airlines. Although the Bush administration and congressional leaders have been known to play brinkmanship with the budget, time is running out as other problems _ such as the Middle East crisis _ are competing for Washington's front burner. In 1982, 42,000 federal workers were furloughed briefly in a budget dispute between Congress and the Reagan administration. President Bush last week exempted uniformed military personnel from furloughs.

DOC.HEAD: New Esquire Editor-in-Chief Appointed
DOC.TEXT: Terry McDonell has been named editor in chief of Esquire magazine, Hearst Magazines announced Thursday. McDonell, 46, replaces Lee Eisenberg, 44, who is relocating to London to be the founding editor and editor in chief of the new British edition of Esquire, scheduled to make its debut in March 1991. McDonell's appointment is effective September. He joins Esquire from Smart magazine, where he had been editor in chief and president since launching the publication in 1988. Before launching Smart, McDonell was assistant managing editor of Newsweek, with responsibility for all back-of-the-book coverage. Prior to joining Newsweek in 1983, he spent two years with Rolling Stone as the publication's managing editor. Under his direction, Rolling Stone enjoyed a dramatic rise in circulation and received National Magazine Award nominations both years. He was a founding editor of Outside magazine, introduced in 1977, and Rocky Mountain magazine, started in 1979. He began his career with The Associated Press in New York. McDonell's television writing credits include ``Miami Vice'' and ``China Beach.''

DOC.HEAD: Injected Pancreas Cells Help Diabetics, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: Injecting insulin glands into a transplanted liver prevents diabetes in some patients, a procedure that could help diabetics who have kidney damage, researchers said Thursday. The islets of Langerhans, the tiny insulin factories found in the pancreas, were injected into the livers of nine patients whose pancreases were removed at two Pittsburgh hospitals. All nine patients produced insulin at first and for five of them, blood-sugar levels remained normal and insulin shots were unnecessary, according to a study published this week in The Lancet, a British medical journal. Doctors from the universities of Pittsburgh, Miami and Milan, Italy, said FK-506, a drug that prevents rejection of transplanted organs and glands, contributed to the operations' success. Gerold Grodsky, a researcher of islet gland function at the University of California at San Francisco, called the study ``a major step.'' However, he cautioned that the procedure will be useful only for people who are taking anti-rejection drugs, such as kidney transplant recipients, a third of whom have diabetes. The patients in the study had lost their pancreases, spleens, stomachs and parts of their small and large intestines to abdominal cancer and had received liver transplants. The surgery next will be tried on patients with kidney damage due to diabetes that appears early in life, an associate professor of surgery at the University of Pittsburgh said. ``The real target of the research, eventually, is juvenile diabetes, the most troublesome kind,'' said Dr. Andreas Tzakis. One percent of the U.S. population suffers from juvenile diabetes, which can cause blindness, heart problems and kidney failure. The procedure's success is less promising for them because their bodies would reject donor glands, Grodsky said. More research on the body's immune system is needed before people with juvenile diabetes, but no transplants, can be helped, said Dr. Daniel Mintz of the University of Miami's diabetes center, another of the study's authors. In the Lancet study, two patients died of infections and multiple organ failure, and a third died after six months when his cancer reappeared. Another patient became diabetic later. The researchers said the best example of how the gland transplant works is seen in Mary Arthur, 16, of Louisville, Ky., who underwent a transplant in January to replace a liver diseased with cancer. The transplant of the islets of Langerhans takes only 30 minutes. The cells either are injected into a small blood vessel near the liver during surgery or delivered intravenously, the study said. ``The islets seem to be making a new home in the liver, although it's not their normal home,'' Tzakis said. ``They go there to live, and they get a blood supply in there.'' Preparing the islets takes four hours. The cells, comprising only 1 percent of the pancreas and visible only with a microscope, are removed from a dead donor's pancreas. Dr. Paul Lacey, a pathologist at Washington University in St. Louis, said the study confirms results a Washington University team published in the April issue of the journal Diabetes. The Washington researchers transplanted the islets of Langerhans into a diabetic patient with kidney damage, then recorded a reduction in blood sugar when insulin production resumed, Lacey said.

American firepower on the Arabian Peninsula has grown beyond the strictly defensive role that President Bush described nine days ago in pledging to protect Saudi Arabia from Iraq. The clearest sign of a shift toward offensive capabilities is the departure Thursday from Langley Air Force Base, Va., of F-117A stealth fighter bombers. The stealth fighter-bombers, which saw their first combat action during December's invasion of Panama, are designed to penetrate heavily defended areas to attack vital targets. In Iraq they could hit supply depots or key oil facilities. Military sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said plans called for sending 22 of the radar-evading fighter bombers to the Persian Gulf area.

Oil price increases are straining already tight city and state budgets, forcing cutbacks in car and air travel by government workers and causing fresh jitters over the possibility of a recession. Most local budget officials contacted this week by The Associated Press said it was too early to weigh the impact of oil price increases stemming from the 2-week-old Persian Gulf crisis. ``There's no reason to panic at this point,'' said Verlyn Leiker, budget director of Kansas City, Mo., who estimated that the oil price rise has added only ``a few hundred thousand'' to that city's $350 million budget. A few energy-producing states even believe they'll come out winners if oil prices continue upward. But budget officials elsewhere fear sustained oil price increases of 25 percent to 30 percent would almost certainly bring about deep municipal and state service cuts.

A thin washer may have caused the focusing flaw in the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope, and a space shuttle mission can easily fix much of the problem, NASA officials say. ``The Hubble could actually be better than it could be now,'' Charles Pellerin, NASA director of astrophysics, said Thursday. Pellerin and members of a NASA investigative team held a news conference after two days of hearings at Hughes Danbury Optical Systems Inc., maker of the flawed primary mirror that is producing blurry pictures from the orbiting observatory. The mirror has an aberration caused by a 1.3-millimeter error in a measuring device that was used to grind the telescope's mirrors, said Lew Allen, head of the team and director of NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory.

A woman who says she has 21 personalities displayed three of them _ herself and characters named Franny and Jennifer _ in testifying she was raped by a man who took her out for coffee. The judge required her to take an oath each time she changed identities during the hearing Thursday. Lawyers introduced themselves to the different personalities. Each time, she behaved as if the testimony was just beginning. After hearing the testimony, Judge Robert Hawley ordered Mark A. Peterson, 29, to stand trial for sexual assault. No trial date was set. To convict Peterson, District Attorney Joseph Paulus said he must prove three things _ that the victim had a mental illness, that she was incapable of appraising her own conduct and that Peterson knew about the illness. Peterson claims the woman consented to sex and that he did not know she had multiple personalties. But the woman said she told Peterson she had multiple personalities and introduced him to some of them, and that he took advantage of one of them _ Jennifer, a fun-loving 20-year-old.

Actors' Equity bowed to pressure from within its ranks and agreed to let a white actor play a Eurasian pimp in the Broadway production of the hit London musical ``Miss Saigon.'' Now the question is whether the show will go on. Producer Cameron Mackintosh, who had scrapped the $10 million show after the union's initial ban on Jonathan Pryce, said Thursday he will confer with the English actor and the ``Miss Saigon'' creative team to determine whether it can still be brought to Broadway. A decision is not expected until next week, said Mackintosh spokesman Marc Thibodeau.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: The Multiple Personality-Rape item has been withdrawn from the package.
DOC.TEXT: Actors' Equity reversed itself Thursday, and said it would allow a white British actor to play a Eurasian in the Broadway production of the hit London musical ``Miss Saigon.'' The vote to approve actor Jonathan Pryce came at a special meeting of the union's 70-member council, called in response to a petition from more than 600 Equity members outraged by the decision last week to bar the actor. ``The council determined that, indeed, Mister Pryce qualifies as a star in accordance with the criteria established in the agreement between Equity and the League of American Theaters and Producers,'' said Alan Eisenberg. The council ban of Pryce prompted the show's producer to cancel its Broadway run and dividing the theater community. The producer, Cameron Mackintosh, has not said whether he would resurrect the show if the union rescinded its order. ``Miss Saigon'' was to begin previews here in March. Its top ticket price was $100. Mackintosh said the cancellation of the $10 million musical, which had a record $25 million in advance ticket sales, would cost him about $600,000.

U.S. gasoline prices will probably remain higher even if foreign producers make up for the lack of crude oil from Iraq and Kuwait, executives with one major oil company said Thursday. With Kuwaiti refineries not producing, U.S. gasoline refining capacity already is stretched tight, and much refined fuel from other countries does not meet federal standards, they said. Producing nations probably could increase their crude output by up to 3.5 million barrels per day by the fourth quarter, said one executive, who was one of several who spoke to reporters at a briefing given on condition that they and their company not be identified.

DOC.HEAD: Drought in the Business Marsh
DOC.TEXT: Life in the business marsh, which ordinarily hums with innovative little outfits that eventually grow and nip at the heels of giant companies, is quiet these days. Business isn't good for beginners. Many don't even get a hearing from the loan officer at the bank. Venture capitalists, those folks who used to take big risks for big rewards, haven't been very venturesome either. The Federal Reserve, following a tight money policy, has made life miserable for them. And banks, fearful of regulators and often reacting to their own earlier excesses, have all but welded the hinges on their vaults. Congress has hindered rather than helped. Not only has it failed to solve the deficit problem, it is poised now to pile on a whole new set of regulations that can only raise costs and drive small-business people mad. The regulations, all accompanied by energy-draining paperwork, concern minimum wages, mandated health costs, mandated leaves, mandated access for handicapped, mandated pollution controls. The paperwork alone is full time. An American Express Co. survey of new-business formation showed a 4.2 percent decline in the second half of 1989. Dun & Bradstreet Corp. says new incorporations are stagnant; in the first four months of 1990 they totaled 236,102, down 0.9 percent from 238,306 in the year-earlier period. Business failures, meanwhile, are higher for the first time since 1986. D&B puts the percentage at 9.5 percent over last year, and as usual, many of these are upstart companies. In April, the New England failure rate was nearly triple that of a year earlier and the Middle Atlantic rate was more than double. Small and beginning business is the breeding ground of creativity, the source of new jobs, the inventor of new products and services and the future competition for big companies that otherwise might develop clogged arteries. From emerging businesses will come new ways to contain health-care costs, new high-tech companies to solve what has stymied the bigger guys, new products to help the balance of payments, new marketing strategies. Economists accustomed to the big scene, to viewing abstract statistics, to dealing with macro- rather than micro-economics, often make little of the emerging-business problem. ``Everyone suffers in a downturn,'' they say. Others contend, correctly, that much of the credit crunch involves real estate and building, and that many forestalled ventures are speculative. Whatever, they involve the future of jobs and companies. No area of the economy exists in isolation. The construction of one house, for example, involves a thousand economic transactions, including the purchase of raw land, payment of fees to towns, soil testing, sewers, water mains, curbs, gutters, streets, landscaping. It involves, according to the National Association of Home Builders, 1.8 man-years of employment, including the direct services of carpenters, plumbers, electricians, insulators, painters, roofers, cement workers, tilers and others. The jobs, and the businesses involved, are by no means local. Steelmakers, carpetmakers, furnace makers and makers of air conditioners must ship their products from many miles away, by air, by rail, by road. But it isn't just real estate and building that are being deprived of water in the small-business marsh. It isn't only high-tech companies either. When business withers at the grass roots the damage sometimes isn't seen for a while. Big business can shout, threaten and stamp its feet, thus getting the the attention of elected officials. The smallest businesses might not. When ideas and innovations die, when inventions aren't financed, when start-up companies aren't nourished, the signs might be barely detectible in the national statistics. The economic measuring devices aren't always so perceptive that they can detect the pulse of small business, the faint murmurs in the business marsh.

DOC.BYLINE: Tensions Rise as U.S. Anchor Buildup Reported in Middle East ^By JAY SHARBUTT
DOC.TEXT: As the U.S. network anchor buildup continued in the Middle East, ABC's Peter Jennings was asked if he felt a little lonely, staying here to anchor ``World News Tonight.'' ``Not at all,'' said Jennings, who used to cover the Middle East in his correspondent days. ``I'm in exactly the right place. My job is to coordinate the coverage, not just go and do one dimension of it.'' He spoke last Thursday, as the network anchor total in the Middle East rose to seven with the arrivals in Saudi Arabia of NBC's Tom Brokaw and ABC's Sam Donaldson, the latter there for ``PrimeTime Live.'' It was perhaps the largest array of high-priced anchors since the Moscow Summit of 1988, when there were so many news stars running loose only luck prevented a high-speed interview pileup. But this time, they're spread out, those who have been sent to cover and anchor, so to speak, the Middle East crisis caused by Irag's armed takeover of Kuwait. They've reported from Dubai, Jordan, Cairo, Saudi Arabia, and, in CBS' Dan Rather's case, a Navy carrier from which he anchored _ on tape _ part of one newscast. Rather and ABC's Ted Koppel also have been the only U.S. anchors to broadcast from Baghdad yet. NBC's Garrick Utley still is trying to get in. Ironically, Ted Turner's global Cable News Network hasn't sent in an anchor star. It has stuck with its grunts, the correspondents. Why didn't CNN send in just one of its anchors, say, Bernard Shaw? ``It's because of what we are, as opposed to the other guys,'' says Ed Turner, CNN's executive vice president for newsgathering. ``They have half-hour shows, and if that's how they want to use their anchors, super.'' (It should be pointed out that Koppel and Rather have done breaking-news bulletins and report for newscasts on their networks other than their own, just like the lesser-known, lesser-paid correspondents.) ``But this story, unlike any story I can ever remember, has so many different locations,'' Turner says. ``And an anchor is supposed to tie it all together from a central location. ``The place to do that is not downtown Baghdad, or downtown Amman. The place to be is what you consider your news universe.'' Jennings gives almost the same reason _ ``it's a complicated story'' _ as the reason he's staying here. Koppel, the ``Nightline'' anchor, has scored good beats, particularly by being the first U.S. network newsman into Iraq, Jennings says, but ``I can't go off and pursue the one thing and still run our coverage.'' Rather, says Turner, ``is a helluva reporter. He likes doing that, he's excited about it, and that's fine. But that's not an anchor's job . . . if you're really anchoring, you're talking about holding the show together.'' Rather has been in the Middle East since the crisis began. Brokaw started only last Thursday, when he reported for the ``NBC Nightly News'' and anchored part of it from what seemed a palm tree-lined oasis. Why the delay? ``We've been saying all along that if we can get into Baghdad, Saudi Arabia or Kuwait we would go,'' says the show's executive producer, Steve Friedman. Saudi Arabia, which tightly restricted correspondents' visits even before the current Gulf crisis, gave Brokaw approval to enter last week, likewise ABC's Donaldson. That approval was ``why we went in'' with Brokaw, says Friedman. ``We've been holding off because I'm not going to send Tom to a place where I can only get a phone call'' report from the NBC anchorman. With the advent of satellites, the wandering anchorman has become almost routine. There are varied reasons for moving about, Jennings says _ to bring attention to particular event or region, or a single story. Another reason The Anchor is sent in on a major story is clout. The fact an anchor is well-known and has contacts with major movers and shakers sometimes gets him interviews or into places lesser mortals only might dream about. As Friedman puts it: ``An anchorman gives you cachet. Because everybody all over knows who they are. Ted Koppel got into Baghdad because he's Ted Koppel and worked the story.'' Media critics, some of whom may yet cover a fire, sometimes question the validity of anchor expeditions, calling them show-biz moves intended more to drum up publicity and ratings for network newscasts than to commit journalism. The urbane Jennings would give such carpers the back of his hand: ``I don't think they watch what we do. I don't think they even look at content, or look at the reporting . . . our audience wants to know what the hell's going on, not where any of us are standing at any given date. ``My advice is to pay less attention to anchors and more to content.'' __ Elsewhere in television... FARM AID TO CBS: Last April's fourth annual ``Farm Aid'' music concert has been condensed to a two-hour special CBS will air this Saturday. It's hosted by Willie Nelson, John Mellenkamp and Neil Young, and the performers range from Guns N' Roses to the Soviet rockers, Gorky Park. End Adv PM Mon Aug. 20
