DOC.HEAD: `For Younger Wives It's More Difficult'
DOC.TEXT: After growing up as an Army brat, Sandy VonKaenel became an Army wife, and it wasn't long before her husband was off to Vietnam. All that experience helps now that he's away again, in Saudi Arabia. ``For those who've been associated with the Army for a lengthy time, it's not so difficult,'' she said, taking time out from a day-and-night schedule of activities, from ``networking'' with other wives in support groups to distributing red, white and blue ribbons. ``We knew what our husbands' jobs were. It's not a big surprise,'' said Mrs. VonKaenel, whose husband joined the Army 21 years ago. ``For younger wives, it's more difficult.'' Twenty-one years ago, Karen Walsh was born. Recently, when her soldier-husband, just 23 himself, learned he would be among the thousands deployed as part of a force to deter a possible Iraqi invasion of Saudi Arabia, she was unprepared. ``I think my whole generation, I guess we're kind of naive. We don't remember that war,'' she said, referring to Vietnam. ``We never really thought that this would happen. I know I never did when he went into the Army. . . . It's hard to believe it's actually happening.'' This is not to say that the officer's wife is nonchalant, or that the young specialist's wife is overwhelmed as he works long hours preparing and she waits for him to ship out at any time. In both of the wives' voices is the steel of military stoicism. In both of their laughs is the breath of nervousness. Both women, who spoke on the condition their husbands' first names not be used, find some refuge in routine. ``Birthday parties go on. Soccer camps go on,'' said the 42-year-old Mrs. VonKaenel, who has a 13-year-old son and a 5-year-old daughter. ``School starts next week. Normal routine.'' At the same time, there's an out-of-the-ordinary routine since the deployment began. ``I have a family assistance meeting tonight,'' Mrs. VonKaenel said. ``I've been on the phone all morning.'' During an interview, she was interrupted three times by phone calls. Unit by unit, soldiers' spouses set up ``phone trees,'' and she volunteered her name and number. An earlier call had been from a wife who has only a learner's permit and couldn't drive alone. How could she go get groceries? The fort's family aid office would send someone to help. Another call: What if the aid office didn't come? ``If they don't, I'll come and get you,'' Mrs. VonKaenel told the woman. Asked if she has trouble sleeping these days, Mrs. VonKaenel said yes, but laughed. ``Not because I can't sleep,'' she said. ``It's because I'm too busy.'' Mrs. Walsh is getting less sleep, too. Her two children, almost 1 year old and almost 3, wake her up early, and Ted Koppel keeps her up late. ``I usually stay up until `Nightline' goes off,'' she said. ``I keep that little TV in the kitchen on all day so I can hear anything that comes on, any reports. I've always watched a lot of news. . . . But now I watch four or five evening newses.'' As she spoke, her little daughter blurted, ``My daddy's in the Army.'' ``She sees sometimes, on the news, the Army daddies and she asks,'' Mrs. Walsh said. Her husband could leave at any time _ ``he's all packed and ready to go,'' she said. ``I promised myself I wouldn't cry if it happened,'' she said of the deployment. ``Then, as it got worse, I have cried. It's not knowing what's going on that's really bad.'' Mrs. Walsh and her husband were high school sweethearts. Both went to college briefly. He joined the service for the education benefits and ``to give him discipline or something,'' his wife said. ``He felt that he needed that.'' ``It's not a career. He's been in longer than we planned on, but . . .'' Her voiced trailed off and she smiled. He's about a year into his second hitch. The first was spent in Colorado, far from both their families in Charlotte, N.C. Mrs. Walsh said she's happier at Fort Bragg. ``The whole community's centered around the Army,'' she said. Portable signs in front of businesses and churches bear messages such as, ``God bless America and our soldiers overseas.'' A rock music station plays the national anthem at noon, introduced by a disc jockey who says, ``We're damn proud to be Americans.'' At an intersection one day last week, a van with a bumper sticker that read ``Army Spouses Are Special'' waited as a convoy of a dozen boxy medics' ambulances _ olive drab with large red-and-white crosses _ turned eastward, the direction of ports where ships have been loading military vehicles and equipment. The reminders are everywhere. ``I was thinking earlier today, everyone else is kind of going through their normal life,'' Mrs. Walsh said. ``It's just something they see on TV. Maybe they think about it, but not as much as _ I mean, we think about it all the time.'' Feelings get mixed up. Sadness. Fear. Pride. ``I've just started becoming more aware of how lucky we are that we're here, when I see all theoutheast regional reporter, based in Atlanta.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Mon PMs, Aug 20

DOC.HEAD: Met Tenor Who Won Assembly Scholarship: `I Was Very Lucky'
With AM-Grassroots Democracy
DOC.TEXT: The last time a voice from this tiny crossroads town got the world's attention it was that of patriot Patrick Henry, who's buried here. Now, it's Michael Forest's voice. The 27-year-old lyric tenor is singing five roles at the Metropolitan Opera in New York this season _ from ``Porgy and Bess'' to ``Boris Gudonov'' _ but only a decade ago, he was working in the local tobacco fields. In between, he met Essex Moseley, president of the Charlotte County Assembly, part of a network of grassroots self-help groups being set up in poor, rural counties around the South. ``The assembly was sponsoring a music contest and we took Michael down,'' Moseley said. And the voice? ``I was really knocked off my feet,'' he said. Forest, then 18 and trained only in the church choir and school chorus, won the competition. First prize was a scholarship to the Shenandoah Conservatory of Music in Winchester, Va. ``I was very lucky, to be in the right place at the right time,'' said Forest from his Manhattan apartment, shortly after a visit home where he sang in his old Mount Zion Baptist Church. After Shenandoah, Forest made his debut at the Kennedy Center in Washington in 1986, and later won a scholarship to London's Guildhall School of Music and Drama. He sings in six languages and has performed all over the world. ``He signed with the Metropolitan Opera in April of '89,'' said the assemblies' founder, Don Anderson. ``He'd be pulling tobacco today if he had not won that scholarship. He had no money to go to school.'' Forest said he'd been planning to take education classes at a community college but had not applied when the scholarship came along. His is not the only poignant tale of the music scholarships. Once, a trombone virtuoso from coastal North Carolina traveled to the competition and won, but lacked the bus fare home. Anderson supplied the $15. ``The talent out there is really amazing,'' Anderson said, ``but it's going to waste.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Mon AMs, Aug. 20

DOC.HEAD: Shakespeare Teachers Get Refresher Course in Teaching the Bard
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: STRATFORD-UPON-AVON, England (AP) _ On a hazy afternoon in the Bard's birthplace of Stratford, Shakespeare was making particular sense for a room of American and British teachers. Royal Shakespeare Company actor Ralph Fiennes was reciting Sonnet 129 _ ``Th'expense of spirit in a waste of shame.'' He stopped after each word and the teachers shouted, ``What?'' The exercise compelled Fiennes to pay heed to every part of the verse, and his audience was impressed. ``The idea of acting each word _ I can make my students do that,'' said Lynn Lawrence, chairman of the English and drama department at Osbourn Park High School in Manassas, Va. ``I've got tears in my eyes,'' sighed Marcia Rosenboom, who teaches high school drama and English at George Community High School in George, Iowa. Fiennes and vocal coach Andrew Wade were showing how Shakespeare's Elizabethan language emerges clearly through breathing and technical exercises which the teachers can apply at home. The teachers were recently in Stratford on the first phase of a program _ ``Teaching Shakespeare: Texts and Performances'' _ which continued in Washington, D.C. at the Folger Shakespeare Library. The $500,000 program is the brainchild of the education departments of the Folger and the RSC. ``This is the largest-scale Shakespeare-education-for-teachers program that has ever gone on in the world,'' Tony Hill, the RSC's director of education, said in a joint interview with his Folger Library counterpart, Peggy O'Brien. There is a double aim: to immerse teachers in Shakespeare from performing and analytical perspectives, and to give them the chance to meet each other. ``Teachers can be the most insular, self-obsessed, and frankly boring group of people you ever get in the world,'' said Hill, who spent four years with O'Brien planning the current four weeks. ``At least part of that is to do with the fact that they're so seldom given the tools to do their job that you'd give to any other industry.'' O'Brien, a former high school teacher, said teachers are too often ``very invisible. One of the only ways we can see each other is when we get in a group like this at an institute.'' The 40 teachers on the program include 25 Americans and 15 Britons ranging in age from 24 to 60. They were chosen from more than 500 applicants in the United States and 350 in Britain. Three scholars from American universities were on hand throughout to lecture and offer tutorials, and there are as many ``master teachers'' to develop teaching strategies to take back to the classroom. Of primary importance in Stratford is the opportunity to watch classically trained talent such as Fiennes, who is playing Troilus in ``Troilus and Cressida,'' grappling with difficult, knotted verse. ``It's about making the punctuation mark a physical movement,'' Denise Fournier, a 29-year-old teacher from Concord, N.H., decided after the young actor completed a drill in which grammar dictates changes in gesture. For Lynn Lawrence, seeing the plays performed helps to teach them: ``Students are leery. They're afraid of failure and of not understanding (Shakespeare). I need to get them to see it as a story and a performance, and there's no other way to get that.'' The teachers attended Stratford productions of ``King Lear,'' ``Troilus and Cressida,'' and ``The Comedy of Errors,'' as well as ``Edward II'' by Christopher Marlowe, Shakespeare's contemporary. Their textual focus was on ``Lear,'' ``Troilus'' and ``Romeo and Juliet'' _ the last chosen because, said Hill, ``it's something everybody's going to have taught.'' The site, for some, offers its own rewards. ``We (Americans) don't have any of this wonderful scenery or the birthplace,'' said Karen Huffman, who teaches advanced placement English to 12th-graders in Rapid City, S.D. ``It brings Shakespeare home.'' She added that the camaraderie was invaluable. ``I'm getting reassurance that I'm doing the right thing,'' Huffman said. ``I'm really pleased I'm keeping pace out there in the boondocks.'' Martha Christian, one of the ``master teachers,'' said: ``Teaching is lonely; most of us teach in isolation. This gives us a network of people who are enthusiastic.''

DOC.HEAD: For Comedy Relief, Check Out the New York Governor's Race
Retransmitting to fix priority and category code
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 22nd graf to CORRECT that Cuomo has not specifically denied that he will run for president, but has been coy on the subject, picks up 23rd and last graf pvs, The bond ... for governor
DOC.TEXT: This is no joke, it's the New York governor's race. On the Democratic side, Gov. Mario Cuomo is seeking re-election to a third, four-year term. If he wins, some think he might run for president in 1992. He's campaigning by planting trees all across the state. On the Republican side, Cuomo's challenger is economist Pierre Rinfret. If he wins, he won't run for president. He can't. He was born in Canada. You have to be born in the U.S.A. to be president. When Rinfret won the Republican state convention's nomination in late May, he wasn't even a Republican. He said he thought he was. He said he even remembered voting in Republican primaries. It turned out he was listed in voting records as an independent. There was no record of him having voted in any recent GOP primaries. He subsequently enrolled as a Republican. That's not to say there weren't enrolled Republicans ready to run. There were two of them. In fact, they are running. They just aren't running as Republicans. Herbert London, a New York University dean, wanted the Republican nomination but was rejected by GOP leaders. After meeting Rinfret, London said he rejected an offer to become the economist's running mate. London then accepted the Conservative Party's nomination to run for governor. He's since spent much of the campaign attacking Rinfret and the Republicans who rejected him. Louis Wein, a New York City-based consultant, went to the Republican state convention intending to fight Rinfret for the nomination. Rinfret is pro-choice on the abortion issue. Wein, who is anti-abortion, was upset that the Republican platform included a pro-choice plank. Wein said he finally agreed not to challenge Rinfret's nomination after party leaders promised that the pro-choice plank would be removed. Rinfret was nominated by acclamation but a pro-choice plank, weaker than the original, stayed in. Wein then accepted the gubernatorial nomination of New York's Right to Life Party. He also began circulating petitions in an attempt to force Rinfret into a Sept. 11 primary for the GOP ballot spot. When he didn't collect enough signatures, he went to court. He claims he was the victim of fraud and double-cross at the state GOP convention. Republican leaders say they only promised they would discuss the pro-choice stand. Wein wants a state judge to order a Republican primary. ``Once they stop laughing at the courthouse,'' said Rinfret campaign manager John Faso, ``I'm sure that it will be unceremoniously dismissed.'' ``I'd rather see Mario Cuomo governor than Mr. Rinfret,'' said Wein at one point. The campaign has played largely like this: Rinfret attacks Cuomo. Cuomo ignores Rinfret. London and Wein attack Rinfret. Rinfret provides some additional interest. He's never run for office and his political inexperience often shows. Immediately after his nomination, Rinfret told reporters that he wasn't a millionaire. A few minutes later he said his net worth was more than $12 million. He explained the discrepancy by saying he was ``teasing.'' He is a millionaire. In a later interview, Rinfret said he and his wife battled each morning to see who would get to read The New York Times first. He then said that he hated the Times, the state's most influential newspaper, because ``it's biased, it's prejudiced and it lies.'' He later told the Times he had been misunderstood. ``I was fooling around, like a moron,'' he said. Rinfret, who runs an international economic consulting firm and once served as an unpaid adviser to President Nixon, was discovered by Republican leaders less than two weeks before the GOP convention. A host of other prominent New York Republicans, such as Rudolph Giuliani, Assembly Minority Leader Clarence Rappleyea and Staten Island Borough President Guy Molinari, had refused to run. Rinfret called such Republicans, ``gutless wonders.'' A decorated World War II veteran, he also called Cuomo ``chicken'' for going to college instead of off to war in Korea. Cuomo, meanwhile, keeps mum on whether he'll run for president and keeps planting trees. He's planted them on Long Island and in Niagara Falls and at a host of stops in between. It's a device meant to promote passage of a $2-billion environmental bond issue. The bond issue will be on the November ballot in New York state. There is also an election for governor.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday AMs, Aug. 20

For release Monday, Aug. 20, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Major Oil Stocks Should Be a Safe Investment During Mideast Crisis
DOC.TEXT: With the price of petroleum rising and crude supplies falling, are oil company stocks a good bet during the Mideast crisis? That depends. Most experts say shares of the major ``integrated'' oil companies, such as Exxon, Mobil and Chevron, should be a safe investment for the near term. In fact, many of these stocks are considered undervalued. But some suggest it may be wise to avoid companies that are primarily involved in refining crude, such as Diamond Shamrock R&M. These companies, it is argued, may be caught in the squeeze between the steeper prices they must pay for crude and pressure they face to hold down prices at the pump. While major oil companies may be in a good position, investing in these stocks is not risk-free, analysts say. ``It's absolutely not the place to make a quick buck,'' said Frank Knuettel, who follows oil companies at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. For one thing, oil companies face profit pressures as they replace supplies gathered before Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait with higher-price oil. In addition, the oil giants are under increasing pressure by both the government and consumer groups to hold down gasoline prices amid charges of price gouging. Finally, nobody knows whether the higher prices will cause a steep dropoff in demand for gasoline and other refined products that could crimp the bottom line. ``Higher prices and the potential for higher taxes will all work on demand,'' said Bear, Stearns & Co. analyst Stephen Smith. But the oil giants should be able to navigate around most of these pitfalls, analysts say. Replacing crude supplies lost from Iraq and Kuwait should not be a problem, said Barry Sahgal, an analyst at the New York brokerage Ladenburg, Thalmann & Co. Inc. ``They are so flexible that they can move from one crude source to another,'' he said. In addition, analysts say the major oil companies will benefit from the rise in crude prices even if they can't pass along all of the costs to customers. Accounting practices allow them to book a profit when their production subsidiaries sell the crude _ at the newly higher prices _ to their refining units. Companies self-sufficient in crude production, such as Arco, should particularly benefit, Smith said, while those that have to purchase supplies on the world market will benefit less. Knuettel said he believes oil company profits will grow this year even if rising prices crimp demand for gasoline and other refined products. But he is less bullish about buying oil stocks than some analysts. Knuettel advises investors holding stock in major integrated oil companies to stand pat if the shares are considered a long-term investment. But if the shares are held in a trading account, investors should consider selling them to take a profit on days when the stock prices are up, he said. ``The excitement of the moment has caused oil shares to reach excessive prices near term,'' he wrote in a recent analysis. In fact, prices of many of the major oil company stocks hit 52-week highs in the days after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Since then they have moderated somewhat. ``There was panic buying'' in the issues, said Sahgal, on the belief that the stocks would benefit from the rise in oil prices and offer an inflation hedge. Bear, Stearns said in a report last week that even if oil prices average in the low $20 range for the rest of the year, energy company stocks, including gas and coal concerns, are not trading at prices that reflect their true value. The brokerage recommended these stocks be ``purchased aggressively.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, Aug. 20

DOC.HEAD: Ratings War Brings Sex, Nudity to Brazilian Prime Time
DOC.TEXT: Brazilian television, which was pretty steamy already, is filling prime time with nudity and semi-explicit sex in a network ratings battle. Viewers have been favored with such wonders as an all-nude rock band and a near-complete striptease. What many call the TV Sex War has inspired heated debate of electronic eroticism and how much is too much. ``The pornographic use of nudity is indecent, but nudity in itself is innocent,'' said Darcy Ribeiro, anthropologist and former education minister. ``The ancient Greeks performed acts far more indecent than anything seen on local TV.'' It all started in April when Manchete TV, Brazil's third-largest network, launched the prime-time soap opera ``Pantanal'' about a wealthy ranching family in the vast Pantanal wetlands of central Brazil. Manchete had an instant smash. For the first time, its ratings surpassed those of Globo TV, the leading network and the world's fourth-largest after ABC, CBS and NBC of the United States. ``Pantanal,'' broadcast six nights a week and scheduled to run through December, has an excellent cast and features breathtaking views of the wetlands. Was it the scenery that attracted huge audiences and started the whole country talking? Not a chance. It was near-explicit love scenes, the penchant of female stars for bathing in the river, the total frontal nude of an underwater swimmer in the opening credits. As Manchete celebrated its success, Globo counterattacked with a week of steamy, uncut movies running opposite the soap opera. Globo also unveiled, literally, popular star Claudia Raia during a beach scene in its own prime-time soap opera ``Queen of the Junk Yard,'' which runs just before ``Pantanal.'' Other networks joined in. Silvio Santos, owner of SBT, the second-largest, broadcast a series of literary adaptions as an alternative to the racy fare of other channels, and said later: ``We had the worst audience ratings in the nine years of SBT.'' A University of Sao Paulo survey in late June counted 1,145 displays of nudity and 276 scenes of explicit or implict sex in one week of television. Some viewers are outraged. ``We are not voyeurs, we are normal people,'' Ana Conceicao of Rio wrote to a major newspaper. ``The scenes being shown are so raw that explicit sex will soon be broadcast into our homes.'' Romeu Trussardi Filho, head of the Commercial Association of Sao Paulo, accused the networks of ``opportunism to generate higher ratings and greater profit opportunities.'' Justice Minister Bernardo Cabral has scheduled a meeting in early September with station owners, writers, soap opera stars and religious officials to discuss creation of a television code of ethics. Most Brazilians seem to like the spice. A survey by the newspaper Folha de Sao Paulo found 83 percent of those questioned felt ``comfortable'' with the nude scenes in ``Pantanal,'' 13 percent were ``embarrassed when watching with others'' and 4 percent were ``embarrassed when watching alone.'' Most said they wanted as many or more nude scenes. ``The public likes the sex and nudity,'' said Marta Suplicy, a psychoanalyst and author of several books on sex and culture. ``Most people have boring lives and enjoy watching others have a good time.'' Brazilians are used to exposed bodies, in minuscule ``tanga'' bikinis on the beaches or at the wild Carnival holiday before Lent, but eroticism on television was limited until a new constitution abolished all censorship in 1988. Coverage of Carnival heated up immediately and the Justice Ministry asked networks to exercise restraint in live broadcasts of semi-nude samba dancers at private clubs. Rosemarie Muraro, a prominent writer and feminist, said television merely reflects the way most Brazilians view sex and sexuality. ``People here are much more comfortable with their bodies than in Anglo-Saxon countries,'' she said. ``No one even notices the skimpy bikinis on Copacabana beach.'' She advocated more male nudity. Most of the bare scenes on television feature women. Ms. Muraro said her one concern about sex on television was that it might increase the rate of teen pregnancy. Mrs. Suplicy, the psychoanalyst, said gratuitous sex scenes ``reaffirm a macho culture and sexist stereotypes,'' and could harm younger viewers. ``No country in the world exposes its children to the same level of eroticism'' on television as Brazil, she said. ``Seven-year-old girls think about nothing but romance and seducing boys.'' The ratings battle, like the debate, rages on. In late July, Globo presented ``Skid Row,'' a mystery with the fully exposed form of actress-model Silvia Pfeifer as its main attraction. Manchete struck back with ``The Song of the Mermaids,'' a near-plotless revelation of the bare breasts of three other actress-models. Critics panned ``Mermaids,'' including one who said: ``If the show is any guide, Homer's Ulysses did not plug the ears of his brave sailors to protect them from the mermaids' enchanting song. It was to spare them from the stupidities they spouted.'' The public felt otherwise. ``Mermaids'' crushed ``Skid Row'' in viewer polls.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday AMs, Aug. 27

DOC.TEXT: The cost of living rose 0.4 percent in July, the government said in a report showing persistent inflation even before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait sent oil prices soaring. The advance Thursday in the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index was slightly higher than most economists had expected. It came despite a 0.7 percent decline in energy costs, sure to be more than reversed when August prices are reported next month. Excluding the volatile food and energy sectors, prices jumped a worrisome 0.6 percent. Analysts view this so-called ``core'' rate as a better gauge of underlying inflationary pressures.

Oil and gasoline futures prices moved sharply higher again following more saber-rattling by both sides in the Middle East standoff. The September contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark U.S. crude, closed up 90 cents at $27.36 per barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Crude oil's recent rise had stalled earlier in the week on news that Jordan's King Hussein would meet with President Bush, which gave rise to speculation that a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf crisis might be in the works.

Blaming competitive pressures, Amoco Corp. and Unocal Corp. ended a one-week freeze on wholesale fuel prices enacted after a public outcry against alleged price-gouging. Spokesmen for the companies declined to say Thursday whether the price freezes caused losses. Amoco and Unocal said they would monitor prices daily and that increases were possible.

Housing starts in July remained mired at depths not seen since the last recession, the government reported. Analysts forecast little, if any, improvement for the remainder of the year. The Commerce Department said Thursday that starts of new homes and apartments fell for the sixth straight month, down 2.6 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.15 million units. That was the lowest level since builders began 1.14 million units at an annual rate in September 1982. Starts have not fallen for six consecutive months since June-November 1981.

Low wages, few unions and modest unemployment benefits give North Carolina the best manufacturing climate among the nation's industrial states, says a study of business costs released by an accounting firm. North Dakota is tops among the 21 less-industrialized states, according to the survey released Thursday by Chicago-based Grant Thornton. The survey showed a striking increase in manufacturers' concern about the education level of their employees.

The Federal Reserve's rejection of the merger of Bank of New York and a Connecticut bank holding company may be a signal that banks should build strong capital reserves, analysts said. The central bank rarely rejects a bank merger. However, late Wednesday it announced it had denied the application from Bank of New York to acquire Northeast Bancorp Inc., which owns the Union Trust Co. of Stamford, Conn.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York temporarily moved its ``fedwire'' electronic funds transfer system out of New York because of a power problem, averting what could have been an unexpected bank holiday in the nation's financial center. The fedwire is the central bank's funds and securities transfer service, the principal means of transferring money between banks. The New York Fed's fedwire branch is the nation's busiest, shuttling $900 billion worth of securities and funds among banks daily. The move occurred Thursday.

Exxon Corp. said it will try to avoid paying $6.5 billion in taxes that the Internal Revenue Service is seeking in a decade-old dispute. Exxon filed a petition Thursday against the IRS in U.S. Tax Court in Washington. The government is seeking almost three times the $2.5 billion that Exxon has already paid in federal income tax for 1980-82. Exxon said the government's tax claim hinges on allegations the company avoided taxes by charging too little for oil it purchased from Saudi Arabia.

Shareholders in the 70-year-old apparel manufacturer Farah Inc. have voted to remove two officials from the board of directors, including the son of the company's founder. William F. Farah and Charles Wood were removed following a debate this year over who should control the company, Farah Inc. said Thursday. Last week, about 50 shareholders voted on the issue during a special meeting held at Farah's request. Other votes were mailed in.

Stock prices dropped sharply Thursday in moderate trading amid signs of rising inflation and increasing tension in the Middle East. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 66.83 to 2,681.44. The dollar tumbled to an all-time low against the German mark. Bond prices plummeted and interest rates soared. Gold futures prices surged, livestock and meat futures were mixed, and grains and soybeans were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Profits Under Pressure From Oil, Other Fronts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Many executives are trying to keep a stiff upper lip when it comes to how the recent spike in oil prices will affect corporate profits in the final months of 1990. But analysts say there's virtually no industry that will escape unscathed, even if the Middle East crisis is resolved soon, and it appears increasingly less likely that the final quarter will salvage a year of relatively lackluster returns. ``Everybody is going to be hurt by this,'' said Robert Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities Co. International Inc. ``I wouldn't think this is the kind of thing you can diversify against.'' The jump in oil prices is seen as raising costs of production, materials and shipping for everyone from farmers to industrialists. Statistics indicate the economy already was in a slowdown before the oil shock, and the outlook now might include a full-fledged recession. Still, many companies are maintaining their outward composure. They say that although they're monitoring the situation, it's still pretty much business as usual. ``We're concerned about the macro question of peace in our time, but I don't know if (the Gulf crisis) will have a bearing on the (fourth) quarter,'' said Barbara Lucas, a vice president of Towsend, Md.-based Black & Decker Corp. Union Carbide Corp. has seen ``no major effect on our operating or production costs'' and has made no major changes in its strategic plans, spokesman Thomas Sprick said from company headquarters in Danbury, Conn. Both he and Lucas suggested their companies may be somewhat insulated from higher prices because they have long-term contracts for raw materials. But contracts do get renegotiated, or even broken. ``The legal fees associated with breaking a contract might be cheaper than supplying somebody with cheap energy,'' said John Silvia, an economist and vice president at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago. Silvia has revised his profit projections in light of the oil crisis. He's predicting corporate profits will total $306 billion in the quarter ending Sept. 30, down from an earlier estimate of around $320 billion. And for the final quarter of the year, he expects profits to show an 18 percent decline from the year-ago period. ``There will be different degrees of impact, but I don't think anybody is going to walk away from it and say they're not affected,'' Silvia said. Companies taking the hit initially are airlines, transportation companies and consumer durables manufacturers, but that will filter down to most other industries over time, he said. ``The most serious overall issue has to be consumer confidence,'' Silvia said. Given the weakness in demand, manufacturers may have a hard time passing on price increases to compensate for their higher costs. ``The (Middle East) crisis adds another layer to the problems firms are facing,'' Nikko's Brusca said. ``They're cutting back capital spending . . . Inventories have been cut down and order backlogs have been falling for some time,'' all indications that corporate projections are less than optimistic. Many observers were hoping the final quarter would provide businesses with a shot in the arm, similar to the last three months of 1989, when after-tax profits rose 2.8 percent after falling in each of the previous three quarters. Retailers in particular are especially vulnerable in the final quarter, when they typically rack up most of their earnings during the holiday shopping period. This year, things started modestly. The Commerce Department said after-tax profits rose 1.1 percent in the first quarter. Results for the second quarter are scheduled to be released Aug. 24. But executives are not interested in looking backwards. ``If we have an interruption of supply, higher oil prices and a reallocation of resources . . . it would be difficult to see how we would escape that,'' said Leonard Hadley, executive vice president and chief operating officer of Maytag Corp., based in Newton, Iowa.

DOC.HEAD: New Currency Faces Skeptical Public
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The gold cordoba, Nicaragua's new money, has stumbled out of the starting gate despite an aggressive campaign by the government to bolster confidence in the currency. Nicaraguans seem wary of the gold cordoba, which went into circulation on Monday, and with the old cordobas still circulating, confusion mingles with the uncertainty. The old cordoba was devalued Thursday, the 31st time since President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro took office April 25, trading at 750,000 to the dollar from the previous rate of 690,000. It was bringing up to 800,000 to the dollar on Managua's flourishing and illegal black market. Francisco Mayorga, the head of Nicaragua's Central Bank, said the gold cordobas will be backed by dollars and will be exchanged on par with the dollar. Mayorga said tying the new currency to the dollar is intended to end the string of devaluations and bring some stability to the economy. The government said the devaluations of the old cordoba will continue until it is entirely replaced by the new money, possibly by the end of the year. On Monday, 4.5 million of the new cordobas went into circulation, representing about 10 percent of the value of the money in the country. State workers received up to 50 gold cordobas as a part of their salaries, and got the rest in old cordobas. But the lowest gold cordoba denomination is 5 cordobas, equal to five dollars, a large sum in one of the hemisphere's poorest countries. Bills of one gold cordoba and less are to begin circulating in October, but for now Nicaraguans spending gold cordobas have to take change in the old money at the official rate. Thousands of government employees, meanwhile, headed to black market moneychangers to try to swap the new money for dollars in case the new money became devalued, but the black marketeers, known locally as ``coyotes,'' weren't interested. ``The gold cordoba cannot be on par with the dollar,'' said one. ``The dollar is the world currency and even in underdeveloped countries with stable economies the money is not on par with the dollar.'' The Central Bank also refused to change the new cordobas for dollars, saying such a run would deplete its supply. Nicaragua is swimming in virtually worthless cordobas. In their last year in office the leftist Sandinista government stopped devaluing them, leaving the currency extremely overvalued. Mrs. Chamorro's government began a series of devaluations that sent prices for basics soaring, leading to two damaging general strikes, mostly by Sandinista-led unions.

DOC.HEAD: Even If Crude Becomes More Plentiful, Gas Prices Might Go Up
Graphic from of Aug. 16
DOC.TEXT: An increase in the world supply of crude oil will not necessarily translate into plenty of gasoline for the United States, according to oil industry sources who warned that higher prices might persist. Even though oil-producing nations could probably boost their output by up to 3.5 million barrels per day, making up for most of the 4 million barrels kept off the market by the boycott of Iraq and Kuwait, there could be problems in getting the crude refined to meet U.S. standards, the sources said. Additional production might be the wrong kind of crude, or it could come from Libya and Iran, which the United States will not do business with, several executives of a major oil company told reporters in a meeting Thursday. The executives, who spoke on condition that neither they nor their company be identified, said refineries that could increase output in several foreign countries are also unable to make oil products that meet stringent U.S. environmental standards, such as unleaded gasoline. ``There are certain crudes and certain products and certain suppliers you can't turn to,'' one of the executives said. ``The stuff that's idle today does not serve the purposes of the U.S.,'' said another executive. A spokesman for the American Petroleum Institute, the industry's main trade group, said refineries generally are geared to take a certain type of oil and they try to get that oil. ``There's great variation,'' among crudes and refineries, he said. World oil markets have been in a state of chaos, with prices steadily on the rise, after Iraq invaded neighboring Kuwait on Aug. 2 and an international boycott of the oil from both nations was put in place. The oil executives said three modern, sophisticated refineries in Kuwait have been knocked out of the world market because of the boycott. Those refineries had a capacity of about 600,000 barrels of refined oil per day, some of which was arriving in the southern United States through the Gulf of Mexico, the executives said. The executives predicted that OPEC nations will not immediately increase production to make up for the Iraq-Kuwait shortfall until they allow time for oil inventories to drop. Crude oil futures traded higher Thursday as investors remained uncertain about what might happen in the Middle East. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the September contract for West Texas Intermediate, rose 90 cents to $27.36 a barrel. Retail gasoline prices shot up after the invasion and remain well above their levels of a month ago. Unleaded, self-service gasoline averaged $1.216 a gallon nationally on Monday, compared with $1.075 a gallon on Aug. 1, according to a spot check of 1,400 service stations by the American Automobile Association. One of the oil executives called the current situation ``a long-term problem.'' He predicted the price of crude would stay high, as will the price of gasoline in coming months. Dozens of U.S. refineries have closed in recent years when oil prices declined. It would take a continued higher margin of profit on gasoline prices before oil companies build new refineries or increase the capacity of existing refineries, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Amoco, Unocal Lift Freeze on Wholesale Prices
With PM-Gulf-Gas Prices, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Two oil companies that had frozen wholesale fuel prices as consumers cried foul over steep increases at the pump lifted the moratoriums citing competitive pressure. Spokesmen for the Amoco Corp. and Unocal Corp. declined to say whether the one-week price freezes caused losses. Amoco and Unocal said they would monitor prices daily and that increases were possible. President Bush, in a televised address, last week called on the nation's oil companies to hold down pump prices and not take advantage of market jitters and rising crude oil prices following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Amoco and Unocal were among several big oil companies to freeze or lower wholesale prices. The reductions did not directly affect prices at retail gas stations, which by federal law set their own prices. ``There remains a lot of upward pressure,'' Amoco spokesman Michael Thompson said Thursday. ``We'll be watching the marketplace in the days to come and we'll see what happens.'' Amoco had frozen prices on gasoline, jet fuel and distillates. Thompson said the company, based in Chicago, did not change prices Thursday it charges wholesalers. Unocal, based in Los Angeles, had frozen only wholesale gasoline prices. It was to lift the freeze at 3 a.m. EDT today. ``It's a daily review and hourly review depending on how the market moves,'' Unocal spokesman Jim Bray said. ``We made a marketing decision. Several of the other majors have gone up recently.'' On Wednesday, Atlantic Richfield Co. extended a freeze on gasoline, jet and diesel fuel prices, but said it would review it on a daily basis. Arco, which sells gasoline at 1,500 stations in five Western states, was the first oil company to announce a freeze after pump prices increased sharply following Iraq's invasion. But there was no indication that the freezes were anything more than cosmetic, as crude oil prices have risen only slightly in the interim. On Thursday, crude oil gained 90 cents to $27.36 per 42-gallon barrel, compared with about $26 a barrel a week earlier. Retail gasoline prices shot up 16 cents a gallon on average after the invasion, but apparently have stabilized at the higher levels. Unleaded, self-service gasoline averaged $1.216 a gallon nationally on Monday, compared with $1.075 a gallon on Aug. 1, according to a spot check by the American Automobile Association. Phillips Petroleum Co., which cut its wholesale gasoline price by 4.5 cents a gallon on Aug. 8, said Thursday it has increased the price by 1.8 cents since then. British Petroleum Co.'s U.S. unit, which last Friday said it would hold its pump prices steady and later lowered them by about 3 cents a gallon in most markets, said its prices were about the same.

DOC.HEAD: Chemical Suits Could Boost Economies of Oklahoma Towns
With PM-Gulf-Gas Prices, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: While soldiers stand guard in the deserts of Saudi Arabia, some Oklahomans are busy at sewing machines and cutting tables to prepare equipment that may be needed on the front lines. Sac and Fox Industries has a $30 million contract with the Department of Defense to produce nearly 500,000 chemical warfare suits, protective garments that would be needed if Iraqi President Saddam Hussein uses his stockpiles of poison gas. The company owned by the Sac and Fox Indian tribe is planning to almost double its work force and reopen a clothing factory in Temple. Some say that may help some Oklahoma towns bounce back from recent pullouts and cutbacks by major employers. Sac and Fox employs 550 people at plants in Commerce, Cushing and Idabel. The increase in production, including eventual operations at Temple, could raise the employee total to more than 1,000, said Sac and Fox Industries president James Brannum. He said the increase is dependent on the company getting more of the type of fabric it uses, which he said is in big demand. For now, 19 workers from Temple, the southwestern Oklahoma town where Haggar Clothing shut down a factory in February, are commuting 220 miles to Idabel, in the state's southeastern corner, where they stay during the week at a hotel the company has leased, said office manager Mary Chambers. ``They're patriotic,'' Brannum said. ``They're not just doing it for the town or Oklahoma. They're wanting to do what is right for the country in a time of crisis.'' People are also eager for work. In addition to the Haggar shutdown in Temple, Idabel has been hit by Defense Department cuts at the Red River Army Depot in northeast Texas. While it is possible that Sac and Fox won't be able to hire all of the 270 workers laid off when Haggar left, Temple Mayor Jack Kindred said any opportunities are encouraging. Sac and Fox Industries has already signed a lease on the former Haggar plant, Kindred said. The community's economy sagged when Haggar left, Kindred said. ``We had about five little towns that we drew into Temple,'' he said. ``You used to drive through downtown and both sides of the street would be lined with cars,'' said Glen Good, manager of Warehouse Discount Food. ``We've got a dress shop that's barely hanging on. Even our (car license) tag agent is hurting. ``If Sac and Fox can put nearly as many people back to work than were here before, that's good.'' In Idabel, the impact may not be as noticeable. The McCurtain County seat was projected to grow even before the Sac and Fox expansion, said Bruce Willingham, a Sac and Fox Industries director. ``There's been a gradual increase in employment,'' Willingham said. ``The situation in the Middle East has brought home (to the workers) how pivotal their jobs are.'' He said it takes between 30 to 60 days to complete a suit, with a good piece of that time spent on detailed inspection process. About 10,000 suits are near completion and 60,000 total are under way. On Tuesday, 3,200 suits were shipped, plant officials said. Ms. Chambers said when the current contract is complete, the government has the option to order additional suits. The 2,500-member tribe expects there will be a market for the suits for some time, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Image Consultant Says Businesses Can Use Color to Compete
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Marily is cq
DOC.TEXT: Clothing, colors and table manners can make or break business executives, image consultants said here at their annual trade show. ``We have been programmed by television to deliver a message in 30 seconds,'' said Marily Mondejar, founder and executive director of Image Industry Council International, a trade organization for consultants who teach businesses how to polish their images. ``In the first five seconds of meeting a person, that person will make a decision about you ... based on maybe the colors you're wearing, your jewelry, your hair, how you're moving. That is what image is all about,'' she said Thursday at the San Francisco-based group's third annual meeting. ``Image ... is about bringing the best in you ... so that people will listen to what you have to say,'' Ms. Mondejar said. Wearing appropriate-colored clothing is one way executives can create an image to achieve their goals, she told about two dozen executives at a seminar titled ``Corporate Savvy.'' For example, darker colors convey a sense of authority, while lighter ones indicate friendliness. A businessman seeking to consummate a deal might want to convey both traits by wearing a dark suit with a light-colored necktie, she said. Table manners also can be a winning tool for executives, according to Ms. Mondejar, who said 70 percent of all business deals ``are closed during a meal.'' To project a polished, professional image, executives should know the proper way to butter their bread, said M.J. Cross, an image consultant from Munster, Ind. ``To butter a bread roll, take a bite-sized pinch, butter that bite, and put it in your mouth,'' rather than chomping into a large piece of buttered bread, she advised as the executives prepared to launch into a five-course demonstration meal at a posh downtown restaurant. ``Otherwise you have a great tendency to leave a buttery moustache,'' if you happen to have facial hair, Ms. Cross said. Color analysis is another way to assess people's personalities and help businesses succeed, Ms. Mondejar said. The theory groups people into categories based on the four seasons, depending on the color of their eyes, hair and complexion. An emerging branch of color analysis attaches personality traits to each season, Ms. Mondejar said in an interview during the conference. For example, dark-featured people are ``winters'' while those with lighter eyes and complexions are ``summers,'' she said. ``Winters'' tend to be bossy and power-hungry, while ``summers'' are more compromising and harmonious, Ms. Mondejar said. Executives can use the theory to assess their competitors and also determine what clothing colors can help them project the most complimentary, professional image, she said. Joan C. LeValley, president of a suburban Chicago accounting firm, was among the 150 or so executives who sought business-boosting tips at the four-day conference. Ms. LeValley said she has used a color consultant to improve her own appearance, and has decorated her office in earth tones to project a warm, comfortable image for clients. ``Business are learning that if we don't project ourselves in the professional status we are, we're going to fail, because somebody else is'' going to do it better, said Ms. LeValley.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Hopes To Whittle Down Multibillion-Dollar IRS Tax Claim
DOC.TEXT: Exxon Corp. is fighting a $6.5 billion tax claim brought by the IRS and the oil giant predicted it will chip away most of the government's case before going to trial next year. ``This case, when it gets to court, is not going to be a $6.5 billion case,'' Exxon tax lawyer William D. O'Brien said Thursday after filing a petition against the Internal Revenue Service in U.S. Tax Court in Washington. Exxon Chairman Lawrence G. Rawl called the attempt by the government to collect almost three times the $2.5 billion that Exxon has already paid in federal income tax for 1980-82 ``totally unwarranted.'' After Exxon announced its filing late Thursday, an IRS spokesman in Washington said no tax officials were immediately available to discuss the government's position in the decade-old dispute. According to Exxon, the government's tax claim hinges on allegations that the oil giant avoided taxes by charging too little for oil it purchased from Saudi Arabia. ``The IRS completely ignores that Saudi Arabia's policy of price moderation in the late 1970s and early 1980s required Exxon to buy and sell Saudi crude oil at the same prices established by the Saudi Arabian government,'' O'Brien said. At the time, Saudi Arabia was trying to keep the price of oil under control by selling crude cheaply in the wake of the Iranian revolution. At the time, the U.S. government was also encouraging moderation in oil prices, O'Brien said. Exxon finds it ironic that the government now has flip-flopped during the latest oil crisis and started saying Exxon should have charged more for its oil 10 years ago, O'Brien said. Since Exxon's income tax filing is so complicated, the company had waived the normal statute of limitations to give the IRS plenty of time to complete its audits. Earlier this year, Exxon demanded that the IRS move ahead on the matter, giving the tax collectors little choice but to file a claim against the company, O'Brien said. Exxon decided to force the IRS' hand because lawyers did not want to wait on the outcome of a similar fight between the government and Texaco, he said. The government's contention that Exxon did not charge enough for its oil, much of which was distributed to the company's overseas subsidiaries, involves $1.5 billion of the IRS claim. O'Brien described the other elements of the dispute as ``plain-vanilla-type items that ordinarily are in an oil company's tax return.'' They include such items as deductions for drilling costs, he said. Since Exxon pushed the government into making its claim, the IRS employed a shotgun approach because it did not have time to thoroughly explore each item. O'Brien predicted that negotiations between the two sides will result in many of the IRS' contentions being dropped. Should Exxon end up paying more taxes, the company has enough reserves on hand to avoid any effect on earnings, O'Brien said. He expects the case to go to trial before Tax Court Judge Meade Whitaker sometime in 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Ameritrust to Cut 780 Jobs
DOC.TEXT: The Ameritrust Corp. plans to cut about 11 percent of its staff as part of a plan to reduce costs by $60 million by the end of 1992. About 40 percent of the 780 positions are being cut through attrition, said Howard Glassroth, Ameritrust's vice president for corporate affairs. The action is a response to the changing marketplace and the economy, Glassroth said Thursday. ``This is fairly typical of what's going on in the banking industry right now,'' he said. Ameritrust reported losses of $33.2 million for the first half of this year. Jerry Jarrett, Ameritrust's chairman and chief executive officer, said the bank will provide ``comprehensive severance options and career transition programs'' for employees who are losing their jobs. Glassroth said he didn't know who would lose jobs or when the cuts would occur. The company employs about 6,800 people nationwide. The program is expected to last 12 to 16 months, but many of the cuts will occur this year. Bank employees will start learning Monday whether they will stay or go. Ameritrust said the cost-cutting program would not change its plans to move into new headquarters in 1993 nor does the company plan to close any bank branches. The company lost $51.6 million in the first quarter of this year after a regulatory exam led to a special $120 million addition to its reserve against possible loan losses. Daniel Martin, analyst at Standard & Poor's Corp., criticized Ameritrust for not being careful enough in the standards it used to evaluate highly leveraged transactions. ``Growth has taken place apparently without the attention to underwriting standards that should have been in place to avoid affecting asset quality down the road,'' he said. He said the rating on some Ameritrust bonds had slipped in recent years largely because of increased riskiness in its loan portfolio. Martin and other analysts praised the decision to cut costs, saying it reflects increased competitive pressures in the banking industry. ``I think it's tough for the people who are losing jobs, but I think it's a positive move for the company,'' said Tom Brown, an analyst with Paine Webber. He said many banks have begun trimming personnel, branch and administrative expenses to make up for sluggish loan growth caused by a slowing economy.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules On Resorts Reorganization Plan
DOC.TEXT: Resorts International moved closer to emerging from bankruptcy proceedings early today when a judge approved a restructuring plan that would allow entertainer Merv Griffin's casino company to shed some of its massive debt. Shortly after midnight, U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Rosemary Gambardella approved a plan to give bondholders 78 percent of the company, dropping Griffin's stake to 21.5 percent, said Resorts attorney Stephen Kaplan. The plan was filed in December under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code and amended in April to include the proposed sale of Resorts' Paradise Island operations in the Bahamas. Resorts would exchange the $911 million in debt held by bondholders for new notes totaling $434 million, eliminating more than half of the casino company's debt. The plan had been overwhelmingly approved by bondholders but must still be approved by the state Casino Control Commission and the Bahamian government. Last week, the commission approved Resorts' preliminary draft documents concerning ownership restructuring, the transfer of securities, the shift of Resorts to a publicly traded company and Resorts president David Hanlon's employment contract. The panel, which declined to rule on the plan until Ms. Gambardella released her decision, is scheduled to consider the matter today. The commission also will consider part of the plan that sets aside a $5 million legal kitty to allow Resorts bondholders to sue Donald Trump, Resorts' former owner. Bondholders claim Trump left the company insolvent in a 1988 swap with Griffin in which Trump got the unfinished Taj Mahal Casino Resort next door. Trump has said Griffin is responsible for weighing the company down with too much debt.

Stock prices fell steeply in early, heavy trading today, echoing losses overseas amid continued concern about the Mideast. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks fell 41.58 points to 2,639.85 in the first half hour of trading. In the broader market, declining issues outnumbered advancing ones by more than 6 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 145 up, 937 down and 331 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board totaled a strong 34.83 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. The market received a bit of good economic news this morning, but it appeared to be overshawdowed by Thursday's bad report on inflation and Mideast concern. The Commerce Department said the nation's trade deficit dropped to seven-year low of $5.07 billion in June. But analysts expect it to resume rising once the impact of increasing imported oil prices takes effect. On Thursday, the government reported that inflation rose at an unexpectedly high rate last month. Concern was increased because the data was measured before the start of the Mideast tension. In Japan, share prices plunged on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, where the key index closed 2.77 percent lower. Traders said many investors were disappointed that Thursday's meeting between President Bush and Jordan's King Hussein failed to produce any breakthrough in the Iraqi stalemate. Stock prices also were sharply lower in midday European trading. Disappointment over the Iraqi situation, as well as inflationary concerns, were blamed for Thursday's sharp price drop on Wall Street. The Dow Jones average fell 66.83 points to 2,681.44. Among most-active blue-chip stocks in early trading today, American Express fell ] to 25, Boeing dropped 1{ to 49[, General Electric was down 1 to 63~ and Philip Morris lost ] to 44~. The NYSE composite index of all its listed common shares fell 2.37 to 180.36. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index stood at 335.33, down 1.50. On Thursday, volume on the floor of the NYSE came to 138.85 million shares, up from 135.21 million shares in Wednesday's session. The NYSE's composite index fell 3.81 to 182.73. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index lost 3.81 to 336.83.

DOC.HEAD: Fildes Resigns as Cetus Chief Executive
DOC.TEXT: Robert Fildes has resigned as president and chief executive officer of biotechnology company Cetus Corp. The company said Thursday in announcing the resignation that it also plans to cut its workforce of 950 people by about 100 to ``lower its current operating expenses.'' The moves come two weeks after a Food and Drug Administration panel rebuffed the company's request for approval of its anti-cancer drug interleukin-2, and asked for more data. Fildes, who also stepped down as a director of the company, resigned because of ``differing views regarding the company's priorities,'' according to a Cetus news release. Asked what those priorities involved, company spokeswoman Jana Cuiper said she ``could not comment further than what was in the release.'' She said it has not yet been determined who will be involved in the layoffs. ``We should know by Sept. 15,'' she said. Fildes will provide ``continuing services to Cetus as a consultant,'' the company said. Company founder Ronald Cape has been named chief executive and Hollings Renton, the chief operating officer, was elected president. ``In the past, we have sought strategic relationships which contributed to our objectives, and we now intend to pursue more aggressively alliances which will help us build our business and lower our risk,'' said Cape. Cape had relinquished the chief executive's job to Fildes in 1986 and continued as chairman. Founded in 1971, the company develops, manufactures and markets therapeutic products targeted at cancers and serious infectious diseases.

DOC.NOTE: $adv20
For Release PMs of Monday, Aug. 20
DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices and Mideast News Supplant Government Reports as Bond Market Movers
DOC.TEXT: Once the bond market brushes the desert sand from a pile of government reports that show a weakening economy, fixed-income securities could be poised for a rally. The government reports of economic output, leading indicators and unemployment traditionally dominate the market's activity. But since Iraqi troops invaded Kuwait and American forces were dispatched to Saudi Arabia, news on the Persian Gulf crisis has been holding traders' attention. ``Really the Street is preoccupied with Mideast news rather than any government reports,'' said James Marshall, a government securities trader at Clayton Brown & Associates in Chicago. Rather than climbing on the signs of a weakening economy, the market has been swayed in its daily ups and downs by the latest pronouncements from Baghdad or Washington. Most of the movement has been down. The yield of the Treasury's 30-year benchmark bond, which rises when the bond price falls, has climbed from 8.45 percent shortly before Iraq invaded Kuwait to flirting with 9 percent late last week. ``What we've been saying in general is the economic statistics will take a back seat in general to whatever is going on in the Middle East,'' said Kathleen Camilli, chief economist at Ramirez Capital Consultants in New York. Investors are looking for signals of whether the Persian Gulf crisis is headed for a resolution and how oil prices could be affected. Ultimately they're trying to get an idea of what is going to happen to inflation, which erodes the value of fixed-income securities. Investors concerned about inflation have shied away from committing themselves. Thursday's report that the Consumer Price Index rose 0.4 percent in July was slightly more than what economists had expected and made many doubtful the Fed would try to lower interest rates before the Persian Gulf crisis settles down or there is more evidence the economy is sagging. Many are confident the Fed will have to lower interest rates to stimulate growth eventually. The government also reported Thursday that that housing starts had fallen for the sixth straight month in July to their lowest level since the last recession. Once bad news on the crisis slows or oil prices come down, investors are likely to rediscover the economy's weakness, said Irwin Kellner, chief economist at Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. Economists say several reports from the government show the economy is in trouble. July's unemployement rate reached its highest mark in nearly two years at 5.5 percent. Housing starts fell 2.6 percent in July. The gross national product showed a modest 1.2 percent increase in the second quarter. Economists point to a drop in total sales combined with a buildup in inventories as signaling an economic downturn. The Federal Reserve's own ``beige book,'' a survey of the 12 Fed districts, reported the pace of economic growth was slowing. ``If we get back to normal over there and oil prices show some weakening, the market will be in real good shape,'' Marshall said. More statistics highlighting the economy's ill health could also spark more interest in the bond market. The government is scheduled to report its revised second-quarter gross national product figure Friday, with economists expecting the economy to have grown a sluggish 1 percent. July's durable goods orders are expected to have increased 0.5 percent in Thursday's report.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Monday Aug. 20

DOC.HEAD: Trade Deficit Drops Sharply _ For Now
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts Mosbacher and midmorning stock market reaction, picking up 7th graf, The deficit . . . Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. trade deficit dropped to a seven-year low of $5.07 billion in June, the government said today, but analysts expect it to resume acceleration once the impact of the Middle East crisis takes effect on the price of oil imports. The Commerce Department said the June deficit was down 34.7 percent from the $7.77 billion imbalance posted in May. It was the lowest deficit since $3.96 billion in June 1983. Until recently, many economists and government officials, including Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher, were predicting that strong export growth would offset a growing dependence on foreign oil and result in the first U.S. deficit below $100 billion since 1983. In fact, the deficit for the first half of 1990 had been running at an annual rate of $91.62 billion. Mosbacher welcomed today's news, saying that while month-to-month figures can be erratic, ``the strong, positive trend indicates increasing U.S. export competitiveness in the world marketplace.'' But some analysts question the effect of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the subsequent rise in oil prices on later trade reports this month. Some say deficits could grow even larger once the higher oil prices are added to the import bill starting in August. The stock market largely ignored the news and appeared to be concentrating on Thursday's report on inflation and the Mideast itself. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks dropped 33.42 points to 2648.02 by late morning. The deficit improvement in June came from a 2.9 percent decrease in imports to $39.37 billion, and a 4.6 percent gain in exports to a record $34.3 billion. The trade deficit is the difference between imports and exports. A Commerce spokesman said $500 million in airplane shipments contributed to the record exports. It was the first time this year the deficit had dropped below $7 billion. It averaged $7.64 billion a month so far in 1990, compared to $9.12 billion in 1989. But higher oil import costs now threaten to add even more than expected to the U.S. import bill. At the same time, overseas economies have slowed, lessening demand there for U.S. goods. ``So you have a combination of slower export growth and a higher oil import bill,'' explained Mark M. Zandi, an economist with Regional Financial Associates in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. ``Those two things are going to serve to limit any possibility of a significant improvement in the merchandise trade deficit over the next six months to a year,'' he said. Oil imports in June fell 14.6 percent to $3.69 billion. Americans imported 8.40 million barrels a day, down from 8.95 billion in May. The average price per barrel fell to $14.64, down from $15.57. However, in an ominous portent for trade reports this fall, prices of the benchmark West Texas crude had risen to $27.36 by Thursday. In addition to aircraft, other capital goods, foods, and consumer goods added to the export total. On the import side, there were declines in industrial supplies, consumer goods and automobiles. As usual, the biggest deficit was with Japan, a $3.1 billion imbalance, up from a $3.0 billion deficit in May. The United States posted a surplus with western Europe of $899 million. Other deficits included Taiwan, $900 million; China, $800 million; Canada, $700 million; Brazil, $300 million; Korea, $200 million, and Hong Kong, $100 million. The deficit peaked at $152.12 billion in 1987 and then dropped to $118.53 billion the following year. The 1989 deficit slid further to $109 billion. A further improvement this year would have been good news for the Bush administration, which had counted on a strong trade performance to help keep the economy out of a recession and help reduce the federal budget deficit. Over the past three years, fully one-third of overall U.S. economic growth has been supplied by surging export sales. That has become even more important recently as consumer spending has faded in the face of adverse economic news. Zandi noted that, until the Middle East developments, the United States' foreign oil bill totaled about $100 billion a year. Prices have soared since the invasion. ``So if it remains at current levels, it could add between $10 billion and $15 billion over the coming year to our oil import bill,'' he said. At the same time, evidence points to weaker exports because of slower economic growth particularly in Japan and the Pacific Rim nations, and to a lesser extent in Western Europe, Zandi said. ``Our forecast is for real export growth to slow to about 5 percent over the next year'' from about 17 percent now, he said. Zandi also had a scenario that would dramatically improve the deficit, but one which few want to see. ``If the economy slides into a significant recession, where we see consumers and businesses retrenching, that would cause the deficit to improve soley because imports would collapse,'' he explained.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Slip On Weather, Slack Export
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade as concern about slack export demand replaced talk of possible frost in the northern Corn Belt. Few traders took Thursday's frost forecast by one private meteorologist seriously, said Joel Karlin, a grain analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. ``That's absurd,'' he said of the prediction for freezing temperatures Monday night. ``As a matter of fact, we're probably going to have a warmer weekend this weekend than we've had for a while.'' Karlin attributed further selling to expectations that export demand for U.S. feed grains is likely to remain weak _ especially if the Persian Gulf conflict tips the world's major economies into recession. In early trading, wheat futures were 2{ cents to 3 cents lower with the contract for delivery in September at $2.81} a bushel; corn was } cent lower to \ cent higher with September at $2.49 a bushel; December oats were down 2\ cents with the untraded September contract bid at $1.15} a bushel, 2\ cents below Thursday's settlement; soybeans were 9{ cents lower to 3 cents higher with August at $6.06 a bushel. Livestock futures were mostly lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange; pork bellies were mixed. Live cattle futures were .15 cent to .40 cent lower with August at 78.17 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent to .60 cent lower with August at 89.80 cents a pound; live hogs were .25 cent lower to .08 cent higher with August at 57.65 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .30 cent lower to .68 cent higher with August at 48.65 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled mixed on Thursday.

DOC.NOTE: $adv20
For release Monday Aug. 20
DOC.BYLINE: Dog Day Christmas: Sleighs Amid Summer Vacationers at Year-Round Stores
DOC.TEXT: There are 12 days of Christmas, but 12 months of shopping for it. On a recent summer morning, the sleighs outside the Christmas House here looked misplaced on a lush lawn, but inside, cheerily making their way among the nutcrackers and garlands, were plenty of customers. ``I come in here and I just think, `Oh, it's time to start buying,' '' Marcia Mulholland, 50, said over the strains of Christmas tunes. Mulholland isn't alone. Christmas enthusiasts spread enough cheer to keep hundreds of similar stores open year-round throughout the country _ from Nome to New Orleans. ``There is no question in my mind that people are spending more on Christmas than they used to,'' said Barry Vaill, who owns the 45,000-square-foot store in rural Rhode Island. ``Christmas is in renaissance.'' His sales exceeded $1 million last year, but, he said, pointing to 50 carefully trimmed trees, ``first and foremost, I'm in the entertainment business _ if they buy something, fine.'' Last spring, Vaill and 20 other stores formed the National Independent Christmas Shops, an association to share ideas, offer support and guard the Christmas image against cut-rate discounters that use the Christmas name to sell everything from furniture to flower pots. Vaill, the association president, said most year-round Christmas store owners are drawn to the business by a love of the holiday. Still, he estimated about 25 percent are trying to capitalize on a lucrative niche. But the Christmas business isn't all merry and it takes a certain faith to survive. ``I don't think you realize what the first quarter is like until you've been through it,'' said association membership chairwoman Gayle Boutin, owner of the Christmas House of Stone Mountain, Ga. She said sales in January and February can drop to 10 percent of December levels. Vaill helps keep more than coal in his summer stocking by selling decorations for every holiday: St. Patrick's Day trees, Uncle Sam nutcrackers, Halloween garlands and Thanksgiving dolls. Boutin, who had sales of $250,000 in her 1,000-square-foot shop last year, relies on tourists for much of her trade, as do many others who locate their stores in historic buildings, from an adobe in El Paso, Texas, to San Francisco's Fisherman's Wharf. ``Everybody in every market does it differently,'' said Vaill. But ``they all claim to be doing well.'' ``They're all up 20 percent to 25 percent this year and this is not a good year (for retail sales) so tell me what that means?'' he said. He and Boutin agree an increased interest in collectables has helped stimulate the industry. Annalee Dolls started 30 years ago as a woman's hobby and last year employed 450 people to make more than 700,000 felt dolls, said Sam Vachon, executive marketing director of the Meredith, N.H., company. He said about 15 percent, or 105,000 dolls, go to year-round Christmas stores. ``Five years ago it was maybe 5 percent,'' he said. ``Every year there are more and more stores carrying Christmas year-round,'' he said. Annalee makes dolls for other holidays, but about three-quarters are related to Christmas, he said. The reindeer, Santas and such stand from 3 to 30 inches and retail for $12 to $340. ``People have really started decorating for Christmas,'' he said. ``I think it's a feel-good thing. It makes them feel good.'' James Heintze, of Derwood, Md., who is writing a guide to year-round Christmas shops, has identified 150 nationwide. Annalee's Vachon, however, said he thought there are hundreds. Tiny Rhode Island boasts at least six. Heintze, 47, a professor of American Studies at American University in Washington, said he hasn't figured out yet why people shop at Christmas stores off-season, he only knows that they do. He theorized that since many families get together only for Christmas, shopping for the holiday is a reminder of that. Mulholland of Cranston had her mother and daughter in tow at the Christmas House. Kim Mulholland, 26, settled on a Buyers' Choice Scrooge caroler that she put on lay-away. Another customer, Mary Bentson, 55, of Dallas, had her sights set on something less expensive than the $30 to $40 dolls. ``I told my sister when I came (to Rhode Island) I wanted to come buy some little tree ornaments,'' she said. Her brother-in-law, Mike DeCarlo, 62, of Providence, had no qualms about shopping for Christmas during New England's dog day summer. ``There are no crowds, you get the pick of the place, this is the best time to come,'' he said. ``You come here in the winter and you can't get in the place.'' End adv for Monday Aug. 20
