DOC.HEAD: BellSouth Gets OK for Cellular Phone Network in New Zealand
DOC.TEXT: BellSouth Corp. is going ahead with plans to develop an advanced cellular telephone network in New Zealand, believed to be the first such system in the Southern Hemisphere. The Atlanta-based telecommunications company announced Friday it was proceeding with the project following approval from the New Zealand Commerce Commission. BellSouth spokeswoman Carlton Hill said the company plans to spend $100 million over 10 years to develop the network and will begin offering cellular phone service to New Zealanders in 1992. The system will be based on the newly emerging Group Speciale Mobile (GSM) pan-European standard, a communications system which is being used as the platform for the introduction of personal communications service in the United Kingdom. Long-term plans include the introduction of fax and other data applications through the system. ``By the mid '90s, we will be assigning telephone numbers to people, not places,'' said Terry Winters, managing director of BellSouth New Zealand. ``Our customers will be able to communicate with each other, no matter where they are, by using a lightweight, pocket-size, go-anywhere handset.'' Winters said New Zealand was chosen for the company's first GSM project because of that country's strong economy and because customers there have embraced cellular services.

DOC.HEAD: Fantle's Drug Stoire Chain Will Be Liquidated
DOC.TEXT: The Fantle's drug store chain will be liquidated after management and the creditors were unable to agree on a restructuring plan, the company announced today. ``The creditors were more desirous of up front cash, viz a viz long term growth,'' said Sheldon W. Fantle, chairman and chief executive officer. ``We anticipate that within 90 days the stores will be fully liquidated and the leases sold.'' Fantle's, which carries the name of Dart Drug Stores Inc., filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy law last August. Fantle, the former head of People's Drug Stores, bought the company three years ago from a management group which was heavily in debt. He changed the name of the stores last year. The 69 stores in the Washington and Baltimore areas will operate as usual until a ``going out of business'' sale begins next month, he said. Fantle said he ``regrets that management did not have the time and resources to implement fully the new and innovative concepts which the company initiated, but the strong competitive environment and economic conditions precluded this from happening.'' A court hearing is scheduled for Aug. 31, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Sears Won't Confirm Report It Plans to Ax Thousands of Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Sears, Roebuck and Co. plans to eliminate thousands of jobs in coming months to help cut costs and improve profits, a newspaper reported Friday. Sears would not confirm the report. The move, involving administrative and retail employees, is expected to result in annual savings of more than $100 million, according to the Wall Street Journal. It cited an unidentified person familiar with the plan. The newspaper said the cuts are part of Sears Chairman Edward A. Brennan's strategy to revive the company's weak retailing business. Sears spokesman Doug Fairweather would not confirm the report. ``Mr. Brennan is looking at all opportunities to enhance revenues, improve margins and reduce costs in all areas,'' Fairweather said Friday. ``This review is ongoing and no final decisions have been made,'' said Fairweather. He declined to discuss the matter further. According to the Journal, jobs to be eliminated include administrative staff positions at Sears' headquarters as well as non-selling positions at the retailer's 850 U.S. stores. The Journal's source said Sears hasn't determined how many of its 337,000 U.S. merchandising employees will go. But, the newspaper said, the company hopes to reduce corporate overhead by combining its 600-member corporate staff with the merchandise group headquarters staff. By the end of the year, Sears expects to eliminate overlapping jobs in personnel, finance and some positions at the officer level, the newspaper said. An automation system similar to one rival Montgomery Ward & Co. has adopted to cut costs will be used to take the place of retail employees in such non-selling positions as customer service and stocking merchandise, the Journal said. The article comes a week after Brennan took control of the company's Merchandise Group and vowed to cut costs. Net income produced by Sears' Merchandise Group tumbled 32 percent during the second quarter of this year, and Sears' stock has fallen sharply in recent weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Profit Down in First Half for Chemical Group
DOC.TEXT: Ciba-Geigy AG, Switzerland's largest chemicals and pharmaceuticals group, reported Friday that after-tax profit dropped 12 percent in the first half of the year because of economic conditions. Earnings fell to 1.216 billion Swiss francs, or $935 million, from 1.382 billion Swiss francs ($1.06 billion) for the same period last year. First-half sales declined 2 percent to 10.911 billion Swiss francs ($8.39 billion). A company press release said the Swiss franc results were adversely affected by the weakening of the dollar, the yen and the British pound. It said that in addition the economic climate was especially impaired by weak growth in North American automobile, textile and construction industries and by structural problems in Latin America and Eastern Europe. The company said it expected sales and earnings for all of 1990 to develop at a ``somewhat lower rate than in 1989.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Weaker, Gold Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout with closing prices from Europe, midday quotes from New York.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar fell broadly Friday in Europe, posting an all-time low against the German mark as worries over fundamental weakness in the U.S. economy gripped the market. Gold rose in steady trading. The dollar fell to 1.5485 German marks in Frankfurt from 1.5630 marks late Thursday. It was the lowest close in Europe in the mark's 42-year history. The previous closing low in Europe had been 1.5605 marks set Wednesday, and the dollar closed at a all-time New York low of 1.5525 marks Thursday. At midday in New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.5575 marks. The dollar's latest decline came despite the government's report of an unexpectedly small U.S. trade deficit for June of $5.07 billion. Dealers said pessimism over the condition of the U.S. economy had eclipsed any bullishness in the dollar. ``The overall opinion is that the U.S. economy is so bad (the market) doesn't really care if those figures are good or not. The general idea is to sell the dollar,'' a dealer in Frankfurt said. Dealers said the dollar was also hurt by reported comments from West German central bank Vice President Helmut Schlesinger. In a newspaper interview published Friday, he said the U.S. currency's decline fits the central bank's strategy because it reduces West German import prices. This was seen as an invitation to sell the dollar on the presumption that the influential West German central bank probably would not intervene to support it. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.55 Japanese yen to 147.35 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 147.65 yen. At midday in New York, the dollar was quoted at 147.35 yen. In London, the British pound rose to $1.9195 from $1.8985 late Thursday. In New York, the pound was quoted at $1.97425 at midday. Other late dollar rates in Europe compared with late rates Thursday included: 1.2815 Swiss francs, down from 1.3025; -5.2045 French francs, down from 5.2495; 1.7445 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7610; 1,141.75 Italian lire, down from 1,149.75, and 1.1440 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1477. Selected dollar rates at midday in New York included: 1.2795 Swiss francs, 1,149.75 Italian lire and 1.4375 Canadian dollars. Gold rose to $409.25 a troy ounce in London from $403.50 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold rose to $408.25 an ounce from $401.25 late Thursday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $9.95 to close at $410.96. Silver rose in London to $5.20 a troy ounce from $5.13 late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: British Stocks End Sharply Lower
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the London Stock Exchange sank Friday to their lowest levels since April, depressed by fears about the course of the Middle East crisis. Dealers said traders were also squaring positions before the weekend to protect themselves against any unexpected developments in the Gulf region. Only four stocks in the closely watched Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index escaped the onslaught, all of them oil companies. The international sector, undermined by a surging pound, included some of the day's biggest losers. At the close, the FT-SE 100-share index stood at 2,176.9, down 45.2 points, or 2 percent. The narrower Financial Times 30-share index was down 46.0 points to 1,678.9. The 500-share index was down 25.09 points at 1,174.43. Volume was 500.5 million issues, compared with the 375.4 million shares traded Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Price Freeze, Refinery Fire, Drain Arco Supplies
DOC.TEXT: About 270 Atlantic Richfield Co. stations have run out of regular unleaded gasoline during the past week as demand surged for its low-priced fuel and a refinery fire reduced supplies, Arco said. Arco froze its prices to dealers indefinitely after President Bush asked oil companies to exercise restraint following Iraq's invasion of oil-rich Kuwait. Then a fire Monday at Arco's refinery in Carson cut production from 235,000 barrels a day to 205,000. Production is expected to be back to full production next Monday, Arco spokesman Doug Elmets said. Arco, which sells gas at about 1,700 stations in five Western states, said its sales volume has risen 9 percent since it announced the freeze on Aug. 8. It said nearly all the 270 stations that posted temporary ``sold out'' signs are in Southern California and the Phoenix and Las Vegas areas. Elmets said it has taken an average of 2{ hours to replenish tanks of regular unleaded gas at the stations.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Shuts Down Mustang Plant
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. will extend this week's shutdown of its Dearborn assembly plant through next week because of a shortage of 2.3-liter engines for the Ford Mustang car, the company said Friday. Ford spokesman Jay Meisenhelder said the shortage stemmed from the transfer of a slightly different 2.3-liter engine to the company's Lima, Ohio, engine plant. Previously the engine was made in Mexico. The Dearborn plant was closed this week because of a shortage of dealer orders. There are about 2,100 hourly employees at the plant.

DOC.HEAD: Nordstrom Settles All Claims with NLRB
DOC.TEXT: Nordstrom Inc. said today it has settled all outstanding labor claims with the National Labor Relations Board, but a union official questioned whether the year-long dispute with the clothing-store chain is over. Thirteen of the 19 charges filed by the United Food and Commercial Workers Union have been dismissed or withdrawn, said Joe Demarte, Nordstrom vice president for personnel. He said the company would sign a settlement agreement later in the day. ``Nordstrom in no way admits it has committed any violations of law by signing the settlement,'' said Nordstrom spokesman Dave Marriott. But the union will not be party to a settlement ``unless Nordstrom admits it has done what they have been accused of,'' said president Joe Peterson of UFCW Local 1001, which represents some of the retailer's 1,500 area workers. ``As far as we're concerned the company's problems are far from over,'' Peterson said. The settlement concerns complaints filed over Nordstrom's relationship with the union and its role in a union decertification effort. The agreement covers one Tacoma store and five Seattle-area Nordstrom stores, whose employees are represented by UFCW Locals 367 and 1001. Under the settlement, Nordstrom will be required to post for 60 days a notice explaining NLRB findings to employees as well as company actions required under the settlement, Marriott said. The company has promised not to punish employees for union activities or to offer benefits to employees that are effective only if the union is ousted, he said. The retailer also has agreed to provide certain information requested by the union, Marriott said. The company also will allow pro-union employees the same privileges as anti-union workers in the matters of distributing handbills and posting fliers, he said. ``The settlement wipes the slate clean in terms of the unfair labor practice charges that have been filed by the union,'' Demarte said. ``We felt it was more important to reach a settlement of the issues pending before the NLRB rather than continuing to debate the merits of the union's allegations,'' he said. But Peterson said Nordstrom wants the settlement so a new union decertification petition can be circulated, adding that the process cannot begin while there are charges pending before the NLRB. The union has five days to object after the settlement is signed, said NLRB regional attorney Walter Mercer. The union is in the process of filing new charges against the retailer, Peterson said, adding that ``there will not be an election or decertification in the near future.'' The new charges will involve alleged discrimination against union negotiators at a store south of Seattle, Peterson said. The union also plans appeals on four other charges the labor board ruled against, he said. The UFCW represents about 1,500 of Nordstrom's Seattle-area employees. Nordstrom employs about 30,000 people nationwide. In February, the Washington State Department of Labor and Industries ruled that Nordstrom had violated state law by failing to pay some employees for such activities as attending company meetings, making deliveries and writing customer thank-you notes. A union lawsuit seeks back pay for the workers.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures End Mixed; Little Fresh News
DOC.TEXT: Corn and soybean futures closed higher and wheat ended lower Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade after a day of choppy trading in the absence of fresh supply-and-demand developments. Weather forecasts remained beneficial for corn and soybean development and export demand remained weak, leaving traders with nothing to do but play ``a money game,'' said Gerald Zusel, manager of trading-floor operations for Balfour Maclaine Corp. ``We just keep chopping around and everybody buys the rallies and everybody sells the breaks,'' he said. The markets opened lower, led by a 9 cents-a-bushel drop in soybeans, then rallied at mid-morning. But ``there was no news at all today, no significant business to account for the rally, no significant news to account for the break,'' Zusel said. DOC.HEAD: Hourly Chrysler Workers Offered Buyout
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp., which is trying to reduce its salaried work force as a cost-cutting move, is offering nearly all of its 60,000 or so unionized employees money to leave the company. Chrysler spokesman Lee Sechler said Friday that 400 to 450 of the eligible workers had chosen the buyout so far. Another week is left for workers to sign up. The last day of work for anyone choosing to leave will be Aug. 31. ``It's a positive alternative to layoffs,'' Sechler said. ``I think everybody is looking at ways to cut back and reduce costs.'' Last October, Chrysler began a program to carve $1 billion from its $26 billion annual budget by the end of this year. Since then, the target has risen to $1.5 billion. Included in the cuts were the early retirements of about 2,500, or more than 11 percent, from Chrysler's salaried work force. Sechler declined to say how much Chrysler's ``voluntary termination of employment program'' for its union-covered employees will cost. He also declined to give the formula used to calculate the buyout amount, but said it would be based heavily on the employee's seniority with the company. Workers employed with Chrysler for at least one year are eligible. Originally, executives estimated that about 600 workers would sign up for the buyouts, Sechler said. Sechler said the program, contained in the 1988 contract between Chrysler and the United Auto Workers union, was begun in late July or early August. The UAW and each of the Big Three are involved in national contract negotiations. The current agreements, covering more than 450,000 workers, expire Sept. 14. Chrysler is the nation's No. 3 automaker. No. 1 General Motors Corp. has been involved since 1987 in a formal cost-cutting program called the ``Action Plan'' which is expected to cut about $13 billion in costs by the end of this year. Ford Motor Co. has no formal cost-cutting program, but says it constantly looks for ways to reduce expenses.

DOC.HEAD: Eximbank to Help U.S. Firm Compete for Big Helicopter Order
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Export-Import Bank said Friday it is ready to guarantee a $1.37 billion credit to help an American aerospace firm compete for a Turkish order of 200 helicopters. The government-operated bank said it notified Congress of the loan guarantee after reviewing the international situation and evaluating Turkey's credit worthiness. United Technologies Corp. of Hartford, Conn., is competing for the order against Aerospatiale of France, Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm GmbH of West Germany and Agusta of Italy, the announcement said. United Technologies hopes to sell the Turkish Defense Ministry kits for final assembly in Turkey between 1992-94 of 200 Sikorsky UH-50L general utility helicopters expected to cost about $1.5 billion, said the Bank. The unarmed helicopters would be used for reconnaissance, medical evacuation and search and rescue. The Bank said it is allowed by law to make an exception to its policy against financing military equipment sales. Under that exception, the Bank may guarantee loans for commercial sales of defense hardware for Greece and Turkey provided the purchases are not for use on Cyprus.

DOC.HEAD: Commerce Department: Taiwain Dumping Cheap Sweaters in U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Sweaters made of synthetic fibers in Taiwan are being sold in the United States at less than fair market value, the Commerce Department ruled Friday. The National Knitwear & Spsortswear Association in New York had filed complaints last September against sweater manufacturers in South Korea, Hong Kong and Taiwan. The department had ruled against the manufacturers in Hong Kong on July 21 and against those in South Korea on Aug. 3. The findings clear the way for the International Trade Commission to determine whether the products are harming U.S. industry. If the commission finds U.S. firms are being damaged, the government can impose duties on the imports to make their prices comparable to those of U.S. companies. The department said the imports represent 72 percent of the $1.3 billion U.S. market and the three countries represent 55 percent of the imports. It said the value of the sweaters imported from South Korea in 1989 was $476.1 million; from Hong Kong, $208.8 million; and Taiwan, $485.5 million. The department said the imports are made predominantly of acrylic fiber. Sweaters containing at least 23 percent wool are excluded.
