DOC.HEAD: Sunglass Maker Seeks Shade Of Bankruptcy Court
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Mauri in 7th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: Isn't that Foster Grant in bankruptcy court? The company, whose ads asking which star was behind its sunglasses produced sales and advertising prominence, has sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection from creditors. Industry executives said Foster Grant Corp. foundered in the last decade after failing to capitalize on its catchy and successful print and television ads of the 1960s and '70s that asked ``Isn't that . . . behind those Foster Grants?'' In papers filed Thursday in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Tuscon, Ariz., it reported total assets of about $25 million and liabilities of about $36 million, including nearly $19.3 million in unsecured debt. Foster Grant, founded in 1919 by Sam Foster, was the first company to use abrasion-resistant lens coatings that blocked the sun's ultra-violet rays, but is best known for its advertisements. The first of 17 print ads debuted in 1965 and featured Peter Sellers behind a pair of Foster Grants. Other entertainment personalities including Woody Allen, Vanessa Redgrave, Julie Christie, Raquel Welch and Jane Fonda appeared in the ads, which ran until 1968. A series of television ads followed, and commercials later featured non-stars and asked, ``Isn't that you behind those Foster Grants.'' Despite the success of a campaign still remembered today, Foster Grant's recognizable name ``never really took them into the high level part of the market,'' said Mauri Edwards, Foster Grant's vice president of marketing from 1964-73. ``It came through the '70s in pretty good shape but the thing went downhill rapidly in the 80s,'' said Edwards, who now manages public relations for the Sunglass Association of America. He said Foster Grant began its downturn after the death in 1971 of Joe Foster, whose father in 1929 sold a 50 percent interest in what was then a small maker of sunglasses and combs to what is now Goody Products. In 1975, Foster Grant, with more than $300 million in sales of petrochemicals, sunglasses and other products, was sold to the U.S. arm of the West German chemicals concern Hoechst AG. It then was acquired by the American unit of the French pharmaceutical and chemical company Roussel-Uclaf SA. The company sold its bulk plastic making operations in the 1970s. In 1986, Foster Grant was acquired by Andlinger & Co., a private investment banking and management company. Foster Grant vice president Ed Russell blamed the bankruptcy court filing on cash flow problems and low profit margins resulting from competition from Asian imports. ``The company had not been profitable in 1989, nor in the first half of 1990,'' he said, adding that loss figures still were being compiled. The company said it sold more than $50 million of sunglasses, eyeglasses and related lens products in 1989, compared with with $55 million in 1983. In the same period, U.S. retail sales of nonprescription sunglasses rose to $1.7 billion from $885 million, according to industry figures. Foster Grant, which had as many as 2,000 seasonal employees in the 1960s, said it was laying off 345 of 475 employees at its main distribution center in Tucson, an assembly plant in Nogales, Mexico, and a plant in Leominster, Mass., for one week starting Monday. Foster Grant still is one of top names in the mass sunglass industry, where glasses sell for under $10. Opti-Ray Inc., owned by Goody Products of Kearny, N.J., is considered the leader in that field, along with Bonneau of Dallas. The market for more expensive sunglasses is led by Bausch & Lomb Inc. of Rochester, N.Y., maker of the Ray-Ban line. Other popular brands include the French sunglasses Vuarnet and Bolle. Foster Grant's technical products division supplies products to the computer, automotive, sporting goods and electro-mechanical industries.

DOC.HEAD: FundAmerica Files for Bankruptcy Protection
DOC.TEXT: FundAmerica Inc., a buying club with 100,000 members, filed for bankruptcy protection from its creditors Friday and asked the court to appoint an independent examiner to investigate various allegations against it. The Irvine, Calif.-based firm is facing scrutiny from regulators in Florida and other states and is the subject of a $150 million class-action suit in San Francisco. Its federal bankruptcy filing in Santa Ana, which had been expected, listed assets of $17.5 million and liabilities of $14.5 million. ``Prompt and decisive action had to be taken to preserve FundAmerica's viability for its members and marketers,'' said Mitchell G. Blumberg, its president and chief executive. Critics say FundAmerica's discounts on goods and services are available free through other channels or are subsidized by its membership fees. In lawsuits they allege the company's true business is high-pressure marketing of memberships in packages of 40 at $80 apiece. Florida officials have charged FundAmerica founder Robert T. Edwards with fraud for allegedly bilking club members out of $8.2 million in an illegal pyramid scheme. FundAmerica has not been convicted of any crimes. The Chapter 11 filing gives the company breathing room from creditors while it tries to sort out its problems. Blumberg, a past associate of Edwards in real estate, said the filing would give FundAmerica time to develop marketing plans acceptable to regulators. He said he believed it would allow the company to automatically lift a freeze on assets that was reaffirmed Wednesday by Marilyn Hall Patel, the federal judge in the class-action suit. He said FundAmerica would ask the bankruptcy judge to use company funds to meet its payroll. Blumberg said the company was reviewing the legal challenges against it and invited the bankruptcy court to appoint an independent examiner. ``We are confident that we are delivering an honest and valuable product via an honest, credible and reputable marketing organization,'' he said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Lower, Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar sank to another all-time low Friday against the German mark and fell against most other major currencies, reflecting continuing pessimism about the state of the U.S. economy. Gold prices were mixed. After gold posted gains in other markets, Republic National Bank in New York quoted an after-hours bid of $408.50 a troy ounce as of 4 p.m. EDT, down 50 cents from Thursday's late bid. The dollar fell to an all-time closing low of 1.5485 German marks in Europe from 1.5630 marks late Thursday. Its previous closing low in Europe had been 1.5605 marks set Wednesday. In New York, the dollar ended at 1.5500 marks, a new low for that market. The dollar's previous lowest close in New York had been 1.5525 marks on Thursday. For the week, the dollar sank 6.7 percent against the mark in domestic dealings. In other dealings Friday, the dollar fell against every major currency but the Japanese yen in New York trading after falling broadly overseas. The latest decline came despite the government's report of an unexpectedly small U.S. trade deficit for June of $5.07 billion. Despite the improvement, dealers said traders shunned the dollar because they feel the economy may be headed into a recession and that the Federal Reserve will have no choice but to encourage lower interest rates. When U.S. rates are falling relative to those in other countries, the dollar is less appealing to foreign investors. ``Dollar traders are just not interested in the trade picture,'' said Walter Simon, a currency options trader at Bank Julius Baer & Co. ``They are interested in the whole weakening of the U.S. economic climate.'' He said the dollar finished above its lows because of some late dollar-buying by traders who were reluctant to leave themselves exposed over the weekend to the possibility that flareups in the Persian Gulf could push the dollar higher. ``The United States seems to be taking a lot more aggressive posture toward Iraq,'' Simon said. But he said the dollar is demonstrating only limited appeal as a haven currency during this international conflict, which began with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Dealers in Europe said the dollar was hurt by reported comments from West German central bank Vice President Helmut Schlesinger. He was quoted in a newspaper interview as saying the dollar's decline fits the central bank's strategy because it reduces West German import prices. This was seen as an invitation to sell the dollar without the risk that the German central bank would move to brake its fall, dealers said. The dollar rose in New York against the Japanese yen, edging up to 147.60 yen from 147.25 yen late Friday. Earlier, the dollar fell 0.55 Japanese yen to 147.35 yen on Tokyo and was quoted at 147.65 yen in London. The dollar lost ground against the British pound. In New York, the pound rose to $1.9230 from $1.9095 late Thursday. Sterling rose to $1.9195 in London from $1.8985 late Thursday. Other dollar rates as of 4 p.m. EDT in New York, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 1.2820 Swiss francs, down from 1.2915; 5.1975 French francs, down from 5.2220; 1,142.25 Italian lire, down from 1,143.25; and 1.14365 Canadian dollars, down from 1.14815. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with late rates Thursday included: 1.2815 Swiss francs, down from 1.3025; 5.2045 French francs, down from 5.2495; 1.7445 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7610; 1,141.75 Italian lire, down from 1,149.75, and 1.1440 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1477. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery rose 40 cents to $409.60 a troy ounce. Earlier, gold rose to $409.25 a troy ounce in London from $403.50 late Thursday and to $408.25 an ounce in Zurich from $401.25 late Thursday. In Hong Kong, gold rose $9.95 to close at $410.96 an ounce. Silver for current delivery rose 1.1 cents an ounce to $5.179 on the Comex. Silver rose in London to $5.20 a troy ounce from $5.13 late Thursday.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices fell broadly Friday in heavy trading, echoing losses overseas amid continued concern about the Mideast. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks fell 36.64 to 2,644.80, its lowest close since March 1. Earlier in the session, the Dow was down by as much as 65 points. Declining issues outnumbered advancing ones by more than 4 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 310 up, 1,330 down and 365 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 212.56 million shares, up from 138.85 million Thursday. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 262.71 million shares. Traders said the volume was boosted by the expiration of August contracts on stock-index futures and options at the close of trading, producing a so-called double-witching hour. Expiration of the options contracts helped boost prices in the final hour, they said. Earlier in the session, the Dow's steep drop set off a market ``circuit breaker'' designed to prevent a price freefall. The mechanism, triggered by a 50-point Dow decline, bars sales connected to index-futures arbitrage until the prices of the stocks involved rise. The price drop was amplified by the unwillingness of investors to buy stocks before the weekend due to uncertainty over the Iraqi conflict, said Robert L. Kahan, manager of equity trading at Montgomery Securities Inc. in San Francisco. Though there was little news from the Mideast, A.C. Moore, director of research at Argus Research in New York, said the market has started to realize that ``the domestic economy is indeed in a shaky position and in no real position to withstand an oil price increase.'' Oil prices continued to surge Friday, sending prices of oil stocks higher. The market shrugged off a bit of good economic news. The Commerce Department said the nation's trade deficit dropped to seven-year low of $5.07 billion in June. But analysts expect the deficit to resume rising once the impact of increasing imported oil prices takes effect. In Japan, disappointment with the lack of progress in the Mideast sent share prices plunging on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, where the key index closed 2.77 percent lower. Prices also closed sharply lower in London. Wal-Mart was the most-active NYSE issue, falling 1[ to 28 as 4.14 million shares changed hands. The company said it knew of no reason for the activity. Among most-active blue-chip stocks on the NYSE, Boeing dropped 2[ to 48{, AT&T fell ~ to 33], General Electric was down ~ to 64, Philip Morris was unchanged at 45\ and IBM fell 2] to 101]. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $48.225 billion, or 1.52 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 2.54 to 180.19. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 5.69 to 386.73, and S&P's 500-stock composite index dropped 4.56 to 327.83. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market lost 8.78 to 393.49. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index dropped 3.22 to 333.61.

DOC.HEAD: Paper Company Announces Restructuring
DOC.TEXT: James River Corp. unveiled a major restructuring Thursday that includes the sale or shutdown of $1.3 billion in specialty operations that have not been profitable. The announcement was made at the paper company's annual shareholders' meeting in Richmond. In a statement, James River said its restructuring would increase the resources available for expansion and ``allow the company to simplify its structure so that it can concentrate on global growth opportunities in those James River businesses in which it commands a substantial market share, which are less cyclical and which have the highest potential to provide James River with competitive advantage.'' The restructuring, to be completed within a year, will allow James River to focus on four core areas: towels and tissues, Dixie food service products, food and consumer packaging, and communication papers. The operations to be divested or closed include business papers units in Berlin-Gorham and Groveton, N.H., and in Wiggins, Miss.; coated printed papers operations in West Linn, Ore.; and towel and tissue operations in South Glens Falls, N.Y., and Ashland, Wis. The company plans to use cash from operations that are sold to reduce debt and repurchase stock. The repurchase could involve up to 8 million shares, depending on market conditions. ``The financial flexibility provided by these actions is designed to support a major capital investment program to grow the company's core businesses,'' the company said. The operations that are targeted for new spending are in Alabama, Louisiana, Michigan, Maine, Oregon, Washington, Wisconsin and Ontario, Canada. Restructuring charges on first-quarter results are expected to reach about $150 million, the company said, and probably will cause a loss for the period. James River's stock closed at $22.87{ Thursday on the New York Stock Exchange, down 25 cents. James River, based in Richmond, manufactures pulp, paper and plastic products. Sales for the fiscal year ending April 29 were $6 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Venezuela Lobbying for OPEC Emergency Meeting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with new material from Saudi Arabia in 7 grafs after 4th graf, `Continuing interruption; picks up 8th graf pvs, `This would. ADDS info on Saudi, U.A.E. production in new last graf.
DOC.TEXT: Venezuela on Friday continued trying to persuade a majority of OPEC nations to meet to discuss oil production increases in wake of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Energy and Mines Minister Celestino Armas said Venezuela was lobbying hard to get at least seven of the 13 Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to the table in order to work out an agreement to cover at least part of Iraq and Kuwait's 4.6 million barrels per day of blocked supply. Armas sent a letter dated Friday to OPEC President Sadek Boussena calling for the meeting to decide on production increases. ``Continuing interruption of energy could seriously damage the long-term prospects of the petroleum industry, for the producers as well as the consumers,'' said the letter, which was also sent to OPEC's secretary general. In Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, informed oil industry sources reported that Venezuela, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar and Kuwait were responsive to a Saudi call for an emergency session. The sources, who spoke on condition they not be named, said a meeting may be convened either Monday or Tuesday in Geneva. They said Iraq, Libya and Ecuador were opposed to the proposal, while Indonesia has suggested a consultation rather than an emergency ministerial session. Algeria, Nigeria, Gabon and Iran have not yet taken a stand, they said. Iran in the past has sought to maximize prices. Iraq's oil minister on Friday lashed out at the proposal for an emergency meeting, insisting that the shortfall was created by the Saudi blocking of Iraqi oil exports from its trans-Saudi oil pipeline. The state-run Iraqi News Agency quoted minister Issam al-Chalabi as describing the call for the session as ``an attempt to add legitimacy to the justification of overproduction,'' in violation of an OPEC agreement reached July 28 in Geneva. It was not immediately clear whether a small group or the cartel ministers would meet separately should the rest refuse to attend the proposed emergency meeting. In Venezuela, Armas indicated an agreement with several other OPEC nations was possible if attempts at full consensus fail. ``This would be a formula to explore,'' he said. Nor did he rule out a production increase by Venezuela alone. ``We'll cross that bridge when we come to it,'' he said. Armas emphasized that Venezuela had responsibilities to its clients, among them the United States, which buys about half of Venezuela's 1.94 million barrel daily output and has asked Venezuela to produce another 500,000 barrels. ``Venezuela is responding to its hemispheric responsibilities,'' Armas said. ``We have a responsibility to countries who are our friends.'' He admitted that Venezuela initially increased production after the United States had asked for more oil, then changed its mind and turned off the taps. He said Venezuela at first had thought it a good idea to increase its inventories, but changed its mind after realizing that ``this action could be misinterpreted by the market'' as a plan to unilaterally sell more oil, Armas said. Among other OPEC members, Saudi Arabia has the potential to produce an estimated 1 million to 2 million barrels more a day, and the U.A.E. about 500,000 more.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Rise Straining City, State Budgets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf, `Boston already...' to CORRECT to $2.5 million expense sted $10 million; official says she misspoke. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The sudden rise in oil prices is jolting cities and states across the country already struggling with some of their worst budget woes in years. Restrictions on government travel have been ordered in Indiana, thermostats are being adjusted in government office buildings in Baltimore and oil suppliers are being served notice in New York that price gougers will be remembered come contract time. ``This is just another whammy along with the other cutbacks from the federal government we've received over the last 10 years,'' J. Thomas Cochran, executive director of the Washington-based U.S. Conference of Mayors, said in an interview Friday. ``One of the things we learned from the last oil crisis in the 1970s was the tremendous amount of gasoline and fuel that cities use in their fleets and in government buildings. This is definitely an item that will have an impact on their budgets,'' he said. Actual service cuts have been slight just two weeks after the Persian Gulf crisis sent world oil prices soaring, according to budget officials interviewed this week by The Associated Press. What worries them most is the heightened prospect of a recession. ``It could be a killer,'' said Rex Olliff, finance specialist for Los Angeles. ``With a recession it would be difficult to get through this year. And next year there would be a real problem.'' Sustained oil price increases of 25 percent to 30 percent would almost certainly bring about deep municipal and state service cuts, other budget officials added. Virginia, already struggling with its worst budget shortfall since World War II, $1.4 billion for 1990-92, faces $2 million in added costs if fuel prices remain where they are. Department of Transportation officials say they might make up the difference by putting off highway maintenance. ``The oil prices are just one added burden, to be sure,'' said Ellen Davenport of the Virginia Association of Counties. New York City figures each penny rise in gasoline prices will add $166,500 to the cost of fueling its 24,000-car municipal fleet. John Beckman, spokesman for the general services department, said the city is warning heating oil and gasoline suppliers that the city intends to punish price gouging. ``We are going to be scrutinizing them to see who gouged us and who treated us fairly. The people with whom we contract should be cognizant of that. Because at contract time, we're going to remember,'' he said. Boston, already $13 million short in its $1.36 billion budget for the fiscal year that began July 1, could see $2.5 million in additional red ink if fuel prices go up 30 percent, said Barbara Gottschalk, the city budget director. A few energy-producing states believe they'll come out winners if oil prices continue upward. In Texas, state comptroller Bob Bullock estimates the treasury would gain $50 million for every $1-per-barrel oil price increase. New Mexico, the seventh-largest oil-producing state, would realize $4 million a year for every dollar-a-barrel rise. Alaska's revenue department calculates that if oil prices remain at current levels through the next year, the state will have a nearly $300 million surplus by next July. But other cities and states less optimistic about their fortunes have already taken modest savings steps. ``We will be turning thermostats down and wearing more sweaters in anticipation of costs rising this winter,'' said Baltimore finance director William R. Brown Jr. Connecticut, its budget already $244 million in the red, is paying 13 cents more per gallon than a year ago for the 7.5 million gallons needed to fuel its state car fleet and police cruisers. State officials prepared a memo asking state car users to cut back on their driving. Albuquerque, N.M., and Rhode Island, are talking about cutting back on city car fleets or restricting take-home car use. Wyoming may cut back on out-of-state air travel by state officials. Indiana Lt. Gov. Frank O'Bannon sent a memo ordering state agencies to increase car pooling and cut back on discretionary travel. In North Carolina, David Crotts, the state legislature's senior fiscal analyst, said rising oil prices could create a $100 million shortfall in revenue projections, potentially wiping out much of a $141 million state ``rainy day fund.'' State agencies already have cut back on travel budgets. Meanwhile, Minnesota Rideshare, a state-funded agency that promotes car pooling, and the Metropolitan Transit Commission, which operates buses, ran advertisements in local newspapers Thursday showing a picture of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. ``It's about time we showed this guy we don't need his oil. Take the bus or Rideshare and you do just that,'' the ad said.

DOC.HEAD: Truck Maker Reports Decline in Revenues
DOC.TEXT: Navistar International Corp. said Thursday its income for the third quarter dropped 78.6 percent to $6 million, due largely to continuing weak demand for medium and heavy trucks. The Chicago-based truck maker, which blamed a 77 percent drop in second-quarter earnings on slow sales, said Monday that it was suspending assembly operations in its Springfield, Ohio and Chatham, Ontario, plants for five days to balance production with retail demand. Chatham operations will be suspended for an additional 10 days in September and Springfield's medium-truck assembly line will be shut down for another five days in October, the company said. For the quarter ending July 31, Navistar reported earnings of $6 million on sales of $972 million, compared to earnings of $28 million on sales of $1.08 billion for the same 1989 period. After dividends on the Series G preferred stock, income per common share broke even for the third quarter. The company reported earnings of 8 cents per share for the 1989 period. For the first nine months of fiscal 1990, Navistar reported a net loss of $4 million, or 10 cents per share, on sales of $2.8 billion, compared to earnings of $100 million, or 31 cents per share, on sales of $3.2 billion during the 1989 period. James C. Cotting, chairman and chief executive officer of Navistar, said industrywide retail sales of medium and heavy trucks in North America were 74,400 in the third quarter, down 14 percent from the 86,900 sold during the same period last year. Cotting said retail sales of the company's International medium and heavy trucks totaled 20,300 in the third quarter, compared to 23,800 trucks during the same period in 1989. He said shipments of mid-range diesel engines increased 4 percent during the period over last year. Service parts sales were 12 percent higher. Cotting also said the current crisis in the Middle East has increased the fear of recession among some truck owners and operators. If that situation continues, it could further depress the truck market, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Selloff Foreseen in Cattle Futures Following Feedlot Report
DOC.TEXT: Livestock analysts on Friday predicted a sharp drop in cattle futures prices after a government report showed far more cattle were placed on feedlots last month than the market had expected. The anticipated drop of at least a penny a pound would extend losses posted Friday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange ahead of the report. On other commodity markets Friday, pork futures were mixed; oil and gasoline futures skyrocketed; precious metals rose; and grains and soybeans were mixed. Live cattle futures settled .20 cent to .57 cent lower in Chicago with the contract for delivery in August at 77.90 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .67 cent lower with August at 89.65 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .35 cent lower with August at 57.52 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .83 cent lower to 1.17 cents higher with August at 48.12 cents a pound. In a report released after the close of trading, the Agriculture Department said 7 million cattle were on U.S. feedlots as of Aug. 1, 4 percent more than on that date a year ago. The USDA said July feedlot placements rose 18 percent over a year ago while July marketings off of feedlots rose 3 percent. Market analysts were most surprised by the placements figure, which compared with expectations for about a 6 percent increase. Charles K. Levitt, senior livestock analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., said the placements total of 1.5 million head was the third largest ever for July and 19 percent above the 10-year avearge. The July placements represent young cattle sold or moved to feedlots to be fattened on grain for slaughter in November and December. Levitt said feedlot operators aggressively sought animals in July because the feedlot business had been profitable that month and because feed-grain prices were declining, suggesting the profitability would continue. A bountiful winter wheat harvest in the Southern Plains, where many feedlots are located, contributed to a drop in wheat prices from about $3.30 to less than $3 a bushel in July, making wheat an economical and readily available alternative to corn as a feed grain, Levitt said. July placements also were higher than expected because good growing conditions had extended the usable life of the pastures on which young cattle are raised before they are moved to feedlots for finishing. Instead of moving animals to feedlots through the spring, many producers kept their cattle on pastures until July, when pasture conditions finally deteriorated, Levitt said. Petroleum futures soared on the New York Mercantile Exchange as Middle East tensions escalated. As the Persian Gulf crisis entered its third week, evidence mounted that Iraq intends to intern hundreds of trapped Americans, and President Bush decided to call up military reserves to meet the need for doctors and other specialists. Analysts attributed an explosive jump in gasoline futures to reports of tight supplies of unleaded gasoline that meets the environmental requirements of the Northeast. Atlantic Richfield Co. said about 270 of its stations in the Southwest had run out of regular unleaded gasoline as demand surged and a refinery fire reduced supplies. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled .34 cent to 1.27 cents higher with September at $28.63 a barrel; heating oil was 3 cents to 5.07 cents higher with September at 80.54 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 2.65 cents to 8.51 cents higher with September at 95.97 cents a gallon. Most precious metals rose modestly on New York's Commodity Exchange, reflecting inflation fears fed by the rise in oil prices. Gold settled 10 cent lower to 40 cents higher with August at $409.60 a troy ounce; silver was 1 cent to 2 cents higher with August at $5.179 a troy ounce. Corn and soybean futures rose but wheat ended lower on the Chicago Board of Trade after a day of choppy trading in the absence of fresh supply-and-demand developments. Wheat futures settled 1 cent to 2{ cents lower with September at $2.82\ a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 1} cents higher with September at $2.50} a bushel; oats were 1\ cents to 2\ cents lower with September at $1.15} a bushel; soybeans were 1} cents to 8 cents higher with August at $6.15 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Mideast, Inflation Concerns Batter Markets Going Into Uncertain Weekend
DOC.TEXT: Investors dumped stocks and dollars again Friday as oil and gasoline prices shot higher and uncertainty intensified about the desert standoff against Iraq and its effect on the weak U.S. economy. Other markets showed more stability, but trading remained nervous going into the weekend. On Wall Street, sellers took the offensive for most of the day amid speculation that the economy _ already in a recession by some accounts _ would suffer further from expensive oil resulting from Iraq's seizure of Kuwait and its threat to other key Persian Gulf oil states. Trading trends shifted constantly, with blue-chip issues falling sharply at the outset before staging periodic rallies to finish well above the day's lows. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials ended down 36.64 at 2,644.80. At one point in the session the best-known average of Wall Street was down more than 60 points. More than four stocks fell for every one that rose on the New York Stock Exchange. Reflecting the depth of the market retreat was the selloff of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which many consider a more accurate barometer of the market's health than the Dow average. The index fell 4.56 points to 327.83, giving it a more than 3.5 percent drop on Thursday and Friday alone. Inflation and recession worries had been blamed partly for the Dow average's nearly 67-point drop on Thursday. Traders said Friday that investors also seemed unwilling to buy stock before the weekend due to the uncertainties posed by the Persian Gulf conflict, worsening the day's decline. Oil and gas prices again rose sharply as traders continued betting that the standoff between Iraq and a multinational force led by the United States would hamper supplies. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude for September delivery rose $1.27 to $28.63 per barrel. That compared with about $21 a barrel just before Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait touched off the crisis. In further bad news for consumers and businesses alike, unleaded gasoline skyrocketed higher, finishing at the highest level since it began trading in late 1984 on the New York Mercantile Exchange. September wholesale unleaded gas closed up 8.51 cents at 95.97 cents a gallon. A favorable U.S. trade report from Washington did little to settle Wall Street down and provided only temporary help for the dollar, which declined in New York after plunging in Europe. The Commerce Department said the trade deficit dropped to a seven-year low of $5.07 billion in June, although the imbalance was expected to rise due to the surge in oil import prices. The dollar traded at 1.5500 German marks late Friday in New York, compared with 1.5525 late Thursday, a new all-time low. Earlier in Frankfurt, however, the dollar had plummeted to 1.5485 marks from 1.5630 late Thursday. In the credit markets, the yield on the Treasury's key 30-year bond rose to about 8.93 percent from 8.92 percent late Thursday. Foreign markets also continued suffering from Persian Gulf and economic worries. Overnight in Japan, the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange plunged by 2.77 percent. Traders in Tokyo said many investors were disappointed that Thursday's meeting between President Bush and Jordan's King Hussein failed to produce any breakthrough in the Iraqi stalemate. Stock prices also were sharply lower in European trading, with the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index on the London exchange down 2 percent.

DOC.HEAD: KG&E Wants Takeover Bid Rejected
DOC.TEXT: Kansas Gas and Electric Co. asked federal and state regulatory agencies Thursday to reject Kansas City Power and Light Co.'s hostile takeover bid. The Wichita utility, which is opposing the $875 million purchase, made its request to the Kansas Corporation Commission and the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. It said the takeover bid will cost the two utilities at least $15 million. KG&E said in its motion to FERC that the KCPL application to approve the merger should be rejected because the KG&E board has not consented to the deal. KG&E also said the tender offer is subject to ``significant and fundamental conditions which make it virtually impossible for KCPL actually to acquire KG&E under the terms and conditions set forth in the application.'' In addition, the utility said KCPL's attempted takeover ``should not be aided or facilitated in any way by FERC'' and noted that merging utilities seeking approval from FERC have, until now, reached agreement on all aspects of the merger before submitting to FERC an application that has their joint support. ``KCPL's decision to acquire KG&E by hostile means disrupts all possibilities of further coordination between the two companies during the hostile takeover period and forces both companies to incur millions of dollars for commitment fees, other costs and disbursements for bankers, lawyers and financial consultants,'' the Wichita utility said. KG&E estimated that KCPL has spent or committed expenditures of more than $10 million for the takeover bid. KG&E estimated its own costs at $4.5 million. In a separate motion, KG&E cited several reasons for the state commission to reject the KCPL filing: _ The tender offer is believed by KG&E to be illegal. _ The KG&E board did not consent to the KCPL application or acquisition. _ The tender offer is highly conditional, making it virtually impossible that KCPL will acquire KG&E anytime soon under conditions set forth in its application to the KCC.

DOC.HEAD: Retailers to Ask More Time for Filing Chapter 11 Plan
DOC.TEXT: Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. said Friday they were asking a federal judge for more time to file a plan for emerging from Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. is to conduct a hearing Sept. 11 on the request to postpone the filing deadline to Feb. 28, 1991. Federated and Allied said the extension would allow them to concentrate on the Christmas retailing season. It would be the second extension granted by Aug for the companies' exclusive right to file a reorganization plan, independent of creditors. Aug on May 10 granted an extension through Sept. 12. Lawyers for the Cincinnati-based retailers recently told Aug they expected to request a second extension because of the complexity and scope of the reorganization effort. Federated and Allied operate 256 department stores in 28 states and employ about 100,000 people. Lewis Rosenbloom, a lawyer for Federated's unsecured creditors, said this week that he expected the companies to request the filing extension. They filed Chapter 11 reorganization petitions Jan. 15 in Cincinnati. The petitions listed $7.7 billion in debt, most of it inherited from when the Toronto-based Campeau Corp. bought Allied in 1986 and Federated in 1988 in heavily leveraged transactions. Federated and Allied said they still expect to present their business plans to creditors in October. Federated and Allied operate store groups that include Bloomingdale's, Abraham and Straus, Lazarus, Burdines, Rich's, Jordan Marsh, The Bon Marche, Stern's and Maas Brothers.

DOC.HEAD: Commission Approves Resorts Reorganization Plan
DOC.TEXT: The Casino Control Commission on Friday unanimously approved a restructuring plan for Resorts International that leaves owner Merv Griffin with just 21.5 percent of the company and includes a $5 million fund to possibly sue Donald Trump. The commission voted 5-0 for the plan approved early Friday morning by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Rosemary Gambardella. It still must be approved by the Bahamian government, where Resorts also runs a casino. The plan, filed under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code, gives bondholders holding $911 million in bonds 78.5 percent of the company and $434 million in new notes. It allows Resorts to unload more than half of its massive debt and bank on a recovery of its fortunes along with Atlantic City's casino industry. Resorts said the plan would take effect in 11 days, with new notes distributed 10 days later. Griffin also will invest $15 million and another $11 million a year later. ``With the plan in place, Resorts will be able to generate sufficient cash to maintain its operations and service its debt even if it were to experience no growth in its 1989 adjusted operating income throughout the five-year forecast period,'' said acting commission chairwoman Valerie Armstrong. ``Accordingly, I believe that Resorts will continue to have financial stability upon the implementation of the reorganization plan,'' she said. Griffin said afterward that he was relieved and confident Resorts and Atlantic City would rebound from recent months of flat growth in a poor economy. ``It's a load off,'' Griffin said. ``Now it's up all the way.'' The plan was filed in December and amended in April to include the proposed sale of Resorts' Paradise Island operations in the Bahamas. Resorts officials estimate the Bahamian property could fetch between $250 million and $300 million. The plan forecasts the sale by December 1991, two months before Resorts' New Jersey gaming license comes up for renewal. Ms. Armstrong re-emphasized the Bahamian sale remains a key to the restructuring. The revamping also sets aside a $5 million legal kitty to allow Resorts bondholders to sue Donald Trump, Resorts' former owner. Bondholders claim Trump left the company insolvent in a 1988 swap with Griffin in which Trump got the unfinished Taj Mahal Casino Resort next door. Trump has said Griffin is responsible for weighing the company down with too much debt. The plan also features an unusual feature allowing bondholders to buy units in the kitty to be repaid accordingly if a decision goes against Trump. Those unit holders would not have to qualify before the commission, but the kitty's trustee would, the panel ruled. Resorts would have to repurchase the units if litigation does not settle in a year for at least $3.6 million.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices finished mixed Friday, as traders bought after a big sell-off despite soaring oil prices that heightened inflation fears. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond fell 1-16 point, or 63 cents per $1,000 face amount. Its yield rose to 8.93 percent from 8.92 percent late Thursday. Bond prices had plummeted nearly $15.50 Thursday and yields finished the week at their highest levels in three months. Trading was quiet Friday in the absence of fresh developments in the Persian Gulf standoff between Iraq and a multinational force led by the United States. But some dealers capitalized on the low prices to buy, said Bruce R. Lakefield, executive vice president with Shearson Lehman Goverment Securities Inc. Traders also bought bonds to cover positions in borrowed securities before the weekend. ``It seems that the risk is still for Middle East events to be bearish but something could happen,'' Lakefield said. ``In the absence of any events people basically bought back.'' That occurred despite skyrocketing crude oil and gasoline prices, which normally trigger fears of inflation and send investors fleeing from long-term fixed-income investments such as bonds. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude for September delivery rose $1.27 to $28.63 per barrel. That compared with about $21 a barrel just before Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Unleaded gasoline finished at the highest level since it began trading in late 1984 on the Merc. September wholesale unleaded gas closed up 8.51 cents at 95.97 cents a gallon, giving the fuel a rise of 16.5 cents on the week. Lakefield said that when the market traded lower, ``it tended to trade down on higher oil prices.'' Analysts said Thursday's report of sharply higher consumer prices in July led traders to conclude the Federal Reserve would not lower interest rates anytime soon to stimulate the economy. The market ignored a Commerce Department report Friday showing the U.S. trade deficit declining to a seven-year low. The figure that on other days would have been expected to add to the sell-off, because it indicated economic strength. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments were unchanged to up [ point, intermediate maturities were unchanged to up 1-16 point and long-term issues fell about [ point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 0.09 to 1,145.41. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.72 percent as the discount declined 1 basis point to 7.48 percent. Yields on six-month bills dropped to 7.82 percent as the discount lost 3 basis points to 7.43 percent. Yields on one-year bills dropped to 7.80 percent as the discount fell to 7.29 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 7} percent, down from 8[ percent late Thursday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 90 27-32, down ] point. The average yield to maturity rose to 7.49 percent from 7.45 percent late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Board Files Complaint Against Sony; Union Could Be Reinstated
DOC.TEXT: The president of Sony Corp. of America denied Friday that the company tried to influence a union vote by taking pictures of employees who were unaware their faces would appear in an anti-union video. Sony officials showed the video to employees a day or two before a vote was taken on whether to oust their union, Local 888 of the United Food & Commercial Workers International. The National Labor Relations Board has filed an unfair labor practice complaint against Sony in connection with the pictures and a raffle held the day of the vote. Employees in seven New Jersey cities and in New York City voted in March to dump the union, but the election results could be tossed out and a new vote ordered if Sony loses the case, said Michael Lightner, an attorney with the labor board. ``Unfair conduct by an employer might be both unlawful and constitute grounds for a new election,'' Lightner said. ``It's fair to say that if we win on the unfair labor practice, they'll set aside the election.'' Until the case is resolved, the union will remain in power. The company did not tell union officials why the pictures were being taken, which prompted the labor board to file the complaint, Lightner said. The complaint did not concern the content of the video. Neil Vander Dussen, Sony's president and chief executive officer, said the union was told only that Sony routinely photographs its employees for its own use. ``Our people just didn't think that it was necessary to go into great detail,'' he said. ``They were taking them for the video, yes, but we routinely take pictures of our employees.'' Vander Dussen said the complaint was based on ``technicalities'' and said that Sony employees clearly wanted the union out. The vote was 76-44 against the union. ``To make an issue out of this is just to delay the decertification process,'' he said. Vander Dussan said Sony will fight the charges. The case must go to an administrative law judge if facts in the complaint are disputed. It then goes to a three-member panel of the labor relations board in Washington. An attorney for the local said he would argue that the anti-union tone of the video gave employees who watched it a false perception of their co-workers and union sentiment. ``It creates the impression that the individuals pictured are in favor of getting rid of the union,'' said attorney Larry Cary. ``It also creates the impression that the company is watching you, and we think that's coercive.'' A second issue in the complaint filed by the labor board is over a 27-inch television raffled by Sony on the day of the election. Vander Dussen said all employees who voted were entered into the drawing as a way of ensuring a large turnout and not to induce employees to vote against the union, as the complaint charges. ``If they vote for the union, they're still entered into the raffle, so I don't see how that makes any sense,'' Vander Dussen said.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Gets Lower Interest on Major Loan
DOC.TEXT: Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. has agreed to lower the interest on a $500 million loan to Prime Computer Inc. in exchange for getting a bigger equity stake in the company's owner. The loan was secured as part of the $1.3 billion buyout last year of Prime. The company's new owner became DR Holdings, a unit of J.H. Whitney & Co., a New York investment firm. Since then, Prime reported a string of losses and cut more than 2,000 people from its payroll. But in its second quarter, Prime reported operating income of $50.1 on higher revenue of $403.5 million. Prime recently landed $180 million worth of business as part of an Army contract, said Joe Gavaghan, a company spokesman. It was the largest contract Prime has received in its history. Under the revised loan terms, Prime will pay a sharply lower interest rate. Shearson will get an additional 7.5 percent equity interest in DR Holdings, plus an additional 1 percent of equity for each quarter that the present loan is outstanding, to a maximum of 25 percent. Shearson already holds a 19 percent stake. Prime said the revised financing reflects the company's progress and ``Shearson's confidence in Prime's long-term potential.''

Investors dumped stocks and dollars as oil and gasoline prices shot higher and uncertainty intensified about the desert standoff against Iraq and its effect on the weak U.S. economy. Friday, on Wall Street, sellers took the offensive for most of the day amid speculation that the economy _ already in a recession by some accounts _ would suffer further from expensive oil resulting from Iraq's seizure of Kuwait and its threat to other key Persian Gulf oil states.

Unleaded gasoline hit a record high on the New York Mercantile Exchange, as crude oil prices shot up and speculators kept betting that the Middle East standoff would curtail supplies. September wholesale unleaded gas futures soared Friday to as high as 96.25 cents before settling at 95.97 cents per gallon, up 8.5 cents from Thursday's record close. West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark U.S. crude, finished up $1.27 at $26.83 per barrel.

Record exports and shrinking oil imports helped push the nation's merchandise trade deficit to a seven-year low in June, the government reported. Analysts saw oil as a problem in coming months because of the Mideast crisis. The Commerce Department said Friday that the deficit dropped to $5.07 billion, a 34.7 percent decline from $7.77 billion in May and the lowest since a $3.96 billion imbalance was posted in June 1983.

_ ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. (AP) _ Developer Donald Trump's financial footing became more precarious when the state Casino Control Commission said it would not rule on his complex financial bailout until Tuesday. Acting Chairwoman Valerie Armstrong said Friday the commission needed more time to review more than 1,000 pages of documents. Trump attorneys had argued that any delay beyond Friday could jeopardize Trump's $65 million bailout and trigger a chain of bankruptcies in his debt-riddled Atlantic City casino and Manhattan real estate empire.

The Casino Control Commission unanimously approved a restructuring plan for Resorts International that leaves owner Merv Griffin with just 21.5 percent of the company and includes a $5 million fund to possibly sue Donald Trump. The commission voted 5-0 Friday for the plan approved early Friday morning by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Rosemary Gambardella. It still must be approved by the Bahamian government, where Resorts also runs a casino. The plan, filed under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code, gives bondholders holding $911 million in bonds 78.5 percent of the company and $434 million in new notes.

Chrysler Corp., which is trying to reduce its salaried work force as a cost-cutting move, is offering nearly all of its 60,000 or so unionized employees money to leave the company. Chrysler spokesman Lee Sechler said Friday that 400 to 450 of the eligible workers had chosen the buyout so far. Another week is left for workers to sign up. The last day of work for anyone choosing to leave will be Aug. 31.

Consumer food prices are going up 5 percent to 7 percent this year, sharply more than had been predicted, the Agriculture Department said. The new forecast Friday compared with the 3 percent to 5 percent price hike the department has been predicting for 1990 since December. Double-digit price gains in the first half of this year for fresh fruits, pork, eggs and dairy products, along with uncertainties about future energy prices, are mostly to blame for the upward revision, the department said.

Foster Grant Corp., whose ads asking which star was behind its sunglasses produced sales and advertising prominence, has sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection from creditors. In papers filed Thursday in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Tucson, Ariz., the sunglass maker that became popular in the 1960s and '70s reported total assets of about $25 million and liabilities of about $36 million, including nearly $19.3 million in unsecured debt.

FundAmerica Inc., a buying club with 100,000 members, filed for bankruptcy protection from its creditors and asked the court to appoint an independent examiner to investigate various allegations against it. The Irvine, Calif.-based firm is facing scrutiny from regulators in Florida and other states and is the subject of a $150 million class-action suit in San Francisco. Its federal bankruptcy filing Friday in Santa Ana, which had been expected, listed assets of $17.5 million and liabilities of $14.5 million.

Stock prices fell broadly Friday in heavy trading, echoing losses overseas amid continued concern about the Mideast. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 36.64 to 2,644.80, its lowest close since March 1. The dollar sank to another all-time low against the German mark. Bond prices were mixed. Pork futures were mixed, precious metals rose, and grains and soybeans were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Settlement Preserves Independence of Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: The Times Publishing Co. on Friday settled a complicated stock feud with Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass which, according to company officials, preserves independent control of the St. Petersburg Times. The Bass group owns 40 percent of the voting stock but gets only 5.7 percent of the dividends of Times Publishing Co. The partnership had wanted a better return on its investment and maintained directors had an obligation to recall preferred stock. Under the settlement, the company will buy an undisclosed amount of common shares held by the Bass group and will have the right to buy more shares from the partnership after three years. Times Publishing will redeem or retire all of its non-voting redeemable preferred stock, as the partnership requested. In return, the Bass group is dismissing its suit against the Times. It agreed not to comment beyond a three-page announcement. Andrew Barnes, chairman of Times Publishing, said ``the agreement assures the long-term independence, journalistic control and competitive vigor of the St. Petersburg Times, as well as significant ongoing support for the Poynter Institute.'' The Poynter Institute controls a majority of the publishing company's stock and receives 83 percent of the dividends, which are used to run the non-profit journalism school in St. Petersburg. David Bonderman, managing partner for the Poynter-Jamison Ventures Ltd., said he believes the settlement is in everyone's best interest. ``We always believed this to be a good investment and are happy we could work with Andy Barnes to help end a family dispute that has brewed for years,'' he said. The Bass group gained a minority stake in the company in mid-1988. The Times Publishing Co. owns the St. Petersburg Times, Congressional Quarterly and other magazines. The St. Petersburg Times is Florida's second-largest newspaper. The feud between the sides focused on the company's stock dividends. The Bass group wanted to change the stock structure to get a better return on its investment, while the Times defended the arrangement as beneficial to the journalistic standards of the newspaper and the health of the Poynter Institute. The Bass group had made a $270 million buyout offer for the Times Publishing Co., but the directors rejected the offer earlier this year.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES in 2nd graf with agreement being signed.
DOC.HEAD: Nordstrom Admits No Wrongdoing In Settlement of NLRB Claims
DOC.TEXT: Nordstrom Inc. announced Friday it settled all its outstanding claims with the National Labor Relations Board, but a union official demanded the company also admit wrongdoing. The Seattle-based retailer signed the agreement Friday stating it would not punish employees for union activities or offer to employees benefits that are effective only if the union is ousted, Nordstrom spokesman Dave Marriott said. Nordstrom also will allow pro-union employees the same privileges as anti-union workers in the matters of distributing handbills and posting fliers, Marriott said. The settlement included a ``non-admission of guilt'' clause, which NLRB Regional Attorney Walter Mercer said is fairly common. But United Food and Commercial Workers Local 1001 will object to any settlement ``unless Nordstrom admits it has done what they have been accused of,'' said union President Joe Peterson. The union has five days to object after the settlement is signed, Mercer said. Terms of the settlement must be posted for 60 days in the five Seattle-area stores and one Tacoma store with UFCW Local 367 and Local 1001 employees, Mercer said. Overall, 13 of the 19 charges filed by the UFCW have been dismissed or withdrawn, said Joe Demarte, Nordstrom vice president for personnel. ``The settlement wipes the slate clean in terms of the unfair labor practice charges that have been filed by the union,'' Demarte said. He said the settlement was sought because ``we felt it was more important to reach a settlement of the issues pending before the NLRB rather than continuing to debate the merits of the union's allegations.'' But Peterson believed Nordstrom wanted the settlement so that a new petition to decertify and oust the union could be circulated. He said the process cannot begin while charges are pending before the NLRB. The union is in the process of filing new charges against the retailer, Peterson said. Those charges will involve alleged discrimination against union negotiators at a store south of Seattle, Peterson said. The union also plans appeals on four other charges the labor board ruled against, he said. Marriott said Nordstrom expected such an action. The UFCW represents about 1,500 of Nordstrom's Seattle-area employees. Nordstrom employs about 30,000 people nationwide inn 60 stores in six states. In February, the Washington State Department of Labor and Industries ruled that Nordstrom had violated state law by failing to pay some employees for such activities as attending company meetings, making deliveries and writing customer thank-you notes. A union lawsuit seeks back pay for the workers.

DOC.HEAD: Mack Trucks Increases Projected Loss To $180 Million This Year
DOC.TEXT: Mack Trucks Inc. increased its projected loss for the year by 38 percent Friday, saying questions about the U.S. economy and the Mideast crisis will cost the company $180 million in 1990. If the economic and political uncertainties continue into the next year, Mack also predicts a difficult 1991, when more stringent emission standards will increase truck prices. The statement said the company now expects sales to total $1.67 billion, compared with the $1.5 billion predicted earlier. Mack also originally predicted a loss of $130 million. In making the original estimates, the company counted on companies buying trucks in the coming months to avoid the price increases next year. But no surge has occurred, Mack said. Mack cited the overall deteriorating heavy-duty truck market and continued uncertainty about the economy. The company also cited Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and the resulting increase in oil prices. The Allentown truck maker lost $97 million for the first half of the year and went into default on major bank loans. Renault Vehicules Industriels, which holds a 44.6 percent stake in Mack, has made a bid to acquire all of the company's stock. Navistar International Corp. of Chicago, which lost $10 million in the first half of the year, also has said it will make a bid for Mack if RVI pulls out.

DOC.HEAD: Price Freeze, Refinery Fire, Drain Arco Supplies
DOC.TEXT: Amoco Corp. and Unocal Corp. began raising wholesale gasoline prices as promised Friday, citing competitive pressures. Atlantic Richfield Co. said it would continue its price freeze despite a surge in demand that caused pumps to run dry briefly at about 270 stations as buyers lined up for its lower-priced fuel. President Bush appealed for voluntary price restraints last week after Iraq invaded oil-rich Kuwait. Chicago-based Amoco and Los Angeles-based Unocal were among the companies that froze gas prices to dealers for a week. They announced Thursday the freeze would end, blaming competitive pressures. No Arco-style shortages were reported by either company, however. On Friday, Unocal said it had raised prices by a penny a gallon in San Diego and San Jose, Calif.; Seattle; Portland and Eugene, Ore.; Las Vegas and Reno, Nev.; and Phoenix and Tucson, Ariz. Amoco, which sells gas in 30 states, said it raised prices to dealers by 1 cent per gallon in the St. Louis market; by 2 cents per gallon in Indianapolis, Milwaukee, Detroit and Minneapolis; and 2{ cents per gallon in Kansas City and Denver. ``Amoco's refineries are currently using crude oil received and priced since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, and this gasoline price increase partially reflects the higher price of that oil,'' Robert J. Rauscher, Amoco marketing vice president, said in a statement. The increases do not directly affect retail gas prices because federal law requires those to be set independently, but they generally are passed along to consumers. Los Angeles-based Arco has access to ample Alaska oil, which historically has helped it maintain a low-price marketing strategy that includes all self-service stations. It has kept its freeze in effect, although it said it was reviewing the situation daily. It sells gasoline at 1,500 stations in five Western states. An Aug. 10 Lundberg Survey of pump prices found Arco prices 4 cents to 12 cents per gallon cheaper than competitors in the Los Angeles area. That kind of price disparity has caused sales volume to surge by 9 percent since Arco announced its freeze on Aug. 8, spokesman Doug Elmets said. That heavy demand coincided with a fire Monday that cut production of gasoline by 15,000 barrels per day at Arco's refinery in suburban Carson. That and heavy business at gas stations caused ``sold out'' signs to go up at regular unleaded pumps at the 270 stations, Elmets said. Nearly all the stations were in Southern California and the Phoenix and Las Vegas areas. Elmets said it's taken an average of 2{ hours to replenish regular unleaded gas at the stations. He said to ensure an adequate supply to dealers, Arco had taken the unusual step of purchasing 100,000 barrels of gasoline on the spot market Wednesday for $1 per gallon, or $4.2 million. ``We've hired every common carrier we can find to get gas to our stations,'' Elmets said. ``We are going to continue to hold the line as long as we can.'' A Unocal spokesman, Barry Lane, said Unocal preferred not to pursue such a strategy. ``We certainly don't want to get caught into a shortage situation by being too far below the market,'' he said, adding: ``We don't want to be too far above, either.''

DOC.HEAD: Unleaded Gas Sets Record High on Merc
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS Friday settlement price of WTI to $28.63 in 4th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Unleaded gasoline hit a record high Friday on the New York Mercantile Exchange Friday, as crude oil prices shot up and speculators kept betting that the Middle East standoff would curtail supplies. September wholesale unleaded gas futures soared to as high as 96.25 cents before settling at 95.97 cents per gallon, up 8.5 cents from Thursday's record close. ``They're afraid there's not going to be crude around to make gasoline with,'' said Ed Kevelson, a broker with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``The entire mood is up. The whole trend is up.'' The September contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark U.S. crude, finished up $1.27 at $28.63 per barrel. For the week, September crude rose $2.40 per barrel, while unleaded gasoline was up 16.5 cents a gallon. Oil prices have been rising in hectic, rumor-driven trading since Iraq invaded neighboring Kuwait on Aug. 2, and major industrialized nations responded by embargoing their oil. The tighter supply, combined with the possibility of a broader Middle East war, has spurred waves of buying by speculators hoping prices will soar further. As prices moved up Friday, ``there wasn't anything to act as a dampener,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``It's just a real feeling that this situation is going to last for a while.'' Prices had fallen slightly early in the week as traders speculated that diplomats might find a solution to the oil crisis. But the rally renewed with a vengeance after a meeting Thursday between President Bush and Jordan's King Hussein _ an ally of Iraq and the United States _ produced no progress toward a peaceful settlement. Traders were concerned that imports and oil supplies will tighten, particularly in the Northeast, which is more dependent on foreign oil than other regions, Hittle said. Gas prices get an added boost because U.S. refining capacity already is tight and most foreign gasoline can't be imported because it does not meet federal emission standards. Among other energy futures, wholesale home heating oil for September delivery rose to 80.54 cents per gallon, up 5.1 cents for the day and 7.9 cents for the week. September natural gas rose to $1.440 per 1,000 cubic feet from Thursday's $1.430. On the week natural gas was down 5 cents.
